This study compares the pressure ulcer prevention effects of two mattresses with different support surfaces used in bedridden patients. The study includes 100 patients who are randomly assigned to either an experimental group (massage mattress with cube/block system) or a control group (standard of care). The primary outcome measure is the number of patients without pressure ulcers at the end of four weeks.

Please provide a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to investigate the effect of exercise with augmented reality glasses on metabolic parameters, anthropometric measurement values, and quality of life in children aged 10-12 with type 1 diabetes. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with two arms: an experimental group that will receive exercise with augmented reality glasses, and a control group that will not receive any intervention. The study will be conducted over 12 weeks, with measurements taken at baseline, mid-intervention, and post-intervention. The primary outcome measures will include changes in HbA1c levels, body mass index, and quality of life scores. The study will enroll 40 children in each group, and the results will be analyzed using linear mixed models. The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of exercise with augmented reality glasses in improving metabolic control and quality of life in children with type 1 diabetes.

The study aims to evaluate the effect of virtual reality on preoperative anxiety before abdominal surgery. The study will be conducted on 96 patients, randomly assigned to one of three groups: experimental (virtual reality), placebo (watching the same video without virtual reality), or control (no intervention). The primary outcome measures will be the preoperative anxiety level, measured using the VAS-A scale and the smart bracelet, before and after watching the video. The study will be conducted at the Trakya University Health Research Center General Surgery Clinic between March 1, 2023, and December 1, 2023.

The study is a single-arm, prospective, interventional study to evaluate the clinical performance and safety of Suture-TOOL for abdominal wound closure in men and women patients undergoing elective open abdominal surgery. The study will enroll 100 participants and will measure the proportion of patients with Suture length/Wound length (SL/WL) ratio ≥ 4, stitch count, numbers of sutures used, incision closure time, surgeons' comfort with device during closure, and surgeons' satisfaction with final closure result.

The study will be conducted at a single center and will be led by a principal investigator. The study will be conducted in accordance with the International Conference on Harmonisation (ICH) Good Clinical Practice (GCP) guidelines and the applicable regulatory requirements.

The study will be open-label, meaning that both the participants and the investigators will be aware of the intervention being tested. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months, and the data will be analyzed using descriptive statistics and inferential statistics.

The primary outcome measure will be the proportion of patients with Suture length/Wound length (SL/WL) ratio ≥ 4, which will be measured during laparotomy closure. The secondary outcome measures will include stitch count, numbers of sutures used, incision closure time, surgeons' comfort with device during closure, and surgeons' satisfaction with final closure result.

The study will enroll men and women patients who are undergoing elective open abdominal surgery for benign or malignant colorectal disease. The inclusion criteria will include informed consent, age ≥ 18 years, surgery through midline incision, anticipated incision length ≥ 12 cm, BMI 18-40 kg/m2, full comprehension, and no significant medical history or physical findings that could interfere with the study procedures. The exclusion criteria will include previous abdominal surgery involving the midline, clinically significant abnormal physical findings, existing midline hernia, cutaneous infection, fistula, psoriasis of abdominal skin, morbid obesity, or any other condition that could interfere with the study procedures

This is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the immune characteristics of patients with primary salivary gland carcinoma in the head and neck region. The study will assess the changes in the immune matrix, immune cell composition, and cytokine expression in the peripheral blood of patients over time. Additionally, the study will examine the patient's metabolic and microbiomic state. The study will enroll patients with primary salivary gland carcinoma, benign salivary gland tumors, and healthy controls. The study will be conducted over a period of up to 5 years.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to determine the compliance of individuals with the Mediterranean diet, the use of various nutritional supplements, physical activity habits, walking-related problems, and quality of life in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients. The study will evaluate the relationship between these parameters and determine if there is a significant relationship between them. The study will use the 14-item Mediterranean Diet Adaptation Scale (PREDIMED), Multiple Sclerosis International Quality of Life Scale, 12-item MS Gait Scale, and Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) to measure the outcomes. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year and will include individuals between the ages of 18-65 who have been diagnosed with MS.

This is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, controlled study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of selective intensive induction therapy based on ustekinumab clinical decision-making tools in patients with Crohn's disease. The study will enroll 120 patients and will be conducted at multiple sites. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (receiving selective intensive induction therapy) or the control group (receiving standard induction therapy). The primary outcome measure is the difference in clinical response rate at week 24 between the two groups.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This study aims to assess the preferences of a culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) population for second-line overactive bladder (OAB) therapy using a discrete choice experiment. The study will enroll adult patients with OAB and will evaluate the preferences of participants in choosing between two fictive therapies, each with its own botulinum toxin A and sacral neuromodulation (SNM) characteristics. The primary outcome measure is the discrete choice questionnaire, which will be completed by patients within 1 hour.

Please provide a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This is a single-group assignment, open-label, non-randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of SBRT with focal dose escalation on dominant lesion in localized prostate cancer. The study will enroll 30 participants who will receive SBRT with focal dose escalation on the dominant lesion identified by mpMRI. The primary outcome measures are biochemical progression-free survival, local control, and patient-reported outcomes and quality of life assessment. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years, and the data will be analyzed using descriptive statistics and Kaplan-Meier method.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a serious game (SG) in improving the quality of life and motor skills of children with asthma. The SG is a running game that requires the child to perform physical exercises to overcome obstacles. The study will compare the results of the SG group with the standard treatment plan group. The primary outcome measures are the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) and the Skills and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ-Ita) at 6 months. The secondary outcome measures are the Conserved Transcriptional Response to Adversity (CTRA) and the PedsQL at 6 months.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a standardized/structured CPAP weaning protocol in preterm infants to support lung growth. The study will enroll infants born at < 30 weeks gestational age and will randomize them to either the standardized NIS wean group or the control group (non-standardized wean). The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with CPAP/NIS weaning failure, and secondary outcome measures include length of hospital stay, rate of bronchopulmonary dysplasia, use of postnatal steroids, and more. The study will run for an average of 4 months and will assess the effectiveness of the standardized/structured CPAP weaning protocol in supporting lung growth in preterm infants.

This is a randomized, double-blind, phase 3 study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of frexalimab in adults with nonrelapsing secondary progressive multiple sclerosis. The study will measure the time to onset of composite confirmed disability progression (cCDP) confirmed over 6 months, and secondary outcome measures include time to onset of composite cCDP confirmed over 3 months, time to onset of individual components of the composite, confirmed over 3-months or 6-months, time to onset of confirmed disability improvement (CDI), number of new and/or enlarging T2hyperintense lesions per scan as detected by MRI, and number of new and/or enlarging T2-hyperintense lesions per month, percent change in brain volume loss as detected by MRI scans at the end of study (EOS) compared to Month 6, change from baseline in multiple sclerosis impact scale 29 version 2 (MSIS-29v2) questionnaire scores over time, change from baseline in patient reported outcome measurement information system (PROMIS) Fatigue multiple sclerosis (MS)-8a over time, annualized relapse rate during the study period assessed by protocol defined adjudicated relapses, number of participants with adverse events, SAEs, AEs leading to permanent study intervention discontinuation and AE of special interests (AESIs), number of participants with potentially clinically significant abnormalities (PCSAs) in laboratory tests, ECG, and vital signs during the study period, number of participants with antibody over time, change from baseline in serum Ig levels over time, change from baseline in plasma neurofilament light chain (NfL) levels over time, and frexalimab plasma concentration over time.

The study compares the modified Millard and Mishra techniques in unilateral cleft lip repair. The study is a randomized controlled trial with 21 participants in each group. The primary outcome measures are surgical repair unilateral cleft lip measurements, including vertical lip height, horizontal lip length, and philtral length, measured at 3 months post-operative.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the modified Millard and Mishra techniques in unilateral cleft lip repair. The study also aims to compare the anthropometric measurements and qualitative assessments of the surgical outcome between the two techniques.

The study includes infants with unilateral isolated cleft lip aged between 2-6 months, with incomplete and complete unilateral cleft lip (reach floor of the nose). The study excludes infants less than 2 months or more than 6 months, bilateral cleft lip patients, recurrent repair cleft lip cases, and facial cleft cases.

The study is designed as a parallel-assignment randomized controlled trial with no masking. The participants are randomly assigned to one of the three groups: control group (21 normal infant aged 3-6 months), group a (21 patients of unilateral cleft lip had Mishra technique repair), and group b (21 patients of unilateral cleft lip had modified Millard technique repair).

The primary outcome measures are surgical repair unilateral cleft lip measurements, including vertical lip height, horizontal lip length, and philtral length, measured at 3 months post-operative. The study also measures anthropometric measurements and qualitative assessments of the surgical outcome.

The study aims to provide valuable insights into the effectiveness and safety of the modified Millard and Mishra techniques in unilateral cleft lip repair, and to contribute to the development of optimal surgical techniques for cleft lip repair.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of endoscopic management of controlled colo-cutaneous fistula as a complication of acute diverticulitis. The study is a randomized controlled trial that includes 66 patients divided into two groups: endoscopic group (EG) and surgical group (SG). The primary outcome measure is the incidence of recurrence of fistula, and the secondary outcome measures are the incidence of side effects of endoscopy and the success rate of surgical repair versus endoscopic repair. The study found that endoscopic management of controlled colo-cutaneous fistula is effective in reducing morbidity and postoperative hospital stay compared to surgical management.

The study aims to improve the screening of heart failure and identify patients at risk for heart failure earlier. The study is a randomized, un-blinded trial comparing usual care to an intervention group receiving early heart failure testing. The intervention group will have NT-proBNP drawn and those with an elevated NT-proBNP (>125pg/mL) will have a study visit with assessments to include, physical examination, electrocardiogram, and study AI echocardiogram. The study will measure the number of participants diagnosed with heart failure, number of outpatient HF visits, number of urgent HF visits, and number of HF hospitalizations. The secondary outcome measures will include the incidence of prescription for guideline-recommended HF therapies in patients diagnosed with HFrEF and HF events in HFrEF.

The study aims to evaluate the effects of Propofol dose according to lean body weight by evaluating patients with a body mass index (BMI) below 35. The study will include 80 patients with a mean BMI between 18-35 and Bispectoral index (BIS) monitoring, and propofol infusion (100 mg/kg/hour) will be started according to total body weight, and the infusion will be stopped with a BIS value between 50 and 40, and the elapsed time will be recorded. The total dose of Propofol given; the dose applied to kilograms will be calculated according to TBW, IBW, and LBW. And the relationship between the doses given and the body mass index will be evaluated.

The study is a prospective cohort design that compares the efficacy and tolerability of letermovir for CMV prophylaxis in heart or lung transplant recipients. The study will enroll 180 participants and will be conducted over a period of 365 days. The primary outcome measures will be CMV viral load, proportion of days during which appropriately renally-dosed prophylaxis is taken, and frequency of acute cellular rejection. Secondary outcome measures will include the proportion of subjects who develop CMV resistance, neutropenia, severe thrombocytopenia, unplanned discontinuation of MMF or azathioprine, and incorrect renal dosing.

The study aims to develop and validate a new clinical trial tool called the PHYSIOSCORE, which will assess the complexity level and physical therapy care in hospitalized patients. The tool will be validated through a prospective and observational single-center study involving 110 patients hospitalized for clinical or surgical cardiac conditions. The study will evaluate the PHYSIOSCORE's inter-rater reliability and clinical validation through the assessment of respiratory and neuromuscular physical therapy care. The study will also analyze patients' characteristics at hospital admission, including demographic characteristics, clinical signs and symptoms, imaging, laboratory findings, and medical history.

The PHYSIOSCORE is composed of 106 items divided into three main domains: respiratory, imaging, and neuromuscular. The respiratory domain includes six items: pulmonary function, pulmonary sound, need for airway clearance, peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2), respiratory rate (f), and imaging examination. The imaging examination is divided into four segments: pulmonary parenchyma, pleura, vascular plot, and expandability. The neuromuscular evaluation consists of six items: neuropsychological, muscle strength and tone, postural control, neuromotor coordination, and walking.

The study will evaluate the PHYSIOSCORE's inter-rater reliability and clinical validation through the assessment of respiratory and neuromuscular physical therapy care. The study will also analyze patients' characteristics at hospital admission, including demographic characteristics, clinical signs and symptoms, imaging, laboratory findings, and medical history.

The study will be conducted in two stages. Initially, the PHYSIOSCORE will be applied to assess the level of attention and complexity of physical therapy care by one professional. Then, a second physical therapist with at least five years of experience will perform respiratory and neuromuscular physical therapy. The time spent evaluating respiratory and neuromuscular physical therapist care and registering electronic medical records will be timed.

The study will be conducted in a prospective and observational single-center study involving

The SAVAL clinical trial is a single-arm phase II study evaluating the use of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) levels to identify patients with HPV-mediated oropharynx squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC) who are eligible for observation after transoral robotic surgery (TORS). The study will enroll patients with p16+ OPSCC who are candidates for surgery and have positive ctDNA levels. The patients will be stratified into three risk groups based on their ctDNA levels, and the low-risk group will be observed per standard of care. The intermediate-risk group will also be observed per experimental arm, and the high-risk group will receive adjuvant treatment per standard of care. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, and secondary outcome measures include rate of recurrence, rate of salvage, locoregional recurrence, overall survival, number of participants free from distant metastases, number of participants with grade 2/3 xerostomia, patient scores from the Monroe Dunaway Anderson Dysphagia Inventory, PEG-tube rate, and rate of recurrence in all patients stratified by group and post TORS ctDNA levels.

This is a single-institution prospective phase 2 trial conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in Denmark. The study compares ultra-hypofractionated whole breast irradiation (WBI) to partial breast irradiation (PBI) in patients with breast cancer. The study has 2 arms: active comparator (PBI) and experimental (WBI). The primary outcome measures are acute and late toxicity, local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, distant metastasis occurrence, cosmetic outcome, and quality of life. The study is designed as a parallel assignment randomized controlled trial with no masking and open label. The study duration is 5 years, and the follow-up period is 10 years.

This study aims to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary outcomes of a digital health coaching program for patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. The program includes weekly calls from a health advisor, evidence-based content delivery, and a wearable activity tracker. The study will assess the program's impact on symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and financial, physiologic, and psychosocial well-being among patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. The study will also explore the relationship between medical management, health-related quality of life, and engagement in the program. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted over a period of 3 months.

This is a multicenter randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the porcine acellular dermal matrix in the treatment of localized gingival recessions. The study will enroll 60 participants and will be conducted over a period of 12 months. The primary outcome measure is the reduction of gingival recession height, which will be evaluated at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include the thickness of keratinized tissue evaluation after periodontal plastic surgery, which will also be evaluated at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of virtual reality (VR) and stationary bike (SB) exercises on heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients undergoing hemodialysis. The study will randomly assign participants to one of two groups: VR or SB. The primary outcome measures will be heart rate variability behavior during interventions with VR and SB while in hemodialysis. Secondary outcome measures will include blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation during interventions with VR and SB while in hemodialysis. The study will also assess the relative effectiveness of VR and SB exercises in improving heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients before and during hemodialysis sessions.

The study aims to investigate the relationship between ventilatory variability and dyspnea in patients undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation during a weaning trial. The study will measure various parameters such as dyspnea assessment, respiratory variability, spirometry, and electromyography. The primary outcome measures will be clinically significant dyspnea, measured by D-VAS and MV-RDOS, and the intensity of dyspnea, measured by D-VAS and MV-RDOS. The study will also assess the issue of the SBT, success or failure of the SBT, and EMG signal. The study will include 100 patients, including 50 communicative patients and 50 non-communicative patients.

The study compares the outcome of a modified mini-incision approach versus the conventional approach for carpal tunnel release in patients with primary CTS. The study includes 30 patients in each group, and the primary outcome measure is the improvement in carpal tunnel syndrome associated pain, which is evaluated at 6 months postoperative. Secondary outcome measures include pillar pain, recurrence of neuropathic symptoms, operative time, and scar effect, which are evaluated at 1, 3, and 6 months postoperative.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of action observation therapy (AOT) in improving cognitive status, functionality, and balance in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). The study will compare the effectiveness of AOT conducted by a therapist, AOT conducted by patients without cognitive impairment, and a control group. The primary outcome measures will include changes in cognitive impairment, activities of daily living, functionality, upper limb dexterity, balance, and gait. The study will last for 5 weeks, with data collection at the beginning and end of the intervention. The results of the study could have significant implications in educational activities, sports training, and neurorehabilitation.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of central line placement using an ultraportable ultrasound device compared to the standard method. The study will enroll patients scheduled to have a right or left jugular central venous line placed preoperatively or in the ICU. The primary outcome measure is the length of the procedure, which will be measured in seconds. The study will be designed as a randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental and sham comparator.

The study aims to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of Erbium:YAG laser in postpartum patients with episiotomy scars in respect of genital pelvic pain and scar tissue healing. The study is a randomized, sham-controlled, prospective study with 30 participants. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System) or the sham comparator group (Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System with sham handpiece). The primary outcome measures are the rate of change of pain and the rate of scar tissue healing, measured by visual analogue scale (0-10) and USG Elastography for fibrosis, respectively, at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include the rate of improvement in sexual function, evaluated by Female Sexual Function Index, and the incidence and severity of device-related adverse events.

75 adult patients with newly diagnosed gallstone disease will be recruited from East Kent University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust Hospitals. Data will be collected from electronic patient records, anthropometry, blood and imaging results, stool samples, and a 3-day food diary card. The study aims to understand the profile of the gut microbiome in adult patients diagnosed with gallstone disease and its relationship with patient outcomes, including complications of gallstone disease and post-operative complications.

The study will collect data on patient demographics, clinical history, and diagnostic investigations, as well as anthropometry, blood, and imaging results. Stool samples will be collected at the time of diagnosis and at 6-monthly intervals while awaiting cholecystectomy, as well as within 6 weeks of any surgical intervention. A 3-day food diary card will also be collected. The study will measure the bacterial DNA profile in the stool of participants, including the diversity of species present, and will assess the relationship between the gut microbiome and patient outcomes, including complications of gallstone disease and post-operative complications.

The study will have a prospective cohort design and will be conducted at East Kent University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust Hospitals. The study will include 75 adult patients with newly diagnosed gallstone disease. The study will collect data on patient demographics, clinical history, and diagnostic investigations, as well as anthropometry, blood, and imaging results. Stool samples will be collected at the time of diagnosis and at 6-monthly intervals while awaiting cholecystectomy, as well as within 6 weeks of any surgical intervention. A 3-day food diary card will also be collected. The study will measure the bacterial DNA profile in the stool of participants, including the diversity of species present, and will assess the relationship between the gut microbiome and patient outcomes, including complications of gallstone disease and post-operative complications.

The study will have a prospective cohort design and will be conducted at East Kent University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust Hospitals. The study will include 75 adult patients with newly diagnosed gallstone disease

The study aimed to investigate the association between elevated initial APRI value and the development of sepsis-associated liver dysfunction in adult patients with sepsis. The study included 100 patients and was conducted in the intensive care unit (ICU) setting. The primary outcome measure was the occurrence of SALD, which was defined as ALT or AST≥20 folds upper limit of normal level or TBIL≥2.0 mg/dL. The study found that elevated initial APRI value was associated with an increased risk of SALD.

The study used a retrospective design and included patients from the MIMIC IV database. The study excluded patients with chronic liver disease, viral hepatitis, primary acute cholangiopathies, cholecystitis, hepatic infarction, liver necrosis, liver trauma, and length of ICU stay < 24 hours. The study also excluded patients without simultaneous AST and PLT data in the first 24 hours after ICU admission.

The study found that the incidence of SALD was 20% in the non-SALD group and 40% in the SALD group. The study also found that the mean APRI value was significantly higher in the SALD group than in the non-SALD group. The study concluded that elevated initial APRI value was associated with an increased risk of SALD in adult patients with sepsis.

The study's findings have implications for the early detection and management of sepsis-associated liver dysfunction in adult patients with sepsis. The study suggests that monitoring APRI values in these patients may help identify those at risk of developing SALD and guide early interventions to prevent or manage the condition.

The clinical trial is evaluating the immunogenicity and safety of Omicron BA.4/5-Delta recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) in people aged 18 years and older with different immunization programs. The study is comparing the immune response and safety of the vaccine with a control vaccine. The primary outcome measures are the number of adverse events after 2 doses given intramuscularly, laboratory markers of immunity after 2 doses given intramuscularly, and immunogenic end points. Secondary outcome measures include laboratory markers of immunity, positive conversion rate against the prototype Omicron variant (BA.4/5, BF.7) after 2 doses of vaccine candidate, and growth multiples (GMI) of the prototype new coronavirus strain and the Omicron variant (BA.4/5, BF.7) after 2 doses of investigational vaccine. The study is randomized, double-blind, and active-controlled.

The study aimed to investigate the impact of early skin-to-skin contact on maternal-infant bonding and perception of traumatic birth. The study was conducted as a randomized controlled experimental study at Batman Training and Research Hospital TDL service between December 2021 and May 2022. The sample consisted of 350 women who had a normal delivery in the delivery room, and were divided into two groups: early skin-to-skin contact group (n=180) and control group (n=175). The early skin-to-skin contact group received instructions on how to apply skin-to-skin contact, and the control group received standard midwifery practices and labor follow-up. The primary outcome measures were maternal attachment scale score and traumatic birth perception scale score, which were measured from birth to 1 month after birth. The study found that early skin-to-skin contact had a positive impact on maternal-infant bonding and perception of traumatic birth.

The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an ultrasound-guided sacral erector spinae plane block in reducing post-operative pain after lumbar discectomy surgery. 54 patients were randomly assigned to either the intervention group (sacral ESPB) or the control group (no block). Both groups underwent standard general anaesthesia, and a patient-controlled analgesia device was given to both groups. Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) scores were assessed for 24 hours, and total consumption of analgesic and rescue analgesics were recorded. The results showed that the intervention group had significantly lower VAS scores and total analgesic consumption compared to the control group. The study concluded that sacral ESPB is an effective method for reducing post-operative pain after lumbar discectomy surgery.

The study aims to develop and validate a non-invasive multimodal ultrasound-based imaging biomarker for myofascial pain. The study will use deep learning to integrate measurements of echogenicity of latent and active trigger points, dynamic spatial-temporal tissue deformation quantified by strain tensors, and viscoelastic properties of the fascia and muscles measured by ultrasound shear wave elastography. The study will recruit 10 subjects per age decile, ages 20-70, with chronic low back pain and a myofascial component. The study will determine the sensitivity and specificity of the biomarker to classify the myofascial components of pain, as well as the response to treatment. The study will be conducted over a three-year timeframe, with four participant groups: healthy normals, MP without TPs, MP with latent TPs, and MP with active TPs. The primary outcome measure is the diagnosis of one of four MP-related categories, and the secondary outcome measures include the presence of substantial MP, as determined by standardized clinical examinations. The study will use ultrasound imaging to measure the echogenicity of latent and active trigger points, dynamic spatial-temporal tissue deformation quantified by strain tensors, and viscoelastic properties of the fascia and muscles measured by ultrasound shear wave elastography.

The Pain Intervention Via Video Optimization Trial is a two-arm, blinded, randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an adapted telehealth video intervention on pain recovery and opioid use among opioid-naïve adult ED and urgent care patients with musculoskeletal pain. The study will enroll 200 participants and assess them at baseline, 1, and 3 months post-intervention. The primary outcome measures include combined pain severity and interference scores, pain severity on the BPI-SF, pain interference on the BPI-SF, opioid use during the past week, and physical function-4. The study will compare the intervention group with the usual care group to determine the effectiveness of the video intervention.

The study aims to assess the impact of Neuro-linguistic programming on the academic performance of primary school students in Lebanon. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the Neuro-linguistic program in improving the concentration, hyperactivity, and reasoning of schoolchildren, as well as identifying the triggers that affect their academic performance. The study will involve 130 children aged between 5 and 11 years, who will receive 4 (45 minutes) sessions for teachers and 2 for children (total of 6 sessions). The study will measure the primary outcome measures, including the identification of school triggers through ''Identify School Triggers'' questionnaire, schoolchildren's strengths and difficulties progression through the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire, and concentration, hyperactivity, and reasoning of schoolchildren through the Vanderbilt Assessment Scale. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 months after the intervention.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the ECOX teaching tool in improving the final grade for service OSCEs among medical students. The study will enroll 18 years of age or older medical students in a non-ERASMUS emergency department, who are participating in the service ECOS planned at the end of their internship. The study will randomly assign participants to either the ECOX interventional group or the control group. The primary outcome measure will be the students' average score on the end-of-course OSCEs, and the secondary outcome measures will include the average STAI-Y (State-Trait Anxiety) scores and the average scores on the behavioral assessment during the service ECOS. The study will run for 10 weeks.

The study aims to evaluate the effects of a web-based health care program on symptom management, social support, activity tolerance, and quality of life in patients with pulmonary hypertension. The program is designed to improve patients' self-care ability and active tolerance, and reduce symptom distress, anxiety, and depression. The study will be conducted in two phases: a pilot study and a randomized controlled trial. In the pilot study, the program will be developed and tested for feasibility and acceptability. In the randomized controlled trial, the program will be evaluated for its effectiveness in improving patients' outcomes.

The study aims to evaluate the effects of long-term ventilation support on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families. The study will assess the overall quality of life, health-related quality of life, disease-specific quality of life, and caregiver burden of ALS patients and their families. The study will also assess the impact of long-term ventilation support on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families at different time points. The study will enroll ALS patients and their families, and the primary outcome measures will include the overall quality of life, health-related quality of life, and disease-specific quality of life. The study will use various assessment tools, including the Quality of Life Scale, Severe Respiratory Insufficiency Questionnaire, Kidsscreen-27, Zarit Burden Interview, and EQ-5D-5L. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France, and the expected completion date is December 2023.

This is a single arm study to assess the presence or absence of spreading depolarization in patients undergoing standard of care surgical evacuation of chronic subdural hematoma (cSDH) using subdural ECoG monitoring. The study will measure the primary outcome of post operative neurologic deterioration and secondary outcome measures including extended Glasgow outcome scale, Montreal Cognitive Assessment, NIH toolbox cognitive battery, PROMIS 29 profile, TBI QOL, and headache disability index.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This is a randomized, controlled, non-inferiority trial to assess the impact of annual versus semestrial ocrelizumab infusions on freedom from radiological disease activity at two years in patients with active multiple sclerosis. The study includes 120 participants who are randomly assigned to either the annual or semestrial ocrelizumab group. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of patients with no new or enlarged T2 lesion >3mm on cerebrospinal MRI at 24 months compared with inclusion MRI.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and does not include any external sources or information.

The SPARCOL Study is a clinical trial investigating the effectiveness and safety of Combined Endoscopic Laparoscopic Surgery (CELS) in treating early-stage colon cancer in elderly frail patients. The study compares CELS to standard resection and assesses the primary outcome measure of change in patient-reported postoperative recovery, as well as secondary outcome measures such as exercise capacity, quality of life, frailty, and long-term oncological outcomes. The study is conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida in Denmark and includes 100 participants.

The study is a Phase 2 open-label pilot study to evaluate the effectiveness of nebulized hypertonic saline in decreasing respiratory exacerbations in people with neuromuscular disease or neurodisability. The study will enroll 30 participants aged 5 years and above, including adults, who have a history of at least one respiratory exacerbation requiring antibiotic treatment with or without the need for hospitalization in the past 12 months. The study will measure the primary outcome of course of antibiotics for respiratory infections, as well as secondary outcome measures such as lung clearance index, forced oscillation technique, lung ultrasound, electrical impedance tomography, airway inflammation, bacterial diversity, ease of airway clearance, health-related quality of life, patient and main carer treatment satisfaction, family impact, and health economics. The study will be conducted over 52 weeks, with assessments at baseline, week 26, and week 51.

The study aims to investigate the prevalence of paraphilic disorders and other conditions with risk for sexual violence in a clinical population. The study will also investigate the effectiveness of treatment as usual for these conditions. The study will include a qualitative interview to assess the progress of the disorder from first memory to current state. The study will also collect DNA/epigenetic markers associated with sexual violence. The study will include a control group of healthy volunteers. The study will assess the following outcome measures: Karolinska interpersonal violence scale, MINI, Långström Self-assessment Sexual Interests (LASSIE), Personality Inventory for DSM-5 (PID-5), Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment, Hypersexual Disorder: Current Assessment Scale (HD:CAS), The Montgomery-Åsberg Depression Rating Scale - Self rating (MADRS-S), The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), The Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (BIS), Compulsive Sexual Behavior Disorder Scale-19 (CSBD-19), The Rape questionnaire (Bumpy 1996), Susceptibility to Temptation Scale (STS), Insomnia Severity Index (ISI), Brunnsviken Brief Quality of Life Inventory (BBQ), Client Satisfaction Scale (CSQ-8), Revised University of California (UCLA) Loneliness Scale (RULS), Karolinska Sleep Questionnaire (KSQ), DNA/epigenetic markers associated with sexual violence, Hypersexual behavior inventory (HBI), The Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT), The Drug Use Disorders Identification Test (DUDIT), The Childhood Trauma/neglect (CTQ), Computerized testing of impulsivity (CGT Cambridge Gambling (Cambling (Cambling (LASS), The Montgomery-Åsberg Impulsivity (BISI, The Rape questionnaire (Ps (PQ

The study aims to evaluate the metabolic imaging approach (aMRI) in patients with gliomas. The primary outcome measures are the mean values of kᵢₒ*V of the entire tumor region, and the correlation between aMRI and 18F-FDG PET (SUVmax) data. Secondary outcome measures include the mean value of kᵢₒ*V in the tumor periphery and core regions, and the kᵢₒ*V in different normal appearing brain sub-regions unaffected by tumor.

The study will enroll adult patients (greater than 18 years of age) with glioma who require MRI and 18F-FDG-PET imaging. Participants will receive 18F-FDG IV, then 60 minutes later undergo simultaneous MRI and PET scanning. During this scanning period, participants will receive gadoterate meglumine IV to obtain post-contrast MRI. The total scanning time will take 45-60 minutes.

The study will measure the metabolic activity of the tumor using aMRI and 18F-FDG PET. The primary outcome measures will be the mean values of kᵢₒ*V of the entire tumor region, and the correlation between aMRI and 18F-FDG PET (SUVmax) data. Secondary outcome measures will include the mean value of kᵢₒ*V in the tumor periphery and core regions, and the kᵢₒ*V in different normal appearing brain sub-regions unaffected by tumor.

The study will enroll 20 participants and will be completed within 1 year. The results of the study will provide valuable information on the metabolic activity of gliomas and the potential of aMRI as a metabolic imaging approach in clinical practice.

The GREAT-HF Care study is a cluster randomized trial evaluating the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). The study is conducted at 5 clinical practice sites and includes 3 arms: (1) usual care, (2) multi-pronged clinical decision support (CDS) inclusive of a patient portal message about GDMT, an interruptive advisory upon chart entry as a notification to clinicians on GDMT consideration, and a Best Practice Advisory (BPA) that includes a GDMT order set, and (3) multi-pronged CDS as in #2 but replacement of GDMT order set with referral to integrated clinical pharmacist co-management. The study measures the primary outcome of HF GDMT prescription increased (yes/no) within 30 days of index visit, and secondary outcomes of HF GDMT prescription increased (yes/no) within 60 and 90 days of index visit, and addition of SGLT2i or ARNI for HFrEF (yes/no) within 30, 60, and 90 days of index visit. The study also explores the independent and incremental benefits of education with other interventional approaches.

This study compares the effectiveness of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) alone versus ESWL combined with tamsulosin therapy in treating upper ureteric stones. The study includes 100 participants, randomly assigned to either the active comparator group or the experimental group. The primary outcome measure is stone clearance, assessed at 4 weeks after treatment.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of interventional therapy for tracheal stenosis after percutaneous tracheotomy. The study will measure the primary outcome of successful decannulation, as well as secondary outcomes such as technical success, reintervention, type of intervention, clinical success, and additional treatment. The study will enroll adult patients with tracheal stenosis after percutaneous tracheotomy and will be conducted over a period of 12 months.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The DRIVE-Mind II study is a non-randomized, parallel-assignment, health services research study comparing the effectiveness of a community-based psychiatric intervention in reducing the risk of HIV/HCV exposure among people who inject drugs (PWID) with a psychiatric disorder (depression, psychosis, or suicide risk) versus those without such a disorder. The study will enroll 600 participants (200 in the intervention group and 400 in the control group) and will measure the effectiveness of the intervention in reducing viral exposure, severity of substance use, quality of life, and the incidence of psychiatric disorders. The study will also assess the cost-effectiveness of the intervention and explore the factors that may affect access to care.

The study is a randomized, clinical, superiority trial comparing the effectiveness of conventional endodontic treatment with that of endodontic treatment combined with photodynamic therapy (PDT) in patients with apical lesion. The study has three parallel arms: placebo, PDT 10 s, and PDT 20 s. The primary outcome measures are reduction in lesion size and disinfection of the root canals, evaluated through PAI index score and colony formation (ufc/ml) respectively. The success rate of the treatment will also be assessed after 6 months.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of psychiatric orders in the treatment of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The study will assess the primary outcome measures, including the Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (HAM-A), Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-7), Dissociative Experiences Scale - II (DES-II), The Defeat Scale (D Scale), Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS), Severity Measure for Agoraphobia-Adult, BPD Check List, Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSE), Young Schema Questionnaire (YSQ), and Personality Belief Questionnaire (PBQ). The study will also measure secondary outcome measures, including heart rate, systolic blood pressure, and diastolic blood pressure. The study will be conducted over a period of 90 days.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) in reducing post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms in earthquake-affected individuals in Türkiye. The study will be conducted as a pilot randomized controlled trial, and 30 participants will be randomly assigned to either the CPT or enhanced care as usual (E-CAU) control group. The primary outcome measure will be the change in PTSD symptoms assessed by the Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder Check List for PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) from baseline to post-intervention. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in depression, anxiety, and well-being symptoms assessed by the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 (GAD-7), World Health Organization (WHO) Well-Being Scale, Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), and Kessler Psychological Distress Scale (K-10). The study will be conducted over a period of 7 weeks to 1 month after the intervention.

The study aims to assess the perceived quality of family planning counseling among reproductive aged women in El-Dakhla District, New Valley, Egypt. The study will use a validated and client-centered based Quality of Contraceptive Counseling (QCC) Scale to measure the quality of counseling received during family planning visits. The study will also investigate the associated factors of quality of counseling, including client, provider, and facility factors. The study will be conducted in primary health centers and general hospitals in El-Dakhla District, and will include 423 women aged 18-45 years. The study will be conducted over one year, and will use a semi-structured interview administered questionnaire to collect data.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of pulsed-field ablation and complex ablation procedures in treating persistent atrial fibrillation. The study will enroll patients aged 18-75 years old and randomly assign them to either the active comparator group (pulmonary vein isolation) or the experimental group (pulmonary vein isolation supplemented by additional lesions). The primary outcome measure is the recurrence of atrial fibrillation lasting >30 seconds, assessed using repeated 7-day ECG Holter monitoring. Secondary outcome measures include the recurrence of atrial fibrillation on anti-arrhythmic drugs, hospitalization rate, cardioversion, complications, quality of life, and EuroQol Group questionnaire on quality of life. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year following the ablation procedure.

The study is a Phase I clinical trial to assess the safety and immunogenicity of the malaria vaccine candidate RH5.1 formulated with Matrix-M in healthy adult volunteers. The study will enroll 24 participants into two different dosing regimens and will measure safety and immunogenicity outcomes up to 547 days after the last vaccination. The study will also compare differences in innate immune responses following the first and third vaccinations and correlate these with adverse event data and adaptive immune responses.

The study is a monocentric, 18-months, randomized, rater-blinded trial to evaluate the influence of a multidisciplinary, personalized symptomatic treatment plan with integrated mobile palliative care and telemedicine on the baseline to 18-months change in the QoL of individuals with MSA compared to a sex-, age- and disease-duration matched historical European MSA cohort. The study will recruit 46 individuals with MSA and will assess the primary outcome measure of change in the EQ-5D-5L score, as well as secondary outcome measures such as changes in the MSA-QoL score and subscores, time to clinical milestones, changes in the individual healthcare preferences, in-person and telemedicine medical, psychological and neurorehabilitation interventional needs, change in the Short Assessment of Patient Satisfaction (SAPS) referred to the overall individualized treatment plan, individual satisfaction with the single telemedicine and mobile palliative interventions, healthcare professionals satisfaction with the single telemedicine and mobile palliative interventions, number of medical complications, single-intervention and cumulative healthcare costs, changes in the EQ-5D-5L score of informal caregivers of individuals with MSA recruited in the present study, change in the Carers quality-of-life questionnaire for parkinsonism (PQoL Carers) score and other caregiver-burden indicators in informal caregivers of individuals with MSA recruited in the present study.

This study aims to investigate the genetic basis of response to growth hormone treatment in children with idiopathic short stature. The study will enroll participants who have been diagnosed with idiopathic short stature and have received growth hormone therapy for at least one year. The participants will be divided into two groups based on their response to growth hormone therapy, and their genetic samples will be analyzed to identify genetic variants that may be associated with response to growth hormone therapy.

The study will measure the frequency of genetic variants that significantly differ between the two responder groups and the enrichment of genetic variants per gene/pathway. The study will also assess the adherence to growth hormone therapy and the presence of any clinical or biochemical abnormalities that may affect growth.

The study will enroll participants between the ages of 3 and 11 years, and the study duration will be one year after growth hormone therapy. The study will be conducted in two arms, with one arm receiving no treatment and the other arm receiving growth hormone therapy.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the International Conference on Harmonisation (ICH) Good Clinical Practice (GCP) guidelines and the Declaration of Helsinki. The study will be approved by the institutional review board (IRB) and the ethics committee, and informed consent will be obtained from the participants and their parents or legal guardians.

The study will provide valuable insights into the genetic basis of response to growth hormone treatment in children with idiopathic short stature, which may help in the development of personalized treatment strategies for these patients.

The study aims to evaluate the impact of neurochecks on sleep in critically ill adults. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with two arms: hourly neurochecks and every-other-hour neurochecks. The primary outcome measures include sleep efficiency, wakefulness, REM sleep, deep sleep, arousals, and sleep quality (subjective). The study will recruit adult patients aged 25-75 years who are status post uncomplicated elective coiling of unruptured cerebral aneurysm. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to assess the radiologic prognostic importance of extranodal extension (iENE) in head and neck cancer. The study will evaluate the accuracy of radiologists in identifying iENE, its prognostic significance in overall survival, recurrence rates, and risk stratification based on HPV status and N stage. The study will also investigate the utility of various existing standardized diagnostic classification systems in accurately diagnosing iENE and measure interobserver variability amongst radiologists in grading radiographic ENE.

The study will enroll patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, extranodal extension, and human papilloma virus-related carcinoma. The primary outcome measures will assess the accuracy of radiologists in identifying iENE, overall survival rates, recurrence rates, and risk stratification based on HPV status and N stage. The secondary outcome measures will evaluate the improvement in diagnosis of iENE, assess the utility of various existing standardized diagnostic classification systems, and measure interobserver variability amongst radiologists in grading radiographic ENE.

The study will be conducted at multiple sites and will include patients treated between 1999 and 2020. The study will accept patients who are over 18 years old and will exclude those who are diagnosed with distant metastasis at presentation, treated palliatively at first presentation, or presenting with recurrent disease who do not meet all the eligibility criteria.

The study plan includes arms and interventions, primary and secondary outcome measures, and terms related to the study. The study will be designed as a prospective cohort study with radiologists assessing the presence or absence of iENE on CT or/and MRI scans. The study will also include a retrospective analysis of existing data to evaluate the prognostic significance of iENE.

In summary, the study aims to assess the radiologic prognostic importance of extranodal extension in head and neck cancer, evaluate the accuracy of radiologists in identifying iENE, and assess the utility of various existing standardized diagnostic classification systems in accurately diagnosing iENE.

The study aims to compare the efficiency and safety of bedside blind bone biopsy (BB) versus conventional bone biopsy (surgical or radiological) in the diagnosis and management of diabetic foot osteomyelitis (DFO). The study will enroll patients with DFU and suspicion of DFO, and will randomly assign them to either the experimental group (bedside BB) or the active comparator group (conventional BB). The primary outcome measure is the remission of DFO at 12 months, and secondary outcome measures include clinical efficacy, microbiological results, occurrence of adverse events, and costs. The study will be conducted at Lariboisiere Hospital and Bichat Hospital in Paris, France.

The African Americans (AA) Communities Speak study aims to address disparities in end-of-life (EoL) care for older African Americans (AA) by developing a culturally aligned training program for clinicians. The program will be tested in two geographically diverse regions: Birmingham, Alabama, and the Bronx, New York. The study will measure the effectiveness of the program in improving patient/family reported therapeutic alliance, goal concordant care, and clinicians' knowledge of cultural values, awareness of implicit bias, and confidence to change practice. The study will also assess the program's feasibility, acceptability, and potential impact on EoL care quality.

The study aims to assess the genomic alterations and profiles of expression in HPV+ versus HPV head and neck cancers. The study will enroll patients with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma or oral cavity histologically proven. The study will use genetic analysis, including PCR, immunohistochemistry, and immunolabeling, to determine the molecular profile of head and neck tumors. The study will also measure the primary outcome measures, including the molecular profile of oropharyngeal or oral cavity HPV positive and negative tumors.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to validate the use of visual analog scales to measure satisfaction and well-being at work. The study will assess various aspects of work, including job demand, job control, social support, effort-reward imbalance, work addiction, life satisfaction, sociodemographic characteristics, occupation, work hours per week, night and weekend work, alcohol consumption, tobacco consumption, height, weight, sedentary behavior, physical activity, stress at work, ethical conflicts, perceived health, stress at home, fatigue, sleep quality, and mood. The study will also collect data on sociodemographic characteristics, occupation, work hours per week, night and weekend work, alcohol consumption, tobacco consumption, height, weight, sedentary behavior, physical activity, stress at work, ethical conflicts, perceived health, stress at home, fatigue, sleep quality, and mood.

The study will use various questionnaires and scales to assess these aspects, including the Validation of Visual Analog Scales to Measure Satisfaction and Well-being at Work (SoWell-VAS), Job Demand-Control-Support (JDCS) questionnaire of Karasek, Effort-Reward Imbalance Questionnaire (ERI), Work Addiction Risk Test (WART), Minnesota Satisfaction Questionnaire (MSQ), and others. The study will be conducted over a period of one week, with participants completing the questionnaires on inclusion and one week later.

The study aims to determine the validity and reliability of the SoWell-VAS in measuring satisfaction and well-being at work, and to identify the factors that influence these aspects. The study will also explore the relationship between these factors and the SoWell-VAS scores.

The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial design, with a sample of 100 participants. The participants will be recruited from various organizations in the region, and will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive the SoWell-VAS questionnaire, while the control group will receive a standardized questionnaire.

The study will use descriptive statistics and inferential statistics, such as correlation and regression analysis, to analyze the data. The results of the study will be presented in a comprehensive

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, controlled clinical trial to evaluate the effectiveness of different techniques for alveolar ridge preservation after tooth extraction. The study includes 4 arms, each with a different intervention: spontaneous healing (control), bone particle + subepithelial connective tissue graft, bone particle + vascularized interpositional periosteal connective tissue graft, and bone particle + collagen membrane. The primary outcome measures are soft tissue alteration and hard tissue alteration, measured using cone-beam computed tomography data and STereoLithography files, and keratinized tissue width changes, measured using a periodontal probe. The study also assesses visual analogue scale for patient satisfaction. The study is conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida and includes healthy volunteers aged 20-80 years old.

The study aims to compare the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in patients with Essure® contraceptive implants and in control patients with endometriosis or adenomyosis. The study will enroll 30 participants, including 10 patients who underwent removal of the Essure® contraceptive implant, 10 patients with no endometriosis/adenomyosis who underwent benign laparoscopic gynecological surgery, and 10 patients with endometriosis/adenomyosis who underwent benign laparoscopic gynecological surgery. The study will measure the level of cytokine IL10 in peritoneal fluid at an average of 4 months after the surgery. The study is designed to determine if there is a significant difference in the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines between patients with Essure® contraceptive implants and control patients.

This is a two-way (retrospective+prospective) cohort study of patients with primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) and autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) infected with COVID-19. The study aims to compare the difference of COVID-19 infection rate, disease severity, clinical biochemical indicators, hospital stay, and prognosis between UDCA-treated and non-UDCA-treated patients and to study the impact of UDCA on the occurrence, incidence, and prognosis of COVID-19 infection. The study includes 100 patients with autoimmune liver disease who have been treated with UDCA for six months or more and 100 patients who have not been treated with UDCA. The study measures the incidence of COVID-19 infection, severity of disease after COVID-19 infection, COVID-19 nucleic acid disappearance time, and COVID-19 infection outcome. The study is conducted at Beijing Ditan Hospital, Capital Medical University from January 2021 to December 2023.

The study aims to investigate the effect of preoperative prone position training on the incidence of pulmonary complications in patients undergoing laparoscopic colorectal surgery. The study is a prospective, randomized, controlled clinical trial and will include 100 patients, divided into two groups: the prone position training group (PPT) and the control group (C). The primary outcome measure is the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications, and secondary outcome measures include arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2), extubation time, peak airway pressure, and oxygenation index (OI). The study will be conducted at the First Affiliated Hospital of Chongqing Medical University.

The study is a Phase I/II, open-label clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 oral liquid combined with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy in patients with advanced inoperable or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer. The study will enroll 20 patients in the Phase I dose-escalation part and 20 patients in the Phase II efficacy part. The primary outcome measures are DLT determination, RDL determination, overall response rate (PR + CR) after 4 cycles of combination use, overall response rate (PR + CR) after at least 1 cycle of combination use, rate of grade 3/4 hematological toxicity, and effect on quality of life by EORTC QLQ-C30. The study is designed as a non-randomized, open-label study with a 3+3 design in the Phase I dose-escalation part and a following study to determine the efficacy in the Phase II part.

The AGE SELF CARE study is a pilot study that aims to promote healthy aging through a group visit program. The study is designed as a single-group assignment with no masking. The study measures primary outcomes such as recruitment rate, completion of testing, attendance, completion of home practice log, and participant satisfaction. Secondary outcomes include frailty index, loneliness, self-reported health, Godin Leisure-Time Exercise Questionnaire, self-efficacy, Patient health questionnaire 2-item scale (PHQ-2), Generalized Anxiety Disorder 2-item scale (GAD-2), sleep, and Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB). The study is conducted among community-dwelling adults aged 65 years and older who are pre-frail. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the AGE SELF CARE program in promoting healthy aging and preventing frailty.

The study is a multi-center observational cohort study conducted in several European countries to assess the course of functional and clinical outcomes in post-COVID-19 geriatric rehabilitation patients. The study aims to provide insights into the treatment modalities employed and the organization of geriatric rehabilitation provided to post-COVID patients in Europe. The study will collect data on demographic factors, medical history, and treatment outcomes at admission, discharge, and 6 weeks and 6 months follow-up. The primary outcome measures will be change in Activities of Daily Living (ADL)-functioning and quality of life (EQ-5D-5L) from admission to discharge and 6 months follow-up.

Note: This summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and may not reflect the entire study design or all the details of the study.

The PREPARE-iVAC trial is a multicentre, open-label, controlled, randomized study to evaluate the immunogenicity and safety of replacing mycophenolate mofetil/mycophenolic acid (MMF/MPA) with everolimus in kidney transplant recipients. The study aims to determine whether everolimus improves the immune response to COVID-19 vaccination, as measured by neutralizing antibody titer against the Omicron XBB.1.5 strain, and to evaluate the safety of everolimus in terms of incidence of treated acute rejection, kidney function decline, incidence of serious adverse events (SAEs), incidence of adverse events of special interest (AESI) of immunosuppression, incidence of solicited adverse events (AEs) of COVID-19 vaccination, and incidence of solicited AEs of herpes zoster vaccination. The study will enroll 70 participants and will be conducted at 7 study sites in the Netherlands.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of resistance exercises on liver enzymes post burn. 60 patients with partial thickness burns will be randomly assigned to either the study group (receiving resistance exercises) or the control group (receiving physical therapy program and medical treatment). The study will be conducted over 8 weeks, with assessments at baseline, 2 months, and 4 months. The primary outcome measures will be plasma liver enzymes level (AST and ALT enzymes) at 2 months.

Conclusion:
The study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of resistance exercises in reducing liver enzymes level post burn, which can help in developing a new treatment approach for burn patients.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of upper trapezius stretching in reducing neck pain, improving neck range of motion, and reducing disability in patients with cervical spondylosis. The study will enroll 40 participants and will be conducted over a period of 9 weeks, including a 4-week intervention period and a 3-month follow-up period. The primary outcome measures will be changes in neck pain intensity, neck range of motion, and neck disability index. The study will be masked and will have a parallel assignment design.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Tecarterapy on the performance of amateur athletes. The study will be conducted on athletes between 18 and 30 years of age who are federated and competing in university or national amateur leagues. The study will assess the change in 30 meters sprint time, electromyographic activity during sprint, countermovement jump height, isometric leg extension force, and electromyographic activity during isometric leg extension. The study will be conducted in two groups: experimental and sham. The experimental group will receive Tecarterapy, while the sham group will receive a sham treatment. The study will be conducted over a period of 8 weeks.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, it is not a comprehensive analysis of the study.

This study aims to evaluate the cell free DNA quantification in patients with endometriosis followed with medical assistance to procreation. The study will enroll patients who are about to undergo IVF treatment and will collect blood samples before and after oocyte puncture to measure the cell free DNA levels. The study will also evaluate the number of oocytes reaching the metaphase II, fragmentation rate, number of cells at day 2, number of cells at day 3, blastulation rate at day 5 of development, number of clinical pregnancy, and number of live birth in both groups of patients. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida and will include 100 patients in each group.

The study compares the outcomes of maxillary implant overdentures retained by bars or Locators in fully edentulous patients. The study measures the change in marginal peri-implant bone level, implant and overdenture survival, pocket probing depth, plaque score, peri-implant mucosa health, and patient satisfaction at 10 years.

The study includes 20 patients in each group (bar-retained and Locator-retained). The primary outcome measure is the change in marginal peri-implant bone level, which is measured using cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) scans. Secondary outcome measures include implant and overdenture survival, pocket probing depth, plaque score, peri-implant mucosa health, and patient satisfaction, which are assessed using clinical examinations and questionnaires.

The study is a prospective, observational, and parallel-group design with a 10-year follow-up period. The study is conducted at the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, University Medical Center Groningen, the Netherlands.

The study aims to provide evidence on the long-term outcomes of maxillary implant overdentures retained by bars or Locators in fully edentulous patients. The results of this study may help dentists and oral surgeons make informed decisions about the most appropriate attachment system for their patients.
