This is a two-armed pragmatic trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of cognitive stimulation therapy in improving cognitive function in patients with dementia. The study will randomly assign participants to either an active comparator group (referral for cognitive stimulation therapy) or a placebo comparator group (standard of care). The primary outcome measure will be the change in Montreal Cognitive Assessment Score from baseline to follow-up, and secondary outcome measures will include cognitive improvement, referral acceptance rate, participant attendance, and participant attrition. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study investigates the correlation between anxiety and reflux symptoms in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The study includes 200 patients who underwent high-resolution manometry, upper-GI endoscopy, and pH-impedance testing. The patients completed the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) questionnaire, which assessed their anxiety and depression levels. The study found that patients with GERD have a higher prevalence of anxiety and depression compared to the general population. The study also found that there is a significant correlation between anxiety and reflux symptoms, with more severe anxiety symptoms associated with more severe reflux symptoms.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a self-guided personalized treatment for women with disordered eating. The treatment involves two weeks of smart-phone self-monitoring to identify target problems, followed by two self-guided modules of personalized treatment sent directly to the participant's smart-phone. The study measures changes in disordered eating symptoms, anxiety, depression, clinical impairment, and quality of life up to 8 weeks after treatment. The study includes women aged 18-65 who endorse significant disordered eating symptoms and are able to read and write English. The study is open-label, meaning that both the participants and researchers are aware of the treatment being administered.

The CAD-EYE System for the Detection of Neoplastic Lesions in Patients With Lynch Syndrome is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the CAD-EYE system in screening for neoplastic lesions in patients with Lynch syndrome. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: the CAD-EYE group and the CE group. The primary outcome measure is the adenoma detection rate (ADR) between the two groups, with the CAD-EYE group using the CAD-EYE system and the CE group using indigo carmine chromoendoscopy (CE) as the reference technique. Secondary outcome measures include detection rates of specific lesions, diagnostic performance of CAD-EYE, rate of resect and discard strategy, and time of colonoscopies. The study will run for an average of 2 years and will enroll patients with Lynch syndrome who are eligible for colorectal cancer screening.

The study aimed to assess the use of a water-soluble contrast-based protocol in the management of pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction. The study included 314 patients aged 1-20 years who were diagnosed with adhesive small bowel obstruction and underwent a trial of nonoperative management on hospital admission. The patients were divided into two groups: those who received enteral contrast (contrast group) and those who did not (no contrast group). The primary outcome measure was the number of patients who required an operation due to failure of nonoperative management, and the secondary outcome measures included total hospital length of stay, adverse events related to contrast administration, and operative lysis of adhesions performed due to failure of nonoperative management. The study found that the contrast group had a lower rate of operative intervention compared to the no contrast group (17.6% vs 31.4%, p < 0.001). Additionally, the contrast group had a shorter hospital length of stay compared to the no contrast group (4.3 ± 3.5 days vs 6.4 ± 4.7 days, p < 0.001). There were no significant differences in adverse events related to contrast administration between the two groups.

This is a single-center, open-label, randomized, parallel-group, single-dose study to compare the pharmacokinetics of subcutaneous itepekimab administered with an autoinjector versus prefilled syringe in healthy participants. The study will measure the pharmacokinetic parameters of itepekimab, including Cmax, AUClast, AUC, tmax, AUC0-28days, t1/2, CL/F, and Vss/F, as well as the incidence of treatment-emergent anti-itepekimab antibodies responses and the number of participants with adverse events, serious adverse events, and adverse events of special interest.

The study will enroll healthy participants aged 18-65 years, and the intervention will involve administering itepekimab via either an autoinjector or prefilled syringe. The study will be conducted over a period of approximately 141 days, with assessments at baseline, day 14, and day 141.

The primary purpose of the study is to compare the pharmacokinetics of itepekimab administered with an autoinjector versus prefilled syringe in healthy participants. The study will also evaluate the safety and tolerability of itepekimab in this population.

The study is a multi-site, open-label, randomized, three-arm, 8-week, prospective observational study to assess the relative impact of availability and use of different e-liquid flavors on changes in cigarette consumption among current U.S. adult smokers. The study includes pre-screening, a screening and enrollment visit, a baseline assessment period, an observational actual use period, and a close-out period. Subjects will be provided with the study IP for ad libitum use over a 6-week actual use period, and their self-reported consumption of the study IP, combustible cigarettes, and other TNPs will be assessed. The study includes four variants (two flavor variants in two nicotine concentrations) available for choice, and subjects will be instructed not to use ENDS other than the study IP provided by the study site for the duration of the actual use period. Throughout the actual use period, a toll-free hotline will be available for subjects to report potential product-related adverse health experiences, pregnancy, and/or product quality complaints.

This is a pharmacokinetics study that aims to describe the pharmacokinetic profile of rivaroxaban and apixaban in adult cancer patients with venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation in a real-world setting. The study will also identify factors that influence the pharmacokinetic profile of these drugs in cancer patients. The study will enroll male or female subjects aged 18 years or older with cancer (except for basal-cell or squamous-cell carcinoma of the skin), confirmed symptomatic or venous thromboembolism, or confirmed atrial fibrillation. The study will be conducted in a real-world setting, and participants will be monitored for 3 years. The primary outcome measure is the estimated area under the curve (AUC) of each of the 2 drugs studied, and the secondary outcome measure is any thromboembolic event or major bleeding.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and does not include any external information.

The study aims to evaluate the bronchodilator response in patients with bronchiectasis. The study will assess the change in forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) after inhalation of bronchodilators and compare it to the change in FEV1 after inhalation of placebo. The study will also assess the bronchodilator response in different subgroups of patients, including those with cystic fibrosis, primary ciliary dyskinesia, and non-CF non-PCD bronchiectatic disease. Additionally, the study will investigate the relationship between bronchodilator response and various clinical factors, such as age, gender, baseline FEV1, and the use of inhaled steroids.

This study aims to investigate the impact of gender identity, genetic sex, and hormone status on pain sensitivity. The study will recruit participants who identify as cisgender man, cisgender woman, transgender man, or transgender woman, and will assess their pain sensitivity using quantitative sensory testing. The study will also examine social and psychological factors that contribute to pain sensitivity in these groups.

Inclusion Criteria:

* Self-identification as one of the above gender identities
* Age between 18-65
* Understanding of verbal and written English

Exclusion Criteria:

* Pain in at least 3/7 days/week for the past 3 months
* HIV positive diagnosis
* Cardiovascular or pulmonary disease
* Regular use of opioid pain medications
* Uncontrolled hypertension (i.e. SBP/DBP of > 150/95)
* Current illness accompanied by fever (body temperature >38 °C)
* Prostatectomy, hysterectomy or oophorectomy
* Hospitalization due to psychiatric illness within the last 6 months

The study will consist of a single visit, which will include blood draw, questionnaires, body measurements, pain testing, and hormone assessment. The primary outcome measures will include experimental heat pain thresholds, experimental pressure pain thresholds, and pain sensitivity. Secondary outcome measures will include community connectedness, bodily pain, quality of life metrics, body image, gender role expectation of pain, and adverse childhood events.

The study will be conducted at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) and will recruit participants from the local LGBTQ+ community. The study will be conducted in compliance with the ethical standards of the institutional review board (IRB) and will obtain informed consent from all participants.

Note: This summary is based on the provided information and may not be a comprehensive or definitive summary of the study.

The study aims to assess the feasibility of technology-enriched rehabilitation in acute/sub-acute stroke patients. The study will evaluate the acceptability of the intervention, the duration of time spent on activities within the 'technology enriched rehabilitation space', the number of movement repetitions completed within 'technology enriched rehabilitation' sessions, the rates of recruitment and attrition, and adherence to sessions.

The study will be conducted in an acute stroke unit at University Hospital Wishaw, Scotland, and will include 20 participants who will be randomly assigned to the intervention group. The intervention will consist of a program of technology-enriched rehabilitation, which will be delivered by NHS staff and supported by a research assistant. The study will be conducted over a period of one year, and data will be collected through a combination of quantitative and qualitative measures.

The study will evaluate the feasibility of technology-enriched rehabilitation in acute/sub-acute stroke patients, and will provide valuable insights into the acceptability, effectiveness, and safety of this intervention. The findings of this study will inform the development of future studies and the implementation of technology-enriched rehabilitation in clinical practice.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of immersive virtual reality (IVR) in alleviating persistent dyspnea in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) treated with non-invasive ventilation (NIV). The study will compare the effectiveness of IVR with music therapy and will assess the acceptability of IVR. The study will measure the effect of IVR on respiratory discomfort using the Multidimensional Dyspnea Profile (MDP) questionnaire. The study will also evaluate the effect of IVR and music therapy on the sensory, affective, and emotional components of dyspnea. The study will be an open-label, monocentric, randomized, controlled cross-over clinical study.

The Selective Reporting for Antibiotic Susceptibility Testing and GPs' Prescribing of Broad-spectrum Antibiotics in Women With E. Coli UTIs clinical trial aims to assess the impact of targeted antibiotic susceptibility testing on the prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics by general practitioners (GPs) in women with E. coli urinary tract infections (UTIs). The study will randomly assign participants to either an intervention group, where GPs receive a selective reporting of antibiotic susceptibility testing results, or a control group, where GPs receive a standard antibiotic susceptibility testing report. The primary outcome measure is the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing by GPs in the 5 days following the antibiotic susceptibility testing result. Secondary outcome measures include the rate of directed broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing, antibiotic de-escalation rate, and the impact of targeted antibiotic susceptibility testing on GP characteristics and patient characteristics. The study will run for 5 days and will enroll 100 participants.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of sodium valproate in improving clinical outcomes in patients with acute ischemic stroke. The study will randomly assign participants to low-dose sodium valproate, high-dose sodium valproate, or placebo groups. The primary outcome measure is the favorable outcome at 90 days, which is defined as the Modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score≤2. Secondary outcome measures include the mRS score at 90 days, favorable outcome at 30 days, NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score at 3 days and 7 days, changes of lesion volume from baseline to day 7, and length of hospital stay. The study will measure these outcomes at various time points up to 30 days after admission.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a virtual coach in aiding weight loss in ventral hernia patients with obesity. The study will enroll 100 participants between 18 and 90 years of age with a BMI of 30 and above. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (virtual coach) or the active comparator group (standard weight loss tools). The primary outcome measure is the average net amount of weight change per group at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include the number of interactions with the virtual coach, degree of quality of life, and degree of satisfaction with the virtual coach.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and does not include any external sources or information.

The study compares the clinical effectiveness of Calcium Silicate-based Sealer and Epoxy Resin-based Sealer in single-visit Root Canal Treatment. The study includes 100 participants with irreversible pulpitis who are randomly assigned to either the active comparator (Epoxy Resin-based Sealer) or the active comparator (Calcium Silicate-based Sealer) group. The primary outcome measures are change in pain intensity over time, change in pain relief over time, and change in treatment outcome evaluation over time. The study is designed as a parallel-assignment randomized controlled trial with single-blinded masking. The study duration is 7 days, and the follow-up period is 1 week, 3 months, and 6 months after treatment.

This study aims to evaluate the immunogenicity difference between two different domestically produced bivalent HPV vaccines and imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years. The study will enroll 3,000 participants and collect blood samples at baseline, 12 months, and 36 months after vaccination. The primary outcome measures are the neutralization antibody GMT and antibody positivity testing for HPV types 16 and 18 at baseline, 12 months, and 36 months after vaccination.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

The study aims to evaluate the feasibility of integrating homeopathic approach in a comprehensive cancer center. The study will assess the reasons why patients seek this supportive approach, patient acceptance of this approach, and retrospective subjective information from the patients through validated quality of life questionnaires.

The study will evaluate three main ingredients:

1. Obtaining main concerns of patients that agree to utilize this method
2. Patient acceptance of this supportive approach that will be reflected in obtaining and self-administering the remedies as prescribed.
3. Obtaining retrospective subjective information from the patients through validated quality of life questionnaires.

The study will be conducted in patients treated at the Division of Oncology in Rambam Health Campus. The inclusion criteria are patients aged 18 years or older, able to read, write, and understand the Hebrew language, and treated at the Division of Oncology in Rambam Health Campus. The exclusion criteria are patients with inability to understand the intent of the study and follow the instructions, diagnosis of active psychosis, altered mental state or severe cognitive impairment, frailty, ECOG worse than 2, or other unstable medical conditions.

The study will be conducted in three arms: feasibility of a supportive approach, evaluating reasons for patients to use the approach, and evaluating the feasibility of a supportive approach. The primary outcome measures will be feasibility of a supportive approach, quality of life-level of distress, and quality of life-Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status.

The study will be conducted over a period of 6-12 weeks.

The study is designed to evaluate the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis on central venous catheter and midline. The study will enroll adult patients hospitalized at the CHM or CHUA, with a central venous device or a midline, and having catheter-related bacteremia. The primary outcome measure is the evaluation of duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis on central venous catheter and midline, measured by time from the day of diagnosis of septic thrombophlebitis to the day of disappearance of signs of thrombophlebitis on Doppler ultrasound. The study is a non-randomized parallel assignment design with open label, and the arms are presence of thrombosis and no intervention. The study will be conducted over a period of 90 days.

The OLYMPIA-5 clinical trial is a phase 3, open-label, randomized study comparing the efficacy and safety of odronextamab plus lenalidomide versus rituximab plus lenalidomide in participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma or marginal zone lymphoma. The study aims to assess the incidence of dose-limiting toxicities, treatment-emergent adverse events, and progression-free survival as the primary outcomes. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of anti-odronextamab antibodies, odronextamab concentrations, and patient-reported outcomes. The study is conducted at multiple sites in Canada and the United States, and is expected to be completed in 2025.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled clinical trial to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Proliverenol supplementation in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The study will enroll 80 participants and will be conducted over 12 weeks. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four treatment groups: Proliverenol 500 mg twice daily, Proliverenol 500 mg once daily, Proliverenol 500 mg twice daily (placebo), or placebo daily. The primary outcome measures will be changes in serum ALT and AST levels from baseline to week 4, 8, and 12 of study treatment. Secondary outcome measures will include USG examination for Controlled Attenuated Parameter (CAP) and Transient elastography (TE), as well as Aspartate transaminase (AST) to alanine transaminase (ALT) ratio. The study will assess the safety and efficacy of Proliverenol supplementation in patients with NAFLD.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of ozone application in treating periodontitis patients. The study will assess the primary outcome measures of probing pocket depth, plaque index, and gingival index at baseline, 3rd month, and 1st month after treatment. Additionally, the study will measure the proportions of bacterial species in subgingival plaque, inflammatory parameter levels in gingival crevicular fluid, and bleeding on probing. The study will enroll 30 participants and will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This study aims to compare the expression of CD44, PCNA, and E-cadherin in pterygium tissue between patients with primary and recurrent pterygia. The study will enroll 60 patients with pterygium and collect conjunctival samples from 30 patients to form the control group. The investigators will use immunohistochemistry to evaluate the expression of these proteins in pterygium tissue. The study will measure the primary outcome measures of immunohistochemistry, including the expression of CD44, PCNA, and E-cadherin in pterygium tissue. The study will be conducted over a period of up to three weeks after pterygium surgery.

This study aims to identify the underlying mechanisms and consequences of the loss of nasal T cells in older adults. The study will enroll 18-80 year old individuals, including young adults, vital elderly, and frail elderly. Participants will undergo sampling at baseline and after 3 months, and the study will measure the frequency of nasal CD8+ T cells, as well as the phenotype, functionality, transcriptomic cluster composition, clonality, stability, and comparison of nasal and peripheral immune cell populations. Additionally, the study will assess the concentration of nasal and systemic cytokines, metabolites, respiratory tract microbiota profiles, and the presence of asymptomatic viral infections. The study will also investigate the effect of sex on aging effects of nasal and blood immune populations, and the frequencies of antigen-specific T cells in nose and blood post infection.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

This study aims to evaluate the predictive value of platelets to lymphocytes ratio and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio in cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. The study will enroll cirrhotic patients with ascites and untreated spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, and will measure the platelets to lymphocytes ratio and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio in ascetic fluid. The study will determine whether these ratios can predict response to treatment in cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.

The study will be conducted in three arms: cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, normal individuals, and patient liver cirrhosis (child B,C). The primary outcome measure will be the platelets to lymphocytes ratio and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio as predictors of response to treatment in cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. The study will be conducted from 19/4/2023 to 30/4/2024.

The study aims to evaluate the added diagnostic value of point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) in acute dyspnea. The study will include adult patients presenting to the emergency department with dyspnea and will assess the diagnostic accuracy of POCUS performed by emergency medicine physicians (specialists and residents) compared to routine assessment. The study will also evaluate the clinical bedside tests available in the ED, including ecg, blood gas results, and chest imaging. The primary outcome measures will be the discharge diagnosis and the sensitivity, specificity, negative and positive predictive values of the diagnostic accuracy before and after adding POCUS.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of respiratory training and relaxation techniques in improving the success of advanced-technology-based cardiac dose reduction during radiotherapy in deep inspiration breath hold (DIBH) for left breast cancer patients. The study will randomize patients into either the experimental arm (receiving the intervention) or the standard arm (receiving standard care). The primary outcome measure is the change in maximum dose to the heart (Dmax) in DIBH under adjuvant radiotherapy of left-sided breast cancer. Secondary outcome measures include quality of life, heart Dmean, LAD Dmean, LAD Dmax, left ventricle (LV) Dmean, clinic workflow metrics, patient satisfaction, and radiation dose in organs at risk. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention in improving patients' compliance and active participation under radiotherapy.

The study is a Phase IB clinical trial that aims to determine the safety and tolerability of canakinumab and tislelizumab in combination with nab-paclitaxel and gemcitabine in the neo-adjuvant treatment of patients with pancreatic cancer. The study will enroll 10 patients and will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida. The primary outcome measures will be the number of dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs) and the number of patients who proceeded to surgical resection. Secondary outcome measures will include overall response rate (ORR), R0 resection rate (R0), progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), number of delays in outcome of surgery that is attributed to study drug, and number of changes in outcome of surgery that is attributed to study drug.

The study aims to develop and test a digital tool called Connected for Wellness, which will be implemented in school-based and primary care services to improve mental health services access for youth. The study will use a stepped wedge design, where each site will start with a control period, followed by an implementation period, and then cross over to the experimental arm. The primary outcome measures will be the proportion of youth referred to mental health services who initiate care, and the proportion of youth completing a mental health screening who are referred to care.

Keywords: mental health, youth, digital tool, navigation, implementation, stepped wedge design.

This study is a double-blinded prospective randomized comparative clinical trial to compare and evaluate the effectiveness of intra-myometrial oxytocin injection and intra-myometrial tranexamic acid injection in reducing the risk of postpartum bleeding after cesarean delivery in primigravida at term. The study will be conducted in the kasr Al-Ainy hospital, Maternity hospital, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt, during October 2021 to October 2022. After the Ethical Research Committee approval on study protocol, fifty primigravida women at term pregnancy, undergoing elective cesarean delivery will be divided and allocated randomly into two groups after fulfillment eligibility criteria. Fifty women will be included in this clinical study at admission to the labor ward. Written informed permission will be acquired following advising about this study and potential implications. A history in details and clinical examination for all patients to rule out general health problems. Vaginal and Abdominal examinations will be done. Routine preoperative investigations and obstetric ultrasound examinations will be done for all women to ensure that all inclusion criteria were present. The computer will be used for randomization to allocate the patients into two equal groups. Randomization cards will be produced, sealed and stored; sequentially black wrappers will be numbered. The hospital pharmacy is producing packages, and physicians and nurses were unaware of their contents. For the entire length of the trial, all study personnel and participants are blinded to therapy. A senior registrar will execute a cesarean section before the commencement of research, which performs at least 300 cesarean sections. All cesarean section will be operated via spinal anesthesia; the abdomen will be entered through the Pfannenstiel incision. The sealed envelope is carried to the operating room and transferred without informing the researcher or the patients about their contents. The anesthesiologist is administering the medication (Oxytocin or tranexamic acid). After fetal birth and before placental delivery, patients assigned to the oxytocin group (n = 25): 5 I.U of oxytocin (syntocinone

The Innovation for Small-scale Experiments: ReceptIVFity Test is a clinical trial that investigates the effectiveness of the ReceptIVFity test in predicting the chances of successful pregnancy in women undergoing IVF or IVF/ICSI treatment. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with two arms: a shared-decision-making group and a physician decision group. Participants in the shared-decision-making group will use the ReceptIVFity test to determine their chances of successful pregnancy, while those in the physician decision group will have their treatment postponed until a favorable ReceptIVFity microbiome profile is achieved. The primary outcome measures of the study include the rate of successful pregnancy, the number of successful IVF or IVF/ICSI cycles, and the total number of IVF or IVF/ICSI treatment cycles per patient. Secondary outcome measures include patient satisfaction scores, total costs of treatments, and pregnancy rates in women with non-European origin. The study will run for 3 years and will enroll women aged 18-42 years who are undergoing IVF or IVF/ICSI treatment. Keywords related to the study include vaginal microbiome, IVF, IVF/ICSI, and pregnancy.

The study aims to determine the lipid-lowering effect of fenugreek seed tea in patients with hyperlipidemia without diabetes over an 8-week intervention period. The study will measure the changes in plasma microRNAs as non-invasive therapeutic biomarkers of hyperlipidemia. The study will randomize 114 participants into two groups: fenugreek seed tea and black tea. The primary outcome measure is the between-group difference in mean change in serum triglycerides. Secondary outcome measures include total-cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, non-HDL-cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, plasma apolipoprotein B, and microRNAs.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial to assess the role of pioglitazone in vascular transcriptional remodeling in individuals undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). 20 male participants, aged 40-70 years, with a BMI of 20-34.9kg/m2, non-diabetic or diabetic with disease duration < 10 years, Hba1c < 8%, non-user of NPH insulin, ejection fraction > 40%, glomerular filtration rate > 45 mL/min, and no history of cardiovascular disease will be enrolled. Participants will be randomized to receive either pioglitazone hydrochloride 45mg/day for 5 days prior to CABG or a placebo. The primary outcome measures will be changes in HDL-S1P content, SPHK1 expression in the internal thoracic artery, S1PR1 expression in the saphenous vein, and SPHK1 expression in the aortic artery and atrial appendage. The study aims to investigate the potential of pioglitazone in preventing myocardial reperfusion injury.

The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of using different strips (celluloid matrix strips, fruit leather, and chewing gum strips) on reducing the most common error in panoramic imaging, which is the palatoglossal air space shadow error. The study included 270 patients who underwent panoramic imaging, and the results showed that the use of celluloid matrix strips and fruit leather significantly reduced the palatoglossal air space shadow error compared to the control group. The study concluded that using different strips can be an effective method for reducing this error and improving the quality of panoramic imaging.

This clinical trial aims to compare the acute effect of kinesio taping and extracorporeal shock wave therapy on pain severity and lower extremity functionality in patients with plantar fasciitis. The study will enroll 30 patients and will be divided into three groups: ESWT, ESWT and KT, and placebo/sham. The primary outcome measures will be visual analogue scale (VAS) and lower extremity functional scale (LEFS). The study will be conducted over one week, with the first examination of the physical therapy and rehabilitation specialist physician in the placebo/sham group. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of kinesio taping and extracorporeal shock wave therapy on plantar fasciitis patients in terms of pain severity and lower extremity functionality.

The study aims to establish a couple intervention program for adults with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The program includes behavioral therapy, and the primary outcome measures are the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS), Autism Spectrum Quotient (AQ), Empathy Quotient (EI), Social Responsiveness Scale (SRS), and Quality of socialization questionnaire (QSQ). The study is open-label, and the participants are required to be at least 20 years old and no older than 60 years, and able to communicate in Chinese. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

The study is a multicenter, randomized, open-label, blinded endpoint, parallel-controlled trial to assess the efficacy and safety of tirofiban in patients with acute branch atheromatous disease (BAD)-related stroke. The study will enroll 516 patients and randomize them to either the tirofiban group or the standard antiplatelet therapy group. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of excellent functional outcome at 90 days, and the primary safety outcome is the proportion of major bleeding within 90 days. Secondary outcome measures include early neurological deterioration, NIHSS score, Barthel index score, ischemic stroke, stroke, TIA, composite endpoint, proportion of major bleeding, serious adverse events, adverse events, all-cause death, changes in hemoglobin, changes in the count of red blood cell, changes in the count of white blood cell, changes in alanine transaminase, changes in aspartate aminotransferase, changes in direct bilirubin, changes in indirect bilirubin, changes in the concentration of Na, changes in the concentration of K, changes in the concentration of creatinine, changes in the concentration of albumin, changes in urinary occult blood, and changes in fecal occult blood. The study will be conducted at multiple centers in China.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, multicenter clinical trial. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of personalized pacing in improving quality of life in patients with sinus node dysfunction. The study will enroll 100 patients, randomly assigned to either the pacemaker lower rate (PLR) group or the control group. The primary outcome measure is the SF-36 questionnaire score, assessed within three months after the surgery. Secondary outcome measures include LVEF, 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure, and the correlation of elevated blood pressure and bradycardia.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and may not be comprehensive or accurate if the document contains errors or omissions.

This study aims to compare the effectiveness of remote diagnosis and treatment on 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure rhythm of OSA patients between the telemedicine group and the outpatient group. The study will also compare the compliance of APAP treatment, sleep apnea related dysfunction, sleepiness symptom, blood lipids and fasting blood glucose test, and cost-effectiveness between the two groups.

The study aims to investigate the impact of communication between nursing staff and patients on the analgesic response following caesarean section. The study will be conducted in the maternity ward at Carmel Hospital and will include 80 patients who are about to undergo an elective caesarean section under spinal anesthesia. The participants will be randomly assigned to either an enhanced communication group or a normal communication group. The primary outcome measure will be the change in pain intensity one hour after the administration of analgesics.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This clinical trial aims to identify novel biomarkers for lung cancer screening beyond what is achieved with conventional risk prediction models and low-dose CT scanning. The study will measure the sensitivity and specificity of these biomarkers over a 5-year period.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of telepharmacy on clinical outcomes of patients with arterial hypertension. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: telepharmacy and in-person pharmaceutical care. The primary outcome measures include the rate of patients reaching blood pressure targets, adherence to treatment, and patient satisfaction. The study also measures the level of clinical significance of interventions. The study population consists of elderly patients admitted to the service with a diagnosis of systemic arterial hypertension. The study excludes patients who are unable to use their cell phones due to cognitive impairments or are considered unable of using a telephone. The study plan includes a 3-month follow-up period.

The ICU LIBERATION Study is an international multicenter study that aims to investigate the current epidemiology and treatment strategy given to patients with ARDS after the two-year pandemic of the novel coronavirus, and to evaluate how the implementation of evidence-based ICU care is associated with patient outcomes. The study will include patients who are on an invasive or non-invasive ventilator within 24 hours of ICU admission and will measure primary outcome measures such as mortality, compliance of lung protective ventilation, implementation rate of the ABCDEF bundle, and incidence of Post Intensive Care Syndrome at the time of hospital discharge and 3 months after discharge.

The study will have a significant impact on improving outcomes for patients with ARDS worldwide by providing detailed information on the current ICU care given to patients with ARDS and identifying the content of ICU care that can maximize improvement in outcomes. The results of this study will serve as basement data for future interventional research and will contribute to the development of ICU care guidelines.

The study is designed to investigate the relationship between gut microbiota and prostate cancer. The study will enroll 100 men, aged 18-80 years, with either benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either prostate hyperplasia medication or prostate cancer medication. The study will measure the gut microbiota signature before and after treatment, as well as other metabolic characteristics in the gut and systemic circulation. The study aims to determine whether changes in gut microbiota are associated with prostate cancer risk and to identify potential biomarkers for prostate cancer diagnosis.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to investigate the metabolic changes in gliomas and their correlation with IDH mutational status and 1p19q codeletion using MRS. The study will also evaluate the changes in diffusion MRI metrics and amide proton transfer signal during an anti-tumor treatment. The study is designed as a single group assignment with an open label and will include participants with glioma. The primary outcome measures are metabolite concentrations by MRS, diffusion MRI metrics, and metabolic changes during an anti-tumor treatment. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year.

This study aims to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of hydroxyurea and thalidomide in beta-thalassemia patients. The study will assess the response to treatment, laboratory levels, liver and spleen size, and XmnI polymorphism among patients who completed 1-3 years of combination therapy.

Eligibility Criteria:
Patients with clinical and genetic diagnoses of beta-thalassemia major and intermedia, who showed partial response or a decline in response to hydroxyurea, are eligible for the study. Exclusion criteria include married patients, patients with comorbidities such as liver, cerebrovascular, cardiovascular, or kidney diseases, patients allergic to the drug ingredients, patients with mental disorders, and patients who are enrolled in other clinical trials.

The study design is single group assignment with no masking (open label). The primary outcome measures include the frequency of good responders, responders, and non-responders at different time intervals, as well as the mean changes in hemoglobin, platelets, leukocytes, urea, creatinine, and ferritin level from baseline. Secondary outcome measures include the comparison of XmnI polymorphism with outcome among patients who completed 1-3 years of combination therapy.

The study will evaluate the safety of the drug based on parameters such as creatinine, urea, liver function (SGPT), absolute neutrophil counts, platelets, and liver and spleen size. The study will also assess the efficacy of the combination therapy in improving the quality of life of beta-thalassemia patients.

The study aims to determine the role/position of diagnostic imaging in the patient journey for a patient with active or healed ulceration. The study will determine the current practice in primary care for venous leg ulcer management and availability of services to onward referral, and the current practice for diagnosis and management of suspected venous leg ulcers in vascular scientist departments across the UK. The study will use a questionnaire based design, with both primary care practitioners and vascular scientists participating. The study will measure the primary outcomes of current practice in primary care and vascular scientist departments, and the cost-effectiveness of implementing the findings in both primary and secondary care settings.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Virtual Reality in enhancing prospective thinking in early recovery from substance use disorders. The study will randomly assign participants to either an experimental group or a placebo comparator group. The experimental group will receive the Virtual Reality Avatar experience, while the placebo comparator group will receive the Virtual Reality Park experience. The primary outcome measures will include reduced use of drug using days, increased length of abstinence, increased abstinence, future self-identification, future time perspective, and delayed reward preference. The study will be conducted over a period of 30 days, with follow-up visits at 6 months.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to evaluate the stability of short implants versus standard Blx implants with internal sinus floor elevation in the posterior maxilla through a randomized controlled clinical trial. The study will assess the primary outcome measures of crestal bone level at 1 year post-surgery.

Inclusion criteria are single edentulous site at the maxillary posterior region, available bone height below the maxillary sinus of 7-8 mm, patients aged 20 years or older, bucco-palatal bone width of ≥6 mm, adequate interarch space, and bounded, single tooth loss. Exclusion criteria are local pathological defects related to the area of interest, habits that may jeopardize the implant longevity and affect the results of the study, inadequate inter-arch space for implant prosthetic part, smoking, and pregnancy.

The study is designed as a randomized controlled clinical trial with two arms: short implants and standard Blx implants with internal sinus floor elevation. The primary outcome measure is the crestal bone level at 1 year post-surgery.

This is a dose escalation study to determine the maximum tolerated dose of Wharton's jelly mesenchymal stromal cells (WJ-MSCs) for the prevention of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) in patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) with a haploidentical donor. The study will enroll 6 patients in each of 3 dose levels, and the maximum tolerated dose will be defined as the highest dose where no more than 1 patient experiences dose-limiting toxicity. The study will measure the incidence of acute and chronic GVHD, toxicity-related mortality, relapse incidence, overall survival, GVHD-free survival, and poor graft function at 12 months after transplantation.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifying details of the participants.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of eCARTv5, a machine learning-based clinical decision support tool, in identifying high-risk patients in medical-surgical units. The tool will be used by providers to predict clinical deterioration and standardize care based on a real-time, quantitative assessment of patient risk. The study will measure the impact of eCARTv5 on hospital mortality, total hospital length of stay, ICU-free days, and ventilator-free days for elevated risk patients. The study will be conducted in multiple hospitals, with one group using eCARTv5 and the other serving as a control group. The study will be conducted over 12 months, and the primary outcome measures will be tracked during this time frame.

The African-American Social Support Effectiveness Treatment-Partners alleviating Perinatal Depression (ASSET-PPD) is a novel intervention designed to supplement and support the clinical objectives of the mother's depression care without requiring the mother's direct involvement. The intervention targets fathers' support of the mothers' mental health treatment and their active engagement in the family to reduce maternal stress. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of ASSET-PPD in reducing maternal depression symptoms and improving parent-infant interactions. The study will enroll 50 parent dyads, with 25 in the experimental group receiving the ASSET-PPD intervention and 25 in the control group without additional treatment. The study will measure primary outcomes including maternal depression symptoms and secondary outcomes such as breastfeeding, infant affect and mood regulation, and parent-infant interaction quality. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial design with single-masking.

The study is evaluating the effectiveness of a proactive identification and digital mental health intervention approach to address unmet psychosocial needs of individuals living with cancer. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: Treatment as Usual and Moodivate. Participants in the Moodivate arm will receive a mobile app for tracking daily activities, recording daily mood, and identifying new activities to complete that may help improve mood. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants who accrue to the study.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of new algorithms in detecting insulin pump malfunctions in individuals with type 1 diabetes. The study consists of three phases: data collection, induction of hyperglycemia, and retrospective data analysis. The primary outcome measure is the sensitivity of the tested methods in detecting insulin suspension, simulating a pump malfunction. Secondary outcome measures include the number of false alarms per day. The study is open-label, and participants are required to have a minimum of one year since their diagnosis of type 1 diabetes, be between 18 and 70 years old, and have a BMI less than 30 kg/m². Exclusion criteria include pregnancy or breastfeeding, hematocrit less than 36% in females and less than 38% in males, and uncontrolled hypertension.

This is an open-label, single-group study to evaluate the effect of Funk It Cycle Bites on PMS symptoms in female participants aged 18-40. Participants will consume 1 Cycle Bite per day for 4 months. The study will measure changes in symptoms of premenstrual syndrome, acne, pain levels, mood stability, and energy levels using survey-based assessments. The study will also evaluate participant enjoyment of the product.

This study aims to assess the effectiveness of PERSARC in reducing decisional conflict and increasing informed choices in high-grade extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma patients. The study will compare the use of PERSARC with standard care in terms of decisional conflict, informed choice, regret, worry, involvement in decision-making, patient reported outcome, utilities, healthcare cost, and absenteeism/presenteeism from paid work. The study will be conducted in 6 Dutch hospitals that are Soft-tissue sarcoma expertise centers, and will include 120 patients. The study will measure the outcomes at one week after treatment decision, and at 3, 6, and 12 months after treatment decision.

The study population will include patients with primary diagnosis of grade 2-3 extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma who do not have a treatment plan yet and will be treated with curative intent. The exclusion criteria include patients who are treated without curative intent, patients who need to be treated with chemotherapy or isolated limb perfusion, and patients with sarcoma subtypes not included in the PERSARC risk assessment tool.

The study will use a parallel cluster randomized design, where patients will be randomized between standard care and care with the use of PERSARC. The primary outcome measures will include decisional conflict scale, informed choice, decision regret scale, cancer worry scale, SDM-Q-9, PROMIS global health, PROMIS physical function, EQ-5D-5L, medical consumption questionnaire (iMCQ), productivity cost questionnaire (iPCQ), and absenteeism/presenteeism from paid work.

The study will be conducted in 6 Dutch hospitals that are Soft-tissue sarcoma expertise centers, and will include 120 patients. The study will measure the outcomes at one week after treatment decision, and at 3, 6, and 12 months after treatment decision.

In summary, the study aims to assess the effectiveness of PERSARC in reducing decisional conflict and increasing informed choices in high-grade extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma patients. The study will compare the use of PERSARC with standard care in terms of decisional conflict,

This is a cross-sectional epidemiological study that aimed to determine the prevalence of early childhood caries in children attending kindergartens in Jordan, and to evaluate the effectiveness of silver diamine fluoride as a caries control material. The study included 887 children with a mean age of 4.64 ± 1.56, and a subset of 159 children who were randomly assigned to receive either silver diamine fluoride or no intervention. The study found that the prevalence of early childhood caries in Jordanian children was high, and that silver diamine fluoride was effective in preventing new cavities and arresting existing ones.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study is a retrospective cohort and case-control design to evaluate the effectiveness of Pfizer's ABRYSVO vaccine against severe lower respiratory tract infections in older adults. The study will assess vaccine effectiveness against RSV-related hospitalizations, severe lower respiratory tract infections, and all-cause lower respiratory tract infections. The study will also estimate vaccine effectiveness against RSV-related death and describe the demographic, clinical, and laboratory characteristics of patients who received the vaccine and tested positive for RSV. The study will be conducted among Kaiser Permanente Southern California members who are eligible for vaccination per current recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP).

The OSsIRIS study is a post-market clinical follow-up investigation to confirm the performance and safety of the bone substitute b.Bone in extremities and pelvis. The study will enroll patients who are undergoing a standard of care bone grafting with b.Bone for the treatment of surgically created bone defects or bone defects resulting from traumatic injury in the extremities and pelvis. The primary outcome measure will be the radiographic healing/union after surgery, and secondary outcome measures will include clinical outcomes measured by patient-reported outcomes such as pain and quality of life, as well as the safety of b.Bone during the clinical investigation period.

The study aims to investigate the prognostic significance of acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness in patients with acute on chronic liver failure (ACLF). The study will evaluate the change in liver and splenic stiffness values at days 7 and 14 from baseline and its association with different etiologies of ACLF, severity of ACLF, grade of esophageal varices, pattern of organ failures, and changes in biochemical inflammatory markers. The study will also evaluate the change in liver and splenic stiffness with change in AARC-ACLF score and CLIF-C-ACLF score.

The study will be conducted as a prospective cohort study over a period of 1 year, and will include 200 patients of ACLF. The primary outcome measure will be the ability of acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness on day 7 to predict liver transplant free survival at 3 months. Secondary outcome measures will include the ability of acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness on day 14 to predict liver transplant free survival at 3 months, as well as the association of baseline and change in liver and splenic stiffness with various clinical and laboratory variables.

The study aims to determine the optimal depth of injection of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin for the treatment of glabellar lines. The study will compare the efficacy of onabotulinumtoxinA injected at a depth of 2mm versus 4mm in the glabellar complex. The primary outcome measures will be the Merz aesthetics scales used to assess the improvement of glabellar lines at 120 days post-injection. Secondary outcome measures will include the incidence of any adverse effects and a comparison of the efficacy of onabotulinumtoxinA injected at the depth of 2mm versus 4mm for the improvement of glabellar lines.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of music therapy on anxiety in breast cancer patients undergoing adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted at a single center. The study will be conducted over a period of 5 months. The primary outcome measure will be changes in anxiety before the first and third chemotherapy sessions, measured using the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-state score).

Please provide a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The Optimization of Conditioning Regimen for HLA Matched HSCT in SAA is a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study to evaluate different conditioning regimens for HLA matched donor transplantation in severe aplastic anemia. The study aims to determine the optimal conditioning regimen for HSCT in SAA patients. The study includes 2 arms: experimental and control. The experimental arm receives busulfan-based conditioning regimens, while the control arm receives fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and ATG-based conditioning regimens. The primary outcome measures are failure-free survival, mixed chimerism, regimen-related toxicity, myeloid and platelet engraftment, graft-versus-host disease, CMV and EBV reactivation, transplantation-related mortality, and overall survival. The study is conducted at multiple centers in France.

This is an open-label, single-arm treatment study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of switching from emicizumab to fitusiran prophylaxis in male participants with severe hemophilia A. The study will assess the incidence of adverse events, peak thrombin generation, peak antithrombin levels, emicizumab concentrations, and annualized bleeding rate during the fitusiran treatment period. The study will also evaluate participants' treatment satisfaction, pain intensity, physical functioning, physical activity, joint health, and preferences for fitusiran prophylaxis.

This study aims to translate and validate the Malay version of the painDETECT questionnaire (PDQ-M) for the diagnosis of neuropathic or nociceptive pain. The study will enroll participants with stable neuropathic or nociceptive pain and assess their PDQ-M scores. The study will also collect socio-demographic data from the participants.

This study aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a community-based complex exercise program for stroke patients. The study will assess the patients' functional ability, balance, and quality of life before and after the exercise program. The study will also measure the patients' muscle strength, flexibility, and coordination. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial design, with 120 participants divided into two groups: the experimental group, which will receive the exercise program, and the control group, which will receive no intervention. The study will be conducted for an average of 6 weeks, with follow-up evaluations at baseline and the end of the study.

The study's primary outcome measures will be the 6-minute walk test, modified Rankin Scale (mRS), Berg balance scale (BBS), and Functional ambulation category (FAC). Secondary outcome measures will include manual muscle testing (MMT), timed up and go (TUG), grip strength, body composition, international physical activity questionnaire (IPAQ), Euro-Quality of Life-5 Dimension (EQ-5D), getriatic depression scale (GDS), sit to stand, flexibility test, and coordination test.

The study will be conducted in a community setting, and the participants will be recruited from the community. The study will be conducted by a team of researchers, including a principal investigator, co-investigators, research coordinator, and data analyst. The study will be conducted in accordance with the ethical guidelines for clinical trials and will be approved by the institutional review board.

The study's results will be analyzed using statistical methods, and the findings will be presented in a comprehensive report. The study's findings will contribute to the existing literature on exercise programs for stroke patients and will provide valuable insights into the safety and effectiveness of community-based complex exercise programs for this population.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-finding study to evaluate the safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of ABBV-552 in participants with mild Alzheimer's disease (AD). The study will enroll participants aged 50-90 years with a Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score of 20-26 and a Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) global score of 0.5 or 1.0, with a CDR memory score of 0.5 or higher, and at least 1 CDR functional domain (community affairs, home and hobbies, or personal care) score of 0.5 or higher at Screening Visit 1. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four arms: ABBV-552 dose A, B, or C, or placebo for ABBV-552. The study will measure the change in the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog 14) score from baseline to Week 12. The primary outcome measure is the change in the ADAS-Cog 14 score.

This is an observational study that aims to evaluate the causes, complications, and outcomes of severe acute liver disease (ALD) cases admitted to intensive care units (ICUs). The study will assess liver function, kidney function, fluid overload, and mortality rates in patients with ALD. The study will also determine the most likely causes of disease in patients of different ages and assess the effectiveness of treatment.

Inclusion criteria: Patients with reduced conscious state, jaundice with abnormal liver function tests, coagulopathy, multiorgan failure, and acute liver failure (ALF) or acute on chronic liver disease (ACLF) will be included in the study. Exclusion criteria: Patients with known cardiac cirrhosis, pre-existing renal disease, and those who are not eligible for the study will be excluded.

The study will use various tools to assess the patients' condition, including thorough history taking, clinical examination, vital signs, laboratory investigations, imaging, and special scores. The primary outcome measures will be the assessment of liver function, kidney function, fluid overload, and mortality rates in patients with ALD. The secondary outcome measures will be the assessment of morbidity rates in patients with ALD.

The study will be conducted in ICUs in hospitals and will include patients of different ages. The study will not accept healthy volunteers and will only include patients who meet the inclusion criteria. The study plan will involve collecting data on patients' condition at admission, during treatment, and after treatment. The study will also involve measuring various outcome measures, including liver function, kidney function, fluid overload, and mortality rates.

Overall, this study aims to provide valuable insights into the causes, complications, and outcomes of severe ALD cases admitted to ICUs, which can help healthcare providers improve treatment strategies and patient outcomes.

The study aims to determine the predictive effects of impulsivity and coping skills on quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder. The study will be conducted in Adıyaman Besni State Hospital between October 2023-February 2024. The sample will consist of 54 individuals who will be directed to the researcher by the outpatient clinic doctor. The data will be collected by applying the Personal Information Form, Brief Quality of Life in Bipolar Disorder Scale Short Form, Barratt Impulsivity Scale -11 Short Form and Coping Attitudes Assessment Scale prepared by the researchers. The study will evaluate the effect of impulsivity level on quality of life in bipolar disorder patients and the effect of coping skill level on quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder.

The study aims to compare the clinical performance of two different single-color universal composite resin materials (OMNICHROMA and Zenchroma) in the restoration of non-carious cervical lesions over a period of 2 years, using modified USPHS and FDI criteria. The study is a double-blind, prospective, randomized controlled trial with 3 arms: OMNICHROMA, Zenchroma, and Filtek Z250 (control group). The primary outcome measures are retention, marginal discoloration, marginal adaptation, secondary caries, and postoperative sensitivity, scored according to Alpha (best), Bravo (acceptable), and Charlie (unacceptable) criteria. Secondary outcome measures include clinical performance of restorations according to WDO criteria. The study aims to evaluate the clinical performance of these two universal composites in comparison to the control group.

The study aims to evaluate the effect of neuromuscular reversal agents on the time for neurological assessment after endotracheal intubation in critically ill patients. The study will randomly assign participants to one of three groups: Sugammadex, Neostigmine, or Control. The primary outcome measure is the time from administration of neuromuscular blocker to the first available neurological assessment, measured up to 48 hours. Secondary outcome measures include time from administration of neuromuscular blocker to first available spontaneous eye opening, changes in Patient State index (PSi) values, changes in regional cerebral oxygen saturation (O3) values, time from intubation to extubation, total length of hospital stay, total length of intensive care unit (ICU) stay, in-ICU mortality, and in-hospital mortality.

The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, two-arm, interventional clinical trial to evaluate the effectiveness of a behavioral intervention in promoting primary prevention and uterine preservation in premenopausal women with obesity and endometrial hyperplasia. The study will enroll 120 participants and will be conducted over a period of 4 years. The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with atypia-free biopsy with uterine preservation, and secondary outcome measures include time to resolution of hyperplasia, change in weight, change in Cancer Worry Impact Events Scale (CWIES), and atypia-free survival or endometrial cancer-free survival. The study will compare the effectiveness of a behavioral intervention (telemedicine behavioral weight loss intervention) versus enhanced usual care in achieving these outcomes.

The study aims to introduce a new method of safely performing cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis, known as the "Coconut technique." The technique involves identifying the confluence between the cystic duct and the body of the gallbladder and clipping the cystic duct. The study includes two females and one male with a mean age of 50 years who were diagnosed with stage II acute cholecystitis according to the Tokyo guidelines and operated on within three days of symptom onset. The primary outcome measure is the safety of the procedure, which will be evaluated two years after the operation. The study also includes key terms related to the study, such as acute cholecystitis, cholecystectomy, and cystic duct.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) protocol enriched with virtual reality (VR) in supporting physical rehabilitation after anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) operation. The study will randomly assign 60 athletes to one of four groups: CBT+VR, VR, CBT, or control. The primary outcome measures will be re-injury anxiety, rehabilitation adherence, self-efficacy, and kinesiophobia, which will be assessed through various scales at various time points throughout the study. The study will be conducted over an average of 1 year, and the results will be analyzed using multi-level statistics.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a new clinical decision support tool, PT-PENCIL, in improving the proportion of patients discharged home from the hospital. The tool is an electronic clinical decision support tool that uses a statistical model to predict which patients are likely to benefit from daily physical therapy to facilitate a discharge home. The study will also assess the reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the PT-PENCIL. The study will be conducted using a stepped-wedge design and will include patients admitted to the hospital for at least one overnight stay. The primary outcome measures will include the effectiveness of the evaluation on discharge home vs facility, reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the PT-PENCIL.

This is a single-arm, open-label, prospective, exploratory study to evaluate the feasibility and effect of Medical Tai Chi Exercise Healing in treating mCRC patients. The study will enroll 20 mCRC patients who will receive the 7-Form of Medical Tai Chi Exercise Healing for Colon cancer patients intervention. The primary outcome measures are adherence rates, and secondary outcome measures include the Brief Fatigue Inventory (BFI), Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), EORTC - Quality of Life, self-rating anxiety scale（SAS）, and self-rating depression scale（SDS）. The study will be conducted at the Cancer Hospital, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences and Peking Union Medical College.

The Survivorship ECHO Project is an educational intervention study that aims to assess the effectiveness of a platform in improving provider knowledge of cancer survivorship best practices. Participants are healthcare providers from The James Cancer Network who attend 6 sessions of the Survivorship ECHO educational intervention over 1 hour each, every 2 weeks for 12 weeks. The study measures the change in level of understanding in key survivorship knowledge areas, met and unmet needs, acceptability of the current structure, and barriers to accessing ECHO.

The study is designed as a single group assignment with no masking. Participants may optionally participate in a one-on-one interview to give feedback about the sessions over 30 minutes. The study is conducted over a period of 1 year, with data collection occurring at baseline and up to study completion.

The primary outcome measures include change in level of understanding in key survivorship knowledge areas, met and unmet needs, acceptability of the current structure, and barriers to accessing ECHO. These measures are assessed using a Likert survey, qualitative analysis, and other methods.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Survivorship ECHO platform in improving provider knowledge of cancer survivorship best practices and identifying potential barriers to its implementation. The findings of this study can inform the development of similar interventions and improve the quality of care provided to cancer survivors.

The study is a randomized, controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of post facilitation stretch and Maitland mobilization in improving range of motion in post-traumatic stiff elbow patients. The study includes 32 participants who are randomly assigned to either the experimental group (Maitland mobilization) or the active comparator group (post facilitation stretch). The study measures the primary outcome measures of numeric pain rating scale, ROM elbow (flexion), ROM elbow (extension), ROM forearm (supination), and ROM forearm (pronation) at 4 weeks. Additionally, the study measures the secondary outcome measures of disability through DASH questionnaire at 4 weeks. The study is conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a randomized, parallel-group, open-label, blinded end-point assessment study to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of Us2.ai (AI-enabled report) handheld echocardiogram in high-risk patients for heart failure diagnosis. The study will enroll 100 participants, aged 40 years or older, with at least two additional risk factors for heart failure. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental arm (AI-enabled echocardiogram) or the control arm (usual care). The primary endpoint is the diagnosis of heart failure within 6 months from randomization, and the secondary endpoint is the diagnosis of HFrEF within 6 months.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to investigate the effects of an intravenous fluid bolus on volume expanding effects and hemodynamic effects in healthy human volunteers during experimental hypovolemia compared with euvolemia. The study will use a randomized, crossover, factorial 2x2 design with two arms: no intervention and Ringer's acetate. The primary outcome measures will be cardiac stroke volume and intravascular volume, and secondary outcome measures will be middle cerebral artery blood flow velocity.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, it does not include any personal information or any information that could be used to identify the participants in the study.

The eMeistring study is an open naturalistic multicentre cost-effectiveness trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of guided internet-delivered psychological treatment for moderate depression, social anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. The study will enroll patients from four hospitals/locations and will measure the primary outcome measures of depression severity, social phobia, panic disorder symptoms, health related quality of life, work and social adjustment, anxiety severity, system usability, depression severity for social anxiety group and panic disorder group, cost of health care services, medication, work participation, and sickness absenteeism. The study will also collect data on secondary outcome measures and adverse events. The study will be conducted over a period of two years, with follow-up assessments at 14 weeks after treatment start, six months after treatment start, and after two years.

The study compares the effectiveness of two different methods of perioperative analgesia, TLIP block and ESP block, in patients undergoing lumbar spine fusion surgery. The study measures the effectiveness of these methods in terms of pain relief during and after surgery, as well as the incidence of side effects. The study includes 3 groups: a control group that received general anesthesia and no nerve block, a TLIP block group that received TLIP block under ultrasound with ropivacaine, and an ESP block group that received ESP block under ultrasound with ropivacaine. The study measures the effectiveness of these methods by assessing the blockade area, the amount of fentanyl used during surgery, the Analgesia Nociception Index (ANIm) scores, the total dose of morphine used in the first 12 and 24 hours after surgery, and the incidence of side effects.

This study aims to evaluate the accuracy of a novel pulse oximeter, MABOS, in patients of color. The study will compare the accuracy of MABOS with an FDA-approved pulse oximeter (Nonin PureSat) in measuring blood oxygen levels and epidermal melanin concentration. The study will also assess the safety and comfort of MABOS in patients of color. The study will enroll 12 participants, with 4 participants in each of the 3 racial groups (African descent, East Asian descent, and European descent). The study will be conducted over 90 minutes, with 10 minutes dedicated to device calibration and safety questionnaires, and 80 minutes dedicated to data collection. The primary outcome measures will be the Initial Device Safety Questionnaire and Initial Device Comfort Questionnaire, which will assess device safety and comfort, respectively. The secondary outcome measures will be epidermal melanin estimation and blood oxygen level estimation, which will assess the accuracy of MABOS in measuring these parameters.
