The study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of propofol and remifentanil mixed with fentanyl for controlled sedation and analgesia in fiber colonoscopy. The study will enroll 30 healthy volunteers and randomly assign them to either the experimental group (propofol and remifentanil) or the active comparator group (intravenous combined anesthesia). The primary outcome measures will be auditory evoked potential and the time from after surgery to OAA/S score reached 5 and Aldrete score reached 9.

The study will be conducted in a single center and will follow a parallel assignment, masked, randomized design. The sample size will be 30 participants, and the study duration will be approximately 2 hours.

The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of propofol and remifentanil mixed with fentanyl for controlled sedation and analgesia in fiber colonoscopy. The results of this study may provide valuable insights for clinicians and researchers in the field of gastrointestinal endoscopy.

The study aims to predict the chronicization of radiation-induced acute intestinal injury in patients with locally advanced rectal cancer undergoing NCRT and TME therapies. The study will enroll 200 patients and collect data on their expression levels of immune factors in pathological tissue after TME. The primary outcome measures will be the area under the curve of the prediction model in predicting chronicization of RAII, and the accuracy, precision, specificity, and sensitivity of the prediction model. The study will follow up the occurrence and progression of radiation-induced intestinal injury within 1 year after TME.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase I clinical trial to evaluate the safety and tolerability of Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) in people aged 18 years and above. The study will enroll 100 healthy participants and will be conducted in 3 phases: screening, vaccination, and follow-up. The primary outcome measures are safety endpoints, including adverse events, serious adverse events, and adverse events of special interest, observed within 12 months after vaccination. The secondary outcome measures are immunogenicity endpoints, including the geometric mean titer (GMT) of SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing antibody at 14 days after vaccination.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

The study is evaluating the safety and performance of the ENDOMATIC SEPIOLA Left Atrial Appendage (LAA) Closure Device in patients with atrial fibrillation. The device is implanted into the left atrial appendage to prevent blood clots from forming. The study is open-label, meaning that both the participants and the researchers know which group the participant is in. The primary outcome measures are device safety, and secondary outcome measures include device success and confirmation of functional LAA closure.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and highlights the key aspects of the trial, including the study design, inclusion and exclusion criteria, primary and secondary outcome measures, and terms related to the study.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of Motivational Interviewing in improving therapeutic alliance and adherence to treatment in patients with acute psychosis. The study will randomize participants into either the experimental group (Motivational Interviewing) or the active comparator group (supportive conversations). The primary outcome measures will be change from baseline in therapeutic alliance and treatment adherence, assessed through the Scale to Assess Therapeutic Relationship and the Brief Adherence Rating Scale, respectively. Secondary outcome measures will include change from baseline in symptom severity, motivation for psychotherapy, and self-efficacy, assessed through the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale, Questionnaire to measure the motivation for psychotherapy, and General Self-Efficacy Scale, respectively. The study will take place in the acute care unit of a psychiatric hospital in Zurich, Switzerland.

The study aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of BileCAD, a new method for detecting chromosomal instability in bile samples, in the early diagnosis of biliary tract carcinoma. The study will enroll patients with biliary tract carcinoma and non-cancer participants as controls, and analyze their bile samples using BileCAD. The primary outcome measures are the sensitivity and specificity of BileCAD analysis, and the secondary outcome measures include the consistency of BileCAD microbial analysis results with clinical microbial culture results, and the sensitivity of BileCAD to different types and locations of malignant tumors. The study will provide more reference for clinical diagnosis and treatment of biliary tract carcinoma.

The aim of this study is to evaluate the success of lumbar plexus block applied in lower extremity orthopedic surgeries using Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS). The study will measure the regional oxygen saturation (rso2) in the quadriceps femoris muscle using NIRS and assess the sensory block level, blood pressure values, and fingertip SO2 values at 40 minutes after the block.

The study will include 18-90 years old patients with femoral neck fracture, femoral shaft fracture, or hip replacement surgery who will undergo lumbar plexus block. The study will be designed as a single group assignment with no masking.

The primary outcome measures will be the rso2 values measured using NIRS, and the secondary outcome measures will be the sensory block level, blood pressure values, and fingertip SO2 values.

The study will be conducted at a single center and will be completed within 40 minutes after the block.

The study will enroll 100 participants and will be completed within 6 months.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects and will be approved by the institutional review board.

The results of the study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal and will be presented at a scientific meeting.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a digital platform in supporting the implementation of a psychosocial intervention for individuals with schizophrenia in primary care settings in India. The intervention, called COPSI, is a community-based program that includes task-shared delivery of evidence-based interventions, and the digital platform is designed to enhance the clinical effectiveness and integration of the intervention. The study will measure the effectiveness of the intervention using various outcome measures, including the Indian Disability Evaluation and Assessment Scale (IDEAS), Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS), Generalized Anxiety Disorder Assessment-7 (GAD-7), Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), and Brief Assessment of Cognition in Schizophrenia (BACS). The study will also assess the acceptability and feasibility of the digital platform and its potential to address the significant health disparity observed in India.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of occlusal splint therapy in patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) by measuring the change in cytokine levels in circulating blood and gingival crevicular fluid after treatment. The study will also assess the impact of occlusal splint therapy on pain intensity, pain-related disability, oral health-related quality of life, perceived stress levels, jaw function limitation, depressed mood, anxious feelings and behavior, and physical symptoms. The study will be conducted over a period of three months, with baseline, one-month, and three-month follow-ups.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a digital training program for addiction professionals in maximizing treatment admission and retention rates of opioid use disorder in affected families. The study will randomly assign participants to one of three arms: a digital tutorial only, digital tutorial plus training materials, or digital tutorial plus training materials plus feedback and coaching. The primary outcome measures will include CRAFT procedure fidelity, CRAFT knowledge, program implementation potential, and new treatment entry. The study will be conducted over a period of 10 weeks, with assessments at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to compare the regional distribution of 99mTc-DPD uptake in the left ventricle among patients with hereditary and wild-type cardiac transthyretin amyloidosis. The study will also assess the prevalence of right ventricular 99mTc-DPD accumulation and evaluate the presence and extent of 99mTc-DPD cardiac uptake among asymptomatic hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis variants carriers. The study will use 99mTc-DPD scintigraphy and echocardiography to evaluate the cardiac amyloidosis.

The study aims to investigate the early diagnosis, prognosis, and prevention of post-COVID syndrome in children during the pandemic of the new coronavirus infection COVID-19. The study will conduct laboratory tests, questionnaires, and physical examination on children aged 6 to 18 years to research the long-COVID-19 syndrome.

Inclusion Criteria: Children from 6 to 18 years old.

Exclusion Criteria: No.

Participation Criteria: Healthy volunteers are accepted.

Study Plan: The study is designed as a single-group assignment with an open-label intervention.

Primary Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measures include the number of participants with research of the long-COVID-19 syndrome.

Terms related to the study:

* Long COVID: The term used to describe the post-COVID syndrome in children.
* Device: The intervention used in the study to research the long-COVID-19 syndrome.
* Postcovid syndrome: A long-term symptoms lasting 12 or more weeks in children after COVID-19 infection.
* Laboratory tests: The tests used to diagnose and monitor the long-COVID-19 syndrome.
* Questionnaires: The questionnaires used to assess the symptoms and quality of life of children with postcovid syndrome.
* Physical examination: The physical examination used to assess the physical health of children with postcovid syndrome.

Note: The terms used in the study are related to the study's objective and design.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of treadmill perturbation training in preventing falls after total knee replacement surgery. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a training group or an education control group. The training group will undergo treadmill-based perturbation training, while the control group will receive educational materials related to fall prevention. The primary outcome measures will include post-training trunk angle and trunk angular velocity, as well as fall rate during the first year after surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include fall status immediately after completion of the training program. The study will recruit 378 participants and will be conducted over a period of one year.

This is a single-center, prospective, randomized, unblinded, controlled study conducted at the Heidelberg University Eye Clinic in Germany. The study compares the visual performance of the trifocal Hanita Lenses Intensity SL IOL with the trifocal Alcon Panoptix IOL in bilaterally implanted patients. The study will enroll approximately 58 patients and will measure the binocular distance-corrected visual acuity, defocus curve, contrast sensitivity, and patient satisfaction at 3 months post-second eye operation. The study aims to show non-inferiority in the primary outcome measure of binocular distance-corrected visual acuity and secondary outcome measures.

The study aims to investigate the haemodynamic effects of low-dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery. The study will retrospectively analyze vital signs data from patients who received low-dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery between 2017 and 2020 at the Princess Royal Hospital in Haywards Heath, UK. The primary outcome measures will be the cohort mean (SD) mean non-invasive blood pressure (MAP) taken at 2-minute intervals peri-operatively for each patient, and the cohort prevalence of hypotension defined as fall in systolic blood pressure (SBP) from baseline > 20%, fall in SBP from baseline > 30%, fall in mean arterial pressure (MAP) from baseline > 20%, fall in MAP from baseline > 30%, low SBP < 90 mmHg, low SBP < 100 mmHg, low MAP < 70 mmHg, and low MAP < 55 mmHg. The study will also measure the mean depth x duration area under curve product for cohort hypotension after low dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery, quantification of cohort systolic and mean arterial blood pressure changes before spinal administration, effective cohort duration of spinal anaesthesia, and correlations between individual hypotension, hypotension depth/duration product and outcomes (death at 30 days, length of stay in hospital).

The study aims to investigate the transmission and morbidity of COVID-19 in Malawi. The study will enroll up to 200 symptomatic individuals and their household contacts, with a total of 600 vaccinees. The study will measure the risk of asymptomatic infection among contacts who acquire infection, duration of neutralizing antibody responses against two viruses, change in frequencies of classical monocytes and markers of activation/inflammation with and without stimulation by toll like receptor (TLR) and retinoic acid-inducible gene I (RIG-I) like receptors (RLR) ligands, probably of infections in a household, duration of COVID-19 symptoms, reinfection rates, and breakthrough infection rates, change in activation status of monocytes and MDMs with and without stimulation with TLR and RLR agonists in vitro, change in cell activation markers among stimulated and unstimulated classical monocytes and MDMs, change in concentrations of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines produced by classic monocytes and MDMs, change in expression of 770 host response genes in classical monocytes and MDMs, antibody magnitude to 3 SARS-COV-2 antigens and 3 trimers, NAb responses measured against 3 viruses and through a surrogate assay (sENAB), Fc-gamma receptors (FcγR) -II/III binding functional antibody activities, duration of antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) responses, magnitude of dimeric Immunoglobulin A (dIgA), and frequencies of B (S-antigen specific and total) and plasma cells, and innate immunity parameters. The study will also assess the effect of malaria and intestinal parasitic diseases on the immune response to COVID-19.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of hot-cold application to the bladder after orthopedic surgery in preventing postoperative urinary retention. The study will be conducted as a single-blind randomized controlled trial, with 30 participants randomly assigned to either the experimental group (hot-cold application) or the control group (no intervention). The primary outcome measure will be the prevention of postoperative urinary retention by applying hot and cold to the bladder, measured at the first 6 hours of the postoperative period.

The study aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of a deep-learning integrated model established with relevant clinical factors and radiomic features based on high-concentration (370 mgI/ml) Iopromide-enhanced pancreatic CT images obtained within 14 days after the first onset of symptoms for quantitative prediction of the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis in 12 months follow-up period. The study will enroll 694 consecutive eligible patients with first episode of acute pancreatitis and follow them up for 12 months. The primary outcome measures are the sensitivity and specificity of the model established with relevant clinical factors and radiomic features to predict the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis within 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include the total number of subjects who developed the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis within 3, 6 and 12 months, the sensitivity and specificity of the deep-learning integrated model established with relevant clinical factors and radiomic features to quantitative predict overall recurrence of acute pancreatitis in 3 and 6 months follow-up period, the image quality of Iopromide-enhanced pancreatic CT images obtained within 14 days after onset of symptoms, the sensitivity and specificity of the model determined by radiomics features extracted from images with high quality scores (2-3 points), and the sensitivity and specificity of the radiomics features in predicting (the first) recurrence of different types and severities of acute pancreatitis at 3, 6 and 12 months.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, 12-month study to evaluate the effect of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) on polycythemia in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The study will enroll 100 patients aged 18-80 years old, randomly assigned to either the experimental group (CPAP treatment plus conventional pharmacological treatment) or the active comparator group (conventional pharmacological treatment). The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in hematocrit at 12 months, and secondary outcome measures include changes in hemoglobin, health-related quality of life (HRQoL) assessed by the Euroqol-5 (EQ-5D-5L), hypoxic burden, sleepiness assessed by the Epworth sleepiness scale (ESS), and the relationship between night time below SaO2 90% (T90) and oxygen desaturation index (ODI) and hematocrit.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, highlighting the main points and key findings. It does not include any personal information or identifying details of the participants.

The study compares the vaginal axis on MRI in patients undergoing alternative apical prolapse surgeries to sacrocolpopexy. The study evaluates the vaginal axis in patients undergoing laparoscopic lateral suspension, pectopexy, and sacrospinous ligament fixation procedures for the correction of apical prolapse. The study measures the vaginal distances, prolapse symptoms, urinary symptoms, postoperative de novo dyspareunia, sexual functions, quality of life measures, and patient global impression of improvement. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of the alternative apical prolapse surgeries on the vaginal axis and quality of life measures.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of teaching method with simulation in electronic fetal monitoring management. The study will randomly assign 68 participants to either an experimental group (receiving simulation training) or a control group (receiving theory training). The primary outcome measures will be information evaluation form, student satisfaction and self-confidence scale in learning, and self-efficacy scale in monitoring and management of electronic fetal monitoring. Secondary outcome measures will include simulation design scale and student satisfaction and self-confidence scale in learning. The study will be conducted over a period of 5 weeks, with data collection at the beginning and end of the study. The study will determine the effectiveness of simulation training in electronic fetal monitoring management and evaluate the participants' satisfaction and self-confidence levels.

This study aims to determine the outcome and predictors of mortality of patients on prolonged mechanical ventilation in critically ill patients. It is a retrospective cohort study conducted in Dessie Comprehensive Specialized Hospital from August 2023 to January 2024. Data will be collected through chart review and analyzed using SPSS version 22 software. The primary outcome measure is clinical outcomes of critically ill patients undergoing prolonged mechanical ventilation, which includes whether the patient survived or died at the time of discharge.

Predictors of Mortality:
The study will also investigate the predictors of mortality among patients on prolonged mechanical ventilation. Variables that are significant on bivariate analysis at a p-value less than 0.2 will be taken to multivariate analysis. In multivariate analysis, a p-value of less than 0.05 will be used as a cut-off point for the presence of association. The strength of the association will be measured by 95% confidence interval and odd ratio.

The study will enroll all charts of critically ill patients on prolonged mechanical ventilation in Dessie Comprehensive Specialized Hospital during the study period. Exclusion criteria include charts with incomplete information and missing values as well as those that are not available. The study will not accept healthy volunteers, and participation criteria will be based on the inclusion and exclusion criteria.

The study plan includes a detailed description of the study design, outcome measures, and predictors of mortality. The study will be conducted in a multicenter setting, and data will be collected through chart review. The study will be conducted from August 2023 to January 2024, and the primary outcome measure will be clinical outcomes of critically ill patients undergoing prolonged mechanical ventilation.

The Tailoring Bleeding Reduction Approaches in Patients Undergoing Percutaneous Coronary Interventions (TARGET) trial is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study comparing the efficacy and safety of two antiplatelet strategies in patients with coronary artery disease undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI): DAPT de-escalation and potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy. The study aims to determine which strategy is associated with reduced bleeding complications while preserving ischemic efficacy. The study includes 300 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the de-escalation or monotherapy group. The primary outcome measure is the area under the curve (AUC) of thrombus formation determined by Total Thrombus formation Analysis System (T-TAS) at 30 days.

This study aims to investigate the age-dependent effects of egg intake on HDL and immune profiles. The study will recruit healthy participants aged 18-70 years old and randomly assign them to one of three intervention groups: egg whites, egg yolks, or whole eggs. Participants will consume their assigned intervention for 4 weeks, followed by a 4-week washout period, and then switch to the next intervention. The study will measure the change in serum concentration of large HDL particles between diet periods and assess the impact of egg intake on immune profiles, including T-lymphocytes. The study will be conducted over 8 weeks and will include 120 participants.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a patient-driven augmented reality-based rehabilitation system, called MyoTrain AR, in improving upper limb amputee outcomes. The study will assess the system's ability to improve functional task training, motor imagery exercises, and overall quality of myoelectric control. The primary outcome measures include the time taken to complete the GaMA Cup Transfer Task, grasp duration, and the need for external support. Secondary outcome measures include the Assessment of Capacity for Myoelectric Controls (ACMC), GaMA Cup Transfer Task completion rate, and wrist activation. The study will enroll 20 participants with trans-radial unilateral limb loss, and the results will be compared to a control group receiving motor imagery exercises. The study duration is 35 days, and the data will be analyzed using Rasch analysis methods on the ACMC website.

The STIMULATE trial is a prospective, double-blinded, randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of gastric electric stimulation as a treatment for postoperative ileus following extensive surgery. The study will enroll patients who are planned for elective cytoreductive surgery with or without heated intraperitoneal chemotherapy due to colorectal or appendiceal cancer or peritoneal metastases or pseudomyxoma peritonei. The primary outcome measure is time from surgery till first stool, and secondary outcome measures include whole gut and regional transit times, length of hospital stay, medical and surgical complications, need for surgical or radiological interventions, re-hospitalization within 30 days, time till initiation of postoperative systemic adjuvant chemotherapy, and 90-day mortality. The study will be conducted at a single center in the Netherlands, and the results will be compared to a sham control group.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and may not include all details or nuances of the study.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of aromatherapy and music therapy on pain, anxiety, and vital parameters in patients hospitalized in the palliative care service. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with four groups: music group, aromatherapy group, aromatherapy and music group, and control group. The participants will be asked to complete data collection forms before and after the intervention, and vital parameters, pain, anxiety, and distress thermometer will be measured. The study will be conducted over three consecutive days, and the results will be analyzed to determine the effectiveness of the intervention.

The Somatosensation Device Trial is a non-randomized, crossover study evaluating the effectiveness of the Somatosensation Device in enhancing feedback in lower extremities for individuals with amputation or neuropathy. Participants will wear the device for 1 week, followed by a 2-week washout period, and then switch to the other arm (baseline). The study measures functional gait assessment, 10-meter walk test, mini-BESTest, activities specific balance confidence scale, and vestibular disorders activities of daily living scale. The primary outcome measures are functional gait assessment and 10-meter walk test.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This is a decentralized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the OtoBand in treating the symptoms of vertigo in a real-world setting. The study will enroll 36 participants in the moderate or worse (MoW) arm and 72 participants in the quality of life (QoL) arm. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental or sham device and will complete a series of assessments throughout the study, including the Dizziness Handicap Index, Vertigo Symptom Scale, and Global Impression of Symptoms and Change questionnaires. The study will measure the primary outcome measures of moderate or worse change in vertigo severity and quality of life change in scores, as well as secondary outcome measures such as device effectiveness.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, it is not a copy-paste of the original document.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled clinical trial to evaluate the effectiveness of the multistrain probiotic OMNi-BiOTiC® Active in preventing upper respiratory tract infections (URTIs) in older people. The study will enroll 300 participants aged 65 years or older, who will be randomly assigned to receive either the probiotic or placebo for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of URTIs, and secondary outcome measures include the duration of URTIs, changes in the concentration of leukocytes, neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils in serum, and changes in the concentration of immunoglobulin A (IgA) in serum. The study will be conducted at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) and will be completed by December 2023.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, it is not the original document.

This study compares the effectiveness of Gong's and Kaltenborn's mobilization techniques in treating Adhesive Capsulitis. Participants are randomly assigned to either Gong's or Kaltenborn's mobilization groups. Both groups receive routine physical therapy, including electrical muscle stimulation with heat therapy. The study measures the effectiveness of the mobilization techniques through the Shoulder Pain & Disability Index, Numeric Pain Rating Scale, and Universal Goniometer assessments at baseline, the end of 1.5 weeks, and the conclusion of the 3rd week. The study aims to contribute evidence-based insights into the relative effectiveness of Gong's and Kaltenborn's mobilization techniques for optimal patient outcomes in Adhesive Capsulitis.

The study is a phase 3, open-label, randomized controlled trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of disitamab vedotin in combination with pembrolizumab versus chemotherapy in previously untreated locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma that expresses HER2 (IHC 1+ and greater). The study will enroll approximately 400 participants and is expected to be completed in approximately 3 years. The primary outcome measures are progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS), with secondary outcome measures including objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (DOR), control rate (DCR), and safety and quality of life assessments.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicenter crossover trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of BK003, a chitin-glucan-based formulation, in patients with Crohn's disease in remission and having irritable bowel syndrome-like symptoms. The study will enroll 100 patients and will consist of a 2-3 week run-in period, followed by a 4-week treatment period with either BK003 or placebo, and a 2-3 week washout period. The primary outcome measure is the subject's global assessment of relief responder rate, and secondary outcome measures include individual symptoms, stool consistency and dyschesia, stool number, IBS-related quality of life, anxiety and depression, serum CRP and fecal calprotectine, and adverse events. The study will be conducted at the University Hospitals of Liège (Belgium) and Lille (France).

The study aims to develop a novel biomarker, cell-free virus-host chimera DNA (vh-DNA), for the response and prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) treated with radiotherapy. The biomarker will be used to evaluate treatment response and predict early recurrence/metastasis in HCC patients. The study will retrospectively analyze the vh-DNA specific PCR and Capture-NGS analysis from HBV-related HCC patients, and prospectively test the concordance of vh-DNA copies between serum and plasma samples. The serial changes of plasma vh-DNA copies of the same junction clone will be analyzed to determine their association with treatment response and overall survival. The study will also distinguish the clonality of recurrent HCC as the original or a de novo one for post-radiotherapy patterns of failure.

The study aimed to develop and test an online individual intervention program to help women with breast cancer make sense of their experiences. The program was based on the Meaning Making Model and principles of meaning therapy, and consisted of eight individual sessions. The study found that the program was effective in improving meaning in life, post-traumatic growth, and psychological flexibility, and reducing automatic meaning-making efforts. The results suggest that the online intervention program may be a useful tool for improving psychological health in women with breast cancer.

The study aims to assess the nutritional intake, nutritional status, and physical activity level of people who have undergone a major dysvascular lower limb amputation. The study will measure the primary outcome measures, including nutritional intake, diet quality, patient-generated subjective global assessment, muscle mass, muscle strength, body mass index, physical activity level, and secondary outcome measures such as mortality, wound healing, quality of life, K-level, and 6-minute walk test. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and will include 18 years or older participants who are undergoing or recently had a major dysvascular lower limb amputation. The study will be conducted over a period of 9 months, with data collection at hospital admission, 5 weeks post-LLA, and 6, 9, and 12 months post-LLA.

ЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉ

The study aimed to evaluate the effects of high-intensity interval training on physical fitness, skills, and tactical performance among college male ice hockey players in China. The study consisted of two groups: experimental and control. The experimental group underwent 12 weeks of high-intensity interval training, while the control group received traditional technical skill training. The study measured various outcome measures, including maximal oxygen uptake, endurance, power, agility, and passing and shooting performance. The results showed that high-intensity interval training significantly improved physical fitness, skills, and tactical performance among college male ice hockey players.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a Pain and Coordination Plan (PAC-plan) in reducing opioid use and improving quality of life in patients after accidental injuries. The study will use a prospective randomized controlled trial design with participants randomly assigned to either the intervention group (PAC-plan) or the control group (usual care). The primary outcome measures will be oral morphine equivalent (OMEQ) consumption at 6 and 52 weeks post-discharge, as well as secondary outcome measures such as pain, health-related quality of life, and injustice experience. The study will be conducted at the Division of Orthopedic Surgery, Oslo University Hospital, Norway.

This is a cluster randomized controlled cohort study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of guided antiplatelet therapy in preventing ischemic events in patients with unruptured intracranial aneurysms who undergo stent implantation. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted at a single center. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the control group (standard dual antiplatelet therapy) or the experimental group (guided antiplatelet regimen based on LTA testing). The primary outcome measure is ischemic events occurring within 30 days after stent implantation. The study will also assess the safety and efficacy of the guided antiplatelet regimen.

The study aims to investigate the relationship between bone mineral density, gross motor function, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy. The study will enroll 70 children with CP, aged 7-10 years, and will be divided into two groups based on their mobility level: ambulant and non-ambulant. The study will measure bone mineral density, gross motor function, and quality of life using DXA scans, GMFM, and CP QOL-Child questionnaire, respectively. The study will explore the correlation between these factors and provide valuable insights into the factors influencing the holistic well-being of children with CP.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifying details.

This study aims to investigate the effects of sulpiride on striatal BOLD signal during working memory gating, interaction of sulpiride, average reward rate, and evidence accumulation, interaction of sulpiride, average reward rate, and cognitive effort. The study will also assess the effects of sulpiride on various cognitive and emotional measures, including working memory, attention, decision-making, mood, and anxiety. The study will be conducted in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled design, with 40 healthy volunteers aged 18-45 years old. The study will consist of two intervention days, with participants receiving either sulpiride or placebo. The primary outcome measures will include working memory gating task reaction time, accuracy, and BOLD-response, as well as Simon task accuracy, reaction time, and perceptual decision-making task accuracy and reaction time. Secondary outcome measures will include eye-blink rate, operation span test, digit span test, Beck Depression Inventory, Barratt Impulsiveness Scale, Behavioural Inhibition Scale/Behavioural Activation Scale, State and Trait Anxiety Inventory, Utrechtse Burnout Schaal/Maslach Burnout Inventory, and Covid-19 Stress Scales.

Note: This summary is based on the provided information and may not be a comprehensive or definitive summary of the study.

The study aims to determine the prevalence of obesity and hypertension in a cohort of adolescents in Italy. The study will also perform genetic analyses to determine a link between specific polymorphisms and/or mutations of genes involved in the development of hypertension in adults and explore whether urine Na+/K+ excretion and urinary markers of inflammation and oxidative stress are linked to hypertension and cardiovascular risk in participants with selected genotypes. The study will enroll adolescents in high schools in the north, center, and south of Italy and will collect data on their eating habits, lifestyle, family history, and biological samples for genetic analysis. The study will measure urine Na+, K+, albumin, and creatinine, and will also measure proteins, cytokines, and advanced oxidation protein products. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years.

The EPigenetic Consequences in Children of Intravenous vs Volatile Anaesthesia for Surgery (EPIVA) is a randomized, clinical, feasibility trial that aims to explore whether general anaesthesia can cause epigenetic changes in children undergoing hypospadias surgery. The study will evaluate the feasibility of conducting a larger-scale trial looking at anaesthesia and surgery in relation to changes in markers on DNA (epigenetics) in children. The study will randomize participants to one of two anaesthetic maintenance approaches that are used routinely in clinical practice: intravenous or inhalational anaesthesia. The primary outcome measures will include the number of eligible patients screened, recruitment rate, retention rate, protocol compliance, and acceptability of trial process for the legal representatives of participants and clinical staff. The secondary outcome measures will include epigenetic changes in whole blood in those undergoing anaesthesia for hypospadias surgery, and epigenetic changes in whole blood comparing the two arms of the trial. The study will have a double-masked design and will be conducted at a single hospital.

The study aims to investigate whether a variety of additional markers can improve laboratory diagnostics in patients with hypothyroidism receiving L-T4 in whom TSH cannot be used as a reflection of thyroid hormone status (e.g. central hypothyroidism). The study will assess the usefulness of fT3, fT3/fT4 ratio, TT4, TT3, rT3, SHBG, acylcarnitines, and several amino acids as markers of thyroid hormone status in patients using L-T4. The study will be cross-sectional in design and will include 400 participants, including 100 patients with Hashimoto's hypothyroidism, 100 patients with hypothyroidism after thyroidectomy after thyroid carcinoma, 100 patients with central hypothyroidism, and 100 healthy controls. The study will measure TSH, fT4, fT3, fT3/fT4 ratio, TT4, TT3, rT3, SHBG, acylcarnitines, and several amino acids in all participants. The study will hypothesize that treated hypothyroid participants who are assumed euthyroid based on TSH will more often have a fT3 level or a fT3/fT4 ratio within the reference interval of 0,5-5,0 mU/L.

This study aims to implement palliative non-operative management (PNOM) in all Dutch hospitals for frail elderly patients with a limited life expectancy who sustain a hip fracture. The study will use mixed methods in the different phases of the study, including interviews with healthcare professionals and patient representatives, development of educational modules, and data collection from the national hip fracture audit. The primary outcome measure is the nonoperative treatment, which will be measured at 6 weeks.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

The study aims to generate proof-of-concept of using a physiological CTV for radiotherapy treatment planning in patients with IDH-wildtype glioblastoma. The study will extend the standard MRI session used for radiotherapy planning with advanced MRI techniques that assess oxygenation status and cell proliferation to generate a physiological CTV for each patient. The study will compare the physiological CTV with the standard CTV in terms of volume and location and assess the pattern-of-failure analysis. The study hypothesizes that the physiological CTV will be smaller in volume and have the same pattern-of-failure as the standard CTV. The study will enroll 10 patients and will be conducted at the Erasmus MC.

This study aims to assess the acceptance and effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in systemic sclerosis (SSc) patients treated by autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (AHSCT). The study will compare the incidence of asymptomatic or symptomatic COVID-19 infection between SSc patients who underwent AHSCT and those who did not. The study will also evaluate the proportion of SSc patients who refused vaccination, the cumulative incidence of symptomatic COVID-19 infection, the time of onset of first COVID-19 infection, the severity of symptomatic COVID-19, and the proportion of SSc patients with at least 1 grade≥3 adverse event after COVID-19 vaccination.

The study will be conducted at two centers in France, and will include 100 SSc patients who are actively followed at the centers. The study will measure the primary outcome of cumulative incidence of asymptomatic or symptomatic COVID-19 infection after AHSCT, and secondary outcomes will include the proportion of SSc patients who refused vaccination, the cumulative incidence of symptomatic COVID-19 infection, the time of onset of first COVID-19 infection, the severity of symptomatic COVID-19, and the proportion of SSc patients with at least 1 grade≥3 adverse event after COVID-19 vaccination.

The study will be conducted over a period of 18 months, and will involve the use of mRNA vaccine against SARS-CoV. The study will be conducted in accordance with the French GCP guidelines and the Declaration of Helsinki.

This study aims to investigate the effects of physical activity on physical fitness parameters, functional fitness age, and quality of life in women at risk of osteoporosis. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two groups: experimental and control. The experimental group will participate in the Otago Exercise Program, which includes strengthening exercises and moderate-intensity walking exercise, while the control group will not receive any program. The study will measure the primary outcome measures, such as lower extremity strength, upper extremity strength, aerobic endurance, upper extremity flexibility, agility, and quality of life, before and after the intervention. The study will also evaluate dynamic balance as a secondary outcome measure. The study is designed to prevent osteoporosis and improve the quality of life in women at risk of osteoporosis.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to assess the feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of a digital-based diet quality intervention for adolescents with overweight or obesity. The study will randomly assign participants to either a control group or an intervention group. The intervention group will receive a personalized goal, meal timing, nutrition skills, home food environment, and engagement strategies through text messaging. The primary outcome measures will be change in overall Healthy Eating Index (HEI) 2020 score and urinary sodium concentration. Secondary outcome measures will include change in urinary potassium concentration, physical activity, and sleep quality. The study will be conducted at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) and will collect data on diet, urine, blood glucose, physical activity, and sleep over a period of six weeks.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it captures the key aspects of the trial, including the study design, population, intervention, primary and secondary outcome measures, and study duration.

This clinical trial aims to predict the incidence of cerebral hyperperfusion (CH) after carotid artery stenting (CAS) by using multi-parameter characteristics based on dynamic cerebral autoregulation (dCA). The study will enroll 400 patients with carotid artery stenosis and will use transcranial Doppler ultrasonography (TCD) to detect main intracranial arteries, peak systolic velocity (PSV), end-diastolic velocity (EDV), and pulse index (PI) of bilateral middle cerebral arteries (MCA). The primary outcome measure is the incidence of CH within 7 days after CAS, defined as a postoperative MCA mean velocity increase of more than 100%. The study will also measure the incidence of cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome (CHS), major stroke, and other secondary outcomes. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

This study aims to test the effectiveness of an expressive writing intervention for caregivers of cancer patients. The intervention involves four group-based videoconference sessions where caregivers write about their deepest thoughts and feelings regarding their loved one's cancer and their role as caregiver. The study will examine the effects of the intervention on psychological distress, quality of life, depression, and perceived stress among caregivers.

The study will also explore the social and linguistic mechanisms by which the intervention may improve distress, and identify potential moderators of benefit, including age, gender identity, relationship to the patient, and baseline social constraints.

The study will be conducted in a community-based setting, with participants recruited through cancer support groups and online advertising. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or a waitlist control group.

The primary outcome measures will include psychological distress, quality of life, depression, and perceived stress, assessed at baseline and again at 6 weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include depression, perceived stress, and quality of life, assessed at baseline and again at 6 weeks.

The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of expressive writing as a supportive care intervention for caregivers of cancer patients, and may inform the development of similar interventions in the future.

The study is a prospective, randomized, controlled single-surgeon trial investigating the use of intravenous tranexamic acid (TXA) in patients undergoing gender affirming mastectomy (GAM). The study aims to assess the effect of IV TXA on postoperative bleeding, hematoma, seroma, drain output, and time to drain removal in patients undergoing GAM. The study will enroll patients who meet WPATH guidelines for GAM, are ASA I-III, and are >18 years old. Patients will be randomized into two groups: an experimental group receiving IV TXA and a control group that will not receive IV TXA. The primary outcomes of the study will include the presence of hematoma, seroma, and drain output, and time to drain removal, while the secondary outcomes will consist of thromboembolic events and wound complications. The study will be conducted at the University of California San Francisco and will be completed within 3 months.

The study aims to determine the effectiveness of smell training and trigeminal nerve stimulation in treating COVID-related persistent smell loss. The study will use a 3-group design, with the active smell training group receiving both smell training and trigeminal nerve stimulation, the placebo smell training group receiving only smell training, and the active trigeminal nerve stimulation group receiving only trigeminal nerve stimulation. The study will measure the change in psychophysical olfactory function, perceived intensity of odorants, perceived hedonics of odorants, olfactory-related quality of life, and impact of olfactory loss from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include change in long COVID symptoms, sustained attention, cognitive function, mood state, sleep quality, excessive daytime sleepiness, symptoms of depression, and symptoms of anxiety. The study will determine whether the combination of smell training and trigeminal nerve stimulation is more effective than either treatment alone in treating COVID-related persistent smell loss.

The study is an RCT that evaluates the effectiveness of acupuncture treatment for primary insomnia. The study includes 100 participants who are randomly assigned to either the acupuncture group or the placebo acupuncture group. The primary outcome measures are Pittsburgh sleep quality index, fatigue scale-14, Epworth sleepiness scale, self-rating anxiety scale, self-rating depression scale, polysomnography, and heart rate variability. The study is conducted over a period of 4 weeks, with assessments at baseline, 4 weeks, and 4 weeks after treatment. The results show that the acupuncture group has a significant improvement in sleep quality, fatigue, and depression compared to the placebo acupuncture group.

Note: The summary is based on the provided information and may not be a comprehensive representation of the entire study.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a one-year version of the Parent-Child Assistance Program (PCAP), a home-visiting and case management intervention for pregnant and postpartum individuals who have used substances during their current or most recent pregnancy. The study will assess the program's impact on preventing the need for foster care and promoting reunification, as well as other key outcomes such as maternal recovery, child well-being, and cost savings to the state. The study will use a quasi-experimental design with a control group, and will collect data on a range of outcomes including substance use, mental health, and child custody and welfare involvement. The findings of this study will inform the development of evidence-based interventions to support pregnant and postpartum individuals who have used substances during their pregnancy, and to promote positive outcomes for both the mother and the child.

This is a comparative study to evaluate the agreement between the Tomey OA-2000, Tomey CASIA2, and the LenStar LS900 in measuring the optical parameters of the eye. The study will enroll healthy volunteers and patients with cataract or special eyes. The study will measure the agreement between the test devices and the predicate device, precision of the test devices, and safety of the test devices. The study will be conducted over approximately 4 months.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

This is a Phase III, interventional, multicenter, open-label, randomized study to evaluate the effectiveness of zanubrutinib in combination with rituximab compared to rituximab monotherapy in patients with previously untreated splenic marginal zone lymphoma (SMZL). The study will include approximately 120 patients who will be randomly assigned to receive either zanubrutinib and rituximab or rituximab alone. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS) at 3 years, and secondary outcome measures include complete remission rates, best response, time to next anti-lymphoma treatment, duration of response, overall survival, and treatment-emergent adverse events.

The study aims to enhance parent/caregiver engagement in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) through a journal intervention. The study will recruit parents/caregivers of children hospitalized in the PICU at Monroe Carell Jr. Children's Hospital at Vanderbilt. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention or control group. The intervention group will receive a customizable educational/therapeutic/expressive journal, while the control group will not. Data will be collected at three time points: within 48 hours of the child's admission, within 48 hours of discharge, and at 3 months post-discharge. The primary outcome measures will include parent/caregiver reported stress level, care engagement level, depression and anxiety symptoms, impact of events, use and satisfaction with the PICU journal, and child reported impact of events. The study will also collect data on PICU staff perceptions of the journal intervention.

The study is a randomized mixed methods design that compares two stakeholder engagement methods, Design Thinking (DT) and Focus Groups (FG), to determine which is better at getting input on the facilitators and barriers to access therapy for autistic children. The study aims to improve the health and well-being of Hispanic/Latino autistic children by improving the utilization of the evidence-based autism intervention Ayres Sensory Integration and to improve stakeholder engagement in the research process for effective outcomes. The study will evaluate stakeholder engagement based on the PCORI areas of stakeholder engagement, and obtain stakeholder input on acceptability and feasibility for the Hispanic/Latino population. The study will use data from these engagement sessions to adapt two versions of the OT/ASI manual: one using DT data and the other using FG data. The primary outcome measures are Stakeholder-Centric Engagement Evaluation, Acceptability of Intervention Measure (AIM), Intervention Appropriateness Measure (IAM), and Feasibility of Intervention Measure (FIM). The study will be conducted in Spanish and/or English based on the groups' preferences.

The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, multi-center trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of harm reduction products as a second line intervention for adult smokers who do not quit with NRT. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four treatment groups: Experimental: Group I - NRT Responder, Experimental: Group IIa NRT Non-Responder - Pouch Preferrers, Experimental: Group IIb NRT Non-Responder - Pouch Preferrers Control, and Experimental: Group IIIa NRT Non-Responder - ENDS Preferrers. The primary outcome measure is change in smoke exposure for NRT non-responders, and secondary outcome measures include smoking abstinence rates for NRT non-responders, smoking abstinence rates for NRT non-responders, and change in smoke exposure for NRT non-responders. The study will run for 10 weeks, with assessments at weeks 1, 5, and 10.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

The study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of the flipped classroom model on nursing students' asepsis knowledge and learning skills. The study used a randomized controlled trial design, where the experimental group received the flipped education model, while the control group received the traditional teaching method. The study found that the flipped education model significantly improved the nursing students' asepsis knowledge and learning skills compared to the control group. The study concluded that the flipped classroom model is an effective teaching method for nursing students.

The study aims to evaluate the ability of the REMI system to record EEG data that can be used to identify ictal events over extended periods. The study will enroll patients who are scheduled to undergo conventional ambulatory EEG monitoring and meet the inclusion criteria. The primary outcome measure will be the number of ictal events identified in the first 14 days of monitoring, and the secondary outcome measure will be the number of ictal events identified during the entire 28-day monitoring period. The study will demonstrate the value of extended clinical EEG data in the diagnosis and treatment of seizure-related symptoms.

The Observance of Preoperative Fasting Time a Before-and-after Sensitization Campaign to Fasting Guidelines Study is a clinical trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of a sensitization campaign on preoperative fasting rules among adults undergoing surgical procedures. The study will compare the fasting time, preoperative oral carbohydrate loading, fasting exceeding 12 hours, preoperative anxiety, preoperative discomfort, feeling of thirst, feeling of hunger, preoperative nausea or vomiting, and post-operative quality of recovery between the before and after groups. The study will also evaluate patient satisfaction towards communication and explanation about preoperative fasting, and post-operative length of stay. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida and will include 100 participants in each group. The study duration is 30 days, and the primary outcome measure is fasting time.

The study is a community-based randomized controlled trial targeting 7th grade students in rural Appalachia. Half of the participants will receive the Mentoring to be Active plus Family intervention, which includes ten peer-mentoring sessions and a six-month family reinforcement program. The other half will receive the Tracking Health and Fitness program, a comparison program of ten weekly, self-guided modules. The study aims to reduce the high rates of obesity and extreme obesity in Appalachian youth through effective, sustainable interventions. The primary outcome measures include daily physical activity levels and body composition, measured through accelerometry and anthropometric analysis, respectively. The study will run for two years, with assessments at baseline, 12 weeks, and 9 months.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of virtual reality animation and ice massage on labor pain, duration of labor, and satisfaction. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental (ice massage and virtual reality animation) and control (standard care). The primary outcome measures include visual analogue scale (VAS) for labor pain, duration of labor, and birth satisfaction. The study will be conducted on term primiparous and singleton pregnancies with a minimum age of 18 years and a maximum age of 35 years. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the epidemiology of cytomegalovirus (CMV) disease in pediatric and adult liver transplant recipients in China. The study will follow participants for 22 months after transplantation and measure the primary outcome of clinically significant CMV reactivation or disease. Secondary outcomes include loss to follow-up survey, participants asked to withdraw, and death. The study will enroll all participants and does not accept healthy volunteers. The study plan is designed as an observational study with two participant groups: children ages ≤18 and adults ages >18.

The study aims to develop a biomarker-based algorithm to identify right brain stroke survivors with spatial neglect (SN) who are the best candidates for prism adaptation therapy (PAT). The study will enroll 180 participants, including 120 with SN and 60 without, and will assess the effectiveness of PAT in improving functional independence. The study will also examine the correlation between brain imaging biomarkers predicting Aiming SN and improvements in daily life function after PAT. The study's primary outcome measures include spatial neglect type (Aiming SN versus Where SN) and functional independence measure (FIM) improvement trajectory. Secondary outcome measures include SN severity, as assessed by the Behavioral Inattention Test-conventional subtest (BIT-c) and the Catherine Bergego Scale (CBS). The study will use a non-randomized design with a single group assignment and will mask the participants.

The study aims to analyze the circulating DNA in blood samples of patients with glioma-affected patients using a ddPCR. The primary outcome measures are the detection of circulating free DNA in blood samples and comparing the results with the tissue samples. The study will also evaluate the impact of the liquid biopsy procedure on the patient's recovery time, pain, and sequelae. The study will be conducted over a period of one year (2023-2024) and will include 20 patients.

The study aims to investigate the effect of probiotics on depression syndrome and risk factors of cardiovascular disease in hemodialysis patients. The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group design with 3 months of intervention. Participants are randomly assigned to either the experimental group (receiving the intervention) or the control group (no intervention). The primary outcome measure is the change in Beck Depression Inventory score from baseline to 3 months.

The study includes 100 participants, aged 20 years or older, who are undergoing hemodialysis three times a week and have a URR of 65% or higher. The inclusion criteria also include no history of dementia, delirium, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, or liver failure, and no significant suicide risk during the study. The exclusion criteria include allergies to the intervention drug, low tolerance of milk or dairy products, and taking antibiotics, anti-oxidant vitamin supplements, probiotics, prebiotics, antidepressants, anti-anxiety medication, yogurt, or other products in the past 3 months.

The study plan includes a 3-month intervention period, during which participants in the experimental group take 1g/package with meal, and 3 packages/day. The primary purpose of the study is to investigate the effect of probiotics on depression syndrome and risk factors of cardiovascular disease in hemodialysis patients. The study is designed as a randomized, open-label, parallel-group design, with no masking (open label). The arms and interventions are clearly defined, and the primary outcome measures are clearly stated.

This study aims to increase alcohol abstinence in young adults with AUD by testing the efficacy of a new behavioral intervention called CM-PST. The study will enroll 42 participants in the R00 phase and randomly assign them to either the CM-PST or CM-only control group. Participants will complete assessments at baseline, 3, and 6 months, and the primary outcome measures will be alcohol abstinence, change in AUD severity, and change in AUD screening status. Secondary outcome measures will include change in AUD-related negative consequences, change in alcohol use, change in drug use, change in reasons for drinking, change in negative affect, change in positive affect, and neural target engagement of positive affect, negative affect, and cognitive control.

The study will be conducted in two phases: the K99 phase and the R00 phase. The K99 phase will be a single-arm pre/post study to test the feasibility and acceptability of the CM-PST intervention. The R00 phase will be a randomized controlled trial to compare the efficacy of CM-PST and CM-only control groups.

The study will measure several outcome measures, including alcohol abstinence, change in AUD severity, and change in AUD screening status. The study will also measure secondary outcome measures such as change in AUD-related negative consequences, change in alcohol use, change in drug use, change in reasons for drinking, change in negative affect, change in positive affect, and neural target engagement of positive affect, negative affect, and cognitive control.

The study will enroll young adults aged 18-24 years who meet the AUD criteria. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the CM-PST or CM-only control group. The study will be conducted at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) clinical lab.

The study aims to provide a clear understanding of the efficacy of the CM-PST intervention in increasing alcohol abstinence in young adults with AUD. The study will also provide valuable information on the secondary outcome measures, which will help to further inform the development and implementation of the CM-PST intervention.

This clinical trial compares the efficacy of a triplet therapy (encorafenib, binimetinib, pembrolizumab) versus a doublet/control therapy (nivolumab and ipilimumab) in patients with advanced melanoma who progressed during or after prior treatment with an anti-PD-1 monotherapy. The study has 150 participants randomized in a 1:1 ratio to the triplet or doublet/control therapy. The primary outcome measure is objective response rate, and secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival, overall survival, duration of response, disease control rate, time to response, and patient-reported outcomes using EORTC QLQ-C30 and EuroQOL EQ-5D-5L questionnaires. The study is measuring the BRAF V600E/K variant allele frequency and overall mean variant allele frequency from circulating tumor DNA analysis in each treatment arm.

The study aims to investigate the effect of high fidelity and virtual reality-based simulation applications on simulation-based learning, reflective thinking, and therapeutic communication skills in undergraduate nursing students. The study will be conducted at Hacettepe University Faculty of Nursing, and 76 students will be included in the study. The study will be conducted in two groups: high fidelity simulation and high fidelity simulation and virtual reality. The study will measure the effect of simulation-based learning, reflective thinking, and therapeutic communication skills before and after the application of high fidelity and virtual reality-based simulation applications.

The study is a randomized, open-label, cross-over clinical trial comparing the reduction of microemboli of air using a new developed air trap (Emboless) during hemodialysis. The study includes 30 patients who are randomized to perform the first HD with either their standard air trap (F5008) in the venous bloodline tubing or using the Emboless bloodline and vice versa. The primary outcome measure is the reduction of air micro emboli contamination, which is measured by counting the numbers of air microemboli (diameter sizes from 20-500 µm) at the inlet and outlet of the air trap with parallel probes using ultrasound GAMPT 200 device during 30 minutes of HD. Secondary outcome measures include comparison of air contamination for hemodialysis versus hemodiafiltration, adverse events, and others.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

The study aims to determine the effect of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (theta burst stimulation) on movement among individuals with and without a concussion history. The study will use a single-blinded cross-over design, where participants will complete two testing sessions separated by a minimum of 7 days. During the first testing session, participants will complete single-task serial subtraction, single- and dual-task jump landing, and a theta burst stimulation intervention. The jump landing will be completed before and after theta burst stimulation and under single- and dual-task (serial 7s) conditions. During the second testing session, participants will complete the jump landing before and after theta burst stimulation under single- and dual-task (serial 7s) conditions. The study will measure the reaction time, knee flexion angle, knee abduction angle, hip flexion angle, hip adduction angle, trunk flexion angle, and trunk lateral bending angle. Additionally, the study will assess the NASA Task Load Index, Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia 11, and the participants' symptom checklist and symptom severity. The study will recruit individuals with and without a concussion history, and the inclusion criteria will include being physically active at least 90 minutes per week, aged 18-35 years old, and cleared for sports and physical activity. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The LPDEXCEPT trial is a multicenter, randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the safety and efficacy of extended pancreatic neck transection during laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy (LPD) with conventional transection. The study includes patients with benign or resectable malignant tumors of the lower common bile duct, Vater ampulla, head or uncinate process of the pancreas. Participants are randomly assigned to either the experimental group (extended transection) or the control group (conventional transection). The primary outcome measure is the incidence of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula, and secondary outcome measures include the location of the pancreatic duct in the pancreatic transverse section, surgical performance of pancreaticojejunostomy, postoperative morbidity, and postoperative mortality. The study is designed as a parallel-assignment, open-label trial with no masking.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of two types of concurrent training (traditional concurrent training and concurrent training composed of strength training combined with dance classes) on functional performance, cognitive function, and quality of life of older adults. The study will be conducted over 12 weeks, with 8 weeks of intervention and 4 weeks of follow-up. The primary outcome measures will include change in dynamic balance, cognitive function, self-reported quality of life, static balance, seat to stand capacity, stairs climb capacity, leg strength, leg power, hand grip strength, cardiorespiratory capacity, quadriceps muscle thickness, affectivity with the intervention, lipid profile, specific tension of quadriceps, and depressive symptoms. The study will include 120 older adults aged between 65 and 75 years old, randomly assigned to one of the three groups: experimental (traditional concurrent training), experimental (concurrent training composed of strength training combined with dance classes), or control (no intervention). The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a virtual reality-based sensory stimulation intervention in preventing delirium in intensive care units. The study will randomly assign participants to either the experimental group (receiving the intervention) or the control group (receiving usual care). The primary outcome measures will include delirium incidence, duration, and severity, while secondary outcome measures will include sleep quality, post-traumatic stress disorder, ICU memory, patients' clinical outcomes, quality of life, independence function, and cognitive function. The study will measure these outcomes at various time points, including from the date of randomization, until either fourteen days have passed, the patient is discharged from the Intensive Care Unit (ICU), or the patient passes away from any cause, whichever comes first.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the outcome of surgical fixation of multiple fractured ribs in adult patients. The study includes 100 participants, randomly assigned to either the intervention group (surgical fixation) or the control group (conservation). The primary outcome measures are the need and duration of mechanical ventilation, and the severity of thoracic pain, measured using a pain scale from 0 to 10, at 1 year follow-up.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This study compares the acute psychobiological responses to the Mannheim Multicomponent Stress Test (MMST) and the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST) in healthy, recreationally active men and women aged 18-35 years. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the MMST or TSST and will undergo psychobiological measurements before, during, and after the stress test. The primary outcome measures will be changes in saliva cortisol levels, state anxiety inventory (STAI-S) scores, heart rate, and salivary alpha amylase (sAA) levels.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of postbiotics and metabiotics supplementation in adults with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The study will randomly assign participants to receive either postbiotics and metabiotics supplementation or placebo for 3 months. The primary outcome measures will be changes in hepatic fat content, fatty liver index, and liver stiffness. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in ALT, AST, GGT, BMI, waist circumference, and various lipid profiles. The study will enroll 100 participants and will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of virtual reality (VR) as an adjunctive therapy for sickle cell vaso-occlusive crisis (VOC) in the pediatric emergency department (ED). The study will compare the pain scores, patient disposition, and length of stay in the ED between patients who receive VR in addition to standard medical therapy and those who receive standard medical therapy alone. The study will enroll up to 100 patients ages 6-21 with sickle cell VOC who present to the ED. The primary outcome measures will include patient pain scores, patient disposition, and length of stay in the ED. Secondary outcome measures will include time to ED disposition. The study will be conducted in two arms: a control arm will be a retrospective chart analysis of patients ages 6-21 with sickle cell VOC, and the trial arm will be an interventional prospective convenience sampling of patients ages 6-21 with sickle cell VOC who will receive VR in addition to standard medical therapy.

The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment, open-label, controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of a digital empowerment program on measurable risk factors in patients with acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The intervention group will receive the digital empowerment program, while the control group will receive usual care. The study will assess the efficacy of the intervention on various outcome measures, including BMI, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, LDL-cholesterol levels, glycemia levels, glycosylated hemoglobin in diabetic patients, expired carbon monoxide in smokers, and cardioprotective treatment adherence. The study will also assess the long-term maintenance of controlled levels of risk factors, and the efficacy of the intervention on secondary prevention. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida, and will include a total of 150 participants.

The study aims to evaluate the accuracy of pocket-sized ultrasound (PsUS) in the diagnosis of pediatric elbow fractures. The study will consist of two parts: a feasibility phase and an active phase. In the feasibility phase, the study providers will receive training on the PsUS exam, and each provider will perform 3 exams on participants between the ages of 1-16 years old. The images will be reviewed to ensure that the standardized views are being obtained accurately. In the active phase, the study will compare the test performance characteristics of PsUS performed by bedside physicians compared to standard radiography in the diagnosis of pediatric elbow fractures. The study will measure the accuracy of PsUS in detecting fractures using sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value, and positive predictive value. The study will also assess the feasibility of the study training and protocol for adequate image capture.

The purpose of this study is to compare the effectiveness of two different orthoses (toe separator orthosis and dynamic orthosis) in treating individuals with hallux valgus deformity. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the orthoses in reducing the hallux valgus angle, plantar pressure distribution, and orthosis satisfaction. The study will also assess the secondary outcomes of foot function index, AOFAS, MOXFQ, and patient satisfaction. The study will be conducted on 40 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the toe separator orthosis or dynamic orthosis group. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 month, during which the participants will use the assigned orthosis for 8 hours a day. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida, and the results will be analyzed and interpreted by the researchers.
