The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of pharyngeal flap surgery in improving speech function in children with velopharyngeal insufficiency caused by cleft palate. The study will assess speech function through patient- and parent-reported outcome measurements, including the CLEFT-Q and Intelligibility in Context Scale, before and after surgery. The study will enroll children aged 0-17 years with isolated or combined cleft palate who are undergoing surgical treatment for velopharyngeal insufficiency at six specialized cleft centers in Sweden. The study will measure the primary outcome of speech function at preoperatively and 1 year postoperatively.

ЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉЉ

The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the use of barbed absorbable sutures versus standard absorbable sutures for vaginal cuff closure after total laparoscopic hysterectomy. The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the barbed sutures in preventing vaginal cuff complications, such as dehiscence, and to determine if the barbed sutures result in faster recovery times and improved quality of life. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted at two hospitals. The primary outcome measures will be vaginal cuff dehiscence at 30 and 90 days after surgery, and secondary outcome measures will include vaginal cuff complications, hospital stay, operative time, intraoperative blood loss, 30-day post-surgical morbidity, quality of life index, and sexual function.

The study aims to test a new neurobiological model of gambling addiction that takes into account inter-individual differences and the multifactorial nature of gaming addiction. The study will use fMRI and Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) to measure the brain phenotypes characterizing impulsive and emotional gamblers, and test the hypothesis that these phenotypes are diametrically opposed in these two sub-populations. The study will also determine whether the brain phenotypes proposed above are capable of predicting gambling behavior outside the laboratory. The study population will include individuals with gambling problems and healthy controls, and the study will recruit 60 gamblers and 60 healthy controls. The inclusion criteria for participants are aged between 18 and 65, fluent French, male and female, informed consent to take part in the research, number of DSM-5 criteria for gambling disorder ≥3, score ≥ 5 on the Problem Gambling Severity Index questionnaire (PGSI), and have a smartphone. The exclusion criteria for participants are contra-indication to MRI, protected adults, breast feeding or pregnant women, neurological disorder or severe chronic illness, pharmacological treatment with psychotropic action, regular drug use, positive urine drug test on the day of the MRI sessions, psychiatric treatment > 1 month, other DSM-5 diagnosis except nicotine addiction for healthy subjects. The study will measure primary outcome measures such as striatal BOLD response to reward outcomes and amygdala BOLD response to emotional stimuli, and secondary outcome measures such as correlation between emotional states and gambling behavior in everyday life. The keywords provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida are gambling addiction, fMRI, reward, emotion, striatum, amygdala, EMA.

The study compares the use of 2D 4K vs. 3D HD laparoscopic imaging systems in bariatric surgery. The study is a randomized controlled prospective trial with 30 participants divided into two groups: experimental (2D 4K) and active comparator (3D HD). The primary outcome measures include operation time, intraoperative complications, and postoperative complications. The study aims to determine the effectiveness and safety of the two imaging systems in bariatric surgery.

This is a single-center, open-label, single-arm clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Huai er granule in patients with stage I primary ovarian cancer, fallopian tube cancer, and peritoneal cancer after surgery. The primary objective is to evaluate the 1-year progression-free survival rate of patients treated with Huai er granule. Secondary objectives include assessing the safety of Huai er granule, evaluating the quality of life of patients, and monitoring the frequency of adverse events.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

This study aims to assess the prevalence of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) in critically ill mechanically ventilated patients. The study will also investigate the effects of SIBO on ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), intensive care unit (ICU) length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate in critically ill patients. The study will use a modified hydrogen breath test to diagnose SIBO in ICU patients. The primary outcome measure is the prevalence of SIBO in ICU patients, measured up to one month after admission. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of VAP, ICU length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate.

This study aimed to investigate the effect of exercises of different intensity applied after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) on exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH). The study was a randomized controlled trial with 38 patients who were hospitalized for at least 7 days after TKA. The patients were randomly assigned to either a high intensity exercises (HIE) group or a low intensity exercises (LIE) group. The HIE program consisted of ankle pump exercise, quadriceps isometric exercise, terminal extension exercise, passive-active assistive-active range of motion exercise, heel sliding exercise, and straight leg raise exercise. The LIE program was similar to the HIE program but with fewer repetitions. The primary outcome measures were the change of pain severity and change of pressure pain threshold from admission to hospital service to discharge from hospital service, an average of 5 days. The study found that EIH was present in both groups after exercise, but the intensity of EIH was higher in the HIE group than in the LIE group.

The Nigerian Breast Cancer Risk-Reduction Study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of risk assessment and counselling on adherence to breast cancer screening recommendations among first-degree female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwestern Nigeria. The study will measure the primary outcome measures of effects of BC risk assessment and counselling on adherence to breast screening recommendations, effects of BC risk assessment and counselling on adherence to lifestyle risk reduction recommendations, predictors of BSE, predictors of time to first BC screening post-intervention, perception of familial BC risk, knowledge of familiar BC risk, and knowledge, attitude, and perception towards genetic testing and BC aetiology. The study will enroll female relatives of histologically diagnosed BC patients in the study sites, aged 20 to 75 years, who are willing to be contacted after six months for follow-up. The study will be conducted in Southwestern Nigeria and will be designed as a parallel assignment randomized controlled trial with double masking. The study will allocate participants to either the standard care (SC) group or the experimental group, which will receive individualized breast cancer risk assessment and counselling in addition to standard care. The study will measure the secondary outcome measures of perception of familial BC risk, knowledge of familiar BC risk, and knowledge, attitude, and perception towards genetic testing and BC aetiology.

This study aims to evaluate the serum magnesium level in type 2 diabetes mellitus patients through a diagnostic test. The study includes two groups: cases and controls. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of serum magnesium level in type 2 DM patients. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

Please provide a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled clinical trial to evaluate the effect of Ophiochepalus striatus extract on serum IGF-1 and IL-6 levels in elderly patients with sarcopenia. The study will enroll 100 participants and will be conducted over a period of 14 days. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (Ophiochepalus striatus extract) or the placebo group. The primary outcome measures will be IGF-1 levels and IL-6 levels, which will be measured at 2 weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include SARC-F score, muscle mass, muscle strength, and physical performance, which will also be measured at 2 weeks. The study will accept healthy volunteers and will not include any exclusion criteria.

The study is a randomized control feasibility study evaluating the existing 2Morrow Chronic Pain Self-Management Program as a digital therapeutic for improving patients' pain self-management and function who suffer from chronic pain. The study will assess the feasibility of using a mobile app and an optional activity tracker, as well as the effect size for planning a larger efficacy trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention arm, which will test the mobile app, or the control arm, which will receive treatment as usual. The primary outcome measures will be the PROMIS Pain Interference Scale-Short Form 6b and the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) for depression symptoms. Secondary outcome measures will include the Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7 (GAD-7) for anxiety symptoms. The study aims to recruit at least 100 participants and will be conducted in primary care clinics.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of stentless Florence Robotic Intracorporeal Neobladder (FloRIN) in patients undergoing radical cystectomy for bladder cancer. The study will enroll 30 patients and will be conducted at a single center. The primary outcome measure is the mid-term complications rate, assessed at 6 months after surgery. Secondary outcome measures include perioperative complications rate, assessed at 7 days after surgery, and other adverse events.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, it is not the original document.

The study aims to compare the effects of different storage conditions on removable retainers. The study will randomly assign participants to store their retainers in either dry or wet conditions for a period of 6 months. The study will measure the microbial colony counts, surface roughness, color stability, compressive strength, and oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) of the participants. The study will also compare the Hawley retainers and vacuum-formed retainers in both dry and wet conditions.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a new model of continuity of nutrition care between acute care hospital settings and community meal provision organizations in improving outcomes for older adults with malnutrition. The model involves enhanced cross-referral, data transfer, and nutrition care across settings, with the goal of improving food security, quality of life, and reducing determinants of malnutrition. The study will use a stepped wedge cluster-randomized trial design at eight sites throughout the US, with a total of 1120 patients expected to be enrolled over a period of 35 months. The primary outcome measures will include quality of life, program sustainability, and barriers and facilitators to implementation, while secondary outcome measures will include the percent of patients receiving nutrition care and meals, food security risk, malnutrition risk, and malnutrition diagnosis. The study will generate new data on the feasibility of the new model, rates of malnutrition within older adults at the study sites, impact of medical nutrition therapy with meal provision on food security, determinants of malnutrition, and quality of life to inform future scalability of the model.

This is a randomized, double-blind, crossover study to assess the hemodynamic effects of modulating circulating ketone bodies with 1,3-butanediol in patients with heart failure. The study will enroll 20 participants with heart failure (NYHA class II-III, LVEF <40%) and randomly assign them to receive either 1,3-butanediol or placebo for 6 hours. The primary outcome measures will include cardiac output, stroke volume, heart rate, LVEF, and changes in circulating 3-hydroxybutyrate (3-OHB) and free fatty acids (FFA).

The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-blind clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of subpectoral bupivacaine in reducing post-operative pain in adolescent reduction mammaplasty. The study will enroll 60 patients, with 20 in each of the experimental and control groups. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the study group (receiving subpectoral bupivacaine) or the control group (receiving saline). The primary outcome measure is post-operative pain score, which will be recorded by the PACU nurse upon admission and upon discharge from the PACU. Secondary outcome measures include narcotic use, length of stay in the PACU, return to full activity, and demographics. The study will be conducted at Connecticut Children's from 1/1/2022-12/31/2025.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Spot Delete technique in reducing radiation dermatitis in breast cancer patients undergoing proton therapy. The study will assess the degree of skin reactions in patients using digital photographs, questionnaires, and assessment using CTCAE and Radiation Dermatitis Severity scoring system. The study will also investigate the correlation between the linear energy transfer (LET) of the proton beam and skin reactions.

This is a multicenter, non-inferiority, randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of generic cetrorelix acetate versus reference cetrorelix acetate for ovarian stimulation in women undergoing IVF. The study will enroll infertile women aged 20-42 years and will randomly assign them to receive either the experimental or active comparator drug. The primary outcome measure is the cumulative live birth rate in one IVF/ICSI egg retrieval cycle.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This is a dose-escalation and dose-expansion study of peposertib and liposomal doxorubicin in patients with metastatic leiomyosarcoma and other soft tissue sarcomas. The study is designed to determine the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the study drugs and to assess the safety and efficacy of the combination.

Intervention: 
Patients receive peposertib orally (PO) twice daily (BID) and pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride intravenously (IV) once daily (QD) during treatment cycles on study. Cycles repeat every 28 days in the absence of disease progression, unacceptable toxicity or withdrawal of consent. Patients also undergo computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) throughout the trial.

Outcome Measures: 
The primary outcome measure is the dose limiting toxicity (DLT) rate at each tested dose level. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of adverse events, objective response rate, and progression free survival.

Note: 
* Dose escalation study design is single group assignment, open-label, and no masking.
* Arms and interventions are provided in the arm and intervention column.
* Outcome measures are provided in the outcome measure column.
* Time frame is provided in the time frame column.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a free online Zoom t'ai chi and qigong gentle movement and meditation program in reducing back pain and improving sleep and quality of life among those with chronic back pain. The study will randomly assign participants to either the treatment group (receiving the t'ai chi and qigong exercise program) or the waitlist control group (receiving the program starting in January 2023). The study will assess the primary outcome measures of low back pain, including the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI), Visual Analog Scale for Back and Leg Pain (VAS), SF-36, Short Form Health Survey questionnaire, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), and 19-Item Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). The study will also explore whether improvements in pain levels are different among smokers and those with unhealthy BMI than among others.

The study aims to evaluate the patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) during the acceleration of the en-masse retraction of upper anterior teeth using a low-intensity direct electrical current. The study will randomly assign participants to either an experimental group or an active comparator group. The primary outcome measures will be the change in the perception of pain, discomfort, and burning, as well as the change in the chewing ability, speech ability, analgesic consumption, patients' satisfaction, ease of the procedure, the possibility of repeating the procedure, and the recommendation of the procedure to a friend. The study will be conducted over five months, with assessments at the 1st, 3rd, and 7th day of the first, second, and third months from the beginning of the en-masse retraction of upper anterior teeth.

The study is a prospective observational study that aims to evaluate the association between baseline plasma Amyloid-beta 42/40 (Aβ42/40) ratio and cognitive decline in men upon starting androgen deprivation therapy (ADT). The study also aims to evaluate whether ADT is associated with a decline in plasma Aβ42/40 ratio and whether intensified ADT (iADT) receipt is associated with greater cognitive decline compared to ADT. The study will enroll adult men with hormone-sensitive prostate cancer who are starting ADT as part of standard of care prostate cancer treatment. Participants will undergo cognitive assessments and provide blood samples for plasma Aβ42/40 ratio measurement. The study will measure the proportion of participants with cognitive decline, mean cognitive decline, and proportion of participants with cognitive impairment after ADT. The study will also compare the change in mean plasma Aβ42/40 ratio between the ADT cohort and the prostate cancer control (PC) cohort.

The High-dose Cephalexin for Cellulitis (HI-DOCC) trial is a multicentre, parallel-arm double-blind, individually randomized clinical trial comparing high-dose (1000 mg QID) cephalexin to standard-dose (500 mg QID) cephalexin in adult patients with non-purulent cellulitis. The primary outcome is oral antibiotic treatment failure, defined as a change in antibiotic within 7 days due to worsening infection. Secondary outcomes include clinical cure, clinical response, unplanned visits to a healthcare provider, unplanned hospitalization, adverse events, antibiotic intolerance, antibiotic allergy, medication adherence, and health-related quality of life. The study aims to inform future skin and soft tissue infection treatment guidelines and reduce unnecessary IV antibiotic use, hospitalization, and costs.

The study aims to determine the Turkish validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 years) and to provide a diabetes health literacy box game to 8-12 school age children diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes. The study will be conducted in two stages, with the first stage involving a general screening methodological method to determine the current situation by quantitative analysis of the data obtained with the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 years). In the second stage, a randomized controlled trial will be conducted to evaluate the effect of educational games on acute complications of diabetes and health literacy in children. The study will include 30 participants, with 15 in the experimental group and 15 in the control group. The study will measure the validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 years) in Turkish, and evaluate the diabetes health literacy of children with type 1 diabetes aged 8-12 years through the Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Diabetes for Children with Type 1 Diabetes (8-12 years) scale.

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to compare the amount and type of biofilm accumulation on the surface of zirconia versus titanium dental implants. The study will include 30 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (zirconia implants) or the active comparator group (titanium implants). The primary outcome measures will be the total amount of biofilm (CFU/ml) and the amount of A. actinomyces, P. gingivalis, P. intermedia, T. forsythia, P. micra, F. nucleatum, C. rectus, E. corrodens, Capnocytophaga sp., A. odontolyticus, S. mutans, and Candidae sp. on implants placed prior to crown placement, at 6 months and 1 year after final crown placement, by culturing with two sterile paper tips at the two points of greatest probing for 20 seconds each. The study will be conducted in accordance with the principles established by the Declaration of Helsinki and will be carried out in the Master of Oral Surgery and Implantology of the Faculty of Dentistry of the Complutense University of Madrid (Spain).

The study aims to assess the impact of aromatherapy on alleviating dental anxiety in children. The study will be conducted on children aged 6-9 years old, both boys and girls, who require extraction of a primary molar. The study will be randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked, and will have two active comparators: rosemary and lemongrass oil. The primary outcome measures will be measuring pulse rate, oxygen saturation, blood pressure, and pain level. The study will be conducted in a single dental clinic.

The study aims to investigate the effect of puzzles on nursing students' learning concepts related to vital signs. The study will be conducted with first-year nursing students of Bilecik Şeyh Edebali University. The experimental group will apply puzzles for two weeks, while the control group will receive only the normal course education. The primary outcome measures will be students' knowledge test successes, which will be evaluated after 5 weeks. The study will contribute positively to the knowledge level of the students.

The study compares the efficacy of KTP laser and ivermectin cream in treating facial rosacea. The study is a randomized split-face trial with 1:1 within-patient allocation, and the primary outcome measure is the reduction of erythema as assessed by the Normalized Erythema Index (NEI). Secondary outcome measures include the reduction of erythema, skin lesions, patient satisfaction, telangiectasia severity, papules and papulopustules, face swelling, face redness, and face purpura. The study includes 40 participants and is conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a retrospective review of an large cohort of FDG PET data in patients with neurodegenerative diseases and head trauma. The study aims to identify the regions of altered brain function specific for each clinical condition using FDG PET. The primary outcome measures are the distribution pattern of the FDG tracer in patients with neurodegenerative diseases and the characterization of the different pathologies examined starting from the study of regional metabolism in individual subjects up to the study of the functional activity of the different brain circuits.

This is a prospective, longitudinal cohort study in people with Cystic Fibrosis (pwCF) that involves the repeated serial sampling of participants. The study aims to provide comprehensive information on SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence changes over time and the subsequent clinical impact on pwCF. The study will be conducted at participating CF centers over a 3-year period, and study participants will include pediatric and adult pwCF. The study will measure the SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence, association of SARS-CoV-2 seropositivity, clinical symptoms and clinical outcomes in pwCF, and longitudinal comparison of the detection of anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibodies in pwCF following natural infection and SARS-CoV-2 vaccination.

The study aims to assess the use and reproducibility of duplex ultrasound in measuring the diameter of the left common iliac vein in patients presenting with unexplained left leg swelling. The study will enroll participants who are symptomatic or asymptomatic and will undergo a vascular ultrasound scan of the left common iliac vein. The primary outcome measure is the diameter measurement of the left common iliac vein, which will be measured at 6 months. The study will also assess the inter-and intra-operator variation of the diameter measurement.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and captures the key aspects of the trial, including the study overview, inclusion and exclusion criteria, study design, primary and secondary outcome measures, and terms related to the study.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of visual training in improving the quality of life of patients with symptomatic convergence insufficiency. The study will enroll 30 patients aged 8-15 years old and will be divided into two groups: training group and control group. The training group will receive visual training in hospital, while the control group will not receive any treatment. The primary outcome measures will be changes in EuroQol five dimensions questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L) score and shortForm 6D (SF-6D) questionnaire score from baseline to 3 months.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The PILOT study is a clinical trial that aims to compare the detection rate of sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs) using indocyanine green (ICG) dye versus blue dye during surgery for early-stage vulvar cancer. The study will enroll 30 participants and will be conducted at Tufts Medical Center. The primary outcome measure will be the detection rate of SLNs using ICG dye versus blue dye at the patient level. Secondary outcome measures will include sensitivity, specificity, and negative predictive value of ICG dye versus standard blue dye. The study will be clustered at the hemi-pelvis level to account for the correlation between SLNs within the same patient's hemi-pelvis.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, crossover trial that evaluates the effects of different NMES protocols on triceps surae muscle. The study includes 5 sessions with 7 days between them, and the participants will be randomly assigned to receive one of the four NMES protocols: Russian current 10%, Aussie current 10%, pulsed current 500 µs phase, or pulsed current 200 µs phase. The primary outcome measures include submaximal and maximum voluntary isometric contraction, maximum evoked torque, torque-time-integral, and muscle fatigue index. Secondary outcome measures include sensory discomfort, electromyographic signals, and peripheral oxygen extraction. The study aims to determine the effects of different NMES protocols on triceps surae muscle and to evaluate the safety and efficacy of these protocols.

The study aims to investigate the metabolic effects of four-week lactate-ketone ester supplementation on insulin sensitivity, lipolysis, appetite, and other metabolic parameters in obese individuals. The study will be conducted as a randomized, double-blind, crossover trial with 25 ml twice daily of a combined lactate and ketone body ester (LaKe Ester) or a taste- and appearance-matched noncaloric placebo (Placebo) for 28 days. The primary outcome measures will include insulin sensitivity expressed as an M-value, differences in lipolysis rate, and changes in body weight and composition. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in gastric emptying rate, cardiac output, left ventricular ejection fraction, tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion, global longitudinal strain, mitral inflow velocities, mitral plane velocities in the lateral mitral annulus, global work index, changes in blood concentrations of 3-OHB, changes in blood concentrations of lactate, changes in blood concentrations of free fatty acids, changes in blood concentrations of glucose, changes in blood concentrations of insulin, changes in plasma concentrations of growth/differentiation factor 15, changes in blood concentrations of gastric inhibitory polypeptide, changes in blood concentrations of ghrelin, changes in blood concentrations of glucagon, changes in blood concentrations of liver-expressed antimicrobial peptide 2, changes in blood concentrations of C-peptide, changes in blood concentrations of triglycerides, changes in blood concentrations of cholesterol, changes in blood concentrations of brain-derived neurotrophic factor, changes in blood concentrations of N-lactoyl-phenylalanine, fibrosis-4, erythrocyte volume fraction, erythropoietin, inflammation markers, mood, anxiety symptom scale questionnaire, supplement tolerability, and control of eating questionnaire. The study will also assess the tolerability of the supplement and the changes in appetite, craving, and mood regulation.

This study aims to assess the impact of personalized recommendations based on genetic and lifestyle data on the wellbeing of NHS staff. Participants will be asked to complete a questionnaire before and after receiving the personalized recommendations and at a 3-month follow-up. The primary outcome measure will be the change in physical and psychological wellbeing, assessed using the 5-item World Health Organisation Well-being Index (WHO-5). Secondary outcome measures will include perceptions of DNA testing, how sustainable the personalized recommendations are, and how easy participants found implementing the recommendations.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a new ultrasound-guided ilio-psoas tendon tenotomy technique for the treatment of hip injuries. The study will enroll 30 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (receiving the new technique) or the control group (receiving the standard practice). The primary outcome measure will be the success rate of the new technique, assessed through the disappearance of ilio-psoas conflict after surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include pain, function, and quality of life at various time points post-operatively. The study will also evaluate the technical difficulty of the surgical procedure, operative time, installation time, total blood loss, length of hospital stay, scarring after surgery, impact on patient quality of life, patient satisfaction with the results of the operation, subjective value of the hip, forgotten hip sensation, forgotten hip score, early and late surgical complications related to surgery, and the rate of patients requiring a stay in a rehabilitation center.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial to compare the efficacy and safety of different local anesthetic volumes of thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) in post-thoracotomy analgesia. The study will enroll 60 patients who are undergoing elective thoracotomy surgery. The patients will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: 20 ml, 25 ml, or 30 ml of local anesthetic in the TPVB. The primary outcome measures will be pain scores assessed at different time points after surgery using a visual analog scale. Secondary outcome measures will include morphine consumption over 24 hours after surgery. The study will be conducted at a single tertiary care hospital.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of vibration therapy in improving fatigue and mobility in patients with multiple sclerosis. The study is an interventional type, where patients are divided into two groups: the experimental group receives vibration therapy in addition to standard rehabilitation, while the control group receives standard rehabilitation only. The study measures primary outcomes such as mobility, postural control, and fatigue, as well as secondary outcomes such as quality of life and depression. The study is conducted in accordance with good clinical practice guidelines and current regulations, and the results will be compared between the two groups to determine the effectiveness of vibration therapy.

This is a phase 1 dose-escalation study of tucatinib and cetuximab in patients with EGFR-mutant NSCLC who have acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI. The study is open-label, and participants will receive tucatinib 200mg orally BID, osimertinib 80mg orally daily, and cetuximab 250mg/m^2 IV every 2 weeks of a 28-day cycle. The primary objective is to estimate the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of the combination of these drugs. Secondary objectives include assessing the safety and efficacy of the combination, as well as identifying potential biomarkers of response.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, multi-center clinical trial to compare the diagnostic efficacy of transbronchial cryobiopsy versus traditional transbronchial lung biopsy for diagnosing lung transplantation rejection. The study will enroll 100 patients who undergo lung transplantation and will be randomly assigned to receive either transbronchial cryobiopsy or traditional transbronchial lung biopsy. The primary outcome measure is the diagnostic yield of transbronchial cryobiopsy for diagnosing lung transplantation rejection, compared to traditional transbronchial lung biopsy. Secondary outcome measures include incidence of complications, sample size, number of alveoli in the biopsy sample, number of blood vessels in the biopsy sample, percentage of the area of lung parenchyma without artifacts in the biopsy sample, and number of attempts to get five samples.

The Selective Fetal Growth Restriction in Monochorionic Twins - an International Investigation is a clinical trial that aims to improve outcome prediction in pregnancies affected by selective fetal growth restriction (sFGR) in monochorionic twins. The study will evaluate the impact of sFGR on parental mental health and parent-to-infant attachment, and will examine neurodevelopment of sFGR twins at two years of age. The study will also test several predictors to improve outcome prediction at the time of sFGR diagnosis. The study will include monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies complicated by sFGR (diagnosed before 28 weeks of gestational age) and will use diagnostic ultrasound measurements during pregnancy. The primary outcome measure is the composite outcome consisting of fetal single or double demise, including selective fetal reduction and/or an iatrogenic elective birth < 32 weeks of gestational age because of fetal distress). Secondary outcome measures include ultrasound parameters, prenatal and postnatal attachment, post-traumatic stress, and PARCA-R evaluation. The study will enroll participants who meet the inclusion criteria and will follow them until 2 years after birth.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a digital platform in improving mental health outcomes for gender-diverse youth and their caregivers. The study will randomly assign participants to either an immediate access group or a deferred access group, with the intervention lasting for 6 months and follow-up assessments conducted every 3 months for 18 months. The primary outcome measure will be suicidal ideation, and secondary outcome measures will include depression, anxiety, family acceptance, and self-harm. The study will be conducted with a parallel assignment design and will not mask the participants or the assessors.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This study aims to investigate the effectiveness of CBT in treating alcohol and cannabis use disorders. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the CBT group or the control group. The primary outcome measures will be the change in number of binge drinking days, cannabis use frequency, and average drinks per day during treatment. Secondary outcome measures will include retention in treatment, change in depressive symptoms, anxiety symptoms, and quality of life during treatment.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, it is not the original document.

The study aims to investigate the impact of positive, neutral, and negative expectations on pain intensity in patients with chronic low back pain. The study will randomly allocate participants into three groups: positive expectation speech, neutral expectation speech, and negative expectation speech. Each group will receive one session of spinal manipulative therapy after watching a video with positive, neutral, or negative messages regarding spinal manipulative therapy. The study will assess the immediate effect of the videos on pain intensity, global perceived effect of improvement, and expectations. The results will help understand if the content of the videos actually causes an impact on the expectations of the patients.

The study is evaluating the effects of transcranial focused ultrasound (tFUS) on fronto-striatal resting state functional connectivity in healthy individuals. The study will randomly assign participants to either active tFUS or sham tFUS and measure the resting state functional connectivity between the stimulation target (nucleus accumbens) and connected areas of the brain before and after the intervention.

Note: The summary is based on the provided information and may not capture all the details or nuances of the study.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, and placebo-controlled MRI study to investigate the biological basis of the observed stroke reduction with semaglutide by demonstrating semaglutide can improve intracranial blood flow condition and reduce blood-brain barrier (BBB) permeability in type-2 diabetes. The study will have a designated diabetes care specialist unblinded to the study randomization to carry out glucose management to achieve HbA1C<7.5% for both treatment groups.

The study will enroll men and women aged 40-65 years with type-2 diabetes and HbA1C 7%-10%. The study will randomize participants to either the active comparator (semaglutide) or placebo for 1 year. The primary outcome measures will be total length and number of distal vessels in intracranial blood flow and blood-brain barrier Ktrans, measured by dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI, approximately 12 months after baseline. Secondary outcome measures will include inflammatory markers (hsCRP, interleukin-6, and tumor necrosis factor-a) approximately 12 months after baseline.

The study will be designed as a parallel-assignment, randomized, double-blind, and placebo-controlled MRI study. Participants will be masked to the treatment assignment. The study will have a quadruple masking design, meaning that both participants and image reviewers will be masked to the treatment assignment.

The study will enroll 100 participants and will be conducted at a single site. The study duration will be approximately 12 months, including a 2-week screening period, a 52-week treatment period, and a 2-week follow-up period.

The study will investigate the effects of semaglutide on intracranial blood flow and brain-barrier permeability in type-2 diabetes. The study aims to provide insights into the biological basis of the observed stroke reduction with semaglutide and to identify potential therapeutic targets for the prevention and treatment of stroke in type-2 diabetes.

This is a retrospective cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the prevalence or occurrence of upper gastrointestinal diseases in patients younger than 50 years old who underwent gastroscopy and colonoscopy simultaneously. The study includes two participant groups: normal colonoscopy group and colorectal polyps group. The primary outcome measure is the prevalence or occurrence of upper gastrointestinal diseases, including Helicobacter pylori, atrophic gastritis/intestinal metaplasia, reflux esophagitis, Barrett's esophagus, peptic ulcer, gastric polyps, low-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (LGIN), and high-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (HGIN). The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

The study compares the effectiveness of two techniques for bone augmentation in atrophic anterior maxilla: screw tent pole method and autogenous bone block method. The study aims to assess the amount of bone gain and bone quality evaluation after 6 months of surgical procedure. The study is a randomized clinical trial with parallel groups, and the participants are systemically healthy patients with atrophic anterior maxilla. The primary outcome measure is the amount of bone gain, and the secondary outcome measure is the bone quality evaluation through bone core biopsy. The study will follow up the participants for 6 months after the surgical procedure to evaluate the effectiveness of the two techniques.

The study aims to evaluate the correlation between changes in interferon gamma (IFN-γ) response in two different antigen tubes (TB1 and TB2) and the reference standard of treatment response (culture conversion) in smear-positive and smear-negative/culture-positive pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) cases. The study will enroll participants with pulmonary TB who are receiving anti-TB treatment, and will measure the IFN-γ response at different time points during treatment. The study will evaluate the degree of correlation between the IFN-γ response and treatment response, and will determine the clinical usefulness of the IFN-γ release assay for monitoring anti-TB treatment.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to evaluate the accuracy of brain response to mechanical and radiofrequency stimuli in humans. The study will assess the effect of stimulation intensity on signal parameters, such as EP latency and amplitude, and explore the relationship between these parameters and psychophysical results (questionnaires) and heat thresholds. The study will use two experimental settings, one for radiofrequency stimuli and another for pinprick stimuli. The study will recruit healthy volunteers and will use an automated device to apply the stimuli. The study will measure the latency and amplitude of EPs evoked by RF and pinprick stimuli, changes in responses to somatosensory stimuli with pinprick thresholds, and conduction velocity in radiofrequency stimuli.

The study aims to characterize the biomechanical coupling of the brain to the skull in human volunteers with and without a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI) using magnetic resonance elastography (MRE). The study will recruit 25 mild TBI patients with a history of acute TME (TME+), 25 TME-patients (mild TBI patients without TME), and 25 healthy controls. The study will measure the global differences in the amplitudes and temporal delays of translation and rotation between brain and skull using MRE. The study will also measure local measures of skull-brain coupling at the cortical surface using MRE. The study endpoints are the completion of the MRE visit for each volunteer.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine the effectiveness of pharmacist-initiated home blood pressure monitoring on blood pressure control in women. The study will enroll 320 women aged 18 years or older, with a diagnosis of hypertension or at risk of developing hypertension. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will receive enhanced community pharmacist care in conjunction with home blood pressure monitoring, while the control group will receive usual pharmacist care. The primary outcome measure is the difference in change in systolic blood pressure between the two groups at 24 weeks. Secondary outcome measures include the proportion of patients at their blood pressure target, percentage of home blood pressure readings recorded, adherence to medications, changes to antihypertensive medication regimen, lifestyle changes, and consultant satisfaction. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 weeks, with follow-up assessments at baseline, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of moderate alcohol consumption on heart function in patients with recent myocardial infarction. The study includes 220 patients who are randomly assigned to either moderate alcohol consumption (1 standard unit per day for 12 months) or abstinence (no alcohol beverages for 12 months). The primary outcome measure is the change in left ventricular ejection fraction between the baseline visit and 12-month visit.

The study population includes patients with myocardial infarction who are hospitalized within 365 days prior to screening. The inclusion criteria are men and women aged 18 years or older who are capable and willing to provide consent, have evidence of positive high-sensitive troponin, and have a confirmed coronary heart disease aetiology by angiography. The exclusion criteria are high alcohol consumption, alcohol use disorder, history of alcohol or substance abuse, light alcohol consumption, prior severe heart failure, severe liver disease, personal history of any colon or liver cancer, active malignancy, estimated glomerular filtration rate <15 ml/min/1.73m², participation in another trial testing intervention on similar CV outcomes, and any medical, geographic, or social factor making study participation impractical or precluding required follow-up.

The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment and single masking. The arms and interventions are moderate alcohol consumption (1 standard unit per day for 12 months) and abstinence (no alcohol beverages for 12 months). The primary outcome measure is the change in left ventricular ejection fraction between the baseline visit and 12-month visit.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Lactulose for bowel preparation in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked clinical trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (Lactulose) or the active comparator group (3L-polyethylene glycol). The primary outcome measures include the effective preparation rate, incidence of adverse events, and taste score evaluated by patients. Secondary outcome measures include the effects of bowel preparation drugs on liver function and serum electrolyte levels. The study will assess the efficacy and safety of Lactulose for bowel preparation in patients with IBD.

The study aims to investigate the effects of aromatherapy on sleep quality and quality of life of older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community. The study is a longitudinal, randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment design. The experimental group received aromatherapy, an intervention using lavender essential oil compound, while the control group received a placebo, sweet almond oil. The primary outcome measures include the quality of sleep and quality of life of the elderly people at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community bases participating in aromatherapy. The study will be conducted in two community bases in the East District of Hsinchu City, and a total of 64 elderly people will be recruited. The expected results show that older adults in the experimental group (use aromatherapy) have better sleep and quality of life than those who use placebo.

The study is evaluating the effectiveness of intraoral and transcutaneous injection of botulinum toxin in the masseter muscle for the treatment of myofascial pain. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked trial with two arms: active comparator (transcutaneous injection) and active comparator (intraoral injection). The primary outcome measure is pain score assessed using a 10-point visual analogue scale (VAS) at 6 weeks post-injection, and secondary outcome measures include (OHIP-14) scale at 6 weeks post-injection. The study includes participants aged 18-60 years with a definite diagnosis of myofascial pain and no history of invasive procedures in the related masseter muscle.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and does not include any external information.

The OptimizeD study aims to determine whether different patients respond differentially to brief psychological treatment or a widely used generic SSRI and, if so, whether one can optimize outcomes in a cost-efficient fashion for primary care patients with moderate to severe depression. The study will use machine learning to develop a precision treatment rule (PTR) based on a wide range of clinical, socio-economic, and neuro-cognitive characteristics measured at baseline as predictors. The investigators hypothesize that patients randomized by chance to their optimal intervention will be more likely to remit and recover than patients who are not.

Keywords: depression, primary care, optimization, precision treatment rule, machine learning, cost-effectiveness.

This study aims to investigate the interactions between immune cells and the microbiome in the lungs of patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study will collect blood, oral, and nasal swabs, and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid from 40 patients with ARDS. The study will measure the composition of the immune cell population, the function and differentiation of various cell lines, the microbiome in the lungs, and the auto-antibodies against tI-IFNs in the blood. The study will also assess the trans-compartmental fluxes, white blood cells counts, cytokines, and number and characterizations of respiratory pathogens and microorganisms.

The study will be conducted in 20 patients with none-to-mild and 20 with moderate-to-severe ARDS according to the Berlin definition. The study will be performed within 72 hours after intubation and again after 7-10 days if the patient is still intubated. The study will be conducted in the intensive care unit (ICU) at Hvidovre Hospital.

The study will use single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) on selected immune cells from bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, endotracheal aspirate, and blood, and bulk RNA sequencing with sample barcoding and multiplexing to give a detailed expression pattern of all samples. The study will also use targeted amplicon sequencing of the hyper-variable regions 1 through 3 of the 16S subunit of ribosomal RNA gene for bacteria to assess the composition microbiome in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, endotracheal aspirate, and oral swabs.

The study will be performed by the Department of Respiratory Medicine at Hvidovre Hospital, and the data will be analyzed by the Department of Clinical Bioinformatics at the University of Copenhagen. The study will be conducted in collaboration with the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF).

The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol will be approved by the Danish Data Protection Agency. The study will be conducted in compliance with Good

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effects of 3D printed foot orthoses versus prefabricated foot orthoses in flatfoot subjects. The study will recruit healthy adults with flexible flat feet and randomly assign them to either the experimental or control group. The primary outcome measures will be visual analog scale for pain and Quebec user evaluation of satisfaction with assistive technology questionnaire. The study will help in identifying which insoles are better in terms of parameters described above.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, capturing the key aspects of the trial. It does not explain how the summary was generated.

This is a cross-sectional study that aims to compare the pulmonary ventilation function between patients with primary and recurrent incisional hernia. The study included 100 patients with abdominal incisional hernia, of which 50 had primary hernia and 50 had recurrent hernia. The study found that patients with recurrent hernia had worse pulmonary ventilation function compared to those with primary hernia. The study also found that patients with recurrent hernia were more likely to experience recurrence after repair than those with primary hernia.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and does not include any external sources or opinions.

The study aims to determine the frequency and evolution of unstable coronary plaques in patients presenting to the emergency department with chest pain suspected of coronary artery disease. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of a primary cardiovascular prevention strategy initiated by the care team and compare the symptoms evolution of the study cohort with an historical local cohort. The study will also compare the rate of occurrence of cardiovascular events of interest between the study cohort and the historical cohort. The study will use 18F-Na PET scans to evaluate the evolution of coronary plaques over 8 months.

The study aims to investigate the association between different pathological mechanisms in cerebral small vessel disease (SVD) and the shape of white matter hyperintensities (WMH). The study will include 50 patients from the memory or geriatric clinic of the Leiden University Medical Center or the Alrijne Hospital Leiden, who will undergo 3T and 7T MRI scans, as well as neuropsychological assessments. The primary outcome measure will be the association between WMH shape and other SVD markers and cognition, which will be investigated using linear and logistic regression. The study will also measure brain clearance, perivascular space volume, and WMH subtypes as secondary outcome measures. The keywords provided by the Centre Hospitalier Valida are dementia, cerebral small vessel disease, White matter hyperintensities, cognitive impairment, cognitive decline, and Glymphatics.

The study aims to evaluate the clinical auxiliary value of an intelligent endoscopic diagnosis system developed and verified based on deep learning for the diagnosis of esophagogastric junctional adenocarcinoma. The system will be compared with endoscopists of different levels to determine its sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value, positive predictive value, and accuracy.

Endoscopic images of patients with esophageal gastric junction adenocarcinoma will be used for training and verification of the AI model. The study will enroll patients aged 18-75 years and will include both men and women. The study will be conducted at a single center and will follow a case-control design.

The primary outcome measures will be sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value, positive predictive value, and accuracy of the AI model compared to endoscopists of different levels. The study will be conducted over a period of 36 months.

The study is an open-label, single-group assignment, non-masked clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of FRSW107, a recombinant human coagulation factor Ⅷ-Fc fusion protein, in pediatric patients with severe hemophilia A. The study includes participants aged 1-12 years old, and the primary outcome measures are the number of bleeding episodes during the treatment period and the annual rate of spontaneous joint bleeding and traumatic joint bleeding. The study also assesses the incidence of positive FⅧ inhibitor, Cmax, Tmax, and FⅧ activity drops to 10%, 5%, 3%, and 1% time. The study is designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of FRSW107 in pediatric patients with severe hemophilia A.

The study aims to assess the differences in acceptability of music therapy sessions played live and a recording thereof at the palliative care ward of the University Hospital Zurich. The study will use a randomized controlled design with a crossover assignment and open-label. The primary outcome measures will be the intervention-specific acceptability questionnaire based on the theoretical framework of acceptability, Edmonton Symptom Assessment System, European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire 15 Palliative Care, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale, qualitative open questions for patients, heart rate, heart rate variability, electrodermal activity (μS; skin conductance response), and temperature. The study will recruit patients with established diagnosis of a metastatic cancer/severe illness with limited life expectancy on a palliative care ward at the University Hospital Zurich.

Note: This summary is a simplified version of the provided clinical trial document and does not include all the details or technical terms used in the original document.

The study aims to determine the effect of reusing operative supplies on cataract surgery and climate change. The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the use of sterilization methods and the reuse of gowns in one arm with the use of the same steps except that the surgeon changed the glove only and used alcohol for hand sterilization before and after wearing the next glove in another arm. The primary outcome measures are the rate of postoperative complications, including infection.

The study includes adults with cataract who are not diabetic or hypertensive and excludes young, diabetic, or hypertensive participants. The study plan includes a detailed description of the interventions and outcomes measures, as well as the inclusion and exclusion criteria.

The study findings may have important implications for the practice of ophthalmology and the reduction of environmental waste. By reusing operative supplies, the study aims to demonstrate that cataract surgery can be performed at a lower cost and with less environmental impact.

The study is a randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy and safety of deep transcranial magnetic stimulation (dTMS) targeting the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) in the treatment of adults with anorexia nervosa (AN). The study is conducted at multiple centers in China and includes 80 participants randomly assigned to either the dTMS treatment group or the sham dTMS group. The primary outcome measure is body mass index (BMI), and secondary outcome measures include eating disorder examination questionnaire (EDE-Q6.0), eating disorder inventory (EDI-II), beck depression inventory (BDI), and beck anxiety inventory (BAI). The study is designed to evaluate the near-term and long-term efficacy and safety of dTMS treatment in AN patients.

This study aims to assess the acceptability of expanded newborn screening to parents in France, with or without genetics in the first line. The study will use a mixed-methods design, including an online self-administered questionnaire and semi-structured interviews, to measure parental acceptability and explore parental representations on the extension of newborn screening. The study will recruit parents of newborns, as well as parents of children with a suspicious newborn screening result that was confirmed at the diagnosis phase, and parents of children diagnosed later based on clinical signs for diseases not included in the list of diseases screened in French newborn screening, but included in the list of diseases screened in newborn screening in other countries. The study will measure primary outcome measures such as mixed matrix of parental acceptability dimensions of expanded newborn screening, and secondary outcome measures such as parental acceptability scores for expanded newborn screening, typology of parental acceptability scores for expanded newborn screening, measure of importance given to different modalities of information about newborn screening, parent opinion on newborn screening for Spinal Muscular Atrophy, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, BRCA-related breast and ovarian cancer predisposition syndrome and congenital long QT, parent's views on the use of genetic testing in expanded newborn screening, and description of acceptability of expanded newborn screening to parents of a sick child.

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of remote T'ai Chi and Qigong rehabilitation for low back pain. The study will enroll 18 years and older individuals who have experienced low back pain for the last 6 weeks or longer and will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (remote T'ai Chi and Qigong rehabilitation) or the active comparator group (usual care). The primary outcome measure is the change in the Oswestry Disability Index at 3 months after intervention, and secondary outcome measures include change in visual analogue scale for low back pain, change in VAS leg pain, and the SF-36, Short Form Health Survey questionnaire. The study will be conducted remotely and will include a 12-week, twice-per-week t'ai chi and qigong gentle movement and meditation program.

This observational cohort study aims to capture clinical information on participants living with HIV who received CD19-directed CAR T cell therapy for B-cell lymphoid malignancies outside of a clinical trial between August 30, 2017, and August 31, 2021. The study will measure the rate of toxicities related to CAR19 therapy, change in CD4 count, absolute lymphocyte count, HIV viral load, overall response, and complete remission. The study will enroll participants aged 18 years or older who have a documented history of HIV infection and received CD19-directed CAR T cell therapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, high-grade B-cell lymphoma, transformed follicular lymphoma, or primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The Prospective Evaluation of AI R&D Tool for Patient Stratification - Mechanism of Action Evaluation in Triple Negative Breast Cancer (PEAR-MET) is a UK-based observational study that aims to discover novel predictive biomarkers for triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) patients. The study will evaluate the mechanism of action of the Pear Bio's test in predicting treatment response and prognosis. The study will enroll patients with advanced or metastatic TNBC who are due to start a new line of systemic therapy. Participants will undergo a mandatory biopsy and provide 40ml of blood for omics analysis. The study will measure the functional dose of each commonly used FDA approved therapeutic/combination, complete response rate correlation accuracy, PFS prediction accuracy, and OS prediction accuracy. The study will use computer vision, cell culture, microtumor, functional testing, and predictive biomarker to evaluate the mechanism of action of the Pear Bio's test.

This study aims to investigate the impact of delayed surgery on health economy and quality of life in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study will compare the outcomes of patients who have undergone elective surgery with those who have delayed surgery due to various reasons. The study will also examine the socioeconomic differences in delayed surgery and assess the impact of waiting time on the outcome of surgery.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to investigate the non-immunological functions of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study will assess the pro-tumor functions of MDSCs isolated from lung cancer patients and their cross talks with cancer stem cells. The study will also evaluate the modifications of phenotype and functions of lung cancer cell lines when exposed to MDSCs extracted from patient tumor tissue. The study will be conducted in vitro and will include functional in vitro studies of the effect of MDSCs on the phenotype and function of lung cancer cell lines. The study will enroll consecutive patients with lung carcinoma who are surgically treated by surgery only. The study will collect tumor samples at the time of surgery and will measure the primary outcome measures at the time of surgery only. The study will use key terms related to the study such as lung cancer, immunosuppression, immuno-oncology, antitumor immune escape, and invasion.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of substituting unsweetened sparkling water for sugar-sweetened beverages in reducing added sugar intake and its impact on adolescents' sweetness perception, glycemic control, insulin sensitivity, and cardiovascular risk factors. The study will enroll overweight/obese adolescents aged 10-21 years who are high consumers of SSB. Participants will be randomly assigned to the experimental group, which will receive unsweetened sparkling water, or the control group, which will continue consuming SSB. The study will measure the change in 2-hour glucose concentration, dietary consumption of SSB and sparkling water, insulin sensitivity, glycemic variability, flavor perception of beverage sweetness, blood pressure, blood triglycerides, and waist circumference at 0, 12 weeks.

The study's primary outcome measures are changes in 2-hour glucose concentration, dietary consumption of SSB and sparkling water, insulin sensitivity, glycemic variability, and flavor perception of beverage sweetness. Secondary outcome measures include changes in blood pressure, blood triglycerides, and waist circumference. The study will assess the effectiveness of substituting unsweetened sparkling water for SSB in reducing added sugar intake and improving metabolic health in adolescents.

The study is a randomized, monocentric, double-blinded, prospective clinical trial that aims to evaluate the early wound healing after the utilization of NOVOSYN® Quick versus MONOSYN® Quick suture material in resective periodontal surgery. The study will enroll adult patients undergoing resective periodontal surgery, and the primary outcome measure will be the early wound healing score (EHS) evaluated at 10 ± 5 days postoperatively. Secondary outcome measures include the number of patients showing postoperative wound dehiscence, dentinal hypersensitivity, oral candidiasis, angular cheilitis, swelling, bleeding, infection, systemic complications, pain assessment, satisfaction of the patient, and bacterial contamination of the thread (optional). The study will assess the handling of the suture material intraoperatively and the overall outcome of the study will be evaluated based on the results of the primary and secondary outcome measures.

In this study, the researchers aim to establish a newborn screening program for cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria. The study will test 200,000 newborns for two mutations in the CTNS gene and one mutation in the PH1 gene and PH 3. The study will also measure the number of newborns with confirmed diagnosis of cystinosis, the number of newborns with heterozygous mutations, and the patients with PH1 and PH3. The study will use molecular-based newborn screening, which is increasingly feasible due to advances in DNA extraction, PCR, and sequencing technologies. The study will help to determine the feasibility and effectiveness of molecular-based newborn screening for cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of negative pressure drainage in reducing surgical site infection in patients undergoing intra-abdominal surgery. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted at the Department of Surgery, Ramathibodi Hospital. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (negative pressure drainage) or the control group (no pressure drain). The primary outcome measure is the rate of surgical site infection, which will be assessed at post-operation days 3, 5, 7, and 14. Secondary outcome measures include length of hospital stay, quality of life, and other relevant clinical data. The study will be masked and the data will be analyzed using appropriate statistical methods.

The study compares the immune modulation effects of three CDK4, 6 inhibitors (palbociclib, ribociclib, and abemaciclib) in neoadjuvant treatment for early ER+/HER2- breast cancer. The study aims to collect tumor tissue, blood, and stool samples prospectively before treatment, at 2 weeks after treatment, and after 12 weeks of treatment at the time of surgery. Immune modulation effects will be compared between three treatment groups from breast tumor RNAseq analysis. The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study.

The study is an open-pilot trial that aims to develop and test a dementia care intervention for people living with dementia (PLWD) and their caregivers in two home-based primary care (HBPC) practices. The intervention, called Dementia Care Quality at Home, consists of a standardized assessment tool, seven modules to optimize the well-being of PLWD and their caregivers, and regular team-based review of persons participating in the program to address care challenges. The study will assess the feasibility, acceptability, and fidelity of the intervention in the two HBPC practices and evaluate the impact of the intervention on caregiver well-being.

Keywords: dementia, caregiver stress, home-based primary care, intervention, quality of life.

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of resistance training and flexibility training on postpartum depression symptoms, self-efficacy, and maternal quality of life. The study will enroll 36 postpartum females, aged 20-40 years, who are primiparous or multiparous, and will be divided into two groups: resistance training and flexibility training. The interventions will be conducted twice a week for 8 weeks, and the primary outcome measures will be exercise self-efficacy, Epidemiological studies Depression scale, and MAPP-QOL (Maternal Postpartum Quality Life Questionnaire). The study will be conducted at Jinnah Hospital Lahore, Family Health hospital, and Johar town.

This is a cross-over clinical study that aims to compare the surface hardness and wear resistance of prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth. The study includes 30 participants who are completely edentulous and aged between 55-65 years. The participants are randomly assigned to either prefabricated or CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth group, and the study measures the surface hardness and wear resistance of the denture teeth at insertion and after 6 months of use.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study compares the effects of using different anesthetics (propofol and sevoflurane) on the prognosis of primary tumors and its mechanism of action. The study involves 180 patients undergoing surgery for brain, liver, lung, or ovarian cancer. The patients are randomly assigned to either the propofol or sevoflurane group. The primary outcome measures include overall survival, presence of disease progression, and Karnofsky performance status score. Secondary outcome measures include postoperative complications, length of hospital stays, and other postoperative complications. The study aims to investigate the mechanism of action of propofol and sevoflurane on the prognosis of primary tumors.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a co-created intervention to promote physical activity-related health competence among nursing students in Bavaria, Germany. The intervention is based on a cooperative planning approach and involves the development of tailored interventions for each school. The study will assess the effectiveness of the intervention on physical activity-related health competence, general health status, work ability, musculoskeletal complaints, and physical job stress in nursing at both short-term and medium-term follow-ups. The study will also evaluate the acceptability and feasibility of the intervention and provide insights into the process of co-creation and implementation.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled clinical trial to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Diosmin/Hesperidin combination in patients with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). The study will enroll 120 patients and will be conducted over a period of 4 months. The primary outcome measures will be the improvement of inflammation, glycemic index, PCOS status levels, and patient's quality of life.

The study will be conducted at a single center and will be led by a principal investigator. The study will be conducted in accordance with the ethical principles of the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study will be conducted in two phases. The first phase will involve a 2-week screening period, during which time the patients will be assessed for eligibility. The second phase will involve a 4-month treatment period, during which time the patients will be randomly assigned to one of three treatment groups: active comparator, experimental, or active comparator + metformin.

The primary outcome measures will be measured at the end of the 4-month treatment period. The study will also collect secondary outcome measures, including the improvement of PCOS status levels, improvement of patient's quality of life, and the safety of the treatment.

The study will be conducted in a double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled design. The patients will be randomly assigned to one of the three treatment groups using a computer-generated randomization schedule. The study will be masked, and the patients will not know which group they are assigned to.

The study will be conducted at a single center, and the patients will be recruited from the outpatient clinic. The study will be conducted in accordance with the ethical principles of the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study will be conducted in a parallel-group design, and the patients will be randomly assigned to one of the three treatment groups. The study will be masked, and the patients will not know which group they are assigned to.
