The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of using a fluorescent visualization system for non-visible lung cancer nodules during minimally invasive surgery. The system uses a near-infrared (NIR) fluorescent dye to highlight cancerous tissue, allowing for more accurate and efficient detection and treatment of lung cancer. The study will enroll patients with clinical stage I non-small cell lung cancer who are candidates for minimally invasive surgical resection. Participants will receive the study drug, cetuximab-IRDye800, intravenously before surgery. The primary outcome measures will be the detection of lung nodules during surgery by NIR camera and the lymph node detection of metastatic disease during surgery by NIR camera. Secondary outcome measures will include the unexpected cancer localization during surgery by NIR camera, negative surgical margins with respect to the pathology report, detection speed, and toxicity incidence.

The SPARROW trial is a multicenter, randomized controlled trial evaluating the additional value of pre-emptive antibiotic treatment on clinically relevant organ/space surgical site infections (OSIs) in patients undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy with a high risk for contaminated bile. The study compares perioperative versus pre-emptive antibiotic treatment during five postoperative days in 304 evaluable patients. The primary outcome measure is the rate of clinically relevant OSI between patients with perioperative versus prolonged antibiotic prophylaxis. Secondary outcome measures include the rate of organ/space infection, isolated OSI, superficial incisional SSI, postoperative pancreatic fistula, bile leakage, post pancreatectomy hemorrhage, delayed gastric emptying, postoperative bacteremia, Clostridium difficile infection, major complications, reinterventions, ICU admission, length of hospital stay, readmissions, and in-hospital and 90-days mortality. The study is designed as a superiority trial with a power of 80%, a two-sided significance level of 5.0%, and an expected number of 322 included patients to demonstrate superiority for the intervention.

This is a Phase 2 basket trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination of sotorasib and panitumumab in patients with advanced solid tumors carrying the KRAS G12C mutation. The study will enroll approximately 100 patients and will be conducted at multiple sites in the United States. The primary outcome measure is objective response rate based on RECIST v1.1, which will be assessed through imaging tumor assessment at the time point after Cycle 1 Day 1.

Eligibility criteria include patients aged 19 years or older with histologically confirmed locally advanced or metastatic solid tumors (excluding non-small cell lung cancer and colorectal cancer) with KRAS G12C mutation detected through local next-generation sequencing analysis. Patients must have measurable lesions according to RECIST v1.1 and Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 to 2. Exclusion criteria include patients who have not received previous sotorasib treatment or monoclonal antibodies against epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) such as cetuximab or panitumumab, absence of active brain metastasis or leptomeningeal metastasis, significant cardiovascular events within the past 6 months, history of stroke within the past 6 months, and other malignancies within 2 years prior to enrollment.

The study will be conducted in an open-label manner, and the primary outcome measure will be objective response rate based on RECIST v1.1. The study plan includes a single group assignment, no masking, and no planned major surgery during the clinical trial. The study will enroll approximately 100 patients and will be conducted at multiple sites in the United States.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, controlled clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a novel volume-stable collagen matrix (VCMX) in the treatment of single gingival recession associated with non-carious cervical lesion partially restored. The study will enroll 40 participants and will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The primary outcome measure is the reduction in gingival recession depth, and secondary outcome measures include dentine hypersensitivity, patient-centered esthetic evaluation, oral health impact profile, patient discomfort, number of analgesics, percentage of complete combined defect coverage, modification of the root coverage esthetic score, and clinical parameters. The study will be conducted over a period of 180 days, and the results will be analyzed using descriptive statistics and inferential statistics.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of different nutritional support modes based on nutritional risk screening on the postoperative nutritional status of patients with gastrointestinal cancer. The study will compare the changes of various nutritional indicators between the intervention group and control group before and after propensity score matching.

Intervention/Treatment: 
The intervention group received malnutrition five-step treatment model + conventional nutritional intervention, while the control group received conventional nutritional intervention.

Outcome Measures: 
The study will measure the changes of nutritional risk screening 2002, patient-generated subjective nutrition assessment, dietary energy intake, dietary protein intake, nutrient energy intake, nutrient protein intake, prealbumin, albumin, hemoglobin, BMI, fat-free body weight, grip strength, and walking time between the two groups before and after propensity score matching.

Study Design: 
The study is designed as an open-label, non-randomized, parallel-assignment, and propensity score-matched controlled trial.

Participants: 
The study will enroll 302 patients with gastrointestinal cancer who are admitted to the First Hospital of Shanxi Medical University from July 2021 to June 2023.

Masking: 
The study is an open-label trial, and there is no masking of the participants or the intervention.

Arms and Interventions: 
The study will have two arms: the intervention group and the control group. The intervention group will receive malnutrition five-step treatment model + conventional nutritional intervention, while the control group will receive conventional nutritional intervention.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of the abutment-prosthesis connection on marginal bone loss and gingival sealing around dental implants. The study includes 2 arms: experimental (Connect®) and active comparator (Multi-unit). The primary outcome measures are marginal bone level and peri-implant microbiome, evaluated at 1 year. Secondary outcome measures include peri-implant inflammation, evaluated at 1 year. The study includes 180 participants with edentulous mandibles requiring 2 implants to restore at least 2 molars, 2 molars and 1 premolar, or 2 premolars and 1 molar.

This is a clinical trial that aims to compare the measurements of blood flow in the brain using a wearable ultrasound patch and a conventional transcranial Doppler probe. The study will enroll 60 participants and measure the agreement between the two devices on the blood flow spectrum of different arterial segments. The primary outcome measure is the clinical feasibility of the non-invasive ultrasound patch in comparison to the conventional transcranial Doppler probe.

This is a single-group assignment, open-label clinical trial that aims to evaluate the clearance rate of uremic toxins by hemodiafiltration (HFR) in maintenance hemodialysis patients. The study includes 18-75 years old patients who have been on hemodialysis for at least 3 months and have a vascular access of autogenous arteriovenous fistula or artificial blood vessels with a blood flow ≥200mL/min. The primary outcome measures are the concentrations of β2-microglobulin (β2-MG), indoxyl sulfate, and λ-free light chain (λFLC) before and after HFR, and the secondary outcome measures include spKt/V, Urea Reduction Ratio, other middle molecules and macromolecular uremic, serum albumin, branched chain amino acids, and vitamins A, C, E, and the comfort of HFR treatment.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, controlled clinical trial to assess the effects of 20% human albumin infusions on coagulation parameters in patients with decompensated cirrhosis of the liver. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted over a period of 1 year. The primary outcome measures will be changes in clotting time, clot formation time, and maximum clot formation in both groups, measured at 1 week. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in inflammatory parameters, endothelial dysfunction, pulmonary function, renal function, adverse effects, and the albuminome. The study will also assess the duration of hospital stay and mortality at 28 days.

The study population will consist of all patients aged 18-70 years with decompensated cirrhosis of any cause and serum albumin levels ≤ 2.5 g/dl upon presentation. The study will be conducted at the Institute of Liver and Biliary Sciences, New Delhi.

The study will be conducted in two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental arm will receive 20% human albumin infusions to raise and maintain serum albumin levels above 3.0 g/dl, while the active comparator arm will receive standard of care. The study will be masked (open-label) and the participants will be randomly assigned to either group.

The primary outcome measures will be measured at 1 week, and the secondary outcome measures will be measured at 7 days. The study will also assess the duration of hospital stay and mortality at 28 days.

The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year, and the expected outcome of the project is to derange the ROTEM in the group of patients receiving human albumin solution.

This is a prospective study that aims to evaluate the significance of minimal residual disease (MRD) monitoring in patients with potentially resectable stage III non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study involves 65 patients who are enrolled in the study for 1 year, followed up for 2 years, and the study lasts for 3 years. The patients are followed up for 2 years according to the standard diagnosis and treatment path, with a total of 9 times of follow-up. The study measures the disease-free survival (RECIST), overall survival, prediction of recurrence by positive MRD, pCR rate of MRD-negative patient, negative MRD rate in pCR patients, and 2-year DFS of ctDNA-negative patients in operation group / inoperable group. The study is designed with two arms, and the interventions are immunotherapy alone or chemotherapy combined with immunotherapy. The study is conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a single-center prospective cohort study comparing the use of ciprofol and propofol for sedation in hypotensive ICU patients. The study aims to determine the efficacy and safety of these two drugs in sedating ICU patients and to evaluate their impact on various clinical outcomes.

Keywords: Ciprofol, Propofol, Sedation, Low Blood Pressure, Norepinephrine.

This is a multicenter randomized controlled trial in single blind, in two parallel arms, in ratio 1:1, of superiority. The study aims to evaluate the intermediate effectiveness of laparoscopy on the inflammatory reaction of premature newborns with complicated ECUN, requiring surgical treatment. The study will compare laparoscopy plus laparotomy versus laparotomy alone. The main objective is to evaluate the inflammatory response Day 2 postoperative in preterm infants with ECUN who have undergone surgery. The study will also evaluate the tolerance of laparoscopy, the postoperative biological inflammatory reaction, specific post-operative biological inflammatory reaction, postoperative mortality, postoperative intestinal morbidity, postoperative reoperation rate, length of hospitalization, medium-term postoperative neurological morbidity, oxygen saturation (SaO2), hypercapnia (pCO2), blood pressure (BP), cerebral oxygenation (Near InfraRed Spectroscopy (NIRS)), presence of loco-regional lesions related to the insertion of the trocar.

The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial comparing the effectiveness of intense pulsed light and diode laser for hair removal in the axilla region. The study will enroll 40 female participants who will receive 4 treatments with either intense pulsed light or diode laser, with a follow-up at 30 days and 6 months after the last treatment. The primary outcome measures are hair count, global aesthetic improvement scale, hair thickness, pain score, quality of life, satisfaction level, and self-esteem scale. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of both treatments in removing hair from the axilla region.

The PRecisiOn Medicine In StrokE (PRECISE) study aims to evaluate the evolution of plasma brain-derived tau (BD-tau) levels in acute ischemic stroke patients. The study will assess BD-tau levels every hour from admission to 48 hours after onset in 100 patients with acute ischemic stroke due to a large- or medium-vessel occlusion within 9 hours of symptom onset. The study will also collect clinical data and perform neuroimaging throughout hospitalization and clinical follow-up at 3 months. The primary outcome measures are plasma BD-tau levels, and the study will characterize the time point when BD-tau levels start to rise after onset, the type of rise, and until when BD-tau levels continue to rise. Secondary outcome measures include ASPECTS on non-contrast CT, ischemic core volume on CT perfusion, regional leptomeningeal collateral score on CT angiography, final infarct volume, infarct progression, 90-day functional outcome, 7-day functional outcome, early recurrent ischemic stroke, secondary intracerebral hemorrhage, and hemorrhagic transformation. The study aims to provide valuable insights into the pathophysiology of acute ischemic stroke and the potential use of BD-tau as a biomarker for brain injury.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of artificial intelligence in accelerating the learning curve for mastering contrast-enhanced ultrasound of thyroid nodules. The study will enroll patients with thyroid nodules and will use artificial intelligence to assist radiologists in extracting ultrasound features of thyroid nodules. The primary outcome measures will be the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve, the number of cases, and the time it takes to complete the assessment. The study will be conducted in three phases, with the first phase starting in January 2022 and ending in June 2023.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of AI-powered artificial vision in improving the perceptual experiences of retinal and cortical prosthesis patients. The study will involve basic experimental studies involving humans (BESH) designed to quantify the perceptual experiences of retinal and cortical prosthesis patients. The investigators will produce visual percepts in patients either by directly stimulating electrodes or by asking them to view a computer or projector screen and using standard stimulation protocols to convert the computer or projector screen image into pulse trains on their electrodes. The study will test the ability of different stimulus encoding methods to support simple perceptual and behavioral tasks such as object recognition and navigation.

The study will involve collecting behavioral data and measuring performance in normally sighted control subjects viewing stimuli manipulated to match the expected perceptual experience of prosthesis patients. The study will also involve measuring eye position and collecting data on the ability to locate objects of interest and relay accurate descriptions of the visual scene.

The study will be conducted over an average of 1 year and will involve up to 5 sessions, each carried out on different testing days. The study will involve a single group assignment with no masking and an open-label design. The study will accept healthy volunteers and will involve both male and female participants.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will adhere to the principles of Good Clinical Practice. The study will be approved by the institutional review board and will obtain informed consent from all participants.

The study will be conducted at the [Institution Name] and will involve collaboration with [Collaborator Name]. The study will be led by [PI Name] and will involve a team of experienced researchers and technicians.

The study will use various experimental techniques including same-different, method of adjustment, 2-alternative-forced choice, and identification. The study will also use eye-tracking equipment to measure eye position and collect data on eye blinks.

The study will involve collecting data on a range of outcome measures including phosphene shape, pattern discrimination accuracy, scene understanding performance, and more. The study will analyze the data using statistical methods and will report the results in a comprehensive manuscript.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of ultrasound surveillance in detecting nodal metastasis in patients with primary high-risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck. The study will enroll participants based on their BWH stage and immunosuppression status. Participants will undergo ultrasound surveillance every 6 months and regular visits every 3 months throughout the duration of the study (2 years). The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with nodal metastasis, and secondary outcome measures include the number of participants with local recurrence of squamous cell carcinoma, disease-specific death, and overall survival rate. The study will compare the time to nodal metastasis between the ultrasound surveillance group and historical controls using Kaplan-Meier estimates and Cox proportional-hazards regression.

The study aims to investigate the use of salivary biomarkers for the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux (GER) in infants. The study will enroll infants aged 1-12 months with symptoms of GER or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and will collect saliva samples during a 24-hour esophageal pH monitoring (MII-pH) test. The primary outcome measure is the prevalence of GERD symptoms in the cohort of infants, and secondary outcome measures include the comparison of the biochemical profile of saliva samples from healthy infants, GER infants, and GERD patients, as well as the correlation between symptom onset and nutrition.

The study is a prospective open-label observational study conducted in Greece, comparing the effect of Empagliflozin and Dulaglutide on liver fat fraction in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The study aims to assess the change in liver fat fraction, HbA1c, body mass index, fatty liver index, fibrosis-4 index, aspartate aminotransferase to platelet ratio index, and NAFLD fibrosis score after 52 weeks of treatment with Empagliflozin, Dulaglutide, or control treatment (apart from agents of the GLP1-ras or SGLT2-is families). The study includes 3 groups: Empagliflozin, Dulaglutide, and control. The primary outcome measure is the change in liver fat fraction, and the study also assesses secondary outcome measures such as HbA1c, body mass index, fatty liver index, fibrosis-4 index, aspartate aminotransferase to platelet ratio index, and NAFLD fibrosis score.

The study aims to assess the feasibility of surgical exposure of palatally impacted upper canines with open-eruption technique using a surgical template. The study will compare this method with the conventional free-hand surgical exposure. The study will recruit 20 patients per group and will measure the success of the intervention, success of the open eruption technique, surplus costs of surgical planning and manufacturing the surgical guide, duration of the surgical intervention, postoperative pain, and intra- and postoperative complications associated with surgery. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year.

The Clinician-Assisted Videofeedback Exposure-Approach Therapy (CAVEAT) Trial is an open-trial feasibility study aimed at determining the feasibility of administering a brief manualized psychotherapy for traumatized mothers and their young children in an ambulatory care center. The study will assess the feasibility of recruitment procedures, adherence to treatment, therapeutic alliance, and satisfaction among participants. The study will also evaluate the appropriateness, adequacy, and sensitivity of evaluation measures, including questionnaires and observed interactions. The study will enroll 12 participant-dyads and will be conducted at the CHUV, a public university-hospital. The intervention will consist of CAVEAT, a brief psychotherapy that involves clinician-assisted videofeedback exposure sessions. The study will assess the primary outcome measures of treatment satisfaction, parenting stress, and maternal attributions, as well as secondary outcome measures of interpersonal violence, PTSD, and attachment.

The HAPPY study is a randomized controlled trial and follow-up study conducted in Singapore to assess the effectiveness of a holistic lifestyle digital intervention in preventing Type 2 diabetes in Asian women with a history of gestational diabetes. The study aims to identify post-GDM women and assess the efficacy of the intervention on glucose regulation, as well as to examine the potential impacts of the intervention on the health and wellbeing of subjects' family members, including their children. The study will be conducted over a period of one year, with a 3-year follow-up period, and will include various outcome measures such as glucose tolerance changes, anthropometric measurements, blood pressure, biosample collection, biosample collection (fasting blood, saliva, buccal swab, stool), bioelectrical impedance analysis, depression, anxiety, health status, sleep, lifestyle, and social-emotional development (children).

The study aims to investigate the effect of dry heat and dry cold application on pain, anxiety, and fear levels before blood sampling in school-age children. The study is a randomized controlled trial with three groups: the control group, the dry heat application group, and the dry cold application group. The study will evaluate the primary outcome measures, including Wong Baker Faces Pain Rating Scale, Child Fear Scale, and Child Anxiety Scale, at one minute after blood sampling, two minutes before and after blood sampling, and three minutes after blood sampling. The study will also assess the secondary outcome measures, including Medical Procedures Fear Inventory. The study will be conducted by a pediatric nurse, and the data will be collected between 7-12 years old school-age children.

The study is a phase I clinical trial that aims to assess the safety profile of chemoreduction with intra-arterial melphalan followed by Ru-106 plaque brachytherapy in patients with clinically diagnosed choroidal melanoma with tumor thickness equal to or greater than 8.00 mm. The study will evaluate the primary outcome measures of treatment safety through electroretinography (ERG) and secondary outcome measures such as reduction of tumor size, best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA), signs of intraocular inflammation, treatment-related adverse events, and globe salvage. The study will enroll patients aged 18 years or older and will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in Brazil.

The Trauma Registry in a General Hospital from Villavicencio, Colombia, is an observational retrospective trial that aims to determine the characteristics of patients admitted to the emergency ward by injuries. The study includes patients with blunt or penetrating injuries and will measure the primary outcome of mortality on discharge or within the first 28 days of hospitalization. Secondary outcomes include hospital length of stay, need of ICU, length of ICU stay, need of mechanical ventilation, and length of mechanical ventilation. The study will provide essential information on the severity, mechanisms, type of population affected, immediate or consequential care delivered, and outcomes, which will help prioritize policies, resources, upgrade clinical practice guidelines, and improve results.

This study aims to evaluate the feasibility and safety of a non-invasive postural therapy (NIPT) for older adult veterans with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS). The study will assess the effectiveness of NIPT in improving mobility and reducing symptoms in participants with LSS.

Feasibility: 
The study will assess the feasibility of NIPT in older adult veterans with LSS, including the acceptability of the intervention, the ability to maintain posture, and the impact on mobility and symptoms.

Intervention: 
The intervention is a coordinated suite of DME and training to support continuous maintenance of flexion posture during the 6-week trial.

Participation Criteria: 
Eligible participants must be older adult veterans with LSS who are able to read and write English, understand instructions, and have a diagnosis of LSS as the cause of their symptoms. They must also have symptoms for over 3 months, be able to walk 50 feet without a cane or walker, and have relief of pain (standardly within 5 minutes) by sitting down.

Exclusion Criteria: 
Participants who have previous low back surgery, successful spinal stenosis treatment, or moderate to severe large fiber neuropathy are excluded from the study.

Study Design: 
The study is designed as a single-group assignment with no masking (open label).

Primary Outcome Measures: 
The primary outcome measures are change in mobility by actigraph (positive, negative, or zero) as determined by the difference in mobility at Week 6 compared to baseline.

Overall, this study aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of NIPT in improving mobility and reducing symptoms in older adult veterans with lumbar spinal stenosis.

The study is a pilot, randomized, double-blind, crossover trial to assess the effects of self-administered nitrous oxide (SANO) on urodynamic study (UDS) parameters. The study will enroll healthy volunteers aged 21-85 years who are scheduled for UDS. Participants will undergo two UDS runs, with either SANO or oxygen administered during one run and the other run. The primary outcome measures are bladder capacity, intra-UDS pain, and intra-UDS anxiety. Secondary outcome measures include post void residual, max flow rate, detrusor overactivity, and detrusor pressure at maximum flow. The study aims to determine if SANO has a significant effect on UDS parameters and to evaluate the safety and feasibility of the intervention.

This study aims to investigate the relationship between adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and breast cancer. The study will measure the quality of life of women in remission from breast cancer, as well as other outcomes such as fear of recurrence, fatigue, anxiety and depression, attachment, and resilience. The study will also explore the epigenetic and genetic changes that occur in response to ACEs. The study will include 100 participants and will be conducted over an average of 1 year.

The study is a single-center crossover trial conducted at a hospital in France. The study aims to assess the real-world effectiveness of the DiscoveryTM AI-assisted polyp detector system in detecting colorectal polyps and adenomas during screening colonoscopy. The study will enroll adults aged 45-89 years old who are scheduled for screening colonoscopy. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an experimental group (HD-colonoscopy + AI-HD colonoscopy) or a control group (HD-colonoscopy). The primary outcome measures will be adenoma detection rate (ADR) and polyp detection rate (PDR). The study will also assess the diagnostic performance of the AI-assisted polyp detector system, adenoma miss rate (AMR), and observer agreement. The study will be conducted by expert or non-expert endoscopists, and the results will be compared between the two groups.

The study aims to evaluate the tolerability, seizure frequency, gut bacteria composition, and metabolic pathway alterations of the low glycemic index diet in pregnant people with epilepsy. The study will enroll 21 participants in a 1:2 intervention to control group ratio, with participants choosing to go on the low glycemic index diet or continue their standard diet. Participants will meet with a dietician to initiate the diet and have ongoing dietician support and appointments. The study will collect diet questionnaires and provide a maximum of 3 stool samples and 3 blood samples from participants in the intervention group until 3 months postpartum. The primary outcome measures will be diet tolerability, seizure frequency, gut bacteria composition, and metabolic pathway alterations.

The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of endoscopic ultrasound-guided injection of mesothelin-targeted CAR-T cells in patients with resectable pancreatic cancer. The study will evaluate the pathological response, radiological response, rate of R0 surgical resection, serious adverse events, disease-free survival, and overall survival.

The study will enroll 10 patients with histologically confirmed pancreatic cancer planned for curative resection. The patients will undergo endoscopic ultrasound-guided injection of mesothelin-targeted CAR-T cells. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of major pathologic response on resected specimen of pancreatic tumor, which will be measured 3 months after the injection. Secondary outcome measures include radiological response, rate of R0 surgical resection, serious adverse events, disease-free survival, and overall survival, which will be measured at various time points after the injection.

The study is a feasibility study, and the results will provide valuable insights into the safety and efficacy of mesothelin-targeted CAR-T cells in the treatment of pancreatic cancer. If the results are promising, the study can be expanded to a larger cohort to confirm the findings and establish the efficacy of this approach in clinical practice.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a web-based decision support system (TREAT) in improving adherence to oral anticancer treatments among metastatic breast cancer patients. The study will also identify clinical, psychological, and quality of life predictors of adherence and evaluate the risk perception of patients using visual analog scale. The study is a randomized controlled trial with 100 participants divided into control and intervention groups. The study will be conducted at the European Institute of Oncology (IEO) over a period of 3 months.

The study is designed to evaluate the effects of weight bearing exercises with and without Jaffrey's core stability exercise training on dynamic balance and trunk muscles strength in children with Down syndrome. The study will randomly assign participants to either the experimental group (weight bearing exercises and Jaffrey's core stability exercises) or the control group (weight bearing exercises only). The primary outcome measures will be Pediatric balance scale and trunk control measurement scale. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 weeks.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled clinical trial. The study aims to evaluate the effects of melatonin on cardiovascular and bone metabolism markers in peritoneal dialysis patients. The study will enroll 100 participants and will be conducted over a period of 10 weeks. The primary outcome measures will include Lp (a), MDA, hs-CRP, sICAM-1, glucose, pentosidine, carboxy-methyl lysine, P1NP, Osteoprotegerin, TRACP5b, RANKL, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, triglyceride, total cholesterol, HDL-C, LDL-C, quality of life index (KDQOL) questionnaire, the Beck depression test, and quality of sleep Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures will include albumin, calcium, phosphorous, iPTH.

The study aims to optimize oxygen delivery during cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) by evaluating the effectiveness of a new strategy that uses a device to measure oxygen delivery and adjust it according to the patient's needs. The study will enroll patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery at the University Hospital of Lille, France, and will assess the primary outcome measure of oxygen delivery calculated with the CONNECT software using CPB output and hemoglobin values, as well as secondary outcome measures such as postoperative acute kidney injury, delirium, and vital status. The study will be conducted over a period of 28 days, and the results will be compared to standard care.

The study aims to investigate the changes in lumbar region temperature during auricular acupressure at the Kidney point in healthy volunteers. The study will randomly divide the participants into two groups: AA-SA and SA-AA. The participants will receive either auricular acupressure or sham auricular acupressure, and their temperature changes in the lumbar region will be measured using an infrared thermal imaging camera. The study will also assess the proportion of auricular acupuncture side effects.

The study will be conducted in a controlled environment, and the participants' vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and body temperature, will be continuously monitored. The study will be conducted over a period of 30 minutes, and the participants will be required to acclimate to the environment for 15 minutes before commencement.

The study will be conducted in compliance with the ethical principles of the Declaration of Helsinki and will adhere to the Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The participants will provide informed consent before the study, and their privacy and confidentiality will be maintained throughout the study.

The study will provide valuable insights into the effects of auricular acupressure on the lumbar region temperature in healthy volunteers. The findings of the study will contribute to the existing literature on the use of auricular acupressure for various conditions, including pain management, stress relief, and immune system modulation.

The study will also provide information on the safety and tolerability of auricular acupressure in healthy volunteers. The results of the study will help to establish the optimal parameters for auricular acupressure in future studies, including the duration of treatment, the frequency of treatment, and the intensity of treatment.

In conclusion, the study aims to investigate the changes in lumbar region temperature during auricular acupressure at the Kidney point in healthy volunteers. The study will provide valuable insights into the effects of auricular acupressure on the lumbar region temperature and contribute to the existing literature on the use of auricular acupressure for various conditions.

This is a single-group open-label observational study to assess the acute and subacute effects of furosemide on hemodynamics and pulmonary congestion in patients with acute decompensated heart failure. 80 mg of furosemide is administered intravenously to all participants. The study measures blood pressure, peripheral oxygen saturation, pulmonary fluid content, ultrasound examination of heart and lungs, and assessment of cardiac filling pressures with doppler and strain analysis at multiple time points until 6 hours have elapsed.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a smartphone application in preventing binge drinking among university students. The study will measure the change in the number of standard drinks consumed per week, as well as the concentration of phosphatidylethanol (PEth) in the blood, which is a biomarker of alcohol consumption. The study will enroll students between the ages of 18 and 25 who score high on the Alcohol Use Questionnaire (AUQ) and Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test (AUDIT). The study will be conducted over a period of 30 months and will have two arms: an experimental group that will receive the smartphone application and a control group that will not. The primary outcome measure will be the change in the number of standard drinks consumed per week, and the secondary outcome measures will be the change in PEth concentration in the blood.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, 12-week clinical study to evaluate the potential benefit of nitazoxanide as adjuvant therapy in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The study will enroll 70 participants (35 in each group) who will receive either no intervention (control group) or nitazoxanide 500 mg orally twice daily in addition to metformin and dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors (such as vildagliptin). The primary outcome measure is glycemic control, and secondary outcome measures include insulin resistance, lipid profile, serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1, and serum levels of asprosin.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and does not include any external information.

The study aims to investigate clinical risk factors of autism and to elucidate changes in the gut microbiome in Egyptian autistic children and their possible correlation with clinical outcomes and the severity of the disease. The study will recruit autistic children aged between 3-9 years and their parents will be asked to provide medical history. The study will measure primary outcome measures such as autism clinical risk factors, intestinal microbiome, and metabolome analysis. The study will be designed as a cross-sectional study and will be conducted in Egypt. The study will accept healthy volunteers and will not provide any intervention. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an internet-based self-help money management program in improving financial self-efficacy and associated outcomes among adults with severe mental illness. The program consists of 4 weekly modules, incorporating the key components of money management and the Model of Human Occupation (MOHO). The study will compare the program's efficacy with a wait-list control group. The primary outcome measures include change from baseline assessment in financial self-efficacy, financial behavior, and financial attitude, as well as change from baseline assessment in psychological wellbeing, anxiety symptom, depressive symptom, and quality of life. Treatment adherence, treatment satisfaction, and acceptability of the internet for delivering online programs will also be assessed.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of START (Startle Adjuvant Rehabilitation Therapy) in enhancing arm function post-stroke. The study will assess the capacity of START training to generalize to untrained tasks and evaluate the retention of skill transfer at one-month post-training. The primary outcome measures will include change in EMG onset, amplitude, and movement onset during functional reaching task, and change in functional reaching task scores. Secondary outcome measures will include retention in functional reaching task, skill transfer to sorting and dressing tasks, and retention of skill transfer at one-month post-training. The study will be conducted in a randomized, single-blind, parallel, controlled trial with 30 participants, aged 18-99 years old, with cerebral stroke at least 6 months prior to testing. The study will be conducted in a clinical setting, and the results will have significant implications for the treatment of stroke survivors, particularly those with low socioeconomic status.

The study aims to evaluate the effects of endoscopic lung volume reduction on diaphragm function and conformation in patients with COPD. The study will assess the transdiaphragmatic pressure and diaphragmatic conformation before and 3 months after unilateral valves setting.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to evaluate the clinical performance of three bulk-fill resin composites (Dual-cure, Light-cure, and Tetric N-Ceram Bulk Fill) in Class ӀӀ restorations over a two-year period. The study is a randomized clinical trial with 100 participants, each receiving three Class ӀӀ restorations with one of the three bulk-fill resin composites. The primary outcome measures include esthetic, functional, and biological properties of the restorations, assessed using FDI criteria. The study will provide valuable insights into the clinical performance of bulk-fill resin composites in Class ӀӀ restorations and help dentists make informed decisions when selecting materials for these restorations.

This is a phase II, open-label, randomized, parallel-group study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of 177Lu-DOTATATE versus everolimus in patients with metastatic/unresectable midgut neuroendocrine tumors who have progressed following previous peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT). The study will assess the primary outcome measures of progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), post progression survival (PPS), and time to second objective disease progression (PFS2).

The study compares the effects of Mulligan techniques versus McKenzie extension exercises with manual traction in patients with chronic unilateral radicular low back pain. The study is a randomized controlled trial conducted at Rehab Care and Jinnah Hospital Lahore, from 1st June - 31st January 2024. The study includes 16 patients in each group, aged between 28-50 years, with both genders included. The primary outcome measures are NPRS, Oswestry Disability Scale (ODI), and lumbar Range of Motion. The study aims to evaluate the outcome of Mulligan technique versus McKenzie extension exercise with manual traction in terms of pain reduction and ROM.

The study is a long-term, open-label extension trial evaluating the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of weekly subcutaneous doses of TransCon CNP in children and adolescents with achondroplasia. Participants must have completed a previous clinical trial with TransCon CNP and meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria. The study will assess primary outcome measures such as safety and tolerability, height Z-scores, and annualized growth velocity over an average of 10 years.

This study aims to investigate the impact of illness perceptions, coping strategies on quality of life in patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The study will use an observational design and measure quality of life using the 12-item Short Form Health Survey (SF-12). The study will recruit patients aged 18-75 years with a diagnosis of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and will assess the mediating effects of self-efficacy, coping, depression, and anxiety on quality of life.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The LORENA trial is a clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of local excision for organ preservation in early rectal cancer patients with no adjuvant treatment. The study aims to assess the success rate of local excision, postoperative complication rate, radicality of resection, histological poor outcome predictor rate, and radical rescue surgery specimen quality. The study includes patients diagnosed with rectal cancer and clinical staging cT1N0M0, with the inferior edge of the tumor not further than 2 cm above the anorectal ring. The study will be conducted at multiple participant centers and will follow patients for 36 months.

The study aims to evaluate the impact of center volume-outcome relationship and that on mortality which remain poorly understood in patients undergoing surgery for Type A aortic dissection. The study will measure operative mortality, mesenteric ischemia, permanent neurological deficit, composite of major adverse events, myocardial infarction, acute heart failure, and other outcomes. The study will enroll patients aged 18 years and older who require surgical repair of acute TAAD. The study will use a multicenter registry design and will include patients who will require a conservative prosthetic replacement of the ascending aorta with or without hemiarch repair, ascending aorta replacement with or without aortic valve replacement, ascending aorta replacement with total arch replacement, root and ascending aorta replacement with total arch replacement, or other names. The study will be conducted over 15 years and will include 30-day and in-hospital mortality, as well as long-term outcomes such as reoperation for bleeding, mechanical circulatory support, and late survival.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a virtual reality-based intervention in reducing academic stress and improving academic performance among physiotherapy and nursing students at the University of the Balearic Islands. The study will randomly assign participants to either an experimental group that receives a 4-week virtual reality intervention or an active comparator group that receives a traditional guided visualization intervention. The primary outcome measures will include academic stress and perceived stress levels, measured using the SISCO Inventory and Perceived Stress Scale, respectively, as well as exam qualification. Secondary outcome measures will include blood pressure, heart rate, salivary cortisol level, and arterial tension. The study will take place over 4 weeks, with measurements taken immediately before and after the intervention, and one week after the exam.

The study compares the use of remimazolam and propofol as an induction agent for morbid obesity patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy. The study aims to determine the rate of hypotension events in both groups and evaluate the efficacy and safety of remimazolam as an anesthetic induction dose. The study includes 44 subjects in each group, and the data will be analyzed using a modified intention-to-treat group analysis. The primary outcome measure is the rate of hypotension events during anesthesia induction, and the secondary outcome measures include the induction time and the total amount of vasopressor (ephedrine) used. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked trial.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of darolutamide, leuprolide acetate, and exemestane in patients with recurrent ovarian granulosa cell tumors. The study will measure the objective response rate, duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, and incidence of adverse events. The study will enroll approximately 120 patients and will be conducted at multiple sites in the United States.

This is an observational cohort study using MRI to measure gastrointestinal (GI) function, lung structure and function, and liver endpoints in children with cystic fibrosis (CF) aged 6 to 11 years. The study aims to identify whether these measures are changed before and after starting elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor (ETI) treatment. The study will enroll 12 children with CF and 3 healthy age and gender-matched controls. The study will consist of two phases: a pilot phase and a main phase. In the pilot phase, 3 children with CF and 3 healthy controls will undergo MRI scanning to assess the quality of the images obtained. If successful, the trial will progress to the main phase, where the remaining 12 children with CF will be recruited and undergo the MRI scanning protocol. The study will measure primary outcome measures such as delta small bowel water (DeltaSBW) and secondary outcome measures such as small bowel water content, liver volume, liver elastography, and lung ventilation. The study will also collect validated gastrointestinal questionnaires, GI symptoms, and a 3-day food diary from participants. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of ETI in children with CF.

This is a randomized, double-blind, controlled bi-center study to compare the postoperative analgesic efficacy of dexamethasone and methylprednisolone in caudal block for children undergoing hypospadias surgical repair. The primary outcome measure is the duration of analgesia, and secondary outcome measures include the severity of postoperative pain, side effects, and rescue analgesia use.

The study is evaluating the addition of hemodiafiltration (HDF) to ex-vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) in the regeneration of marginal donor lungs. The study is a prospective, randomized, pilot study with 2 arms: experimental (HDF + EVLP) and active comparator (EVLP). The primary outcome measures are the suitability for transplantation of the lungs after 6 hours of EVLP with HDF and the PGD grade 3 at 72 hours after transplantation. Secondary outcome measures include survival, length of mechanical ventilation, length of ICU stay, length of hospital stay, and lung function parameters (MEF50) at 1, 3, 6, 12, and 24 months after transplantation.

The study compares the effectiveness of white noise and multisensory stimulation in retinopathy examination on premature infants. The study randomly assigned premature infants to three groups: the control group, the white noise group, and the multisensory stimulation group. The study used trained healthcare professionals to perform retinopathy examinations using standardized procedures. The primary outcome measures were physiological responses, behavioral indicators, and overall examination success rate. The study aims to contribute to the development of effective and well-tolerated retinopathy examination protocols for premature infants and inform healthcare professionals and researchers about the benefits of auditory stimulation (white noise) and the additional advantages of multisensory stimulation during retinopathy examinations.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a modified calculation formula for measuring the area of the meibomian glands (MGs) and the whole eyelids. The study will enroll 30 participants aged 18 to 80 years old, and will measure the primary outcome measures of the area of the MGs and the WTW distance of the cornea at baseline.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Zinc Gluconate in preventing oral mucositis in patients undergoing radiotherapy for head and neck cancer. The study will enroll 120 patients and will be conducted over a period of 63 days. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of oral mucositis at one week after the end of radiotherapy. Secondary outcome measures include the time of oral mucositis onset and the severity of oral mucositis.

This is a pilot study to determine the predictive ability of a panel of biomarkers in saliva in healthy and periodontally affected subjects. The study will enroll 100 participants and will measure salivary biomarkers, including CRP, TREM-1, IL-1beta, MMP-8, IL-10, IL-6, MCP-1, MIP-1, IFN-gamma, OPG, RANKL, and TNF-alpha. The primary outcome measure is the combination of these biomarkers at baseline. Secondary outcome measures include age, gender, Hb1Ac, Finn-risk, blood pressure, patient's temperature, habits, plaque index, bleeding on probing, suppuration on probing, probing depth, recession, radiographic bone loss, and microbiological analyses. The study is designed as a cross-sectional clinical study and will be conducted at a single site.

The study aimed to determine the effect of white noise, heart sound, and music on reducing neonatal pain during heel lance. The study was a randomized controlled experimental design with 84 infants aged 28-42 weeks. The infants were exposed to white noise, heart sounds, or the music that the mother listened to most frequently during pregnancy for 10 minutes before, during, and 20 minutes after the procedure. The primary outcome measures were the Neonatal Infant Acute Pain Assessment Scale (NIAPAS) pain score and crying time. The study found that the infants who listened to white noise, heart sounds, or the music had lower NIAPAS pain scores and shorter crying times compared to those who did not receive these interventions. The study concluded that these interventions may be effective in reducing neonatal pain during heel lance.

The study compares the effectiveness of two training and supervision methods for caregiver skills training. One group receives remote training and supervision, while the other group receives face-to-face training and supervision. The study measures the change in caregiver skills and knowledge from baseline to week 12, as well as parenting stress, adaptive behavior, social communication, and caregiver diary scores. The study aims to determine if the type of training provided to the facilitators (face-to-face versus remote) impacts parent progress.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of transcranial electrical stimulation in improving functional recovery in patients with subacromial pain syndrome. The study will randomly assign participants to either a strenghtening and tES group or a sham tES group. The primary outcome measures will include changes in pain and disability index, western ontario rotator cuff scale, visual analog scale for shoulder intensity of pain, shoulder pain pressure threshold, shoulder muscle strenght, shoulder active range of movement, joint position sense, head forward posture, shoulder protraction, and kyphosis. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in EEG amplitude of primary motor cortex, scapulothoracic muscle activation, and quality of life. The study will be conducted over 8 weeks with 24 sessions, and the results will be analyzed using mixed ANOVA and non-parametric tests.

This is a retrospective study to evaluate the effectiveness of hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) in improving verbal scores of children diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The study included 40 children aged 2-17 years who received HBOT (at least 40 sessions for 60 minutes at 2.0 ATA) and 40 children who did not receive HBOT. The primary outcome measures were verbal scores measured using age-appropriate assessments (Verbal Behavior Milestones Assessment and Placement Program (VBMAPP) and Assessment of Basic Language and Learning Skills (ABLLS)) at 6 months. The study found that there was no significant difference in verbal scores between the HBOT and control groups. The study also found that there were no adverse events related to HBOT.

The study compares the analgesic efficacy of ultrasound-guided adductor canal block and 4-in-1 block in patients undergoing knee surgeries. The study is a randomized, double-blinded, comparative study with 2 arms: adductor canal block and 4-in-1 block. The primary outcome measures are postoperative pain score (resting and dynamic) at 6, 12, 18, and 24 hours postoperatively. Secondary outcome measures include change of blood pressure, heart rate, and postoperative opioid requirements. The study aims to evaluate the analgesic efficacy of ultrasound-guided adductor canal block versus 4-in-1 block in patients undergoing knee surgeries.

The study aims to determine whether immediate lymphatic reconstruction (ILR) can reduce the risk of arm lymphedema in breast cancer patients after axillary lymph node dissection. The study is a prospective, randomized, controlled trial with double-blinded masking. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (ILR) or the control group (no intervention). The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of arm lymphedema, measured two years after surgery. Secondary outcome measures include drainage amount, seroma or lymphocele, patient-reported outcome measures (PROM), and subclinical lymphedema.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This is a descriptive study that aims to assess the cosmetic and functional sequelae of patients who received releasing incisions in the management of acute upper limb burns. The study includes adult patients who were hospitalized at the Pierre Colson Burn Center with a hand burn that required releasing incisions. The primary outcome measures include functional score, healing time, scar quality, burn VAS, QuickDASH Score, and scar quality at 3 and 6 months after the burn. The study is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention/treatment in improving functional outcomes and reducing sequelae in patients with hand burns.

The PLANT study is a randomized, delayed intervention trial testing a 6-week multimodal educational program for providers at Stanford in any department. The program includes interactive didactic sessions, cooking classes, and weekly emails with suggested resources and activities. The study aims to assess the effectiveness of the educational program in changing providers' dietary habits and mindset towards a whole-food plant-based diet. The primary outcome measures include change in Diet ID score, mindset about WFPBD, and state of change (motivation/confidence) from baseline to Week 6. The study is designed as a health services research and the allocation is randomized, with no masking (open label). The study plan includes screening, enrollment, intervention, and follow-up.

This study aims to validate a questionnaire to assess survivorship concerns in breast cancer patients in early stage. The questionnaire will be administered twice 15 days apart and the results will be analyzed to identify the levels of agreement between the two assessments.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Connecting and Reflecting Experience (CARE) program in improving postpartum depression, anxiety, parenting stress, and parent-child relationships. The study will enroll 120 postpartum women and their infants, aged 3-12 months, who are experiencing moderate to high levels of depression and/or anxiety symptoms. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the CARE program or a waitlist control group. The primary outcome measures will include changes in postpartum anxiety, depression, and parenting stress from baseline to post-treatment, as well as changes in parental reflective functioning and parent-infant bonding. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in infant temperament and ratings of treatment acceptability and feasibility. The study will be conducted at Montefiore Medical Center in New York, USA, and will be completed within 15 weeks after baseline measurement.

The study aims to investigate the effects of electroencephalography-based neurofeedback (EEG-NFB) training on cognitive function in healthy young men. The study will randomly assign 50 participants into two groups: the experimental group (TR) that will undergo 3 weeks of EEG-NFB training, and the control group (CO) that will not receive any training. The primary outcome measures will be the trail making test (TMT-A and TMT-B), and the Stroop test (ST-I and ST-II) to assess cognitive processing speed, executive function, and selective attention and inhibition. The study will be conducted in a quiet room with only one investigator present, and the participants will be provided with instructions prior to starting each test. The results will be analyzed using SPSS Statistics 22.0 software, and the significance level will be set at 0.05.

This is a randomized, parallel-group, single-blind clinical trial to compare the efficacy and safety of endovascular recanalization via radial approach versus femoral approach in patients with acute basilar artery occlusion.

The BUNDLE study is a mixed-methods, randomized controlled trial aimed at developing and testing an integrated prenatal care model that incorporates community-based doulas and medical providers in Southeastern Wisconsin. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention in improving healthcare engagement, trust, and reducing adverse maternal outcomes among Black/AA pregnant people. The study will also assess the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention among participants and stakeholders.

Keywords: BUNDLE, prenatal care, doula support, healthcare engagement, trust, adverse maternal outcomes, Black/AA pregnant people, randomized controlled trial, mixed-methods study.

This is a Phase 1 open-label study to evaluate the safety and determine the maximum tolerated dose of IBRX-042 in subjects with HPV-associated tumors. The study will enroll up to 60 subjects who will be administered IBRX-042 by injection once every 3 weeks for a total of 3 injections. The study will measure the safety profile and reactogenicity of IBRX-042, and examine HPV-specific humoral and cellular immune responses.

Maximum Tolerated Dose (MTD): 
The maximum dose of IBRX-042 that can be administered without causing unacceptable toxicity.

Determine the safety profile and reactogenicity of IBRX-042: 
The study will assess the overall safety of IBRX-042 by evaluating the incidence of adverse events, including treatment-emergent major adverse events (MAAEs), serious adverse events (SAEs), solicited local and systemic reactogenicity adverse events, and unsolicited adverse events.

HPV-specific humoral and cellular immune responses: 
The study will examine the immune response to HPV in subjects treated with IBRX-042 by analyzing the humoral and cellular immune response endpoints.

Inclusion Criteria: 

* 18-75 years of age
* Histologically confirmed HPV-associated cancer
* Received at least one standard of care therapy for HPV-associated cancer
* Availability of a representative formalin fixed, paraffin embedded tumor specimen or fresh frozen tissue specimen for diagnostic purposes
* Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 or 1
* Resolution of all toxic side effects of prior therapy for HPV-associated cancer to National Cancer Institute (NCI) Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) Version 5 grade ≤ 1
* Agreement to practice effective contraception for female subjects of child-bearing potential and nonsterile males

Exclusion Criteria: 

* History of autoimmune

The study is a randomized controlled trial that investigated the effects of connective tissue massage and classical massage on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain. The study included 30 participants who were randomly assigned to one of three groups: connective tissue massage, classical massage, or a control group. The intervention lasted for 4 weeks, with 3 sessions per week. The primary outcome measures were visual analog scale (VAS), modified Schober test (MST), sit and reach test (SRT), back pain functional scale (BPFS), and Roland Morris disability questionnaire (RMDQ). The study found that both massage groups showed significant improvements in pain, functional status, and quality of life compared to the control group. Connective tissue massage and classical massage were found to be effective in reducing pain and improving functional status and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study to compare the clinical outcomes of OMNI canaloplasty alone versus OMNI canaloplasty with Hydrus microstent in patients undergoing cataract surgery for glaucoma.

The study will enroll approximately 80 subjects aged 18 years and older with bilateral mild to moderate open-angle glaucoma, including pseudoexfoliation (PXE) and pigment dispersion (PDS). Subjects will undergo uncomplicated cataract surgery and be randomly assigned to receive either OMNI canaloplasty alone or OMNI canaloplasty with Hydrus microstent in one randomized eye. The primary outcome measure is the change in unmedicated intraocular pressure from baseline at 12 months, and secondary outcome measures include reduction in number of medications needed to control intraocular pressure, percentage of patients with greater than 20% reduction in intraocular pressure from baseline, and visual field analysis.

The study will be conducted at multiple study centers and will last approximately one year, with seven study visits and two visits to the surgery center. The study will use competitive enrollment, and subjects will be randomly assigned by chance (like the flip of a coin) to receive either OMNI canaloplasty alone or OMNI canaloplasty with Hydrus microstent.

The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of OMNI canaloplasty alone versus OMNI canaloplasty with Hydrus microstent in patients undergoing cataract surgery for glaucoma. The results of this study may help to determine the optimal treatment approach for patients with glaucoma and cataract surgery.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of text messaging intervention in improving adherence to repeat colonoscopy in veterans. The study will enroll participants who are due for a repeat colonoscopy and will randomly assign them to either the experimental group (text message intervention) or the control group (no intervention). The primary outcome measure is the National Annie Colonoscopy Survey Score, which will be assessed at day 21. Secondary outcome measures include the percentage of participants who attend the scheduled colonoscopy appointment and the percentage of participants who have adequate bowel preparation at the colonoscopy appointment.

The study compares the effectiveness of hysteroscopy and aspiration in managing trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage. The study aims to evaluate the primary outcome measure of uterine vacuity at 6 weeks after surgery, as well as secondary outcome measures such as complication rates, second-line surgical management, synechia rates, mean time to conception, and pregnancy rates. The study is a prospective, randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial conducted at multiple centers in France. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the hysteroscopy or aspiration group. The study will include 220 patients in total, with 110 patients in each arm. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years, with follow-up visits at 6 weeks, 6 months, and 24 months after surgery.

This study aims to investigate the ability of humans to make multi-timescale inferences using on-line testing. The study will involve 100 participants who will be asked to complete a series of tasks that test their ability to make decisions based on short-term and long-term information. The study will measure the participants' behavioral responses and will be conducted in a single group assignment with no masking.

Please provide a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This study is an N of 1 trial to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of lemborexant in treating insomnia in adults with early-onset dementia. The study will be conducted over 8 weeks, with the participant receiving alternating treatments of lemborexant and placebo in an ABBABAAB format. The primary outcome measures will include total sleep time, sleep onset latency, wake time after sleep onset, number of night awakenings, quality of sleep, presence and severity of adverse drug reactions, and drop-out due to adverse drug reactions.

This is a prospective, double-blind, randomized, multicenter clinical trial to evaluate the therapeutic evaluation of treatment with sinomenine versus glucocorticoid for early knee osteoarthritis. The study will enroll 300 participants with knee osteoarthritis aged between 40 and 70 years old. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either sinomenine or glucocorticoid injections every 4 months for 24 months. The primary outcome measures will be the total WOMAC score and tibial cartilage volume, and secondary outcome measures will include the Timed Up and Go test and 20m walking time. The study will assess the non-inferiority of sinomenine compared to glucocorticoid in treating early knee osteoarthritis.

The study aims to determine the effect of breathing exercises applied with virtual reality glasses on dyspnea, anxiety, and quality of life in COPD patients. The study is a randomized, parallel-group, pre-test post-test single-blind controlled experimental design. The sample size is 48 patients, 24 in the experimental and 24 in the control group. The primary outcome measures are oxygen saturation, respiratory rate, forced vital capacity (FVC), volume of air exhaled in 1 second of forced expiration (FEV1), peak expiratory flow rate (PEF), FEV1/FVC, COPD Evaluation Test (CAT), Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) dyspnea scale, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), St George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ), and Virtual Reality Experience Evaluation Form. The study will be conducted in the homes of the patients by making home visits. The intervention will be applied in the experimental group, and routine treatment and care will be continued in the control group. The study will be conducted in a single-blind pre-test post-test parallel group randomized controlled experimental design.

This study aims to investigate the multilevel determinants of cardiovascular health in Black women through ongoing monitoring. The study will assess macrovascular function, arterial stiffness, blood flow measurements (large blood vessels and cerebral blood vessels), physical activity, and other secondary outcome measures. Participants will undergo lab-based assessments and a 10-day free-living monitoring period with mobile and wearable devices.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel, phase 2 clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of RCN3028 in treating drug-induced moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms in breast cancer patients. The study will enroll 140 female subjects aged 18-80 years who have completed chemotherapy and radiotherapy and are on a stable dose of tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors for at least 8 weeks at baseline. The subjects will be randomly assigned to receive either 0.8 mg RCN3028 or placebo, and the study will measure the mean change in frequency of moderate to severe VMS, mean change in severity of moderate to severe VMS, menopause specific quality of life questionnaire, the 50%, 75% and 100% responder rates, time to onset of efficacy, subject's and physician's global assessment, frequencies (number and percentage) of subjects with treatment-emergent AEs (TEAEs), change from baseline in weekly weighted severity score, change from baseline in the number of mild, moderate, and severe hot flashes, and change from baseline in the number of nighttime awakenings because of hot flashes. The study will be conducted over 12 weeks.

This is a retrospective cohort study that aims to investigate the association between Tranexamic Acid (TXA) dose and the incidence of post-operative delirium after cardiac surgery. The study will include all patients undergoing elective or in-house urgent cardiac surgery at Royal Perth Hospital between May 2018 and August 2022. The primary outcome measure will be the Richmond Agitation Sedation Score, measured up to 48 hours after surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include 30-day mortality. The study will be conducted without patient contact, using data collected on the hospital's electronic systems as part of routine clinical care and data collection.

The study compares the effects of myofascial decompression and positional release therapies on pain, range of motion, and functional disability in patients with chronic non-specific neck pain. The study is a randomized controlled trial with 2 arms: experimental and control. The experimental group receives myofascial decompression therapy, while the control group receives positional release therapy. The study measures the primary outcome measures of Numerical Rating Scale (NPRS) and Neck Disability Index (NDI) at 6th week. Secondary outcome measures include range of motion cervical spine (flexion), range of motion cervical spine (extension), range of motion cervical spine (side flexion), and range of motion cervical spine (rotation) at 6th week. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of myofascial decompression and positional release therapies in managing chronic non-specific neck pain.

This is a parallel-controlled randomized clinical trial comparing the ileostomy dumpling suture method with traditional suture method in rectal anterior resection surgery with specimen extraction via stoma. The study aims to evaluate the complication rate of stoma and assess the effectiveness of the dumpling suture method in reducing stoma complications. The study includes 100 participants who are randomly assigned to either the experimental or control group. The primary outcome measure is the complication rate of stoma, and secondary outcome measures include stoma DET score, stoma pain score, and quality of life scale score for patients with stoma. The study is conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

The study is a follow-up assessment of patients with Parkinson's disease who were previously enrolled in the ABC-PD study. The study aims to evaluate the progression of cognitive and instrumental activities of daily living (IADL) function in patients with Parkinson's disease over a period of 6-8 years. The study will use a comprehensive neuropsychological test battery to assess cognitive function, including global cognition, memory, attention/working memory, executive functions, language, and visuospatial abilities. Additionally, the study will assess IADL function using the Pfeffer Activities of daily living scale. The study will also evaluate the relationship between cognitive and IADL function and motor function in patients with Parkinson's disease.

The study aims to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium for the prevention of myofibrillation caused by the injection of succinylcholine. The study will enroll healthy volunteers aged 18 to 80 years old, and the participants will be randomly assigned to one of three age-based groups. The intervention will involve the administration of rocuronium before the injection of succinylcholine. The primary outcome measure will be the appearance of myofibrillation, which will be assessed within 45 seconds after the injection.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to investigate the presence of environmental pollutants in human carotid atherosclerotic plaques and their relationship with the plaque phenotype and clinical outcomes. The study will enroll 300 patients with carotid stenosis who will undergo carotid endarterectomy. The presence of microplastics in plaques will be assessed through pyrolysis-gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, and the abundance of pollutants will be categorized into terciles. The study will also examine the association between the presence of pollutants and the incidence of a composite outcome constituted by non-fatal myocardial infarction, non-fatal stroke, and all-cause mortality, adjusted for age, sex, BMI, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, the prevalence of diabetes, dyslipidaemia, and smoking.

This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of transarterial radioembolization (TARE) in patients with colorectal cancer liver metastases. The study will compare the effective tumor dose and safe healthy liver dose in patients who received TARE with or without response to radioembolization. The study will also investigate dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships after TARE.

The study will enroll patients who are over 18 years old and have histopathologically proven colorectal cancer diagnosis treated with radioembolization for liver metastases. The study will include two arms: observation group and treatment group. The observation group will receive radioembolization, while the treatment group will receive TARE. The study will measure the effective tumor dose and safe healthy liver dose at 3 months after treatment, and investigate dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships at 6 months after treatment.

The study is designed as an open-label, single-center, randomized controlled trial. The primary outcome measure is the effective tumor dose and safe healthy liver dose, and the secondary outcome measures are dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships. The study will enroll 20 patients in each arm, and the sample size calculation is based on the assumption that the effective tumor dose and safe healthy liver dose will be significantly different between the two groups.

The study will be conducted at a single center, and the patients will be randomly assigned to the observation or treatment group using a randomization method. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years, and the follow-up period will be 6 months after treatment.

The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of TARE in patients with colorectal cancer liver metastases, and will provide insights into the dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships after TARE. The study will also help to determine the optimal dose of TARE for colorectal cancer liver metastases.

18 healthy patients with 36-second molar teeth will be selected for the study. Each patient will have two oclusso-mesial cavities, one restored with chemically cured conventional GICs without any enhancement (M1 group) and the other with chemically cured conventional GICs that enhanced with light-emitting diode radiant heat (M2 group). The clinical performance of biological and functional properties of each restoration will be evaluated immediately after restoration (T0), six months later (T1), and after 12 months (T2) using Federation Dentaire International (FDI) criteria for assessment of dental restorations.
