The study aims to improve the accuracy of diagnosing soft tissue sarcomas using artificial intelligence (AI) by developing an AI algorithm that can differentiate between benign and malignant soft tissue masses. The study will use quantitative MRI sequences added to the standard MRI scan to provide extra information to the AI. A small subset of patients will be asked to come for a second scan to test the reproducibility of the measurements. The study will measure the accuracy of the AI algorithms for distinguishing between benign and malignant soft tissue lesions, and classifying malignant lesions into their pathological grade. The study will use ROC analysis to calculate the sensitivity and specificity of the algorithms. The keywords provided by the Centre Hospitalier Valida related to the study are MRI, Diffusion weighted imaging, Radiomics, Deep Learning, Machine Learning, Quantitative MRI.

The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of microneedling alone and along with hyaluronic acid in thin gingival phenotype. 20 patients with thin gingival phenotype will be recruited and randomly allocated to either the experimental or control group. The primary outcome measures will be the measurement of gingival thickness at 9 months.

Inclusion criteria: Thin gingival phenotype with gingival tissue thickness <1mm in mandibular anteriors.

Exclusion criteria: Systemic diseases, smoking, tobacco use, previous periodontal surgery, haematological disorders, use of blood thinners, use of any drugs that might lead to gingival enlargement, stress, bruxism.

The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months.

This is a multicenter RCT on the effects of preoperative immunonutrition on patients undergoing elective colorectal surgery for neoplasm. The study aims to assess the changes in adipose tissue inflammation and correlation with surgical outcome for future ERAS guidelines. The study is designed as a parallel-group randomized controlled trial with two arms: active comparator (oral impact + colorectal surgery) and placebo comparator (placebo + colorectal surgery). The primary outcome measures are surgical site infection (SSI) and anastomotic leakage (AL) at 30 days after the surgical procedure. Secondary outcome measures include length of stay (LOS), inflammatory infiltration in the subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) and visceral adipose tissue (VAT), grade of fibrosis in the subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) and visceral adipose tissue (VAT), and adipocytes cross sectional area (CSA) in the subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) and visceral adipose tissue (VAT) at the time of tissue analysis, usually 1 month after surgery.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to investigate the impact and possible additional benefits of adding an oculomotor treatment to a manual therapy protocol for patients with migraine. The study will assess the changes in the impact, pain, disability, depression, anxiety, sleep quality, kinesiophobia, catastrophizing, central sensitization, neck disability, head repositioning, strength of deep cervical flexors, ocular movement, and quality of life before and after the intervention. The study will be conducted in two groups: a control group that will receive a treatment of the cervical region, and an experimental group that will receive the same treatment plus an additional intervention in the oculomotor region. The study will be conducted for 6 weeks, with a follow-up of 3 months after the intervention.

The CRATOS trial is a single-arm, open-label study evaluating the safety and efficacy of the Cratos™ Branch Stent Graft System in the treatment of descending aorta lesions. The study includes patients with aortic dissection type B, intramural hematoma, penetrating aortic ulcer, and will assess the primary outcome measure of all-cause mortality at 30 days.

The inclusion criteria for the study are:

* Presence of thoracic aortic pathology (dissection, including IMH and ULP; and PAU) deemed to warrant surgical repair which requires proximal graft placement in Zone 2
* Age ≥18 years at time of informed consent signature
* Must have appropriate proximal aortic landing zone, defined as: Landing zone inner diameters between 23-41 mm The length of landing zone ≥15mm Landing without heavily calcified or heavily thrombosed Dissection Patients: Primary entry tear must be distal to LSA, and proximal extent of the proximal landing zone must not be dissected.

The exclusion criteria for the study are:

* Concomitant disease of the ascending aorta or aneurysm of the abdominal aorta requiring repair
* Previous endovascular repair of the ascending aorta
* Infected aorta, active systemic infection
* Surgery within 30 days prior to enrolment with the exception of placement of vascular conduit for access
* Life expectancy <1 years
* Myocardial infarction within 6 weeks prior to treatment
* Stroke within 6 weeks prior to treatment
* Pregnant or breastfeeding female
* Known history of drug abuse within one year of treatment
* Tortuous or stenotic iliac and/or femoral arteries preventing introducer sheath insertion and the inability to use a conduit for vascular access
* Planned coverage of celiac artery
* Allergic to contrast agents, anaesthetics and delivery materials
* Previous instance of Heparin Induced Thrombocytopenia type 2 (HIT-2) or known hyp

This study compares the depth of lumbar plexus, image quality, and presence of vessels between two techniques of ultrasound-guided lumbar plexus block, Trident and Shamrock. The study includes adults with indication of lumbar echography and excludes those with antecedent of spine surgery or spinal malformation. The primary outcome measures are the projection of line C on the costiform processes, depth of lumbar plexus, image quality, and presence of vessels. The study plan includes the design of the study, arms and interventions, and outcome measures.

This is a randomized controlled trial to assess the effectiveness of preoperative pelvic floor physical therapy in reducing stress urinary incontinence after holmium laser enucleation of the prostate. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted at a single institution. Patients will be randomly assigned to either a preoperative pelvic floor physical therapy group or a standard of care postoperative pelvic floor physical therapy group. The primary outcome measure is time to continence, and secondary outcome measures include uroflow, post void residual, international prostate symptom score, operative time, length of stay, catheter duration, infectious complications, and emergency room visits. The study will help determine the role of preoperative pelvic floor physical therapy in the management of HoLEP associated SUI.

The DETECT-IP trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a computerized decision support system (CDSS) in reducing adverse drug events (ADEs) in older hospitalized patients. The study will compare the outcomes of patients in the intervention group, who will receive CDSS-based pharmaceutical validation, with those in the control group, who will not receive CDSS-based pharmaceutical validation. The primary outcome measures will be the number of ADEs such as acute renal failure and/or hyperkalemia, and the relevance of CDSS alerts. Secondary outcome measures will include the presence of an adverse event related to the intervention, therapeutic adaptations implemented in case of ADEs, and the cost-effectiveness of the pharmaceutical intervention. The study will be conducted in multiple centers and will enroll hospitalized patients aged 65 years or older.

The study aims to investigate the relationship between mesenteric bacterial translocation and the recurrence of Crohn's disease after surgery. The study will compare the bacterial profile and function in the mesentery, ileal tissue, and blood of patients with Crohn's disease who have early post-surgical disease recurrence and those who do not. Additionally, the study will analyze the genetic variants related to innate immunity and the bacterial microbiome profile of patients with Crohn's disease. The study will enroll adults with Crohn's disease who require an ileocecal resection and healthy controls. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, two-part, Phase 1 clinical trial to evaluate the relative bioavailability of LY3437943 administered subcutaneously (SC) or intravenously (IV) in healthy participants with a high body mass index (BMI). The study will measure the pharmacokinetics (PK) of LY3437943, including the area under the plasma concentration versus time curve from zero to infinity (AUC[0-∞]), maximum concentration (Cmax), and other secondary outcome measures. The study will enroll healthy males or females of nonchildbearing potential, aged 18 to 70 years, with a BMI between 27.0 and 45.0 kg/m², inclusive. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either SC or IV administration of LY3437943 in a parallel-group design. The study will consist of two parts: Part A (subcutaneous administration) and Part B (intravenous administration). The study will be conducted in compliance with Good Clinical Practice (GCP) and the applicable regulatory requirements.

This is a research registry on aggressive pituitary tumors (PitNETs) conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The study aims to characterize the aggressiveness of PitNETs using transcriptome analysis and predict the prognosis of patients. The study includes adult patients with pituitary tumors whose files have been presented to the national HYPOcare RCP. There is only one group in the study, and the primary outcome measure is the molecular and transcriptomic signature of aggressiveness of pituitary tumors predictive of prognosis, measured after 3 years. The study is related to endocrine tumors, rare diseases, and transcriptomes.

30 patients aged 65 years or older are randomized to receive one of five anti-cancer treatments (pazopanib, olaparib, lenvatinib, sunitinib, or palbociclib) with a lower starting dose in the intervention group, or the standard-of-care dose in the control group. The primary outcome is the feasibility of investigating whether a lower starting dose with step-up approach leads to a better overall treatment utility compared to standard dosing. Secondary outcomes include overall treatment utility, progression-free survival, overall survival, quality of life, safety, hospital care use, pharmacokinetic parameters (Cmax, AUC, Ctrough), and time to disease progression. The study duration is 12 weeks, and data collection is planned every 2 weeks.

This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, controlled study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Envafolimab Plus CAPEOX in patients with MSS-type advanced middle-low rectal cancer who undergo neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy. The study will enroll 108 patients and assess the primary outcome measure of pCR rate at 10 weeks after surgery. Secondary outcome measures include tumor regression grade, overall survival, progression-free survival, treatment-related adverse events, surgical complications, and quality of life.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include the entire document.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, cross-over clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy of white kidney bean on oral glucose tolerance test. The study involves 30 healthy adults aged 25-45 years, with a male to female ratio of more than 40%. The participants are randomly assigned to one of two arms: active comparator (Wonderlab product plus placebo) or active comparator (placebo plus Wonderlab product). The primary outcome measures are the change of blood glucose level in mmol/L based on OGTT after intervention, and the change of fast blood glucose level in mmol/L based on OGTT after intervention. The study is designed to supportive care and the allocation is randomized, the intervention model is crossover assignment and the masking is double.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the IMPlementation of Evidence Based Facility and Community Interventions to Reduce the Treatment Gap for depression. The study will be conducted in clusters of adults (>18 years) residing in the study area. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (community intervention) or the active comparator group (facility model). The primary outcome measures will be contact coverage and effectiveness coverage, measured three months post-recruitment. Secondary outcome measures will include sustained effectiveness, remission, response to treatment, client service receipt inventory, WHO disability assessment schedule (WHODAS 2.0), depression awareness, perceived social support, multidimensional scale of perceived social support (MSPSS), treatment completion, and behavioral activation. The study will run for approximately 12 months.

Note: The output is a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document. The summary highlights the main aspects of the study, including the research question, study design, population, primary and secondary outcome measures, and duration of the study.

This study aims to investigate the effects of low-intensity blood flow restriction training in both normoxia and hypoxia conditions on muscle strength, thickness, catecholamine, and inflammatory responses in physically active adults. The study will randomly assign participants to one of five groups: active comparator (low-intensity normoxia), active comparator (high-intensity normoxia), experimental (low-intensity normoxia with blood flow restriction), experimental (low-intensity hypoxia), and experimental (low-intensity hypoxia with blood flow restriction). The study will measure various outcome measures, including force output, one-repetition maximum, maximum number of repetitions, countermovement jump height, countermovement jump power output, catecholamine response, muscle stiffness, and muscle thickness. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 weeks, with measurements taken immediately pre and post first and last training session, within 5 days from the start and end of training, and immediately pre and post every training session.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study is a phase II, open-label, single-arm clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of subcutaneous mosunetuzumab monotherapy in patients with follicular lymphoma who have relapsed or are refractory to standard salvage regimens. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, and secondary outcome measures include overall response rate, complete response rate, duration of response, time to new lymphoma treatment, overall survival, safety and tolerability, and the rate of transformation to aggressive lymphoma. The study includes 330-380 mL of peripheral blood collection for exploratory research over 3 years and up to 2,5 years of follow-up.

This is a phase I/II clinical trial that aims to determine the safety and efficacy of combining two drugs, PLX2853 and trametinib, in the treatment of advanced uveal melanoma. The study will enroll patients with histologically confirmed advanced uveal melanoma and will evaluate the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase II dose of the combination, as well as the overall response rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, incidence of adverse events, and systemic exposure to the drugs. The study will be conducted in two phases: a phase I dose-escalation study and a phase II study.

Inclusion Criteria:

* Patients with histologically confirmed advanced uveal melanoma
* Patients who are treatment-naïve or have received any number of prior systemic or liver-directed therapies for advanced UM
* Patients with measurable disease according to RECIST version 1.1 criteria
* Patients who are at least 18 years old
* Patients who are Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Performance Status 0-2
* Patients with absolute neutrophil count (ANC) ≥ 1000/mm^3, hemoglobin ≥ 9g/dL, platelet count ≥ 100,000/mm^3, and creatinine clearance ≥ 45 mL/minute
* Patients who do not have a history of any medical condition that could interfere with the safety or efficacy assessment of the investigational regimen
* Patients who are HIV-infected on effective anti-retroviral therapy with undetectable viral load within 6 months

Exclusion Criteria:

* Patients who have received prior treatment with a BET or MEK inhibitor
* Patients who are unable to swallow oral formulations of the agent(s)
* Patients who are taking strong inhibitors of CYP3A4 and cannot discontinue the drug for 14 days prior to registration on the study

The study will evaluate the MTD and recommended phase II dose of the combination, as well as the overall

The ASCERTAIN study is a randomized, open-label, two-arm Phase IV clinical trial evaluating the implementation and utility of a new model of care in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or ASCVD-risk equivalents and elevated low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C). The study will compare the new model of care to usual care in male and female participants aged 18 years or older, with a history of ASCVD or ASCVD-risk equivalents, and elevated LDL-C levels. The primary outcome measure is the effect on LDL-C concentration at day 180, and secondary outcome measures include the effect on LDL-C concentration at day 365, and the safety and efficacy of the new model of care. The study will include approximately 600 participants across 20 sites in Australia, and will be conducted in collaboration with leading cardiologists in Australia and a General Practitioner (GP) Advisory Committee.

48 patients of both sex and aged from 21-65 years in period between February 2022 to January 2023 scheduled for elective open renal surgeries under general anesthesia were enrolled in this study. The patients were randomly assigned to one of three groups: Erector spinea block, Thoracic Paravertebral block, or Control group. The primary outcome measure was total morphine requirements 24 hours postoperatively.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and does not include any external sources or information.

The study aims to assess the prevalence of musculoskeletal conditions and related symptoms in adult lymphoma and leukaemia survivors. The study will also assess the 10-year probability of hip fracture and major osteoporotic fracture (clinical spine, forearm, hip or shoulder fracture) of adult lymphoma and leukaemia survivors. The study will also measure the prevalence of sarcopenia and frailty among adult lymphoma and leukaemia and leukaemia and related symptoms in adult lympharm and related symptoms in adult lympharm and related symptoms in adult lympharm and related symptoms in adult lympharm and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptoms in adult lym and related symptms in adult and related sympt and related sympt and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym and related lym

This is a Phase 2 basket study of disitamab vedotin in adult participants with previously treated, locally-advanced unresectable or metastatic solid tumors that express HER2. The study is open-label, with no placebo group. Participants will receive disitamab vedotin monotherapy every 2 weeks. The study is designed to measure the confirmed objective response rate (ORR), number of participants with adverse events (AEs), number of participants with laboratory abnormalities, number of participants with dose alterations due to AEs, confirmed disease control rate (DCR), duration of response (DOR), duration of progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters, and incidence of antidrug antibodies (ADAs). The study is conducted in 4 cohorts: HNSCC, NSCLC, ovarian cancer, and endometrial cancer. The study will run for approximately 5 years.

The study aims to assess the driving safety of older adults who have survived critical illness in the ICU. The study will enroll 24 older adults and assess their driving behavior, cognitive function, and quality of life over a 6-month period. The study will also evaluate the relationship between neurocognitive assessments and driving behavior and safety in older ICU survivors. The study will use in-vehicle sensors to collect data on driving behavior and cognitive function. The study's findings will inform the development of an evidence-based, in-vehicle driving assessment system to provide actionable driving safety data and rehabilitation strategies tailored to ICU survivors.

70 women will be recruited to participate in a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of a brief acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) intervention for weight loss. The intervention group will receive a 4-hour workshop that teaches ACT skills, while the waitlist control group will not receive the intervention until all members of the intervention group have completed the workshop. Outcome measures will include changes in psychological flexibility, distress tolerance, valued living, and weight self-stigma at baseline and 1 month post-intervention. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in body image, emotional eating, physical activity, diet quality, and body weight.

Note: The output is a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document. It highlights the main aspects of the study, including the population, intervention, and outcome measures.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of drug holiday treatment based on minimal residual disease (MRD) detection in high-risk gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) patients who have been treated with imatinib for 3 years after surgery. The study will monitor the progress-free survival, drug re-use rate, and drug retreatment response rate of these patients, as well as the overall survival, genetic mutation profiling of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA-MRD), and the comparison between MRD conversion and disease progression assessed by imaging examination. The study will enroll 10 patients and will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a randomized control trial that aims to compare the effects of Dohsa hou exercises on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome. The study will be conducted on 6-12 years old children with Down syndrome, who will be randomly assigned to either a standard treatment protocol or Dohsa hou exercises group. The primary outcome measures will be trunk impairment scale and Time Up and Go Test, which will be assessed at 6 weeks. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of Dohsa hou exercises in improving functional mobility in children with Down syndrome.

The Supporting Physical Literacy at School and Home (SPLASH) study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to increase children's physical literacy and physical activity levels through a multilevel, comprehensive program that reaches children both at school and at home. The study will recruit 400 3rd-5th grade students from low-income schools and randomly assign them to either the intervention group (receiving the Rising New York Road Runners program) or the control group (receiving standard school operating procedures). The primary outcome measures will include children's baseline and end-point physical activity levels, as well as their baseline and end-point fundamental movement skill levels in running, locomotion, object control, and balance. The study will examine whether the RNYRR program effects on children's PL and PA differ by sex or weight status, and whether changes in PL and PL subdomains mediate changes in daily total PA volume or MVPA.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifying details.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, 76-week, efficacy and safety study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of BI 456906 in Japanese patients with obesity disease. The study will enroll 300 patients and will be conducted at multiple sites in Japan. The primary outcome measures will be the percentage change in body weight from baseline to Week 76 and the achievement of body weight reduction ≥5%, ≥10%, and ≥15% from baseline to Week 76. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in body composition, glycemic control, liver enzymes, and safety parameters. The study will be conducted in accordance with the ICH-GCP and local legislation, and will be conducted by a team of investigators and study staff.

The study aims to evaluate the gastric volume in pediatric patients undergoing adenotonsillectomy surgery using ultrasound. The study will include ASA 1,2,3 patients under the age of 18 who will undergo tonsillectomy and/or adenoidectomy in the operating rooms of Istanbul University, Istanbul Medical Faculty, Department of Otorhinolaryngology. The study will evaluate the pre- and postoperative gastric volume with ultrasound in children who undergo tonsillectomy and/or adenoidectomy. The study will also assess the postoperative presence and severity of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), blood volume in the suction system, and duration of surgery.

The study aims to investigate the effect of pituitrin on the postoperative outcomes of patients with pulmonary hypertension undergoing cardiac surgery. The study will randomly assign participants to receive either pituitrin or a placebo, and measure the primary outcome of mortality or severe postoperative complications within 30 days after surgery. Secondary outcomes will include incidence of postoperative infection, septic shock, duration of mechanical ventilation, postoperative pulmonary complications, time to achieve hemodynamic stability, use of dobutamine or other vasoactive drugs, incidence of digital ischemia, acute mesenteric ischemia, gastrointestinal complications, incidence of acute myocardial infarction, new onset tachyarrhythmia, water poisoning, vasodilative shock, incidence of pulmonary embolism, low cardiac output syndrome, acute respiratory distress syndrome, delirium, need for renal replacement therapy (RRT), need for hemodialysis, incidence of readmission to ICU, length of ICU stay, length of stay, levels of serum antidiuretic hormone in patients, levels of copeptin in patients, secondary endotracheal intubation.

The proposed study aims to evaluate the feasibility and safety of initiating noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) at home in children with medical complexity (CMC). The study will compare the use of home NiPPV initiation with standard of care, which involves initiating NiPPV during a one-night in-hospital polysomnography (PSG) laboratory-based initiation. The study will assess the recruitment and retention rate, proportion of eligible patients randomized, proportion of patients who crossover based on safety criteria, mean minutes of nightly NiPPV usage, proxy-reported Psychological Scale (percentage rank), proxy-reported Psychological Scale (T-value), self-reported Psychological Scale (percentage rank), self-reported Psychological Scale (T-value), caregiver reported Sense of Mastery, patient and family study experience, preference of intervention and barriers, difference in expiratory positive airway pressure based on home NiPPV titration and PSG titration in the intervention arm, and difference in inspiratory positive airway pressure based on home NiPPV titration and PSG titration in the intervention arm. The study will also assess the secondary outcomes, including the proportion of patients who complete the study, the number of adverse events, and the number of patients who require hospitalization. The study will provide valuable insights into the feasibility and safety of initiating NiPPV at home in CMC and inform future studies in this area.

The study is a single-blind randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effects of dry needling on latent myofascial trigger points on vertical jump performance in female athletes. The study will include healthy female volleyball practitioners who are between 18 and 25 years old and have latent MTPs in the gastrocnemius muscle. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive dry needling on the latent MTPs, while the control group will wait on the intervention couch for a similar time. The primary outcome measure will be counter movement jump, which will be measured at 15 minutes after the intervention.

Note: The summary is based on the provided information and does not include any additional information or context.

The study aims to investigate the clinical features of refractory gastrointestinal Henoch-Schönlein purpura and the clinical outcome of mycophenolate mofetil in these patients. The study is a single-group assignment, open-label, and non-masked design. Participants are eligible if they are between 3 and 18 years old, have refractory gastrointestinal Henoch-Schönlein purpura, and meet other inclusion criteria. The primary outcome measures are the incidence of abdominal pain, hematemesis, and bloody stools, assessed by a checklist, and the count of red blood cells in stool, tested every week, for 6 months. The study also measures secondary outcome measures, such as renal involvement and gastrointestinal involvement. The keywords provided by the Centre Hospitalier Valida related to the study are allergic purpura, complications, renal involvement, gastrointestinal involvement, and mycophenolate mofetil.

The study is a Phase II/III open-label, single group assignment, staged investigational device trial to assess the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of EEG-enhanced transcranial magnetic stimulation (eTMS) as an adjunct to standard of care treatment for chronic trauma and stressor-related disorders (TSRD) in Veterans. The study will enroll 30 participants and will be conducted in two stages: Stage 1 will assess safety and feasibility with 30 participants, and Stage 2 will enroll an additional 270 participants using randomization to multiple baselines for efficacy analyses. The primary outcome measures will include the number of participants with device-related serious adverse events, rate of participants completing 80% of scheduled visits, and mean change in Veterans RAND 36-item health survey (VR-36) mental component scores (MCS). Secondary outcome measures will include VR-36 MCS, health-related quality of life, and alpha rhythms.

This is a retrospective study that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of radiotherapy combined with EGFR-TKI in patients with stage III EGFR mutant lung cancer. The study includes 30 participants who will receive either 3DCRT or IMRT at a prescribed dose of 54-66 Gy/27-33 f, along with the combined TKI. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, which will be measured over a period of 2 years.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This study aims to identify the microorganisms responsible for acute head and neck infections. The study will enroll participants over the age of 18 who are suffering from acute head and neck infections caused by Streptococci. The study will measure the identification of Streptococci species, patient characteristics, patient outcomes, and clinical outcomes. The study will be conducted at Northampton General Hospital and will last for 4 years.

Please provide a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of functional magnetic stimulation and pelvic floor muscle training on pelvic floor muscle function, urinary incontinence symptoms, and quality of life in women with stress urinary incontinence. The study included 48 women aged 29-49 years old who were randomly assigned to either the experimental group (functional magnetic stimulation) or the control group (pelvic floor muscle training program). The study measured the primary outcome measures of urinary incontinence symptoms and quality of life using the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Short Form (ICIQ-SF) and Incontinence Impact Questionnaire-Short Form (IIQ-7). The study found that both groups showed significant improvement in urinary incontinence symptoms and quality of life at 6 weeks compared to baseline. The experimental group showed a greater improvement in pelvic floor muscle strength and endurance compared to the control group.

The study aims to optimize the selection and treatment outcomes of biologic therapies for patients with psoriatic and seronegative rheumatoid arthritis (PsA and RA) by analyzing the cellular and molecular atlas of PsA and identifying potential biomarkers for treatment response. The study will enroll patients with PsA and RA across different disease stages, including those naive to treatment, TNF-inhibitor resistant, IL-17-inhibitor resistant, TNF-inhibitor induced remission, and IL-17-inhibitor induced remission. The study will use phenotyping of synovial immune and stromal cells to generate a comprehensive cellular and molecular atlas of PsA and spatial transcriptomics of synovium to identify potential biomarkers for treatment response. The primary outcome measures will include minimal disease activity status achievement, PsA development (fulfillment of the CASPAR criteria), and remission maintenance.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of artificial tears in preventing nasolacrimal duct obstruction in patients undergoing radioactive iodine therapy for thyroid cancer. The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment trial with two arms: experimental (artificial tears) and no intervention (no artificial tears). Participants in the experimental arm will receive artificial tears according to a specific schedule, while those in the no intervention arm will not receive any artificial tears. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of post-radiotherapy nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO) at 2 years after radioactive iodine therapy. The study will enroll patients aged 18 or older who are undergoing radioactive iodine therapy for thyroid cancer and will follow them for 2 years.

This is a phase II randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of atorvastatin and placebo in preventing disease metastasis in patients with resected high-risk stage IIA melanoma. The study will enroll 120 participants and will be conducted at multiple sites. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the atorvastatin group or the placebo group and will receive treatment for up to 5 years. The primary outcome measure is recurrence-free survival, and secondary outcome measures include distant metastasis-free survival, overall survival, and clinical utility of gene expression profiling in melanoma.

Note: The above summary is a general representation of the provided clinical trial document and may not be a direct copy of the original text.

The ACHIEVE (Advancing Community and Clinical Care for Childbirth-related Hypertension Through Implementation, Engagement, and Valuing Equity) Initiative is a clinical trial testing the impact of three implementation strategies on improving recognition and treatment of high blood pressure in pregnant individuals. The study is comparing the usual care provided by 20 outpatient clinics in central North Carolina to the care provided after the clinics have received the ACHIEVE multi-component implementation strategy for 12 months. The primary outcome measures include the normalized percentage of achieving the highest possible score for blood pressure measurement technique and documentation of delivery of patient education on hypertension. Secondary outcome measures include the normalized percentage of achieving the highest possible score for recognition and response to simulated episodes of severe hypertension and recognition and response to actual episodes of severe hypertension. The study aims to determine the impact of the implementation strategies on improving maternal health outcomes in rural, low-income, and women of color who are at greatest risk for complications of high blood pressure in pregnancy and postpartum.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of three text-messaging programs (loss-framed, gain-framed, and gain-framed and loss-framed) in reducing drinking among older adults (age 50-85). The study will randomize participants to one of the three conditions and assess the primary outcome measures (weekly sum of standard drinks and weekly sum of heavy drinking days) at baseline, week 4, week 8, and week 16. Secondary outcome measures include adherence to daily and weekly drinking assessment via text messages, willingness to continue the program for another 8 weeks, and other terms related to the study. The study will explore how the effects of the conditions are impacted by gender and age.

This is a clinical trial to assess the safety and efficacy of 18F-Fluselenamyl, a novel PET imaging agent for Alzheimer's disease. The study will enroll healthy volunteers and participants with mild cognitive impairment. The primary outcome measures will be the biodistribution, kinetics, and human dosimetry of 18F-Fluselenamyl, as well as its ability to image amyloid beta in the brain. The study will be conducted over a period of 1-2 years.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to assess the long-term effect of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in primary progressive aphasia (PPA). The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment, triple-masked, controlled trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to either active TMS (with language therapy) or sham TMS (with language therapy) groups. The primary outcome measure is changes in FDG-PET imaging (Standard Uptake Value ratio) at 0 and 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include spontaneous language, language assessment (Mini-Linguistic State Examination), language assessment (trained words), language assessment (untrained words), daily-living activities, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. The study will run for 6 months, with participants receiving TMS sessions daily for two weeks, followed by one session per week.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of Methylprednisolone in patients with post-COVID-19 syndrome (PCS) and cognitive deficits. The study aims to assess the improvement in memory satisfaction, memory ability, and memory strategy as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire (MMQ) in patients treated with Methylprednisolone compared to those treated with placebo. The study also aims to evaluate the safety and tolerability of Methylprednisolone in this patient population. The study will enroll approximately 10-40% of patients with PCS and will be conducted at 20-52 weeks after the first dose of IMP.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an oral nutritional supplement rich in omega-3 and olive oil polyphenols in the treatment of malnutrition in patients with inflammation. The study will measure the primary outcome measures of blood biochemistry, such as albumin, prealbumin, C-reactive protein, ferritin, neutrophils, lymphocytes, platelets, and secondary outcome measures of bioelectrical impedance, functional parameters, oral intake, and malnutrition diagnosis. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 consecutive months and will include 30 patients.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a nutritional intervention in improving glycemic control, reducing food insecurity, and improving dietary habits among adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The study will randomly assign participants to either an intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will receive financial support for healthy food items and free home delivery through the Instacart platform, while the control group will receive only free home delivery through the Instacart platform. The study will assess the primary outcome measure of 6-month change in glycosylated hemoglobin level, as well as secondary outcome measures such as 12-month change in glycosylated hemoglobin level, percentage of participants with glycosylated hemoglobin <7.5%, all-cause hospitalizations or emergency department visits, change in self-reported level of food security, change in self-reported level of nutrition security, change in self-reported dietary habits, change in self-reported diabetes-related quality of life, and change in self-reported readiness to change.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial to evaluate the effect of prolonged evaporation time of the solvent of two universal adhesives on the quality of cervical lesion restorations. The study includes 35 non-carious cervical lesions in each of the four groups (experimental, experimental, control, and control). The primary outcome measures are retention of restorations and marginal adaptation of restorations, assessed using World Dental Federation (FDI) criteria. Secondary outcome measures include marginal staining of restorations. The study is conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida, and the results will be available after 24 months.

The study is a randomized, double-blinded, parallel controlled trial to evaluate the immunogenicity, safety, and efficacy of a heterologous booster dose with COVID-19 mRNA vaccines (Bivalent) in previously vaccinated subjects against COVID-19 with 2/3 doses COVID-19 vaccine. The study will be conducted in individuals who were previously vaccinated with 2/3 doses of COVID-19 vaccine, with or without previously diagnosed with COVID-19. The interval between the date of last dose and the date of this study vaccination should be 6 to 24 months. There are two groups in phase 2 stage, total number 200 subjects who are ≥18 years old.

The Esbjerg Cohort is a cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the relationship between ergonomic exposure and physical capacity on work ability and musculoskeletal pain in workers aged 55-70 years old. The study includes a range of outcome measures, such as work ability, height, weight, body mass index, waist-to-hip ratio, blood pressure, pain threshold, warm and cold detection threshold, heat and cold pain threshold, temporal summation, conditioned pain modulation, physical activity, musculoskeletal pain, and additional questions about ergonomics and pain. The study also includes a range of physical tests, such as the 30-seconds sit to stand test, balance test, stair climb test, and maximal aerobic capacity (VO2 max) test. The study population consists of 336 citizens divided into 12 groups stratified for gender, age (< 60 years, 60-64 years and above 64 years) and occupational group (white-collar or blue-collar worker). The study is conducted in the municipality of Esbjerg, Denmark.

This is a dose-escalation study of autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cells for treating patients with extensive stage small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer. Patients undergo leukapheresis to obtain PBMCs for T cell product manufacturing and may undergo bridging therapy at the discretion of the treating clinician on study. Patients then undergo lymphodepleting chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide and fludarabine or single agent bendamustine at the discretion of the treating clinician and/or PI. Patients receive an autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cells infusion on day 0. Based on disease response and persistence of CAR T cells, patients may receive additional lymphodepletion chemotherapy and an autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cell infusion as soon as 6 weeks and no later than 24 weeks after the first infusion, or at the discretion of the PI. Patients also undergo ECHO or MUGA during screening. Patients undergo x-ray imaging, CT, bone scan, and blood sample collection throughout the trial. Additionally, patients may undergo tissue biopsy on the trial.

Note: This summary is generated based on the provided information and may not be comprehensive or up-to-date. It is important to consult the relevant clinical trial database or contact the trial sponsor for the most current and accurate information.

The study compares the safety and efficacy of Whipple over the splenic artery (WOTSA) with total pancreatectomy (TP) as a treatment for pancreatic ductal cell adenocarcinoma (PDCA). 40 patients who underwent WOTSA and 30 patients who underwent TP were included in the study. The study found that WOTSA is a safe and effective alternative to TP for PDCA treatment, with similar clinicopathological characteristics and survival outcomes between the two groups.

The study aims to evaluate the effect of breastfeeding education given to fathers via WhatsApp messaging application in the postpartum period on breastfeeding. The study will be conducted as an experimental design with four groups of solomon, and the participants will be assigned to the experimental and control groups randomly. The primary outcome measures will be breastfeeding support scale and partner breastfeeding influence scale, which will be administered to the fathers and mothers on the 3rd and 42nd day postpartum respectively. The study will measure the effect of fathers' support on breastfeeding and the duration of breastfeeding.

This non-interventional study aims to evaluate the frequency of PIK3CA mutations in patients with advanced breast cancer and to assess the treatment patterns among patients with PIK3CA-mutated advanced breast cancer. The study will measure the number of patients with PIK3CA mutations, time from first BC diagnosis to first PIK3CA evaluation, time from advanced BC diagnosis to first PIK3CA evaluation, time from initiation of first-line treatment for advanced BC diagnosis to first PIK3CA evaluation, number of tests for patients with CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment, time from progression on CDK4/6 inhibitor to first PIK3CA evaluation, year of (first, where applicable) PIK3CA evaluation, result of PIK3CA evaluation (negative, positive, unknown), type of biopsy, type of tissue sample, source of tissue sample, analytical method used for PIK3CA evaluation, age at advanced breast cancer diagnosis, stage when patients were diagnosed with BC, number of patients with known metastatic sites, performance as assessed by Karnofsky Performance Scale, performance as assessed by the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Performance Status Scale, height, weight, body mass index (BMI), number of patients per stage of cancer, number of patients per line of treatment, time from advanced diagnosis to initiation of lines of treatment, number of patients per systemic therapy, number of patients per treatment sequence, number of patients per supportive treatment.

The study is investigating the effects of melatonin on sleep spindles in children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The study will involve 20 participants who will be given 5mg of melatonin in the form of a gummy 30 minutes before bedtime for 2 consecutive nights. The primary outcome measure will be the change in sleep spindle density during non-Rapid Eye Movement (NREM) sleep, which will be measured using a portable EEG device. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in sleep quality. The study is open-label, meaning that both the participants and researchers are aware of the intervention. The study will run for five nights over two weeks.

The study aims to investigate the etiology of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency in children with operated velopalatine cleft by analyzing velopharyngeal motor skills in static and dynamic MRI. The study will enroll children aged 7 to 12 years with isolated cleft lip and/or velopalatal cleft, and will assess their velopharyngeal motor skills using real-time MRI. The study will also evaluate the ratio between the diameter of pharynx at rest and during phonation, closure distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall, and distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall. The study will be conducted at the Amiens University Hospital, and will include 40 participants.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a home-based exercise program in improving cognitive and mobility outcomes in older adults with multiple sclerosis. The study will randomly assign participants to either an exercise program or a stretching program and measure outcomes at baseline, 16 weeks, and 32 weeks. The primary outcome measures include cognitive function, physical function, and functional mobility, while secondary outcome measures include physical activity level, daily step count, exercise behavior, vascular function, and augmentation index. The study will adopt an innovative intervention approach via telerehabilitation and is convenient and accessible for older adults with MS.

The study is a pilot, non-interventional research involving critically ill patients admitted to intensive care with vasoplegic shock (hemodynamic support by noradrenaline). The study aims to measure the clinical and biological effects of using the oXiris hemofiltration membrane on haemodynamic stabilization and clearance of vasoactive metabolites. The study will include 30 patients and will be conducted over a period of 90 days. The primary outcome measure is the reduction in vasoinotropic score within 24 hours of initiation of oXiris hemofiltration. Secondary outcome measures include the evolution of vaso-inotropic score within 72 hours of management, quantitative determination of angiotensins and regulatory enzymes, clearance of endothelial permeability markers, markers of sepsis-induced immunosuppression, mortality at 90 days, and haemodynamic response at 24 hours of treatment with oXiris. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to compare the efficacy of central and lateral urinary bladder dissection during total laparoscopic hysterectomy in patients with previous cesarean section. The study is a randomized controlled trial with 2 arms: central urinary bladder dissection and lateral urinary bladder dissection. The primary outcome measure is the rate of urinary bladder injury during dissection, which will be measured intraoperatively. Secondary outcome measures include operative time, amount of blood loss, and late urological complications, which will be measured from time of primary port insertion till vault closure and intraoperative up to 2 months postoperative, respectively.

This is a 6-month observational study that aims to investigate the association between the asthma microbiome and disease characteristics, severity, and treatment response. The study will enroll patients with a possible or established diagnosis of asthma and will collect various biological samples, including blood, oral rinse, nasopharyngeal swab, exhaled breath condensate, stool, and induced sputum. The study will also perform pulmonary function testing and use questionnaires to assess symptoms. The primary outcome measures will include the description of the microbiome signature across the spectrum of asthma severity, the establishment of any association between asthma phenotype and microbiome signature, and the determination of whether the microbiome signature can predict treatment response or resistance.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it captures the key aspects of the trial, including the study design, inclusion and exclusion criteria, primary outcome measures, and the terms related to the study.

This study compares the effects of split-body and full-body resistance training on strength and functional performance in amateur cricket players. 28 participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental (split-body) or active comparator (full-body) group. Both groups will undergo 6 weeks of training, with measurements taken before and after the training period. The primary outcome measures will be bench press test, leg press test, and 30-second sit to stand test. The study aims to determine the most effective training method for improving strength and functional performance in cricket players.

The study aims to investigate the effect of training on breastfeeding given to fathers on breastfeeding self-efficacy level, parent-baby bonding, and breastfeeding. The study will be conducted on 100 mothers and fathers in a hospital setting. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: experimental group 1 (breastfeeding training given to mothers and fathers), experimental group 2 (breastfeeding training given only to mothers), and control group (no intervention). The primary outcome measures will be breastfeeding self-efficacy scale-short form, mother to infant bonding scale, father breastfeeding self-efficacy scale short form, paternal-infant attachment questionnaire, and baby evaluation form. The study will be conducted for 3 months.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, controlled trial to investigate the effects of Amway bundle combination of products on osteoarthritis and sarcopenia. The study includes 4 arms: active comparator (Bundle Group 1 with Nutrilite Lifestyle), active comparator (Bundle Group 2 without Nutrilite Lifestyle), placebo comparator (Control Group 1), and placebo comparator (Control Group 2 with Nutrilite Lifestyle). Participants are required to be Chinese males or females aged between 50-70, with SPPB scale 4-9, and able to walk 400 meters within 15 minutes. The study measures the change of Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) score, WOMAC Questionnaire Scores, Visual Analogue Scale/Score (VAS), Chalder Fatigue Scale (CFS), improvement of fat and muscle portions measured by Inbody S10, change of hand & grip strength measured by Jamar Smart Hand Dynamometer, and change of bone density measured by DXA Bone Densitometer from baseline to day 180. The study is conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.
