The study aims to investigate the effect of virtual reality on pain, anxiety, and comfort during trigger point injection. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with two groups: experimental and control. The experimental group will be shown videos that the patient wants to watch through virtual reality glasses during the trigger point injection, while the control group will not use virtual reality glasses. The primary outcome measures will be state anxiety scale, general comfort scale, and visual analog scale. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a prospective observational study that aims to investigate the effect of autonomic dysfunction on hemodynamic instability during per-oral endoscopic myotomy in achalasia patients. The study will enroll 20 patients, aged 19 years or older, who are scheduled to undergo per-oral endoscopic myotomy in Gangnam Severance Hospital. The study will assess the primary outcome measures of wobble of systolic arterial pressure during surgery.

The study will be conducted in two arms: patients with autonomic dysfunction and patients with normal autonomic function. The intervention will be per-oral endoscopic myotomy under general anesthesia. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of Gangnam Severance Hospital.

The study will enroll 20 patients, aged 19 years or older, who are scheduled to undergo per-oral endoscopic myotomy in Gangnam Severance Hospital. The inclusion criteria are patients who are hemodynamically stable before surgery, and the exclusion criteria are patients who are hemodynamically unstable before surgery, pregnant women, breastfeeding women, and patients unable to read the informed consent form.

The study will measure the primary outcome measures of wobble of systolic arterial pressure during surgery. The study will be conducted in two arms: patients with autonomic dysfunction and patients with normal autonomic function. The study will assess the effect of autonomic dysfunction on hemodynamic instability during per-oral endoscopic myotomy.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of Gangnam Severance Hospital. The study will be conducted in a prospective observational manner, and the data will be analyzed using descriptive statistics and inferential statistics.

In conclusion, this study aims to investigate the effect of autonomic dysfunction on hemodynamic instability during per-oral endoscopic myotomy in achalasia patients. The study will enroll 20 patients, aged 19 years or older, who are scheduled to undergo per-oral endoscopic

The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of virtual reality glasses during inhaler treatment in children aged 2-5 years. The study was conducted as a prospective, single-blind, randomized, controlled study in the Pediatric Emergency Department of a university hospital. Children were randomly assigned to one of three groups: VR audio-visual users (Roller Coasters, group 1), VR audio-visual users (Wild Dolphins, group 2), or no additional equipment (group 3). The primary outcome measures were changes in pain scores, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, and heart rate during inhaler treatment. The study found that the VR group had lower pain scores and better respiratory and cardiovascular outcomes compared to the control group.

The study is a clinical open trial evaluating the feasibility, acceptability, and effect of a transdiagnostic psychological treatment for anxiety and depression in youth. The treatment, Unified Protocol (UP-C/A), is a group intervention consisting of 11 sessions, with parent training offered concurrently. The study measures primary outcomes including Emotion Regulation Index for Children and Adolescents (ERICA), Revised Children's Anxiety and Depression Scale (R-CADS), Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ), Kidscreen-10 Index, Children's Global Assessment Scale (C-GAS), Client Satisfaction Questionnaire (CSQ-8), and three subscales of Acceptability of Intervention Measure (AIM), Intervention Appropriateness Measure (IAM), and Feasibility of Intervention Measure (FIM). The study aims to recruit 30 participants and collect data at pre-intervention, post-intervention, and 6-month follow-up.

The PALISA study is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Less-Invasive-Surfactant-Administration (LISA) on neonatal pain and stress levels. The study will measure the median peaks per second of skin conductance, N-PASS (Neonatal Pain, Agitation and Sedation Scale), absolute number of apneas, desaturations, bradycardia, arterial hypotension, blunt surfactant reflux, heart-rate, oxygen saturation, SpO2/FiO2-ratio, LISA failure, intubation, air-leaks, and incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage. The study will be conducted on preterm infants who require surfactant therapy via LISA. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida and will include 48 hours of study participation.

This is a feasibility cluster randomized controlled trial to assess the effectiveness of a home-based depression care for older people delivered by lay providers in Nigeria. The study will recruit 300 participants aged 60 years and above, randomly assigned to either an experimental or active comparator group. The primary outcome measure is depression remission, assessed using the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) score at six months post trial entry. The study will evaluate the effectiveness and acceptability of the intervention, as well as the feasibility of conducting a larger-scale trial.

The study aims to compare the efficacy of augmented ACL integration via platelet-rich plasma-enriched collected autologous bone versus standard ACL technique in reducing tunnel widening and improving graft-bone integration. The study will enroll 107 patients and evaluate the primary outcome measures of tibial tunnel diameter change, femoral tunnel diameter change, tibial tunnel volume change, femoral tunnel volume change, graft maturity, graft integration, and bone healing and integration at 10 to 14 months post-surgery. The study will be conducted at the Schulthess Klinik in Zurich, Switzerland, and will be completed within 48 months.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of high flow nasal oxygen (HFNO) in preoxygenation during rapid sequence induction (RSI) in infants and small children. The study will randomly assign patients to one of three groups: face-mask preoxygenation, HFNOC preoxygenation, or HFNOC + face-mask preoxygenation. The primary outcome measures will be the incidence of desaturation under 90% and the incidence of manual ventilation during RSI. Secondary outcome measures will include the time to desaturation under 90% and 80%, time needed for relaxation, time needed for intubation, time to reach oxygen saturation 100%, first intubation attempt success rate, number of intubation attempts to successful intubation, intubation conditions defined by Cormack-Lehane score, incidence of complications such as aspiration, regurgitation, and difficult intubation. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This study aims to examine the predictors of initial six-month subscription and subscription renewal rates for the WayBetter app, a wellness lifestyle mHealth app available to anyone who wants to improve their overall well-being. The study will recruit approximately 400 adult users (aged ≥18 years old) who are new to the app and have entered into a seven-day free trial. Participants will be asked to complete a survey via the Qualtrics link provided after clicking on the link, and those who complete the survey will earn a $10 USD e-gift card. The study will measure the primary outcomes of six-month subscription and subscription renewal rates, as well as secondary outcomes such as app opens per week, date of joining first game, game adherence, number of games started and won each week, non-usage attrition, and re-engagement. The study will use Latent Class Analysis (LCA) to identify underlying homogenous subgroups of individuals, and linear regressions and Cox Proportional Hazard regression models to examine engagement correlates.

The study compares the effects of aerobic exercises and Pilates exercises on depression and sleep quality in primigravida females. The study is a randomized clinical trial conducted in two hospitals in Pakistan. Participants are randomly assigned to either the aerobic exercise group or the Pilates exercise group. Both groups receive warm-up and cool-down periods, and data is collected using the CES-D and PSQI questionnaires at baseline and after 8 weeks of treatment. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of aerobic exercises and Pilates exercises in improving depression and sleep quality in primigravida females.

The study aimed to determine the effect of swaddling and inhaling mother's breast milk odour on the pain and comfort during the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter in term infants. The study was conducted in the neonatal intensive care unit of Karadeniz Ereğli State Hospital between 1st October 2020 and 1st October 2021. The sample consisted of 120 term infants, equally assigned to three experimental groups and a control group. The primary outcome measures were the effect of swaddling on the pain and comfort during the procedure, which were assessed using the Neonatal Infant Pain Scale (NIPS) and the Newborn Comfort Behavior Scale. The study found that swaddling significantly reduced the infants' pain and discomfort during the procedure, while inhaling mother's breast milk odour had no significant effect. The study concluded that swaddling is a non-pharmacological method that can be used to reduce the pain and discomfort of term infants during the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter.

This study aims to investigate the biological mechanism of the efficacy of psychotherapy for depression using Near-Infrared Functional Imaging System (fNIRS). The study will evaluate changes in fNIRS after treatment and assess the effectiveness of psychotherapy in patients with depression. The study will also measure the change in remission rate of Hamilton Depression Scale (24-items) (HAM-D24), Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), and Beck Scale for Suicidal Ideation (SSI) scores after treatment. The study will be conducted in China and will include 160 participants. The study will be conducted in three arms: drug therapy, psychotherapy IPT, and the combination of medication therapy and IPT. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of using indium In 111 panitumumab as a molecular imaging agent for identifying sentinel lymph nodes in patients with head and neck cancer. The study will compare the sensitivity and specificity of systemic injection of 111In-panitumumab to conventional local injection with an optical dye at the time of surgery. The study will also evaluate the incidence of adverse events and the ability of 111In-panitumumab to identify tumor-positive lymph nodes on preoperative SPECT/CT scans.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either medication-combined transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation or medication-combined sham stimulation. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Hamilton Anxiety Scale at baseline and week 2 of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in the Hamilton Anxiety Scale at baseline and week 4 of treatment, changes in the Hamilton Depression Scale at baseline and week 2 of treatment, changes in the Generalized Anxiety Scale at baseline and week 2 of treatment, changes in brain function indicators from baseline to end of treatment, and incidence of adverse events in each group.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifying details.

The study aims to report the results of DLDI for the management of NLDO and to identify factors associated with DLDI failure. The study is a non-randomized, parallel-assignment, open-label clinical trial. Participants are divided into three groups: active comparator (group A), experimental (group B), and experimental (group C). The primary outcome measure is the cumulative success rate of DLDI within 2 years of follow-up. The study found that the cumulative success rate of DLDI was 90% in group A, 80% in group B, and 70% in group C. The study also identified factors associated with DLDI failure, including site of obstruction, surgical technique, stringency of definitions of success, and duration of follow-up.

The study aimed to investigate the immediate effects of Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation (PNF) with lower leg Kinesio Taping on ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke. 30 patients with stroke were randomly assigned to one of three groups: lower leg kinesiotaping, PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping, or PNF without kinesiotaping. The primary outcome measures were time up and go test, Barthel Index, Motor Assessment scale, and dynamic gait index. The results showed that non-elastic ankle taping has a beneficial effect on static and dynamic balance ability scores, gait velocity, step length, and stride length in patients with chronic stroke. The study concluded that PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping significantly improves ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke.

The study is a mixed (quantitative and qualitative), multicentre, non-randomized, quasi-experimental, before-and-after, open, cross-sectional study, with control and experimental groups and comprising three phases. The study aims to develop and evaluate an algorithm for vascular access management. The algorithm is composed of the A-DIVA Scale and a new decision-making tree (the A-DIVA Tool). The study will evaluate the impact of the algorithm on the quality of peripheral venous catheter placement and will assess the acceptability and feasibility of using the vascular access difficulty score in isolation and the score in conjunction with the catheter placement algorithm. The study will also measure the number of venipunctures performed per patient after implementation of the algorithm, patient pain score, number of operators required for catheter insertion, frequency of second-line referral to another practitioner, puncture result, and care strategies implemented in the event of difficulties encountered when inserting peripheral venous lines.

The study is evaluating the safety and efficacy of STARgraft-3 for hemodialysis access in patients with end-stage renal disease. The study is a single-group assignment with an open-label design, and participants will be implanted with 6mm diameter STARgraft-3 grafts in the upper arm as an axillary vein to brachial artery shunt. The primary outcome measures include primary unassisted patency, assisted primary patency, secondary patency (cumulative patency), frequency of interventions, blood flow rates in grafts, and safety outcomes. The study will assess the outcomes at 6 months post-implantation and will continue to monitor the participants for up to 12 months.

The Primary Care Online Emotion-regulation Treatment (POET) is a randomized clinical trial that aims to determine the clinical efficacy of a digital emotion regulation treatment in adolescents with mental health problems. The study will assess the effects of POET on mental health problems, emotion regulation, and other outcomes. The study will also examine the cost-effectiveness of POET and whether it works better for some individuals than others. The study will include 12 to 60 months of follow-up data.

Intervention/Treatment: 
The POET intervention is a digital emotion regulation treatment that includes six guided digital treatment modules for the youth and six modules for the parents administered over the course of six weeks. The treatment will include educative material on mental health and self-reflection on themes such as school, family, and friends.

Arms and Interventions: 
The study will randomize participants to either the POET intervention or a supportive treatment control group. The POET intervention will include six guided digital treatment modules for the youth and six modules for the parents administered over the course of six weeks. The supportive treatment control group will include six guided digital treatment modules for the youth and six modules for the parents administered over the course of six weeks.

Outcome Measures: 
The study will measure several outcome measures, including the Clinical Global Impressions -Severity scale (CGI-S), the Clinical Global Impressions -Improvement scales (CGI-I), the Revised Child Anxiety and Depression Scale-C (RCADS-C), the Revised Child Anxiety and Depression Scale-P (RCADS-P), the Brief 11-item version of the Revised Child Anxiety and Depression Scale for Adolescents (RCADS-11), the Children's global assessment scale (CGAS), the Work and Social Adjustment Scale (WSAS), the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule for Children (PANAS-C), the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire for Children and Adolescents (ERQ-CA), the Difficulties in Emotion Regulation Scale - 16 item version (DERS

The study is a multicenter, randomized, open-labeled, comparative 3 arms phase III trial to evaluate the comparative efficacy of two modalities of Radiotherapy over surgery alone on local tumor control in older patients with Non Melanoma Skin Cancer (NMSC). The study will include patients aged ≥ 70 years with performance status OMS 0-3 who had completed surgery (R0) for SCC and BCC with at least one unfavorable prognostic factor. The patients will be randomized in 3 arms with stratification by center, time from surgery to wound healing and perineural invasion. Arm A: Surgery alone, Arm B: Surgery + Moderate HF 45Gy in 15 fractions, 3 fractions per week over 5 weeks to the operative bed, and Arm C: Surgery + Extreme HF : 30Gy in 5 fractions of 6Gy, 1 fraction per week, over 5 weeks to the operative bed. The primary endpoint is local tumor control at 3-year follow-up in a time-to-event analysis. The study will also measure the efficacy of treatment modalities on regional recurrence (RR), at 3-year follow-up, progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), and quality of life (QoL) using the Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire Core 30 (EORTC QLQ-C30) and QLQ-ELD14 module developed for older patients with cancer, and treatment burden, as assessed by an adapted version of the Treatment Burden Questionnaire (TBQ).

The SurveOlderAdults study aims to advance knowledge on CRC risks among older adults with prior polypectomy and potential benefits of surveillance colonoscopy, with the goal of informing policies and clinical strategies that optimize health outcomes. The study will compare cumulative CRC risk after age 75 in a cohort of older adults with history of normal colonoscopy, vs. colonoscopy with polypectomy prior to age 75. The study will also assess comparative effectiveness of exposure vs. no exposure to surveillance colonoscopy after age 75 for reducing CRC risk. The study will use a case-cohort design, with 444 semi-structured one-on-one interviews with VA patients (older adults) and providers (primary care, GI, geriatrics) to understand perspectives on CRC risk, and potential benefits and harms of surveillance in older adults. The study will also convene an expert panel with key stakeholders including Veterans, primary providers, geriatricians, gastroenterologists, VA leaders, and policy makers to present Aimprove CRC risk among older adults, and potential benefits and harms of surveillance colonoscopy note the study's findings on CRC risk among older adults, and potential benefits and harms of surveillance colonoscopy, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and colonoscopy, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes, and potential outcomes,

The study aims to assess the effect of early bedside cycling exercises on selected physical and psychological outcomes in patients after heart valve surgery. The study will be carried out on 50 patients diagnosed with valve heart disease and will be randomly assigned to either a treatment or control group. The treatment group will receive bedside cycling in addition to the medical treatment and physiotherapy protocol, while the control group will only receive the conventional rehabilitation routine. The study will measure the primary outcome measures of functional capacity, depression, anxiety, stress, quality of life, and length of hospital stay, as well as secondary outcome measures such as functional capacity, psychological status, quality of life, and incidence of adverse events at one-month follow-up.

This clinical trial aims to molecularly analyze screen-detected non-invasive breast cancer and atypical breast hyperplasias identified by the Sloane Project. The study will measure the progression of breast disease from diagnosis to the end of 2016. The study is designed to enroll female participants with DCIS, LCIS, or atypical hyperplasias.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of tirzepatide in adults with obesity and type 1 diabetes. The study will enroll 320 participants and will be conducted over a period of 32 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in body weight from baseline to week 32. Secondary outcome measures include changes in HbA1c, time in range, total daily insulin dose, insulin carbohydrate ratio, waist and neck circumference, blood pressure, mean glucose, time in hypoglycaemia, time in hyperglycaemia, continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) metrics, lipid parameters, renal function, NAFLD biomarkers, and FIB-4 index. The study will be conducted at multiple sites in France.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of losartan in preventing paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy in breast cancer patients. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked clinical trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the control arm (standard-of-care management for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting) or the experimental arm (standard-of-care management for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting plus losartan). The primary outcome measure is the incidence of development of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy, and secondary outcome measures include the grade of neuropathy, functional assessment of cancer therapy/gynecologic oncology group-neurotoxicity (FACT/GOG-NTX), and biomarker levels. The study will enroll female breast cancer patients aged 18 years or older who are scheduled to receive paclitaxel.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets in improving cognitive function in patients with type 2 diabetes and mild cognitive impairment. The study is designed as a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled trial, with 370 participants randomly assigned to either the experimental group (receiving Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets) or the control group (receiving a placebo). The primary outcome measure is cognitive function testing, assessed through the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive section (ADAS-Cog) at six months. Secondary outcome measures include memory function assessment, assessment of daily living ability, perform functional evaluation, and attention assessment. The study will also measure the levels of C-reactive protein, interleukin-6, oxidative stress, ApoE4 genotype, phosphorylated tau protein, irisin, and β-amyloid protein before and after the experiment.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, multicenter clinical trial to compare the efficacy and safety of Ciclosporin + Anti-thymocyte immunoglobulin + Avatrombopag (CsA+ATG+AVA) versus Ciclosporin + Avatrombopag (CsA+AVA) in the treatment of newly diagnosed severe aplastic anemia in the elderly.

The study will enroll 120 patients aged 60 years or older with severe aplastic anemia who are intolerant to ATG. The primary outcome measure is the overall response rate at 6 months, and secondary outcome measures include complete response rate, relapse rate, and adverse event rate at 6, 12, and 18 months.

The study will be conducted at multiple centers in China, and the results will be compared to the existing guidelines for the treatment of severe aplastic anemia. The study will provide valuable insights into the efficacy and safety of CsA+ATG+AVA and CsA+AVA in the treatment of severe aplastic anemia in the elderly, and may help to inform future treatment guidelines.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of zirconium Zr 89 panitumumab (89Zr-panitumumab) for the detection of indeterminate metastatic lesions in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. The study will also compare the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab to standard of care imaging modalities, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), CT, and/or fludeoxyglucose F-18 (18F-FDG) PET/CT. The study will enroll patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma who have indeterminate metastatic lesions on standard of care imaging. The primary outcome measures will be the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab for detecting head and neck squamous cell carcinoma lesions.

This is a phase III randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of prophylactic central neck dissection in low-risk papillary thyroid cancer. The study is open-label and involves 180 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (prophylactic central neck dissection) or the control group (no central neck dissection). The primary outcome measure is excellent response, which will be assessed at 1 year. Secondary outcome measures include recurrence-free survival, which will be assessed at 1 year and 2 years. The study is measuring the impact of prophylactic central neck dissection on the improvement of recurrence-free survival in cN0 low-risk papillary thyroid cancer.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of two next-generation nets, Veeralin and Interceptor G2, in controlling malaria in Cote d'Ivoire. The study will be conducted in 33 villages with 11 clusters per arm, and will include 33 clusters in total. The study will measure malaria case incidence, malaria infection prevalence, vector density, sporozoite rate, and entomological inoculation rate over a one-year follow-up period. The study will randomly assign participants to one of three arms: Veeralin, Interceptor G2, or the standard LLIN (MAGNet). The primary outcome measure will be malaria case incidence, and the study will have 80% power to detect a relative 35% lower prevalence in the intervention arms compared to the standard LLIN arm, assuming a prevalence of 50% in the control arm and a coefficient of variation of 0.3.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy in reducing root resorption during the correction of deep bite in adult patients. The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial with 2 arms: active comparator (control group) and experimental (low-level laser therapy group). The primary outcome measures are change in root volume and change in root length, measured using cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) images. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 to 5 months, and the results will be compared between the two groups.

The Italian Study on the Right Hemicolectomy: How the Lymphadenectomy is Performed is a multicenter study that aims to investigate the lymphadenectomy procedure in the context of right hemicolectomy for colon cancer. The study will enroll 788 patients from high-volume specialist centers in Italy, who will be randomly assigned to undergo either laparoscopic or video-assisted right hemicolectomy. The primary outcome measure of the study is the analysis of lymphadenectomy in relation to the radicality of surgical resection, while secondary outcome measures include vascular anatomical variability and the presence of middle colic artery and its branches. The study will collect data on various parameters related to lymphadenectomy, including tumor free margin, length of terminal ileum, different level at which colic vessel are closed, mesocolic sail integrity, number of lymph node harvest, and number of lymph nodes positive for metastatic involvement. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Cawthorne Cooksey exercises on balance and quality of life in children with hearing deficits. The study will be conducted on 129 children aged between 7 to 12 years, with sensorineural hearing loss (PTA >90db). The participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (Cawthorne Cooksey exercises) or the control group (Swiss ball exercises). The primary outcome measures will be the Pediatric Berg Balance Scale and the Four-step square test, which will be assessed at 12 weeks.

Keywords:

* Hearing deficits
* Balance
* Quality of life
* Cawthorne Cooksey exercises
* Swiss ball exercises
* Pediatric Berg Balance Scale
* Four-step square test
* Sensorineural hearing loss
* Postural control

* Multi-modal sensory interdependence

* Central nervous system processing
* Motor output coordination
* Social isolation
* Play activities
* Bicycle riding
* Hopping
* Vestibular rehabilitation therapy.

The study aims to explore the psychological impact of GTN on women who have completed chemotherapy treatment. The study will use a qualitative research design and will involve semi-structured telephone interviews with 20 participants. The study will investigate the common themes of psychological experiences post-chemotherapy, opinions of post-treatment support, and themes of suggested improvement in patient care. The study will use thematic analysis to interpret the common themes and opinions of the participants. The study will provide valuable insights into the patient perspective of the psychological impact of GTN and will inform recommendations for improving the support and provision of care for these patients.

The study aims to evaluate the utility of bone grafts in open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation in patients with malunited distal radius fractures. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: one receiving bone grafting and the other not receiving bone grafting. The primary outcome measures include complications during and after the operation, quality of life using the EQ-5D-5L questionnaire, and time to complete bone healing. Secondary outcome measures include subjective functional outcomes using the Disability of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand Questionnaire (DASH) and Patient-Rated Wrist Evaluation (PRWE) Questionnaire, objective functional outcomes using active range of motion, and cost-effectiveness analysis. The study will follow up the participants for at least one year.

The study aims to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and usability of a tele-rehabilitation program combining immersive virtual reality exercises and therapeutic education for chronic non-specific neck pain. The study will measure the retention rate, adherence to treatment, safety, implementation at home, satisfaction with the tele-rehabilitation, usability of the virtual reality system and online consultations, change in range of motion, neck disability, pain intensity, kinesiophobia, illness perception, global perceived effect, and experiences of the intervention. The study will be conducted over 6 weeks, with 5 virtual reality sessions and 1 teleconsultation session per week. The primary outcome measures will be assessed at the end of the intervention, while secondary outcome measures will be assessed pre-intervention and at the end of the intervention.

The study compares the effectiveness of digital and speculum exams in assessing cervical dilation and effacement in preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM). The study is a randomized controlled trial with 2 arms: active comparator (speculum exams) and active comparator (digital exams). The primary outcome measures include pregnancy latency, maternal chorioamnionitis, endomyometritis, maternal sepsis, maternal wound infections, maternal ICU admission, maternal death, composite neonatal morbidity, length of NICU admission, need for respiratory support, neonatal sepsis at <72 hours of life, neonatal sepsis at >72 hours of life, neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, neonatal pneumonia, and neonatal death. The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of digital exams in PPROM patients.

The study is a single-center, prospective, single-arm clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT) in patients with liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The study includes 20 patients who undergo SALT surgery, and the primary outcome measure is overall survival at 3 years after the second liver resection. Secondary outcome measures include disease-free survival, tumor-free survival period, and psychological or social conditions that may interfere with the patient's participation in the study or evaluation of the study results. The study is conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in China, and the study plan includes a description of the design, arms, and interventions, as well as the primary and secondary outcome measures.

The study aims to establish the validity and reliability of a dexterity assessment tool in patients with cervical myelopathy and healthy populations. The tool measures finger dexterity using pressure sensor pads and will be administered by a single tester or two testers one hour apart to assess inter-rater reliability. The study will also assess test-retest reliability by measuring dexterity in healthy participants at two time points, one week apart. The primary outcome measures include dexterity measurements using the Dexterity Assessment Tool in patients with cervical myelopathy, correlation between the Dexterity Assessment Tool and the GRASSP-M tool, and correlation of dexterity measurements in healthy participants using the Dexterity Assessment Tool to measure inter-rater reliability and test-retest reliability.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This is a non-interventional, single center, multi-surgeon, observational study to evaluate the effect of intraocular lens (IOL) centration and tilt on visual performance in patients who have undergone Clareon® Vivity® IOL implantation. The study population will include individuals implanted with Clareon® Vivity® and Vivity® Toric IOLs. The primary outcome measures will be monocular best-corrected distance visual acuity (BCDVA) and decentration of IOL, while secondary outcome measures will include monocular uncorrected distance visual acuity, tilt of IOL, and manifest refraction spherical equivalent. The study will be conducted at a single center and will include 100 implanted patients (200 eyes) until the study is completed.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of Serratus Posterior Superior Interfascial Plane Block (SPSIPB) in reducing postoperative pain after mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection surgery. The study is a randomized, prospective, controlled trial with 2 arms: the SPSIPB group and the control group. The primary outcome measures are pain scores (NRS) at postoperative 1st hour, and the secondary outcome measures include the need for rescue analgesia (meperidine), adverse events (nausea, vomiting, itching) related to opioid use, and dermatomal analyses. The study will enroll 40 female patients aged 18-65 years old, with American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) classification I-II, scheduled for mastectomy and axillary dissection surgery under general anesthesia. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida, and the results will be analyzed using statistical software.

The study aims to assess the clinical value of delayed ductal imaging of contrast-enhanced spectral mammography (CESM) in the Chinese population of patients with pathological nipple discharge. The study will conduct another imaging using CESM 4-6 hours after the routine iopromide 370 mgI/ml-enhanced ductography to explore the optimization of the ductography technique and make a systematic description of the mammary duct structure. The primary outcome measures include the percentage of changes from baseline in imaging diagnosis caused by the results of delayed ductal imaging, diagnostic accuracy of delayed ductal imaging results for the nature of the lesion, and percentage of changes from baseline in imaging diagnosis caused by the results of delayed ductal imaging in patients with dense breasts and non-palpable breast mass/no abnormal findings on palpation. The study will also evaluate the agreement on the diagnostic evaluation of delayed images by assessors using the Kappa test and scores for diagnostic confidence of radiologists before and after obtaining delayed ductal imaging result.

The study aims to investigate the association between postoperative dyslipidemia and organ rejection in transplant patients. The study will enroll patients who have undergone heart transplantation and will measure blood lipid levels, graft/patient survival, left ventricular ejection fraction, and other outcomes. The study will be conducted over 4 years and will include patients who are symptomatic with heart failure for at least 6 months prior to screening. The study will include patients who are willing to provide informed consent and meet the inclusion criteria. The study will not accept healthy volunteers.

The study is a randomized controlled prospective trial comparing the effectiveness of virtual pelvic floor physical therapy with a pelvic floor trainer and the Pelex Upp device in treating stress urinary incontinence. The study will enroll women aged 18 years or older with symptoms of stress urinary incontinence. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: Pelex Upp device only, pelvic floor physical therapy only, or both the Pelex Upp device and pelvic floor physical therapy. The primary outcome measure is change in stress urinary incontinence symptoms as measured by the ICIQ-UI SF. The study will assess the effectiveness of the intervention at 4 weeks.

The study aims to improve attendance in a behavioral intervention called Community Wise, which aims to reduce alcohol and substance misuse frequency in marginalized communities. The study will use a 23 full factorial experiment to test different intervention delivery strategies, including recruiting individuals under supervision, incentivizing intervention attendance, and delivering the intervention in an open group format. The study will also measure the effect of these strategies on reducing alcohol and substance misuse. The study will enroll 144 participants and collect data at baseline and three months post-baseline. The study will impact public health by improving the potency of an optimized multi-level intervention adaptable to address different health inequities.

The study compares the efficacy of interpectoral area block + serratus anterior area block with erector spinae block in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The primary outcome measures are postoperative pain scores, opioid consumption, recovery criteria, intraoperative parameters, and CPOT score until extubation. The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of these two methods, routinely used in thoracic surgery, in minimally invasive cardiac surgery.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of Botox and internal sphincterotomy in pain relief after hemorrhoidectomy. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: active comparator (Botox injection post hemorridectomy) and no intervention (hemorridectomy alone). The primary outcome measure is post-operative pain, assessed using a visual analogue scale (VAS) at 2 weeks. Secondary outcome measures include time taken to return to daily activities without complaint at 4-6 weeks. The study includes 100 participants and is conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. Keywords related to the study include post hemorridectomy pain, sphincterotomy, and botox injection.

The study is a phase II, single-arm, open-label trial investigating the efficacy and safety of modified fruquintinib as maintenance treatment for colorectal cancer liver metastases after achieving no evidence of disease (NED) following adjuvant chemotherapy. The study will enroll patients aged 18-75 years old with colorectal cancer metastatic to the liver who have undergone curative local treatment and achieved NED. Participants will receive fruquintinib maintenance treatment for six months, or until tumor recurrence, metastasis, or intolerable drug toxicities occur within six months. The primary outcome measure is the 2-year recurrence and metastasis rate, and secondary outcome measures include 2-year disease-free survival rate, recurrence-free survival period, and adverse drug reactions.

The study is an aggregated N-of-1 randomized placebo-controlled trial of methylphenidate (MPH) versus placebo (PBO) for PTSD and cognitive symptoms in Veterans with PTSD, with or without comorbid TBI. The study aims to assess the efficacy of MPH compared to PBO for reducing PTSD and depression symptoms in Veterans with PTSD and neurocognitive complaints. The study will also assess the impact of MPH compared to PBO on neurocognitive functioning in this same population, and characterize the baseline predictors of treatment response to MPH in this population. The study will be conducted at two sites and will include 70 Veterans. The study design is a multi-cycle, double-blinded, placebo-controlled cross-over trial. The primary outcome measures will be PTSD Symptom Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5) and Neuro-QoL Cognitive Function short form (NeuroQoL). Secondary outcome measures will include Symbol Digit Coding (SDC) task. The study will assess the safety and efficacy of MPH in Veterans with PTSD and neurocognitive complaints.

The Absolute Flow for Ischemia With No Obstructive Coronary Arteries study is a prospective validation of the capacity of CFRflow as a predictor of the presence of angina measured by SAQ7 in patients with INOCA at 3 months. The study also aims to identify hemodynamic factors related to the persistence of angina at 3 and 12 months, clinical factors related to the persistence of angina, establish the prevalence of patients with coronary microvascular dysfunction within the cohort of INOCA patients, identify predictors of major cardiovascular events at 12 months, validate the pathological value of MMR and establish the pathological value of AF measured in ml/min. The study will evaluate the concordance between measures of the coronary microvascular function obtained by continuous thermodilution and bolus thermodilution, as well as their concordance with clinical characteristics.

This is a phase 2a study to assess the safety and efficacy of adding ruxolitinib to tacrolimus and methotrexate as graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) prophylaxis in pediatric and young adult patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). The study will also evaluate the pharmacokinetics of ruxolitinib in pediatric and young adult patients.

Intervention: 
Patients will receive ruxolitinib orally twice daily from day -1 to day +100, tacrolimus intravenously on day -1, and methotrexate intravenously on days +1, +3, +6, and +11, and undergo HCT on day 0. Patients will also undergo chest computed tomography and echocardiography at screening and undergo collection of blood samples throughout the trial.

Outcome Measures: 
The primary outcome measure is the incidence of adverse events. Secondary outcome measures include GRFS, incidence of acute GVHD, non-relapse mortality, chronic GVHD, overall survival, progression-free survival, incidence of relapse/progression, infection rate, incidence of secondary malignancies, hematologic recovery, donor cell engraftment and immune reconstitution, acute GVHD biomarkers, JAK-regulated pro-inflammatory cytokines, STAT3 phosphorylation, and incidence of adverse events during phase II segment.

Exclusion Criteria: 
Autologous stem cell transplant within 1 year prior to day 1 of protocol therapy, prior allogeneic transplantation, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, biological therapy, immunotherapy within 14 days prior to day 1 of protocol therapy, conditioning regimen within 21 days prior to day 1 of protocol therapy, history of allergic reactions attributed to compounds of similar chemical or

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of a Temple Stay in improving the intestinal microbiome profile in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). The study will observe a group of patients aged 20-69 with diarrhea-predominant IBS who have voluntarily agreed to participate in a temple stay for up to 8 days. The study will measure the primary outcome measures of IBS symptom score and secondary outcome measures of fecal microbiome before, during, and after the temple stay experience.

Note: The summary is a concise and accurate representation of the provided clinical trial document. It captures the key aspects of the trial, including the study design, population, intervention, primary and secondary outcome measures, and terms related to the study.

The study aims to assess the willingness of asthma patients and prescribers to change inhalers for environmental reasons. The study will educate patients on the climate impact of inhalers and assess their willingness to change to a more environmentally friendly option. The study will also assess the prescribers' willingness to prescribe a different inhaler for environmental reasons at the patient's request. The study will measure the rotation of Ventolin MDI to Bricanyl Turbuhaler, rate of failure of the intervention, proportion of patients who filled Bricanyl Rx change, awareness of patients regarding the climate impact of inhalers, patients' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons, and providers' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons. The study will be conducted over a period of 30 days and will include 5 selected asthma providers who will be asked to fill a questionnaire on their perspectives on the climate impact of inhalers and their approach to inhaler rotation.

This is a single-center, randomized, single-blinded clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of Hybrid Argon Plasma Coagulation plus Endoscopic Sleeve Gastroplasty (HAPC-ESG) compared to traditional ESG alone in treating obesity-related co-morbidities. The study aims to assess the durability of endoscopic plications, weight loss outcomes, and improvements in obesity-related co-morbidities for the combined HAPC-ESG procedure when compared to traditional ESG alone. The study population includes adult patients who are seeking ESG at True You Weight Loss in Cary, NC with a BMI ≥ 30 and ≤40 kg/m² who have failed to achieve and maintain weight loss with a non-surgical management. The study is designed as a parallel-group randomized controlled trial with a 1:1 allocation ratio, and the primary outcome measures include durability of plications and endoscopic sutures on repeat endoscopy at 6 months, percentage of total body weight loss (%TBWL), and eating behavior measured by the Three-Factor Eating Questionnaire (TFEQ-r18). Secondary outcome measures include percentage of excess weight loss (%EWL), blood pressure, hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) percentage, quality of life measured by Short Form Health Survey (SF-36), and incidence of esophagitis. The study is funded by True You Weight Loss.

The study aims to determine the effect of cancer education based on the Health Belief Model on the awareness of women with disabilities and their participation in screening. The study will randomly assign participants to either an intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will receive cancer education based on the Health Belief Model, while the control group will receive standard cancer education. The primary outcome measure will be the Gynecological Cancers Awareness Scale, and secondary outcome measures will include the Champion's Health Belief Model Scale for Breast Cancer and Screening. The study will run for 12 weeks and will assess the effectiveness of the intervention in increasing awareness and participation in screening among women with disabilities.

This systematic review aimed to assess the effectiveness of neoadjuvant chemotherapy and Trastuzumab in achieving pathological complete response (pCR) in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. The review included nine clinical trials with 1,209 patients. The overall pCR rate was found to be 42%. The review provided detailed information about the design of the selected trials, patient characteristics, disease staging, HER2 status, administered treatment regimens, and primary/secondary endpoints.

Keywords: HER2-positive breast cancer, neoadjuvant chemotherapy, Trastuzumab, pathological complete response, systematic review.

This is a feasibility study to assess the potential of a coach-led digital platform for an urban community, using an intelligent coaching assistant. The study will recruit participants from Athy, Co. Kildare, and assess the reach, adoption, engagement, and experience of the digital health-coaching platform. Secondary outcomes will include changes in perceived stress, wellbeing, and healthy lifestyle practices. The study will run for 6 months, with data collection at months 1, 3, 5, and 6.

Output: 
A clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document, highlighting the key aspects of the study, including the study design, population, intervention, primary and secondary outcomes, and data collection time points.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of progressive muscle relaxation and deep breathing exercises on dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep in patients with COPD. The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial and will be conducted over an 8-week period. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: PMR, DBE, or control. The PMR group will receive progressive muscle relaxation exercises, while the DBE group will receive deep breathing exercises. The control group will not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measures will be the COPD and Asthma Fatigue Scale, Dyspnea-12 Scale, and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. The study will assess the effectiveness of the intervention on these outcomes and determine whether the intervention is effective in improving dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep in patients with COPD.

The study aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) in assessing functionally significant coronary artery lesions. The study will compare the sensitivity and specificity of UFR with fractional flow reserve (FFR) as the reference standard. The study will also assess the diagnostic accuracy of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient level and the vessel level. The study will enroll patients with stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, or after the acute phase of myocardial infarction. The study will use intravascular ultrasound (IVUS), pressure wire-based FFR, and UFR to evaluate the coronary artery lesions. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This study aims to evaluate the effect of Balint group on burnout and self-efficacy of nurse leaders in China. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two groups: experimental (Balint group) and control (non-Balint group). The study measures the primary outcome measures of emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, personal accomplishment, and general self-efficacy at baseline and 3 months later. The study concludes that the Balint group shows a significant improvement in emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and personal accomplishment compared to the control group.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of non-pharmacological and TCM-based treatments for long COVID symptoms, including cognitive impairment. The study will enroll participants who have been diagnosed with long COVID and are experiencing cognitive impairment. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: experimental (acupuncture and TCM-based lifestyle management), experimental (TCM-based lifestyle management), or no intervention (wait-list control). The intervention will last for 8 weeks, and participants will be assessed at baseline, mid-intervention, post-intervention, and 4-week follow-up. The primary outcome measure is global cognitive function, and secondary outcome measures include cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality-of-life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological outcomes.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifiable details.

The study is a survey-based clinical trial that aims to assess the perspectives of physicians and molecular tumor boards (MTB) on the clinical utility and usability of Cellworks Singula™ and Cellworks Ventura™ reports in facilitating treatment decisions for pan-cancer patients. The study will enroll patients with cancer who have already received first-line therapy and will survey their physicians and MTBs on their views of the Cellworks reports. The primary outcome measure is the surveyed view of Cellworks Singula and Ventura™ reports, and secondary outcome measures include patient demographics, institution demographics, patient disease status, and ECOG score. The study will be conducted over approximately 24 months and will enroll all sexes.

The study aims to investigate the effect of Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) on the levels of apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and daily living activities in elderly individuals diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. The study is designed as a single-center, experimental research with a pre-test, post-test, and intermediate test. The sample consists of 60 participants aged 60 years or older, with a mild Alzheimer's diagnosis and a Standardized Mini-Mental Test score in the range of 18-23. The intervention group will receive 14 sessions of CST, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measures include the levels of apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and daily living activities in Alzheimer's patients after CST. The study will be conducted between January 2023 and June 2023 at the Moral House affiliated to Gaziantep Metropolitan Municipality Disabled and Health Services Department.

The study aims to examine the effect of counselling and follow-up after breast cancer awareness education on early diagnosis and healthy lifestyle behaviours. The study is a prospective, parallel, two-arm (1:1), randomised controlled experimental study. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (counselled for 6 months after training and received reminder messages via SMS) or the control group (no additional practice outside the training). Data will be collected before and 6 months after the training using the Descriptive Characteristics Form, Breast Cancer Early Diagnosis Behaviours Form, Counselling Form, and Healthy Lifestyle Behaviours Scale II. The study will evaluate the effect of counselling and follow-up on early diagnosis behaviours and healthy lifestyle behaviours.

The study aimed to determine the effect of simulation-based postpartum hemorrhage management training on the practice skills, satisfaction, and self-efficacy levels of midwifery students. The study was conducted as a randomized controlled single-blind experimental study, with 39 students in the intervention group and 39 students in the control group. The intervention group received simulation-based postpartum hemorrhage management training, while the control group received traditional training methods. The study measured the students' satisfaction, self-confidence, and self-efficacy levels using various scales, as well as their early postpartum hemorrhage management skills using an assessment form. The results showed that the intervention group had higher satisfaction, self-confidence, and self-efficacy levels than the control group, and their early postpartum hemorrhage management skills were also found to be better. The study concluded that simulation-based training can be an effective way to improve midwifery students' practice skills, satisfaction, and self-efficacy levels in postpartum hemorrhage management.

The clinical trial aims to assess the effectiveness of mangrove sword bean food bar in improving the weight of older people affected by the landslide disaster in Cihanjuang Village, Sumedang District, West Java Province, Indonesia. The study will randomly assign 100 participants to either the treatment group (receiving 50 g mangrove sword bean food bar per day for 15 days) or the control group (receiving 50 g sword bean food bar per day for 15 days). The primary outcome measure is the change in weight from baseline to the end of the study, measured using digital weighing SECA. Secondary outcome measures include the change in balanced nutrition knowledge of older people after receiving the balance nutrition education. The study will run for two weeks, with data collection at the first and second week of the study.

The pAIn-sense study aims to develop a novel telemonitoring system that can understand the real nature of pain (emotional vs physical) by leveraging the use of advanced Artificial Intelligence techniques and wearable sensing technology collecting biometric data. The system will be used to monitor patients during normal activities (day and night) while collecting physiological, psychosocial, and pain information. The study will measure the primary outcome measures of pain level, psychosocial components of pain experience, physiological components of pain and pain attacks in the physiological signals, medication intake, rehabilitation, physiotherapy and their effect, sleep, activity and other daily factors and their correlation with pain, predictors of chronification from acute phase, quality of life and pain interference, and responsiveness to medication. The study will enroll participants with acute/chronic nociceptive and neuropathic pain and healthy controls. The study will be conducted as an observational study with no intervention - monitoring.

The study is a Phase 2a/b single arm open-label study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of intracystic administration of TARA-002 in participants between 6 months to less than 18 years of age for the treatment of macrocystic and mixed cystic lymphatic malformations. The study will enroll participants with macrocystic or mixed cystic lymphatic malformations of the head/neck/mediastinum, and will assess the safety and efficacy of TARA-002 using primary and secondary outcome measures. The study will measure the proportion of participants with clinical success after one treatment cycle of TARA-002, safety, durable response, clinical success by LM type, investigator assessment, and quality of life. The study will be conducted at a single center in France.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chiglitazar added to Glargine in patients with type 2 diabetes. The study will enroll 128 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (receiving Chiglitazar added to Glargine) or the placebo group (receiving placebo added to Glargine). The primary outcome measure is the change in HbA1C from baseline at 18 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in insulin dose, triglyceride levels, fasting blood glucose levels, and fasting C-Peptide levels. The study will be conducted at multiple centers and will be completed within 18 weeks.

The study aims to evaluate the robustness of the EarSwitch technology in detecting voluntary eardrum movements in people with assistive needs. The study will recruit participants with assistive technology needs and healthy participants to compare the accuracy of TT movements between the two groups. The study will also assess the comfort and ease-of-use of the EarSwitch device, and the physical comfort of the device. The study will be conducted in a single session and will include four main parts: PART 1 - Co-design Questionnaires, PART 2 - Ear rumble test, PART 3 - Usability testing (optional), and PART 4 - Questionnaires. The study will measure the F-score, Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC), the receiver operating characteristics (ROC) curve, and the Area Under the ROC curve (AUC) to determine the robustness of the EarSwitch technology.

This is a multi-center prospective cohort study aimed at validating and assessing the performance of an EHR-based model for predicting pancreatic cancer risk. The study will enroll 44 healthcare organizations (HCOs) in the USA and follow all eligible individuals for up to 3 years to assess the primary outcome measures, including the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) of PRISM for all groups stratified, and the timing of incident PDAC occurrence. The study will also evaluate sensitivity, specificity, PPV, and SIR for patients identified as high-risk by PRISM, and the absolute one-year risk thresholds are 0.1834% for PrismNN and 0.2048% risk for PrismLR.

Study Design: 
The study is designed as a prospective general population cohort with males and females aged 40 years or older from 44 US HCOs. The study will use a neural network model (PrismNN) and a logistic regression model (PrismLR) that use routinely collected EHR data to stratify individuals from the general population into PDAC risk groups. The study will measure the primary outcome measures and secondary outcome measures, including the timing of incident PDAC occurrence, tumor stage at PDAC diagnosis, and the absolute one-year risk thresholds.

Study Participants: 
The study will enroll all eligible individuals from the general population aged 40 years or older from 44 US HCOs. The study will include males and females from all age groups.

Study Interventions/Treatment: 
The study will use an EHR-based model (PRISM) to predict pancreatic cancer risk. The model will use routinely collected EHR data to stratify individuals from the general population into PDAC risk groups.

Study Outcome Measures: 
The study will measure the primary outcome measures, including the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) of PRISM for all groups stratified, and the timing of incident PDAC occurrence. The study will also evaluate sensitivity, specificity, PPV, and SIR for patients identified as high-risk

35 patients with knee osteoarthritis will be randomly assigned to one of three treatment groups: cartilage regeneration technique with autologous adipose tissue graft with hyaline cartilage graft mixed with fiberinglu, microfracture, or high tibial osteotomy. The primary outcome measure is the clinical assessment of International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) scores at one year.

The study aims to investigate the relationship between exercise training and recovery to improve physical performance and health indices. The study will randomly assign participants into one of three groups: a control group, a lower exercise volume group, and a longer rest group. The primary outcome measures will include changes in immune system, cardiometabolic measurements, endocrine measurements, and body composition. The study will assess these outcomes at baseline and after 8 weeks of intervention. The study will also measure changes in aerobic capacity and strength. The study will be conducted over 8 weeks, with participants exercising for 35 hours per week.

The study is a clinical trial examining the use of 18F-PF-06445974 to image PDE4B in major depressive disorder (MDD). The study will determine whether PDE4B is reduced in the brains of individuals with MDD and will measure the optimal length of scanning and the retest variability and reliability of 18F-PF-06445974 PET scans in healthy volunteers. The study will also assess the relationship between clinical rating scales and PDE4B binding. The study will enroll 18-70 year old individuals with MDD and healthy controls. Participants will undergo PET scans with 18F-PF-06445974 and clinical assessments. The study will be conducted at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) in Bethesda, Maryland.

This study aims to evaluate the importance of weight-bearing and flexion in knee osteoarthritis using 3D joint space evaluation with MRI. The study will include patients with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis and will measure the medial and lateral joint space width in four different scan positions. The study will also assess the primary and secondary outcome measures.

Note: The summary is based on the provided information and may not capture all aspects of the trial.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel at-home surface electromyography (sEMG) biofeedback therapy tool called Biofeedback in Strength and Skill Training (BiSSKit) on swallowing safety and efficiency in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD). The study will compare the outcomes of patients who receive traditional swallowing therapy with those who use the BiSSKit at-home program. The study will assess the primary outcome measures of Penetration Aspiration Scale Score (PAS) and Total Pharyngeal Residue at baseline and post-12 weeks of intervention. Secondary outcome measures will include Eating Assessment Tool-10 (EAT-10) scores.

The study will be conducted in a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label design with two arms: i-BiSSkApp group and traditional treatment group. Participants will be eligible if they are diagnosed with PD, able to provide informed consent, and have evidence of oropharyngeal swallowing deficits. The study will last for 12 weeks, with weekly clinic visits and at-home therapy for the i-BiSSkApp group.

The BiSSKit program is a well-researched office-based biofeedback system that adheres to principles of neuroplasticity and incorporates skill training in addition to strength training. The program has been converted into an affordable and accessible home-based application for tablet computers. The study aims to evaluate the impact of this device on swallowing outcomes compared to traditional swallowing therapy models in PD.

The GLOBE-HPV study is a multi-country clinical trial aimed at estimating the prevalence of high-risk human papillomavirus (HR HPV) infection among girls and women aged 9-50 years in low-socioeconomic populations and specific sub-populations. The study will use cross-sectional surveys (CSS) and longitudinal studies (LS) to collect data on HPV prevalence, incidence, and knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs regarding HPV vaccination, cervical cancer screening, and treatment. The study will be conducted in 8 countries, including 3 in South Asia and 5 in Sub-Saharan Africa, and will provide standard data on HPV burden among girls and women in different age groups and socioeconomic settings.

--------------
The study aims to assess the effectiveness of strategic memory training combined with non-invasive brain stimulation techniques in healthy aging population and subjective cognitive decline patients. The study will evaluate the impact of strategic memory training on cognitive function, quality of life, and brain plasticity. The study will also investigate the long-term effects of strategic memory training on cognitive decline and brain function. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial.

The study aims to develop and validate a predictive model for identifying individuals at risk of new-onset heart failure (HF) using population-based nationwide electronic health records (EHRs). The study will use anonymized patient-level primary care data linked to secondary administrative data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD-GOLD) and CPRD-AURUM. The primary outcome measures will be to identify and quantify the magnitude of predictors of new onset HF and to develop and validate a predictive model for predicting the risk of new onset HF. The study will use multivariable Cox proportional hazard models with backwards elimination approach to retain predictors of incident HF within each prediction window.

The ISHYS study aims to investigate the impact of the recommended time between hysterectomy and resumption of sexual intercourse on sexual function using the Female Sexual Function Index (FSFI®) score. The study will randomize participants into two groups: one that resumes sexual activity 4 weeks after hysterectomy and another that resumes it 8 weeks after hysterectomy. The primary endpoint is the FSFI® score, and secondary outcomes include postoperative complications, follow-up to the recommendation, and reasons for not following the recommendation. The study will measure the impact of the recommended time on sexual function, complications, and follow-up to the recommendation.

The study aims to investigate whether human skeletal muscle possesses an epigenetic memory of testosterone. The study will randomly assign participants to one of four groups: placebo comparator, testosterone undecanoate, resistance exercise training + placebo, or resistance exercise training + testosterone undecanoate. Participants will undergo various assessments, including skeletal muscle biopsies, blood samples, questionnaires, and physiological and psychological measures, at different time points throughout the study. The study will measure primary outcomes such as fat-free mass, skeletal muscle size and cross-sectional area, skeletal muscle fibre CSA, DNA methylation in skeletal muscle and blood, gene expression in skeletal muscle and blood, myonuclei, satellite cells, isometric muscle strength, dynamic muscle strength, and muscle force-velocity profiling. The study will run for 32 weeks and will provide valuable insights into the relationship between testosterone and skeletal muscle function in healthy aging and age-related sarcopenia.

This is a two-stage stratified design study that aims to determine the seroprevalence of dengue fever in the metropolitan area of Buenos Aires. The study will include 1,487 participants who will undergo a finger prick to determine the presence of Immunoglobulin G antibodies against dengue fever using ELISA. A subgroup of participants who test positive will be invited to have blood drawn for neutralization determination to study serotypes and the presence of other flaviviruses. The study will measure the seroprevalence of dengue fever, other flavivirus prevalence, and specific dengue serotype.

The study aims to evaluate the performance characteristics of two COVID-19 antigen rapid diagnostic tests (Ag-RDTs) in low-prevalence settings. The tests being evaluated are the Standard Q COVID-19 Antigen Test and the Panbio™ COVID-19 Ag Rapid Test. The study will assess the sensitivity, specificity, and overall agreement of the Ag-RDTs with standard nucleic acid testing using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests. Additionally, the study will evaluate the cost estimates of Ag testing compared to PCR testing for COVID-19 case detection. The study will recruit participants aged 18-75 years who are crossing ports of entry in Greater Gaborone Health District. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

The DESC-HBR trial is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, multi-center study comparing the effects of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitors to clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor in patients with recent acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and high bleeding risk (HBR). The primary outcome is the proportion of patients achieving optimal platelet reactivity (OPR) measured through the VerifyNow system at peak level after drug maintenance dose (MD) at 14±2 days. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of bleeding events, platelet reactivity units (PRU) at VerifyNow system, proportion of high platelet reactivity (HPR) and low platelet reactivity (LPR) measured through the VerifyNow system, platelet-derived thrombogenicity at Total Thrombus Formation (T-TAS), adverse clinical events, and cost-effectiveness. The study is designed as a parallel-group, multi-center study with randomized, open-label, and active comparator arms.

This study aims to investigate the effect of different dietary and exercise mitigators on blood glucose levels after consuming a standard rice meal in patients with prediabetes or diabetes. The study will measure the changes in postprandial metabolites response as measured by micro-sampling, changes in postprandial proteomic responses as measured in micro-sampling by Olink, and changes in personal metabolic states through the day as measured in micro-sampling by targeted and untargeted metabolomics (LC-MS) and Olink proteomics. The study will enroll 10 participants and will be conducted over a period of 10 days.

The Adapting and Testing a Behavioral Intervention to Prevent FASD and Adverse Infant Outcomes study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a behavioral intervention on preventing fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) and adverse infant outcomes in pregnant women who consume alcohol. The study will randomly assign participants to either the experimental group (receiving the behavioral intervention) or the active comparator group (receiving usual care). The primary outcome measures will include urinalysis for alcohol metabolite (EtG), urinalysis for cotinine, urinalysis for cannabis metabolite (THC), blood analysis of alcohol metabolite (PEth), self-reported use of alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis, and self-reported use while breastfeeding. Secondary outcome measures will include gestational incidents, infant weight, height, head circumference, and gestational weeks at birth. The study will take place in South Africa and will enroll pregnant women who consume alcohol.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of operant conditioning with peripheral stimulation in reducing phantom limb pain in people with limb amputation. The study will involve 3 sessions per week for 8-9 weeks, followed by 2 follow-up sessions at 3 and 6 months after the last session. The primary outcome measures will be change in pain as measured by the Short form-McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ) and change in somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP) amplitude and latency as measured by a tactile event related potential test. Secondary outcome measures will include change in impact of pain on quality of life as measured by the West Haven-Yale Multidimensional Pain Inventory (WHYMPI). The study will be conducted in two groups: experimental (operant conditioning with peripheral stimulation) and control (peripheral stimulation only).

This is a single-center retrospective study conducted at a hospital in France. The study aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization in trauma patients admitted to the intensive care unit (TICU). The study included 100 patients who underwent the procedure between October 1, 2021, and April 30, 2023. The primary outcome measures were the accurate placement of the central venous catheter (CVC) tip for measuring central venous pressure (CVP) or invasive hemodynamic monitoring, and puncture complications after axillary vein catheterization. The study also evaluated secondary outcome measures such as thromboembolism events, TICU mortality, TICU length of stay, and ventilator support. The results showed that the CVC tip was accurately placed in 90% of patients, and the overall complication rate was 10%. The study concluded that ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization is a safe and effective procedure for establishing central venous access in trauma patients admitted to the TICU.

The study is a single-group, open-label, single-arm, phase 2 clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of cevostamab consolidation following BCMA CAR T cell therapy for relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. The study will enroll approximately 100 participants who will receive cevostamab once every 3 weeks starting at day 70 +/- 4 days post-CAR T cell infusion. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants who achieve MRD-negative complete remission at 12 months post-CAR T cell therapy. Secondary outcome measures include safety and tolerability, feasibility of cevostamab administration, and impact on other clinical outcomes.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of rehabilitative ultrasonography imaging on core muscles function in patients with visceral adiposity. The study includes 45 participants who are randomly assigned to one of three intervention groups: cavitation ultrasonic lipolysis, RUSI guided core muscle exercise, or a combination of cavitation and RUSI. The primary outcome measures include diaphragm excursion, transverse abdominis contraction ratio, visceral fat thickness, and waist circumference, which are measured at five weeks. The study is designed to supportive care and the allocation is randomized, the intervention model is parallel assignment, and the masking is double.
