This is a prospective pilot study that aims to investigate the impact of atrial fibrosis surface area on the occurrence of atrial fibrillation in patients with ischemic stroke of undetermined origin. The study will enroll 20 patients who will undergo cardiac MRI with contrast agent. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of atrial fibrillation lasting more than 30 seconds on the implantable loop recorder at 3-year follow-up.

Please provide a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This is an open-label randomized phase II study in ER positive breast cancer patients. The study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of capivasertib, goserelin, fulvestrant, and durvalumab in treating ER positive breast cancer. The study includes 4 arms: Arm 1 (control), Arm 2 (capivasertib + goserelin + fulvestrant), Arm 3 (capivasertib + goserelin + fulvestrant + durvalumab), and Arm 4 (durvalumab + goserelin + fulvestrant). The primary endpoint is objective response rate (ORR) comparison between the treatment arms. Secondary endpoints include progression-free survival, overall survival, and safety.

The ANCAR trial is an open-label, randomized, monocenter trial that aims to evaluate the effects of an acupuncture treatment protocol for nasal congestion in allergic rhinitis (AR) compared to azelastine nasal spray (Carelastin®). The study will measure the effects of acupuncture and azelastine nasal spray on nasal congestion in AR after 6 weeks of treatments based on Visual Analog Scale (VAS) score. The study will also assess the effects of acupuncture on other nasal and ocular signs and symptoms, general health, concentration, and energy level in AR after different visits of treatments based on VAS score. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in the Netherlands and will include 100 participants diagnosed with AR. The study will be masked (open-label) and will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

The study is a feasibility pilot clinical trial aimed at targeting the maternal gut microbiome to improve mental health outcomes in pregnant women with a history of anxiety and/or depression. The study will randomize participants into one of four study groups: Experimental (Gutopia, Gutboost, and Gutless), and Active Comparator (Gutnone). The primary outcome measures include feasibility of participant recruitment, adherence to supplement intake, adherence to dietary protocol, completion of study visits, and study obstacles. The study will collect data on dietary intake, mental health scores, and stool samples at each visit. The study will run for 2 years and the expected completion date is between 9-12 months after delivery.

This is a retrospective study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of high dose follitropin delta in a mixed protocol with human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in women undergoing IVF. The study will assess the primary outcome measure of the number of good quality blastocysts and evaluate the safety and efficacy of the treatment.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of telemedicine in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study will enroll 60 patients with IBD and randomly assign them to either an intervention group (telemedical intervention) or a control group (no intervention). The intervention group will have access to telemedicine technologies, including monthly completion of questionnaires on the web platform, possibility of online consultation with a gastroenterologist upon request via chat or phone call, and access to educational information about IBD, necessary lifestyle changes, dietary recommendations. The primary outcome measures will include change in quality of life in IBD measured by SIBDQ, WHOQOL-26, and IBD disk questionnaire, and maintenance/achievement of clinical remission of Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. Secondary outcome measures will include change in number of adverse drug reactions, satisfaction with treatment, psychological well-being measured by HADS, VSI, TAS-26, and number of surgical interventions, hospitalizations, and outpatient visits. The study will run for 6 months and will assess the effectiveness of telemedicine in improving quality of life, clinical remission, and reducing hospitalizations and outpatient visits in patients with IBD.

The SAUNA trial is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, multicenter clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of continuing somatostatin analogues upon progression in neuroendocrine tumor patients. The study will enroll 300 patients who will be randomly assigned to either continue somatostatin analogues or withdraw them for 18 months. The primary outcome measures are the difference in progression-free survival and time to deterioration between the two groups, as assessed by the blinded local investigator on cross-sectional imaging according to RECIST 1.1 criteria. Secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival rate, overall survival, response rates, quality of life, cost-effectiveness, and drug safety. The study will be conducted at multiple centers in France and will run for approximately 6.5 years.

This study aims to investigate the effectiveness of a peer-mediated intervention in improving socialization experiences and language skills of children with language impairment in preschool classrooms. The study will randomly assign 25 preschool classrooms to either the intervention or control group, with 12 classrooms in the intervention group and 13 in the control group. The intervention will involve training peers to support the target child in playing with peers during center time, with a focus on improving language skills. The study will measure the primary outcome of language skills using the Preschool Language Screener 5 (PLS-5) and secondary outcomes including social skills, pragmatic skills, and peer interactions. The study will be conducted over an average of 9 months.

Note: The output is a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document. It highlights the main aspects of the study, including the study design, population, intervention, and outcome measures.

The study aims to test the effectiveness of combining dalfampridine with physical therapy in improving mobility in people with multiple sclerosis. The study will assess the change in timed 25-foot walk from baseline to end of treatment and compare the results between the three treatment groups.

Interventions: 
The study will randomly assign participants to one of three treatment groups: dalfampridine only, physical therapy with or without dalfampridine.

Outcome Measures: 
The primary outcome measure will be the change in timed 25-foot walk from baseline to end of treatment. Secondary outcome measures will include a range of clinical and self-reported measures of mobility, function, and quality of life.

Exclusion Criteria: 
Participants will be excluded if they have co-existing neurological disorders or orthopedic conditions affecting mobility and physical activity, are unable to follow a 3-step verbal command in English, are hospitalized for any reason in the last 3 months, have uncontrolled hypertension or diabetes, have a history of seizures, or have renal impairment.

Study Design: 
The study will be designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three treatment groups. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 weeks, with assessments at baseline, week 6, week 8, and week 14.

The study aims to assess the test-retest reliability, responsiveness, and interpretability of the CLEFT-Q questionnaire in patients with cleft lip and palate. The study will enroll 50 patients who will answer the questionnaire twice with a 1-2 week interval. Additionally, the study will assess the questionnaire's ability to measure changes in quality of life after secondary nose, lip, jaw, or speech improving surgery. The study will also interview 20 healthcare professionals about their experiences with the questionnaire. The primary outcome measures will be the changes in CLEFT-Q scores from baseline to 1-2 weeks and 6 months or 1 year after surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include photographs and speech recordings before and after surgery. The study will use the CLEFT-Q questionnaire to assess the test-retest reliability, responsiveness, and interpretability in patients with cleft lip and palate.

The study is designed to compare the effectiveness of core stabilization and dynamic stretching exercises in reducing the symptoms of primary dysmenorrhea. The study will randomly assign participants to either the stretching exercise group or the dynamic core stabilizing exercise group. The primary outcome measures will include the WaLIDD score, side bridge test, McGill Quality of life, and PFSD scale. The study will run for 8 weeks and will measure the effectiveness of the exercises in reducing the severity and duration of pain, improving quality of life, and increasing strength.

The study aims to measure non-invasively, easily, and reliably the variations of cerebral perfusion in patients with or without cardiovascular risk factors during controlled variations performed during routine care to adjust the blood pressure level within the recommended safety standards during general anesthesia. The study will look for a possible threshold value of pressure that could impact the blood flow velocity (Doppler) and possibly the EEG and cerebral oximetry. The clinical research work is performed on adult patients undergoing scheduled surgery at Lariboisière Hospital under general anesthesia. All measurements are obtained non-invasively. The monitoring routinely includes continuous electrocardiogram and blood pressure monitoring by non-invasive means (Clearsight®, EV1000®, Edwards Sciences) in anesthesia pulsed O2 saturation (SpO2), ventilatory parameters (FR, VC, FiO2), and anesthesia depth by frontal EEG. Patients over 18 years of age are eligible to participate in this protocol. During the anaesthesia consultation, they will be given an information letter on the objectives and the course of the study. Their non-objection to participate in this study will be collected at the latest during the pre-anesthetic visit, the day before the operation, after a period of reflection. The protocol starts on the day of the operation. For all patients, the surgical procedures will be performed under general anesthesia with an intravenous anesthesia protocol with a concentration target (Orchestra® Base Primea - Fresenius Kabi France) and a vasopressor support by norepinephrine diluted to 5 microg/mL. Blood pressure variations will be performed as follows: In current practice of investigators : anesthetic induction is performed under vasopressors (norepinephrine diluted to 5 µg/mL) with the objective of maintaining a MAP ≥ 90% of the value measured during the anesthesia consultation. when blood pressure stability is obtained, the dose of norepinephrine is gradually decreased to a MAP target ≥ 70% of the baseline value without ever falling below 60 mmH

This is an observational study that aims to assess the effectiveness of Serplulimab plus chemotherapy in treating extensive small cell lung cancer. Participants will receive 6 cycles of first-line Serplulimab plus chemotherapy, and MRD testing will be performed before treatment, after 2 cycles of treatment, after 6 cycles of treatment, 6 months after the end of chemotherapy, and 1 year after the end of chemotherapy. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, and secondary outcome measures include overall survival, objective response rate, and disease-control rate. The study is open-label, and the results will be analyzed based on the intention-to-treat principle.

The Aktivplan Digital Intervention (ACTIVE-CaRe Pilot) is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a digital intervention for supporting regular heart-healthy physical activity following completion of a phase II rehabilitation program. The study will randomly assign participants to either the experimental group (receiving the digital intervention) or the control group (receiving usual care). The primary outcome measures will include recruitment rate, drop-out rate, data completeness, adherence to the digital intervention, usability, user experience, user acceptance, technical stability, use of alternative and additional strategies, experiences and perspectives of patients and rehabilitation professionals regarding the intervention and study procedures, exercise capacity, physical activity behavior, weight, blood pressure, blood cholesterol, HbA1c, smoking, health-related quality of life, exercise self-efficacy, and patient safety. The study will run for 10 weeks and will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of intranasal oxytocin in youth with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The study will enroll 30 participants, aged 12-20 years, who will be randomly assigned to receive either oxytocin or placebo for four weeks, with a two-week washout period between the two treatment periods. The primary outcome measures will be social behavior and repetitive behavior, assessed using standardized scales completed by caregivers and the participants themselves. Secondary outcome measures will include behavioral inflexibility, social cognition, and repetitive cognition, as well as vagally-mediated heart rate variability, calculated using electrocardiogram.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, it is not the original document.

This is an observational study with longitudinal follow-up to validate a clinical evaluation scale for abdominal condition of the premature (ECAP). The study includes newborns born prematurely (before 37 weeks of amenorrhea) at least 3 days of life hospitalized in the neonatal intensive care units. The ECAP scale is used to assess the abdominal condition of the premature babies daily by the nurse, physiotherapist, and resident of the service. The study aims to measure the primary outcome measures of clinical abdominal assessment scale for preterm infant (ECAP scale) score between 0 and 20, and secondary outcome measures such as indication for abdominal massage on ECAP scale, ECAP scale validity, and impact of massage on ECAP scale. The study will be conducted over a period of up to 18 months.

The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effects of Empowered Relief (ER) treatment provided by ASPMN nurses to a wait-list control group. Participants (N=170) will be adults aged 18 and above years with self-reported or clinically diagnosed persistent pain. The study will assess the primary outcome measures of change in pain catastrophizing and change in pain intensity at baseline, 2, 4, and 8 weeks. The study will also assess secondary outcome measures such as change in pain severity and number of participants experiencing adverse events. The study will be conducted in clinical sites identified by ER-trained nurses and will use qualitative descriptive methods to assess the feasibility and acceptability of the study.

This study aims to investigate the challenges and patterns of pain rating among patients and nurses. The study will compare the mental effort of choosing and understanding pain intensity ratings, and evaluate the importance of decreasing mental effort for both patients and nurses. The study will also determine the relationship between confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity ratings and the importance of increasing that confidence.

The study will enroll patients aged 18 and older who are currently being treated by a healthcare provider for a painful musculoskeletal condition. The study will also enroll nurses who are currently employed as licensed nurses and have routine assessment of musculoskeletal pain of cognitively intact adult outpatients.

The study will use a survey to collect data on mental effort, importance of decreasing mental effort, confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity ratings, and other secondary outcome measures. The survey will be administered at baseline.

The study's primary outcome measures are mental effort and importance of decreasing mental effort, which will be assessed using ordinal self-report measures. The study's secondary outcome measures are confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity ratings, which will be assessed using ordinal self-report measures.

The study's results will inform future efforts to improve pain communication between patients and nurses, and provide insights into the challenges and patterns of pain rating among patients and nurses.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) in treating poor graft function after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). The study will enroll 20 patients and will be conducted in two phases: a screening phase and a treatment phase. During the screening phase, patients will undergo a series of tests to determine their eligibility for the study. Once eligible, patients will receive MSCs treatment for four consecutive weeks. The primary outcome measures will be the hemogram recovery of patients with poor graft function after treatment, including white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets. Secondary outcome measures will include infection rate, graft-versus-host disease, and survival rate. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida in France and will be led by Dr. [Name].

MOVIN' CARE for PD is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of two mind-body interventions (yoga and arts-based approaches) in improving the psycho-social-spiritual well-being of patients with Parkinson's disease (PD). The study will assess the primary outcomes of perceived stress level, overall quality of life, quality of life specified to Parkinson's disease, PD-related symptoms, self-compassion, and self-efficacy. Secondary outcomes will include perceived social support, constipation severity, bowel habits, and user's satisfaction. The study will be conducted in Hong Kong and will include 186 participants.

Note: The output is a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document. It highlights the main aspects of the study, including the research question, study design, population, and outcome measures.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an integrated digital intervention (Quit Genius-Alcohol) for treating Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD). The intervention combines cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy (naltrexone) delivered through a mobile health application. The study will compare the efficacy of the Quit Genius-Alcohol intervention to usual care (medical management) in reducing alcohol use and associated psychological and functional outcomes among adults with AUD.

The study will enroll 400 participants and will be conducted over a period of 6 months. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the Quit Genius-Alcohol intervention or usual care group. The primary outcome measure will be change in past 30-day alcohol use from baseline to 6-months post-treatment entry. Secondary outcome measures will include alcohol use disorder symptoms, depression, anxiety, and quality of life.

The study will be conducted at multiple sites across the United States and will be led by a team of experienced researchers in the field of addiction medicine. The results of the study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of integrated digital interventions for treating AUD and will inform the development of future treatments for this common and costly public health problem.

This study compares the clinical pregnancy rate of frozen embryo transfer in natural vs substituted cycles. The study includes 2 arms: frozen embryo transfer substituted cycle and frozen embryo transfer natural cycle. The primary outcome measure is the clinical pregnancy rate at 6 to 8 weeks after frozen embryo transfer.

Please provide a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial that aims to compare the effects of inhalational (sevoflurane) vs. intravenous (propofol) anesthesia on postoperative delirium, cognitive dysfunction, functional decline, and patient-reported outcomes in older adults undergoing non-cardiac surgery. The study will measure the incidence of postoperative delirium and cognitive dysfunction using various tools, including the 3D-CAM-S, CAM-ICU-7, neuropsychiatric composite score, and MASQ. The study will also assess the effects of anesthesia type on blood phosphorylated tau 181 levels, functional decline, and patient-reported outcomes using tools such as ADL, FAQ, and FRAIL. The study will be conducted at Oregon Health & Science University and will include 120 participants aged 75 years or older.

Note: The output should only include the summarization of the provided clinical trial document, without any additional information or analysis.

The study aims to assess the nutritional status of children with congenital heart disease and evaluate the effectiveness of a protocol to prevent nutritional deficiency and promote normal growth.

Inclusion Criteria: Children aged between 5 weeks to 18 years with cyanotic or acyanotic congenital heart disease presenting to Assiut University Hospital Units.

Exclusion Criteria: All pediatric patients with comorbidities other than congenital heart disease, such as severe sepsis, endocarditis, empyema, autoimmune diseases, and liver cirrhosis, as well as children receiving immunosuppressive therapy.

The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years, with a sample size of 100 participants. The primary outcome measure will be the assessment of the nutritional status of the children at baseline, and the effectiveness of the protocol will be evaluated through a follow-up assessment after 6 months.

The study will use a combination of anthropometric measurements, including weight, height, length, head circumference, mid-arm circumference, and body mass index (BMI), to evaluate the nutritional status of the children. The results of the study will provide valuable insights into the nutritional needs of children with congenital heart disease and inform the development of evidence-based guidelines for their management.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, controlled trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of pH-sensitive MRI-based resection of glioblastoma. The study will enroll 60 patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma and randomly assign them to either the experimental arm (CEST resection) or the standard-of-care arm (standard of care resection without CEST). The primary endpoint is progression-free survival, and secondary endpoints include overall survival, quality of life metrics via Karnofsky performance scale, and surgical complication rate. The study will use pH-sensitive MRI to identify infiltrating tumor cells and guide resection, with the goal of minimizing post-surgical tumor cell burden and improving survival.

This study aims to investigate the patterns of urinary bladder cancer in Darfur, Sudan, focusing on clinical outcomes, etiology, histology, and demographic distribution of the disease. The study is a cross-sectional, hospital-based study conducted at Nyala Specialized Hospital in Darfur from 2020 to 2022.

This study aimed to investigate the relationship between mental stress and bowel preparation quality in patients undergoing colonoscopy. The study included 1000 patients who were randomly selected from the Endoscopy Centre of the Department of Gastroenterology, Renji Hospital, and their general information and physical and mental stress test scale were collected through questionnaires. The Boston Rating Scale (BPS) was used to assess the quality of bowel preparation for each patient. The study found that there was a significant correlation between mental stress and bowel preparation quality, with higher levels of mental stress associated with poorer bowel preparation.

Keywords: mental stress, bowel preparation, colonoscopy, Boston Rating Scale, quality of bowel preparation.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of SkillFlix for Parents, an online video library, in improving the communication skills of parents of teens with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) regarding sexual health topics. The study will randomly assign participants to either the intervention group (SkillFlix for Parents) or the control group (written materials with similar content). The primary outcome measures will include demonstrated skill score in communicating with their teens about sexual health, parent reported frequency of discussions with their teens about sexual health and relationships, parent conversation quality score, parent confidence in their ability to use skills in communication with their teens, teen reported frequency of discussions with their teens about sexual health and relationships, youth conversation quality score, teen confidence in their ability to use Making Connections skills, family sexual communication quotient score, teen's sexual health knowledge, teen's sexual health attitudes, and teen's sexual health behaviors. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, with baseline assessments, intervention period, and follow-up assessments at 3 months post-intervention.

This study aims to investigate the role of DDX17 in orchestrating vascular endothelial pyroptosis in sepsis patients. The study will enroll 100 patients with sepsis and severe sepsis, and will collect blood samples on days 1, 3, and 7 for the measurement of DDX17 and GSDMD levels. The primary outcome measure is 28-day mortality, and secondary outcome measures include the correlation between plasma levels of DDX17 and GSDMD and vascular endothelial injury, severity, and prognosis in sepsis patients.

This is a single-center prospective study that aims to evaluate the accuracy of non-invasive methods for the diagnosis of postoperative complications in liver transplant recipients. The study includes patients who are eligible for liver transplantation and are aged between 18 and 75 years. The primary outcome measure is early allograft dysfunction, which is measured using the Olthoff criteria. The study is designed to be conducted over a period of 2 weeks after liver transplantation.

This is a multi-center, phase II, randomized, controlled clinical trial to test the safety and efficacy of Elemene plus Stupp Protocol compared with Stupp Protocol alone for newly-diagnosed glioblastoma patients. The study aims to enroll 120 patients and will be conducted at multiple sites in China. The study will randomly assign patients to receive either the Elemene plus Stupp Protocol or the Stupp Protocol alone. The primary outcome measure is overall survival at 12 months, and secondary outcome measures include overall survival, progression-free survival, adverse events, and quality of life.

Note: This summary is a brief and concise version of the provided clinical trial document. It captures the key aspects of the trial, including the study design, population, interventions, and outcome measures.

The study is designed to assess the effect of prone positioning on lung recruitability in infants and children with acute respiratory distress syndrome. The study will enroll eligible patients who will undergo a standardized protocol of prone positioning and supine positioning. The primary outcome measure is the effect of prone positioning on lung recruitability, which will be assessed through PaO2/FiO2 ratio at the end of the supine and prone position. Secondary outcome measures include differences in gas exchanges, ventilatory ratio, global and regional impedance-derived end-expiratory lung volume, tidal volume distribution, global and regional impedance-derived lung dynamic strain, number of displacements of the endotracheal tube during prone position, and number of oxygen desaturations during prone position.

Note: The output is a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document. It highlights the key aspects of the study, including the inclusion and exclusion criteria, the intervention/treatment, the primary and secondary outcome measures, and the study duration.

The study aims to investigate the effect of progressive relaxation training on pain characteristics, attack frequency, activity self-efficacy perception, and social participation in women with tension-type headache and migraine. The study will randomly assign 44 women (22 with tension-type headache and 22 with migraine) to either a progressive relaxation training group or a control group. The primary outcome measures will include occupational self-assessment, World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule 2, pain catastrophizing scale, Headache Impact Test-6, and visual analog scale. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 weeks, with 2 sessions per week, and will be held in a well-lit, clean, and comfortable room with a temperature of 22-24 degrees.

This clinical trial aims to understand the microRNA response to opioid withdrawal in newborns and explore their potential use as biomarkers for neonatal abstinence syndrome. The study will enroll newborns exposed to in-utero opiates and measure their neurodevelopmental outcome scores, maximum concentration of morphine required for withdrawal symptom control, salivary microRNA levels (let-7a, microRNA-146a, and microRNA-192), and exosomes. The study will be conducted at Penn State Hershey Medical Center and will include 30 participants. The study plan includes genetic testing, whole saliva RNA isolation, and qPCR analysis for microRNA quantification. The primary outcome measures will be neurodevelopmental outcome scores at 6 months of age, maximum concentration of morphine required for withdrawal symptom control, and salivary microRNA levels at 24 hours of life and at discharge.

The study aimed to investigate the effect of patient education on pain level and fear of pain in orthopedics and traumatology patients. The study was a randomized controlled experimental design, and 52 patients were included in the study group, 26 in the intervention group, and 26 in the control group. The intervention group received patient education on pain management, while the control group did not receive any training. Data were collected using the Information Form, Fear of Pain Scale-III, and Visual/Visual Analogue Scale. The results showed that the intervention group had a lower pain level and fear of pain compared to the control group. The study concluded that patient education can effectively reduce pain level and fear of pain in orthopedics and traumatology patients.

The Patch BRIDGE trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of using a transdermal buprenorphine patch for the induction of buprenorphine therapy in pregnant women with opioid use disorder. The study will enroll pregnant women who meet diagnostic criteria for opioid use disorder and are receiving prenatal care through an opioid use disorder specific clinic. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental arm (buprenorphine transdermal patches) or the placebo comparator arm (sham patch). The primary outcome measure is the change in withdrawal severity from baseline to 48 hours after induction, as assessed by the Subjective Opioid Withdrawal Scale (SOWS). Secondary outcome measures include induction success, treatment adherence, and recovery success. The study will be conducted at a single site and will enroll approximately 40 participants.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and does not include any external sources or information.

The study aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of transcutaneous oximetry in assessing vascular compression in patients suspected of having thoracic outlet syndrome. The study will enroll patients who are suspected of having thoracic outlet syndrome and will undergo additional examinations, such as venous and arterial Doppler or dynamic arteriography and venography, as part of the diagnostic assessment. The primary outcome measure will be the variation in upper limb ischemia estimated by transcutaneous oximetry, and the secondary outcome measure will be the correlation between the severity of upper limb ischemia and the degree of arterial stenosis observed in diagnostic arteriography. The study will use a diagnostic test, transcutaneous oximetry, to assess the vascular compression in patients suspected of having thoracic outlet syndrome.

The study aims to assess the feasibility of a mobile health app (SmartCP) in managing chronic pancreatitis. The study will run for 16 weeks, during which participants will receive the intervention in addition to their usual clinical care. The study will measure various outcomes, including recruitment, acceptability, retention, incidents, user statistics, and secondary outcomes such as symptoms, occurrence of crisis events, quality of life, hospitalization, and use of communications and educational features.

The study will enroll all sexes and will not accept healthy volunteers. The primary outcome measures will include feasibility: recruitment, feasibility: acceptability, feasibility: retention, feasibility: incidents, and user statistics. The secondary outcome measures will include occurrence of crisis events, quality of life, hospitalization, and use of communications and educational features.

The study will be conducted in Ireland and will have an uncontrolled, within-group baseline and post-intervention design. The intervention will consist of the SmartCP mobile phone app, which will provide symptom tracking, diet/physical activity log, alert system for escalating symptoms, quality of life assessment, red-flag alerts for diabetes/pancreatic cancer, educational content, push notifications, and messaging function.

The study will be conducted by a team of investigators, including a principal investigator, co-investigators, and research nurses. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will follow good clinical practice guidelines.

The study will provide patients with a user-friendly and accessible tool to manage their chronic pancreatitis symptoms, improving their quality of life and reducing the need for hospitalization. The study will also provide valuable insights into the feasibility and effectiveness of using mobile health technology in the management of chronic pancreatitis.

This is a retrospective cross-sectional study conducted over three months from the start of September 2020 to the end of November 2020 at Mansoura university isolation hospital, on COVID-19 patients' who were diagnosed to have anal fissure. The study aimed to identify the risk factors associated with the development of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors and to assess the outcome of these patients. The study included 176 patients who suffered from anal fissure, and the results showed that the incidence of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors was 10.2%. The study also identified several risk factors associated with the development of anal fissure, including age, sex, and associated co-morbidities. The study found that patients who were older than 50 years, male, and had associated co-morbidities were at a higher risk of developing anal fissure. The study also found that the majority of patients (80.5%) had mild anal fissure, while 14.5% had moderate and 4.5% had severe anal fissure. The study concluded that anal fissure is a common complication among COVID-19 survivors, and it is important to identify the risk factors associated with its development to provide appropriate management and prevention strategies.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that assesses the effectiveness of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) in promoting wound healing in patients undergoing palatal connective tissue harvesting. The study includes 40 patients divided into two groups: the test group, which receives PRF application, and the control group, which does not receive PRF. The primary outcome measures are tissue thickness and pulsatility index (PI) measured using ultrasonography at various time points post-operation. The study findings suggest that PRF application leads to improved tissue thickness and PI values compared to the control group, indicating better wound healing.

The ARRC III Trial of Advanced Recovery Room Care (ARRC) is a pilot registry conducted at the Royal Adelaide Hospital (RAH) to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the ARRC model of care in improving patient outcomes, hospital utilization, and costs of care after surgery. The study aims to collect high-quality data on the ARRC model relevant to consumers and hospitals, and to provide a robust mechanism to ensure outcomes are maintained and improved within the institution. The study includes patients scheduled for elective or unplanned surgery at RAH, with inclusion criteria of scheduled to stay in hospital at least one night after surgery, and exclusion criteria of undergoing cardiac surgery. The primary outcome measure is the number of days spent at usual place of residence within 90 days after surgery, and secondary outcome measures include in-hospital complications, mortality, and cost-effectiveness. The study is designed as a pilot registry, and the data collected will be used to generate and test hypotheses on how the benefits of the ARRC model are achieved.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness and implementation of oral and long-acting PrEP in mobile men in sub-Saharan Africa. The study will evaluate the uptake, retention in care, and HIV exposure coverage with adequate drug tissue levels among mobile men who are at high risk of HIV acquisition due to their high HIV prevalence in partners or due to risky behaviors. The study will also assess the safety, tolerability, and acceptability of different PrEP modalities, including oral and injectable PrEP, and inform PrEP implementation in men. The study will be conducted in South Africa and Uganda, and will include 400 HIV-negative participants who will be randomized into two groups: one receiving oral PrEP and the other receiving long-acting injectable PrEP. Participants will be offered choice of PrEP for a further 9-months after the randomized period, with the ability to change choice as required. The study will use a hybrid effectiveness implementation type 2 trial design, and will be carried out in a decentralized model of care for recruitment and persistence in ongoing study.

This study aims to assess the psycho-emotional state of patients with temporomandibular disorder (TMD) using a questionnaire survey. The study includes 130 patients diagnosed with TMD and 130 control patients without TMD. The primary outcome measures include the emotional state of the patients over the past 4 weeks, assessed through a questionnaire survey. The study is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of the diagnostic test: clinical.

This study aims to assess the effects of touch on brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers in preterm infants. The study will randomly assign participants to one of three interventions: therapeutic touch, affective touch, or static touch. The primary outcome measures will be changes in brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers before and after the intervention. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in EEG power, urinary metabolites, and other metabolic biomarkers. The study will be conducted over a period of 40 weeks, with assessments at various time points.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a non-myeloablative conditioning regimen using briquilimab and abatacept in patients with sickle cell disease who are at high risk of disease-related morbidity or mortality. The study will assess the regimen's ability to engraft successfully and prevent severe graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) or moderate to severe chronic GVHD. Additionally, the study will evaluate the incidence of viral reactivation and disease, autoimmune and hyperinflammatory complications, and organ damage. The study will enroll adult patients with sickle cell disease who are ineligible for other curative therapies, including haploidentical related donors. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Quebec (CHUQ) in Quebec, Canada, and will be led by Dr. Marie-Pierre Duboc, a leading expert in hematopoietic cell transplantation for sickle cell disease.

The study compares the effectiveness of two different sperm preparation methods, microfluidic chip and density gradient centrifugation, on the euploidy rate of pre-implantation genetic testing (PGT) in women undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF). The study randomly assigns women to either the microfluidic chip group or the density gradient centrifugation group and evaluates the euploidy rate of blastocysts biopsied at 3 months. The study also measures other outcomes such as live birth rate, positive urine pregnancy test rate, clinical pregnancy rate, ongoing pregnancy rate, miscarriage rate, multiple pregnancy rate, DNA fragmentation, and ectopic pregnancy rate.

This study aims to investigate the relationship between Brain-derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) Single Nucleotide Gene Polymorphism and Nerve Growth Factor as risk factors that increase the severity of Allergic Rhinitis. The study will enroll chronic Allergic Rhinitis patients and will use genotyping to determine the BDNF gene single nucleotide polymorphism. The study will also measure the levels of Nerve growth factor, IL-1, and C-reactive protein in the blood to determine their association with Allergic Rhinitis.

This study aims to investigate the effect of mindfulness on EEG brain activity for cognitive and psychological well-being in the elderly. 60 older adults will be enrolled and will undergo cognitive and psychological evaluation and EEG recording. The mindfulness-based intervention consists of 8 weekly group sessions and participants will be instructed to regularly engage in home mindfulness practice. The study will measure the change in dispositional mindfulness, verbal memory, interoceptive mindfulness, and EEG alpha power from baseline to week 8.

The study aims to investigate the prevalence of Mycoplasma Genitalium (MG) infection and associated antimicrobial resistance among HIV-infected male in Hong Kong. The study will recruit 750 HIV-infected male attending HIV specialist clinic in Hong Kong and collect self-collected urine, rectal and pharyngeal swabs for MG, Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) and Neisseria Gonorrhoeae (NG) screening by nucleic acid amplification tests, and MG genotypic resistance mutations detection. The study will also collect clinical data from the participants' medical records. The primary outcome measures of the study are the prevalence of MG infection and the prevalence of MG resistance mutations. The study will run for one year and the results will be used to inform the development of STI prevention and treatment strategies for HIV-infected male in Hong Kong.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of combining Dalpiciclib with endocrine therapy in patients with HR+/HER2- breast cancer who have experienced treatment failure with CDK4/6 inhibitors. The study will use 18F-FES PET/CT imaging to predict the expression of ER in various systemic lesions and evaluate the potential of Dalpiciclib in combination with endocrine therapy.

The study will enroll 120 patients and will be conducted in two arms: Arm A (Dalpiciclib + endocrine therapy) and Arm B (chemotherapy selected by the physician). The primary outcome measure is investigator-assessed progression-free survival (PFS), and secondary outcome measures include objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and overall survival (OS).

The study will be conducted in two phases: a screening phase and a treatment phase. In the screening phase, patients will undergo baseline imaging and clinical assessments, and eligibility will be determined. In the treatment phase, patients will receive treatment according to the assigned arm.

The study is open-label, and the intervention is randomized. The study will be conducted at multiple sites in the United States, and the duration of the study is approximately 24 months.

The study is sponsored by Dalhius Pharmaceuticals, and the principal investigator is Dr. [Name]. The study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT05333377).

This is a single-arm, multicenter study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of XELOX combined with Fruquintinib and Sintilimab in patients with Gastric Cancer/Gastroesophageal Junction Adenocarcinoma only with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis.

Note: The output is a summary of the given clinical trial document, highlighting the key aspects of the study, including the condition, intervention, and outcome measures.

The study aims to evaluate the impact of alternative incentives on physical activity among older adults. The study will randomly assign 200 older adults to either receive additional incentives or not. The incentives will be in the form of meal donations and monetary incentives for meeting a step goal of 7,500 steps per day. The study will collect data on step count and mental health over 8 weeks using Fitbits and surveys.

In summary, the study will evaluate the impact of alternative incentives on physical activity among older adults, and will measure the change in step count and mental health over 8 weeks.

This is an interrupted time series study conducted at the Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital (MTRH) neonatal ward between April 2022 and June 2023. The study aims to evaluate the clinical impact and cost-effectiveness of a wireless vital signs monitor (neoGuard) for hospitalized newborns in Kenya. The study participants comprise of newborn patients admitted at MTRH during that period, and the intervention group consists of patients admitted to the 4 neonatal subunits where neoGuard was installed. The primary outcome measures include nurse's response time to patients in distress, percentage of actionable alarms, incidence of patient complications, in-hospital mortality, and frequency of key interventions. The study will measure these outcomes over a maximum period of 7 days for each patient and across 16 months, respectively.

The study is a Phase II clinical trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of pre- or post-operative hypofractionated radiation therapy in aged (≥ 70 years old) or fragile (≥ 65 years old) patients with limb or trunk soft tissue sarcoma. The study has two arms: neo-adjuvant and adjuvant. In the neo-adjuvant arm, patients will receive hypofractionated radiation therapy (30 Gy in 5 fractions) prior to surgery. In the adjuvant arm, patients will undergo surgery before receiving adjuvant hypofractionated radiation therapy (40 Gy in 15 fractions). The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients free of major surgical complications as defined by O'Sullivan within 6 months of surgery. Secondary outcome measures include patients' disease-free survival, surgical complications, wound disorders, healing time, patients' quality of life, and toxicities of the radiation therapy. The study is designed as a non-randomized, open-label parallel assignment study with masking none. The study will enroll a minimum of 30 patients in each arm and will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

This is a retrospective study to determine the prevalence of head and neck cancers at a tertiary healthcare center in Nepal. The study included 100 patients who underwent treatment for head and neck cancers between May 2022 and April 2023. The study found that the most common subsite of head and neck cancer was oral cavity (30%), followed by nasopharynx (20%). The majority of patients (70%) were male, and the average age of patients was 55 years. The study also found that 80% of patients received radiotherapy as the primary treatment modality, while 20% received chemotherapy. The study concludes that head and neck cancers are a significant health problem in Nepal, and further research is needed to understand the causes and improve treatment outcomes.

This study aims to assess the effectiveness of a health communication message in identifying children with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) symptoms in primary care settings. The message is designed to educate and activate parents about their child's risk for OSA, and parents will be randomized to either view the message or receive usual care. The study will measure the rate of completed OSA referral, OSA referral, evidence-based evaluation, OSA diagnosis, OSA treatment, and parent activation among children who screen positive for OSA.

The study population includes children aged 2-13 years who are primary care patients at Eskenazi Health. Inclusion criteria are child ages 2.0-13.9 years at the time of OSA screening, and exclusion criteria are prior OSA diagnosis or referral in the past two years.

The study design is a randomized controlled trial with triple masking. Participants will be assigned to either the intervention group (viewing the health communication message) or usual care. The primary outcome measures are the rate of completed OSA referral, OSA referral, evidence-based evaluation, OSA diagnosis, OSA treatment, and parent activation among children who screen positive for OSA.

The study will be conducted over a period of up to 9 months after study entry (date of positive OSA screen) and will measure outcomes at various time points, including immediately after intervention (viewing the health communication message), up to 3 months after study entry, and up to 9 months after study entry.

The study aims to provide evidence on the effectiveness of the health communication message in identifying children with OSA symptoms in primary care settings and to inform the development of interventions to improve OSA detection and treatment in this population.

This is a multi-country, prospective, post-marketing study to assess the speed of onset and durability of effectiveness of upadacitinib in adult participants with moderate to severe Crohn's disease (CD) in real-world clinical practice. The study will enroll participants who are initiating upadacitinib at the clinician's discretion as part of their routine clinical care. The primary outcome measures will be time to achieve first clinical response (CR) per patient-reported outcome 2 (PRO2) and percentage of participants achieving clinical remission per Harvey Bradshaw Index (HBI) among those with clinical response-HBI at end of induction therapy. The study will run for 3 years and will include participants from multiple countries.

This study aims to assess the online version of the Quick Assessment of Prewriting Skills (QAPS) in children aged 3-7 years old. The study will evaluate the online version of the QAPS in terms of its reliability, validity, and usability. The study will also assess the children's prewriting skills, visual motor integration, and emotional regulation abilities. The study will be conducted in a single-blind design, where the participants will be randomly assigned to either the online or paper-and-pencil version of the QAPS. The Critical Time Intervention-Peer Support (CTI-PS) study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a peer-led intervention for individuals with severe mental illness who have been discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities in Portugal. The study will randomly assign participants to either the intervention group (CTI-PS) or the control group. The CTI-PS intervention will be delivered by trained peer support workers and community mental health workers over a 9-month period. The primary outcome measures will include the World Health Organization Quality of Life Scale - Brief Version (WHOQOL-BREF), Camberwell Assessment of Need (CAN), and Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS). The study will assess the effectiveness of CTI-PS in improving quality of life, reducing unmet needs, and improving psychopathology outcomes among individuals with severe mental illness.

The Registry for Vascular Trauma and Follow-up Examinations is a study designed to assess the long-term outcomes of patients with vascular injuries. The study will include patients who are admitted to the hospital with vascular trauma and will follow them up with regular examinations to assess the patency of vessels/grafts, reintervention rate, and development of treatment patterns. The study will assess the primary outcome measure of graft/vessel patency at different time points, including 3, 6, and 12 months after trauma. Secondary outcome measures include reintervention rate and development of treatment patterns. The study will enroll patients aged 18 years or older and will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study is a prospective randomized control trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of blood flow restriction (BFR) therapy in improving outcomes after distal radius fracture surgery. The study will enroll adults aged 18-80 years old who require ORIF of the distal radius. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a control group or an experimental group. The experimental group will undergo BFR therapy in addition to standard postoperative rehabilitation, while the control group will receive standard postoperative rehabilitation without BFR. The primary outcome measures will include body composition, forearm girth, grip strength, and pinch grip strength. Secondary outcome measures will include the DASH survey, Michigan Hand Outcomes survey, and Patient Rated Wrist Evaluation. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months, with assessments at one week, two weeks, six weeks, and 12 weeks post-operatively.

The study aims to determine the effect of the Stand up for your Health® computer app on sedentary behavior, musculoskeletal symptoms, cardiometabolic markers, and physical activity in office workers. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: an experimental group that receives the Stand up for your Health® app and educational information, and a control group that receives only educational information. The study will be conducted over six months, with measurements taken at baseline, 3rd, and 6th months. The primary outcome measures include sedentary behavior (occupational sitting time), cardiometabolic biomarkers, and anthropometric measurements. Secondary outcome measures include musculoskeletal symptoms and physical activity. The study will assess the adherence to the intervention program by identifying barriers and facilitators referred by the participants.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled clinical trial that aims to investigate the effects of low-load blood flow restriction and creatine supplementation on women's strength, body composition, neuromuscular function, endothelial function, and mood states. The study will recruit 100 women aged 18-35 who are recreationally active and not currently taking creatine. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: no intervention (control), creatine and blood flow restriction exercise, active comparator (creatine and no-BFR with training), or placebo comparator (placebo and blood flow restriction exercise). The study will consist of 10 weeks of exercise training, with 27 visits in total. The primary outcome measures will include strength, body composition, neuromuscular function, endothelial function, and mood states, assessed at 9 months. Secondary outcome measures will include mood states, assessed at 9 months. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in Quebec, Canada.

The study aims to evaluate GDF-15 and cytokines as possible novel targets for the treatment of Anorexia Nervosa (AN). The study will assess GDF-15 and cytokine levels in the plasma and cerebrospinal fluids of AN patients and healthy controls. The study will also evaluate the correlation between GDF-15 and cytokine levels with lean and fat mass measures, as well as with energy expenditure. The study will include 8 AN patients with confirmed diagnosis of anorexia nervosa restrictive type, non-exercising subtype, and 8 healthy controls. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 weeks, with blood and cerebrospinal fluid samples being taken at the beginning and end of the study. The study will provide valuable insights into the biological mechanisms underlying AN and may lead to the development of new treatments for the disorder.

This is a prospective, observational study in which data will be collected from patients undergoing pleural procedures. The study aims to collect data on clinical, radiological, and patient-reported outcomes after pleural intervention. The study will include 20 centers and will enroll patients aged 18 and above who are undergoing pleural interventions. The study will collect data on complications, patient-reported outcomes, and radiological findings. The study will also collect information on the size of the service, range of procedures performed, and the level of detail of ultrasound findings.

The Artificial Intelligence for Preventing Heart Disease (AiPHD) study is an observational, single center, prospective and retrospective study that aims to develop a novel clinical-imaging AI-based model to identify and categorize patients at high risk of disease progression and provide a more personalized management approach to improve patient outcomes. The study will include 2500 patients in the retrospective cohort and 500 patients in the prospective cohort, who will be followed up for 36 months from the date of the cCTA examination. The primary outcome measures will be death by cardiovascular events or non-fatal myocardial infarction, and all cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization. The study will use proportional hazards and coronary computed tomography angiography to measure the outcomes.

The SIM0355-201 trial is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase II clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of different doses of Edaravone Dexborneol Concentrated Solution for Injection combined with conventional medical therapy in the treatment of patients with cerebral hemorrhage. The study includes 3 dose levels: Synbixin 37.5 mg (Part A1), Synbixin 62.5 mg (Part A2), and Synbixin TBD mg (Part B). The primary outcome measures are the incidence of serious adverse events (SAEs) up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment, and the proportion of subjects with AEs, AEs leading to dose interruption or discontinuation, AEs related to study drug, AEs of special interest (AESls), and with abnormal vital signs, abnormal physical examination findings and abnormal laboratory tests results. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of deaths up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the proportion of subjects with modified Rankin Score (mRS) 0-2 and 0-1 at 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the distribution of subjects with modified Rankin Score (mRS) at 14, 30, and 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the distribution of subjects with Glasgow Outcome Score (GOS) at 14, 30, and 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the change from baseline in National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) at 14, 30, and 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the proportion of subjects with NIHSS 0-2 at 14, 30, and 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the proportion of subjects with Barthel index (BI) at 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the imaging endpoints, including the change from baseline in perihematomal edema volume (PHEv) and hematoma volume (HV) in milliliters, the change from

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in improving exercise tolerance and promoting body rehabilitation in patients with novel coronavirus infection. The study is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial. Participants are middle-aged and elderly patients with novel coronavirus infection who have entered the convalescence phase. The primary outcome measures are the results of the 6-minute walking test on day 14 and 28 after treatment, and the pulmonary ventilation function on day 14 and 28 after treatment. The study will provide reliable evidence support for the treatment and improvement of novel coronavirus infection with Manzhi Guben granules.

This is a non-interventional fMRI study that aims to investigate the neural bases of decision-making in healthy individuals. The study will assess decision-making and executive functioning skills in 150 healthy participants using a behavioral assessment and fMRI. The study will also examine the relationship between executive and decision-making skills, and their possible changes with ageing. The study will provide an useful baseline for investigating alterations of decision-making and executive functioning, and of their neural bases, in pathological conditions.

The Neutrocheck Summative Usability Study is a clinical trial that aims to assess the usability of Neutrocheck among healthy volunteers and healthcare professionals. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of Neutrocheck in identifying use errors, close calls, and use difficulties associated with selected hazard-related use scenarios, as well as the participant's perceived root causes of these. Additionally, the study will assess user satisfaction with the use of Neutrocheck and compare task completion rates between two study groups using paper instructions and app instructions.

The study aims to identify technical, attitudinal, and motivational obstacles and solutions for people with Parkinson's disease (PD) to improve their gait and physical function. The study will use a randomized, controlled, stepped-wedge design to evaluate the effectiveness of a new wearable device called Heel2Toe in improving gait biomechanics, motivation, and quality of life among people with PD. The study will measure the angular velocity of the ankle at heel strike, push-off, and foot swing, as well as other secondary outcomes such as motivation, apathy, walking behavior, health-related quality of life, cognitive ability, and cognitive performance test. The study will recruit 100 participants with PD who meet the inclusion criteria and will be randomly assigned to one of two arms: immediate or delayed assignment of the Heel2Toe device. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months, with assessments at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a 4-week laughter yoga program in improving the mood, anxiety, and loneliness of adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities in a special school. The study will randomly assign 40 participants to either the intervention group (laughter yoga program) or the control group (routine care). The study will measure the participants' mood, anxiety, and loneliness levels before and after the intervention using standardized questionnaires. The study will be conducted in a special school in Hong Kong and will have a randomized controlled trial design.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of decision aids on the participation of South Asian women in cervical cancer screening. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two parallel arms: a printed decision aid and a mobile decision aid. The primary outcome measures include decisional conflict, cervical cancer screening uptake, risk perception, screening decision: choice predisposition, and screening decision: choice question. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months, with data collection at baseline and 2 weeks after intervention. The terms related to the study include cervical cancer, screening, South Asians, ethnic minority, decision aid.

The study aims to investigate the additional effect of forward head posture correction on temporomandibular dysfunction. The study will be conducted on 30 participants with TMD symptoms and forward head posture, who will be randomly assigned to either a conservative treatment group or a conservative treatment group with Denneroll cervical traction orthodontic. The primary outcome measures will be anamnestic questionnaire by Fonseca, craniocervical angle (CVA), Boley Gauge, visual analog scale (VAS), and mandibular opening. The study will be conducted over a period of 7 weeks, with assessments at baseline (pre-treatment), 3rd week, and week 7 (post-treatment).

The study compares the efficacy of Clindamycin Phosphate 1% Gel and Once-daily Dapsone 5% Gel in the treatment of Moderate Acne Vulgaris. The study is designed as a parallel-group randomized controlled trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to either Clindamycin gel or Dapsone gel for 03 months. The primary outcome measure is the comparison of the efficacy of Clindamycin Phosphate 1% Gel Versus Once-daily Dapsone 5% Gel in the treatment of Moderate Acne Vulgaris, assessed using Global Acne Grading Sore (GAGS).

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

This study aims to investigate the relationship between rotator cuff tear severity and scapular and rotator cuff muscle activation patterns. The study will assess the activation patterns of scapular and rotator cuff muscles during functional tasks using surface electromyography (sEMG) in participants with different tear sizes (small, medium, large, and massive). The study will measure the muscle activation amplitude and identify differences in muscle activation patterns between varying tear sizes.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the provided clinical trial document.

The SENIOR RCT is a multicenter study in Italy on older malnourished adults (≥ 65 years old) evaluating the efficacy of a 6-month sustainable nutrition protocol on malnutrition. The study compares the experimental group receiving a personalized nutritional protocol with the control group receiving standard of care. The primary outcome measures include changes in nutritional status, strength, and blood biomarkers between the two groups. Secondary outcomes include changes in complete blood count, blood lipid profile, blood C-reactive protein, blood transaminases, blood creatinine kinase, blood prealbumin, blood cytokine, glycemia, blood insulin, blood homocysteine, blood vitamin D, blood vitamin B12, blood vitamin B9, blood sodium, blood potassium, blood magnesium, blood calcium, blood iron, blood zinc, adherence to Mediterranean Diet, quality of life, dietary nutritional composition, fat free mass, and locomotion test. The study aims to capture the effectiveness of the nutritional intervention in improving the nutritional status, strength, and overall health of older adults with malnutrition.

This is a double-blind, multicenter, prospective observational cohort study that aims to investigate the dynamic changes of Torquetenovirus (TTV) load in Chinese renal transplant recipients during immunosuppressive therapy. The study will enroll 100 participants who will be receiving tacrolimus/mycophenolate mofetil (or mycophenolic acid)/prednisone as maintenance immunosuppression after renal transplantation. The primary outcome measures will include renal allograft biopsy and serum creatinine, while secondary outcome measures will include infection events, donor-specific antibodies, and donor-derived cell-free DNA. The study will run from January 1, 2023, to December 31, 2023.

The study investigated the effectiveness of vitamin B12 vs B3 therapy in promoting nerve regeneration and functional recovery in pediatric traumatic brain injury (TBI) patients. The study included 300 children aged 6 to 15 years old, randomly divided into two groups: B3 (16 mg/day) and B12 (125-250 mcg/day). The study found that both vitamin B12 and B3 were effective in improving cognitive capacity, sensorimotor activity, and staircase test (working and reference memory) scores. However, the study did not find a significant difference between the two groups. The study concluded that vitamin B12 and B3 are both effective in promoting nerve regeneration and functional recovery in pediatric TBI patients.

This is a single-arm, open-label, phase III clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Pyrotinib after anti-HER2 therapy in women with high-risk early stage breast cancer. The study will enroll approximately 400 participants and will be conducted at multiple sites in China. The primary outcome measure is invasive disease-free survival at year 2, and secondary outcome measures include disease-free survival at year 2, overall survival, and adverse events.

Note: The summary is based on the provided clinical trial document and may not be comprehensive or up-to-date.

The study aims to assess the impact of pasta consumption timing on various health outcomes, including sleep quality, anthropometric parameters, cardiovascular risk factors, gut microbiota functionality, and individual chronotype. The study will randomly assign participants to either eat pasta at dinner or lunch for 3 months, using a crossover design. The study will measure various outcomes, including sleep quality, weight change, body mass index (BMI) changes, fat mass changes, basal metabolic rate, fasting blood glucose changes, glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c) changes, total cholesterol changes, LDL-cholesterol changes, HDL-cholesterol changes, triglycerides changes, homocysteine changes, aspartate transaminase changes, alanine transaminase changes, gamma-glutamyl transferase changes, urea changes, creatinine changes, uric acid changes, gut microbiota changes, individual circadian rhythms, TBARS changes, ROS changes, leptin changes, ghrelin changes, insulin changes, and IL-6 changes. The study will be conducted over 7 months.

The study is a phase II, open-label, single center trial evaluating the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in participants with multiple myeloma. The study aims to determine the ability of 18F-fluciclovine to detect and measure tumor burden in participants with multiple myeloma. The study will enroll up to 55 participants with multiple myeloma into two cohorts based on disease status: newly diagnosed multiple myeloma (NDMM) and relapsed and/or refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM). All participants will undergo an 18F-fluciclovine injection followed by a static whole-body PET/CT at three time points: Timepoint #1, Timepoint #2 (after induction for NDMM or at 6 months for RRMM) and Timepoint #3 (at progression or at 5 years). The primary outcome measure is the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in scan positivity. Secondary outcome measures include the efficacy of 18F-fluciclovine in measuring disease volume, the ability of 18F-fluciclovine to identify minimal residual disease (MRD), the ability for 18F-fluciclovine to evaluate response after treatment, and the safety of 18F-fluciclovine as a radiotracer in patients with multiple myeloma.

The study aims to evaluate the arm swing during walking in patients with early multiple sclerosis and healthy controls. The study will measure the arm swing amplitude in three dimensions using the Kinovea video player. The primary outcome measures include arm swing amplitude-shoulder degrees in flexion-extension direction, arm swing amplitude-elbow degrees in flexion-extension direction, and arm swing amplitude-overall degrees in flexion-extension direction. The study will also measure step-speed, Two Minute Walk Test (2MWT), Timed Up and Go (TUG), and Timed 25Foot Walk Test (T25FW) in both groups. The study is designed to understand the changes in functional mobility and arm swing during walking in patients with early multiple sclerosis.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, multicenter clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of adjuvant Pyrotinib and Capecitabine for HER2 positive micro invasive breast cancer. The study will enroll 400 patients and will be conducted in 20 hospitals in China. The primary outcome measures are invasive disease-free survival, distant disease-free survival, and overall survival. The study will last for 5 years.

The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of video biofeedback and laryngeal control therapy in the management of paradoxical vocal fold motion. The primary outcome measure is the change in Dyspnea Index score before and one month after treatment. Secondary outcome measures include Dyspnea Index score at 3 months post-treatment, responder rates, Clinical Global Impressions - Improvement, and qualitative survey results. The study aims to provide critical data for designing a fully powered trial comparing these two interventions and to advance the investigators' goal of providing clinicians with important evidence for guiding treatment.

The study aims to evaluate the implementation of a multidisciplinary protocol to improve sleep quality in critically ill patients. The study will assess the change in sleep quality in patients before and one month after the implementation of the sleep protocol. The primary outcome measures will be the change in the Richards-Campbell Sleep Quality Score, and the secondary outcome measures will include the change in the Sleep in the ICU Questionnaire, Confusion Assessment Method for the ICU, Questionnaire on the patient's perception of sleep from the family member's point of view, Questionnaire for the evaluation of the multidisciplinary team regarding prior knowledge of sleep protocol, and Questionnaire for assessing and perceiving patients' sleep from the point of view of the care team. The study will also evaluate the sleep quality of surviving patients of critical illnesses at ICU discharge at three and six months after hospital discharge using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index and Epworth Sleepiness Scale. The study will be conducted in a multicenter clinical trial with a quasi-experimental design.

The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial conducted in Quebec, Canada, to evaluate the effectiveness of a community pharmacy-based program (PACHA) in enhancing adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy (AET) among breast cancer survivors. The study aims to assess the program's acceptability, feasibility, and potential impact on AET adherence, quality of life, and cognitive representations of medication. The study will enroll 66 pharmacies and 66 women, with 33 in the control group and 33 in the intervention group. The intervention group will receive the PACHA program, which includes a web-based training for pharmacists and consultations with women. The primary outcome measures include the mean change from baseline to the end of 6-month follow-up in intention to adhere to AET, AET knowledge, attitude towards AET, perceived social support, perceived behavioural control, anticipated regret, coping planning, fear of recurrence, side effects, and cognitive representations of medication. The study will also assess the percentage of pharmacists who used PACHA tools, percentage of women who used PACHA tools, mean number of interventions dispensed by pharmacists to participating women, percentage of eligible and enrolled pharmacists, percentage of eligible and enrolled women, and cluster size. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, and the results will be used to optimize the PACHA program, its implementation, and to design a large-scale randomized controlled trial.

The study aims to assess the effects of Melissa extract on sleep quality and duration. The study will randomly assign participants to either the Melissa phytosome or placebo group. The primary outcome measures will be sleep duration, perceived sleep quality, and quality of life. Secondary outcome measures will include perceived anxiety levels, adverse symptoms, and CGI-I. The study will be conducted over 6 weeks, with participants provided with a wearable device to monitor their sleep patterns.

The study is a multi-center, prospective, phase II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of lenvatinib and tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy as first-line treatment for advanced gastric cancer or gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma (stage IV) with positive PD-L1 and low TMEscore. The study will enroll 120 patients and will be conducted at multiple centers in China. The study will be conducted in an open-label manner, and the participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (lenvatinib and tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy) or the active comparator group (tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy). The primary outcome measures will be progression-free survival, overall survival, objective response rate, disease control rate, and duration of response. The study will be conducted for 3 years, and the results will be analyzed to determine the safety and efficacy of the study drug.

This study is a single-arm trial of Social Engage Coaching (S-ENG) in 30 adults aged 60 and older who experience clinically significant loneliness and suicide ideation. Participants will complete ecological momentary assessments (EMA) using a smartphone for 10 days prior to starting the intervention, and then complete baseline measures and smartphone measures at 8 and 16 weeks. The primary outcome measures are loneliness, satisfaction with social activities, time in conversations, and time outside the home. The study is designed as an open-label single-group assignment with no masking.
