The study aims to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of higher doses of estrogen therapy in women with premature ovarian insufficiency (POI). The study will assess the severity of estrogen deficiency symptoms, quality of life, and changes in sex hormone levels. The study will also evaluate bone mineral density (BMD) response to higher doses of estrogen therapy for 12 months.

The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, participants will be randomly assigned to receive either transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% 1.5mg/day or 2.0mg/day. In the second phase, participants who have insufficient effect from previous treatment will be given higher doses of estradiol gel 0.1% 2.0mg/day.

The primary outcome measures will be the evaluation of the severity of estrogen deficiency symptoms, quality of life, and changes in sex hormone levels. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in bone mineral density (BMD) response to higher doses of estrogen therapy for 12 months.

The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months, with blood sampling performed at baseline and after 3 months. Participants will be assessed using the Green scale questionnaire, Short Form Health Survey-36 (SF-36), Menopause-Specific Quality of Life (MENQOL) questionnaire, and bone mineral density (BMD) measurement.

The study will enroll women aged 18-45 years with karyotypically normal spontaneous POI diagnosed before the age of 40. Exclusion criteria include any contraindication to HRT per the current drug labels, history of venous thromboembolism, estrogen-sensitive cancer history, regular cigarette smoking and history of or active liver disease, bleeding from the genital tract of unknown origin, etc.

The study will be conducted at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, University Hospital, and will be led by a principal investigator. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good

The Symbiont-Restore Study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial investigating the effects of a probiotic, prebiotic, and synbiotic combination on immune health, metabolome, and gut microbiome in overweight/obese adults. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: active comparator (probiotic), active comparator (prebiotic), experimental (synbiotic), or placebo. The study will measure changes in immune profile, faecal microbiome composition and diversity, metabolic profile, satiety rating, and gastrointestinal tolerance to dietary fibre over an eight-week intervention period.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of AD16 tablets in healthy adult subjects after a single administration. The study will enroll 24 participants and will be conducted in a single-center, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind manner. Participants will receive a single oral dose of AD16 or placebo, and vital signs, laboratory tests, and adverse events will be monitored throughout the study. The primary outcome measures include adverse events, serious adverse events, and laboratory test results. The study will also measure the pharmacokinetics of AD16, including the time to reach the maximum plasma concentration (Tmax), the maximum plasma concentration (Cmax), the elimination half-life (t1/2), and the area under the plasma concentration versus time curve (AUC0-∞ and AUC0-t).

This study aims to measure the effect of urolithin A supplementation on endothelial function, cerebral blood flow regulation, and serum biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function in middle-aged adults with obesity. 54 adults aged 40-64 years of age with a body mass index equal to or greater than 30 kg/m2 will be recruited to participate in a double-blind placebo-controlled parallel study for 4 weeks. Participants will be randomly assigned to intervention or control group. The study will measure the change in arterial function and local stiffness, blood flow on the surface of the hand, homeostatic cerebral blood flow, plasma biomarkers of NO homeostasis, and plasma biomarkers of mitochondrial function at baseline (day 0) and endpoint (day 28). The investigators expect that urolithin A supplementation in middle-aged adults with obesity improves endothelial function and cerebral blood flow regulation, and that this improvement is accompanied by changes in biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function.

This study aims to investigate the effect of vibration therapy on pain, functionality, and proprioception in individuals with cervical disc herniation. The study will compare the results of the conventional treatment program with the vibration therapy group. The study will measure the neck disability index, pain intensity, and kinesiophobia of the participants.

Conclusion: 
The study will provide information on the effectiveness of vibration therapy on pain, functionality, and proprioception in individuals with cervical disc herniation. The results of the study will contribute to the existing literature on the use of vibration therapy in the treatment of neck pain.

The study aims to create a registry of patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) to assess the influence of gender characteristics, clinical and anamnestic factors, body composition, topical characteristics of congestion, instrumental data, and markers of cellular inflammation and stress on immediate and long-term outcomes in patients with acute decompensation of HFpEF. The study will also determine the nearest outcomes, including in-hospital outcomes and long-term outcomes after 6 months, and evaluate the expected results in relation to the characteristics of the course and outcomes of the disease in Moscow patients.

The study is titled "Brothers Building Brothers by Breaking Barriers for Telehealth Delivery (Tele-B6)" and is a clinical trial conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The study aims to adapt and pilot a group-level intervention called Brothers Building Brothers by Breaking Barriers (B6) for telehealth delivery (creating tele-B6) within the context of an established community-based organization (CBO). The study will evaluate the feasibility and scalability of tele-B6 and assess its impact on various outcomes, including acceptability, change in the acceptability surveys, change in recruitment rates, change in retention, change in intervention fidelity, safety (adverse events), and qualitative description of intersectional stigma. The study will also measure change in perception of structural racism and discrimination, change in perception of HIV stigma, change in perception of internalized homonegativity inventory, qualitative description of logistical barriers, and changes in perception of individual resilience process: identity affirmation, and changes in the community resilience process: social capital. The study will enroll 180 participants and will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

The study aims to investigate the effects of caregiver training on the outcomes of Dynamic Temporal and Tactile Cueing (DTTC) treatment in children with Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS). The study will randomly assign participants to either a direct training group or an indirect training group, where the direct training group will receive DTTC treatment administered by a speech language pathologist (SLP) during half of each session, while the caregiver observes, and the indirect training group will receive DTTC treatment administered by the SLP during the other half of each session. The study will measure the effects of direct vs. indirect caregiver training during a period of DTTC combined with home practice on whole word accuracy, phoneme accuracy, speech intelligibility, and functional communication at post-treatment and maintenance.

The study aims to test and validate the creation of self-help and support groups for laryngectomized patients. The study will include laryngectomized patients who wish and can participate in these groups. The sessions will take place over four months, with five patients in each group. The primary outcome measures will be differences in quality of life scores before and after the program, between the program and non-program control groups. The study will also evaluate the participation rate during each session via the OVET software.

The study is evaluating the effectiveness of MSCopilot® Detect in detecting disability worsening in patients with Multiple Sclerosis. The study will assess the sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy of the MSCopilot® Detect application in detecting clinically meaningful worsening based on the revised-MSFC scores. The study will also evaluate the ability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores to detect disability worsening earlier than the EDSS, detect disease progression in absence of a relapsing activity (PIRA), measure the association between digital and clinical scores, assess reproducibility and reliability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores between in-clinic and at-home digital tests, evaluate Patient QoL (Multiple Sclerosis Impact Scale: MSIS-29 and Modified Fatigue Impact Scale - 5-item version: MFIS-5) and their association with MSCopilot® Detect individual and composite scores, and assess the safety and adherence of the MSCopilot® Detect application.

The study will enroll 200 patients with Multiple Sclerosis and will be conducted over a period of 24 months. The primary outcome measure will be the ability of MSCopilot® Detect to detect disability worsening based on the revised-MSFC scores. Secondary outcome measures will include the ability of MSCopilot® Detect to detect disability worsening earlier than the EDSS, detect disease progression in absence of a relapsing activity (PIRA), measure the association between digital and clinical scores, assess reproducibility and reliability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores between in-clinic and at-home digital tests, evaluate Patient QoL (Multiple Sclerosis Impact Scale: MSIS-29 and Modified Fatigue Impact Scale - 5-item version: MFIS-5) and their association with MSCopilot® Detect individual and composite scores, and assess the safety and adherence of the MSCopilot® Detect application.

The study will be conducted at multiple sites

The PCOS Challenge Study is a clinical trial that aims to collect information to advance research and improve care for patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The study is designed to include individuals diagnosed with PCOS by a healthcare provider, self-diagnosed with PCOS, or who are exhibiting PCOS symptoms and willing to sign the consent. The study will measure the responses to survey questions and will be conducted over a period of one year. The study will accept healthy volunteers and will include a control population of people born biologically female who have not been diagnosed with PCOS and who also do not have symptoms of PCOS. The study will use the keywords provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida, which include PCOS, polycystic ovary syndrome, polycystic ovarian syndrome, and Stein-Leventhal syndrome.

This is a cluster-randomized trial that aims to compare the safety and efficacy of two low molecular weight heparins, dalteparin and tinzaparin, in the prevention and treatment of venous thromboembolism (VTE). The study will enroll patients with indications for low molecular weight heparins and will randomly assign them to either the active comparator arm (tinzaparin) or the active comparator arm (dalteparin). The primary outcome measures will be 30-day all-cause mortality and bleeding requiring blood transfusion, and secondary outcome measures will include 30-day all-cause mortality, blood transfusion during admission, 90-day risk of pulmonary embolism, 90-day risk of deep venous thrombosis, heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, liver failure, and length of hospital admission. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year.

This is a randomized, parallel-assignment, triple-masked clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of two respiratory muscle training protocols in acquired brain injury patients. The study will assess the effectiveness of inspiratory muscle training and expiratory muscle training on inspiratory muscle strength, expiratory muscle strength, pulmonary volume, and pulmonary flow. The study will be conducted over 8 weeks, with each participant undergoing 5 sessions per week. The primary outcome measures will be measured at the end of the 8-week period.

The ASARD-TMA study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an automated surveillance, alert, and rapid diagnosis system for thrombotic microangiopathies (TMAs) in smaller hospitals. The study will assess the primary outcome measure of time of diagnosis and treatment of TMAs, and will enroll patients aged 18-100 years with a predictive probability of TMA of at least 90%. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months, and will include patients from multiple hospitals.

The Access-H20 faucet is a sensor-driven smart faucet designed to enable and empower individuals living with spinal cord injuries (SCI) to access water more independently for basic activities of daily living (ADLs). The faucet incorporates electromechanical controls and software programs that adjust spray outlets, spray angles, and water temperatures. A proximity sensor and voice recognition function allow users to control the faucet through a smart speaker. The study aimed to test the feasibility of the prototype of the Access-H20 faucet by assessing whether subjects can activate the faucet to control water outputs via the motion sensor, eye gaze, and a speech speaker. The primary outcome measures included water access for activities of daily living, and a System Usability Scale was determined.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an activity wristband-based intermittent teaching unit in promoting physical activity and its psychological mediators among students. The study will be conducted in a cluster-randomized controlled trial design, with two arms: intervention and control. The intervention group will receive the intermittent teaching unit, while the control group will not. The study will measure the change in perceived autonomy support, basic psychological needs, motivation toward Physical Education, self-determined motivation toward physical activity, intention to be physically active, and habitual physical activity at pre-intervention, immediately post-intervention, and after 6-week follow-up.

The study population will be students in the seventh to tenth grade at the secondary education level. The inclusion criteria are being enrolled in the seventh to tenth grade, participating in normal Physical Education lessons, being exempt of any health problem that would make them unable to engage in physical activity normally, presenting the corresponding signed written consent by their legal tutors, and presenting their own corresponding signed written assent. The exclusion criterion is not having performed the evaluation of the dependent variables correctly at the pre-intervention, post-intervention, and/or follow-up measures following the administration rules (being removed only for incomplete variables and not for the overall study).

The study will be conducted in a school-based setting, and the participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention or control group. The intervention group will receive the intermittent teaching unit, which will be delivered twice a week for eight weeks. The control group will not receive the intervention. The study will measure the change in perceived autonomy support, basic psychological needs, motivation toward Physical Education, self-determined motivation toward physical activity, intention to be physically active, and habitual physical activity at pre-intervention, immediately post-intervention, and after 6-week follow-up.

The study will use a cluster-randomized controlled trial design, with two arms: intervention and control. The intervention group will receive the intermittent teaching unit, while the control group will not. This clinical trial aims to assess the agreement between a new non-invasive device and a reference device in measuring blood pressure and heart rate during various tests, including the Valsalva maneuver, deep breathing test, and head-up tilt table test. The study will also measure the agreement between the devices in measuring cardiac output. The study includes patients with orthostatic intolerance and healthy volunteers. The primary outcome measures are the agreement of blood pressure and heart rate between the devices, as well as the agreement of cardiac output. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

The proposed study aims to develop and evaluate an online psychotherapy program and AI-assisted interventions for post-secondary students in Kingston, Frontenac, Lennox & Addington (KFL&A) region. The program will offer a comprehensive care model using a stepped-care approach, with the goal of improving post-secondary student mental health care substantially. The study will assess the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs by comparing them to treatment as usual. The study will also monitor the success and fidelity of the programs using surveys and focus groups. The study will be conducted in three phases: pre-adoption, delivery, and post-adoption. The pre-adoption phase will assess post-secondary students' current mental health landscape through surveys and focus groups. The delivery phase will determine the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs. The post-adoption phase will use the collected data to monitor the success and fidelity of the programs using surveys and focus groups. The study will recruit participants through on-campus flyers, advertisements, and wellness-center announcements, media advertisements, expert end-user referrals, and self-referrals. The study will measure the primary outcome measures including change in anxiety severity, depression severity, stress severity, quality of life, resilience, social anxiety severity, and ADHD severity.

The study aims to assess the efficacy of Omnivirol-Salicylic Acid Combination Therapy for cutaneous warts with an emphasis on persistent warts. The study will randomly assign participants to either the experimental group (AV2-SA2) or the active comparator group (SA). The primary outcome measures will be the cure rate and recurrence rate of the index warts at 12 weeks and 6 months after enrollment, respectively. Secondary outcome measures will include the number of participants with treatment-related adverse events, time to clearance of index wart, change in size of index wart, number of verrucae remaining, genotype-specific distribution of wart-associated HPV types, and prevalence of mucosal HPV types in cutaneous warts.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group, controlled clinical trial to assess the efficacy of letrozole in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy compared to methotrexate. The study includes 75 women diagnosed with ectopic pregnancy who are randomly allocated to three groups. The primary outcome measures are the beta-hCG level on day 14 and the level of anti-mullerian hormone 3 months after the treatment.

The study aims to evaluate the effect of fenestrated closure compared to non-fenestrated closure on the left ventricular size at systole and diastole in patients with atrial septal defect (ASD) and pulmonary hypertension. The study will enroll patients with ASD who will be randomly assigned to either the fenestrated or non-fenestrated patch group. The primary outcome measure will be the improvement in left ventricular diameter during systole and diastole, measured preoperatively and postoperatively. The study will run from January 2017 to October 2021.

This study aims to investigate the role of oxidative stress and mitochondrial TERT in the progression and therapeutic resistance of papillary thyroid cancer. The study will measure H202 generation, TERT mitochondrial localization, and the effect of exogenous oxidative stress and therapeutic agents on TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation in thyroid cancer cell lines. Additionally, the study will assess the proliferation, apoptosis, and migration of cells treated with Src kinase inhibitors. The study will also genetically and expression profile the tumor tissues.

This is a phase III multi-centre randomised controlled trial to assess the efficacy and safety of whole-body hypothermia compared to targeted normothermia in newborns with mild encephalopathy. The study will enroll 300 newborns born at or after 36 weeks of gestation who require prolonged resuscitation at birth and have evidence of mild hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy. The primary outcome measure is the mean cognitive composite scale score from the Bayley IV examination at 22 to 26 months of age. Secondary outcome measures include neonatal seizures, duration of intensive care, duration of hospital stay, duration of mechanical ventilation, duration of inotropic support, number of babies with bloodstream or cerebrospinal fluid positive infection, number of babies with thrombocytopenia or coagulopathy requiring transfusion of blood products, opioid use, number of babies exclusively breastfeeding at hospital discharge, brain injury scores on conventional magnetic resonance imaging, survival without any neurological impairment, preschool Child Behaviour Checklist (CBCL 1½-5), and other neurodevelopmental outcomes at 2 years of age. The study will be conducted at multiple neonatal intensive care units in the UK.

This study aims to investigate the diagnostic and prognostic role of serum amyloid A (SAA) in intrathoracic sarcoidosis. The study will determine the correlation of SAA concentrations at the time of diagnosis with clinical, radiological, and functional parameters of sarcoidosis, and will assess the potential of SAA as a biomarker for disease activity and prognosis.

The study will enroll patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis confirmed according to European Respiratory Society/World Association of Sarcoidosis and Other Granulomatous disease (ERS/WASOG) criteria, as well as healthy controls. The primary outcome measures will be the correlation of SAA concentrations in patients with those in healthy controls, and the correlation of SAA concentrations with clinical, radiological, and functional parameters of sarcoidosis.

The study will be conducted over 4 years, with patient enrollment lasting 1 year. The study will include several arms and interventions, including a cohort of patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis, a cohort of healthy controls, and a correlation analysis of SAA concentrations with clinical, radiological, and functional parameters of sarcoidosis.

The study will provide valuable insights into the diagnostic and prognostic role of SAA in intrathoracic sarcoidosis, and may help to identify new biomarkers for disease activity and prognosis.

The study is a randomized, single-blind, multicenter controlled trial to evaluate the benefit of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to transfer of a thawed embryo from 1st in vitro fertilization. The study will enroll women who have had a failed fresh or frozen embryo transfer and will randomly assign them to either the experimental group (blank culture transfer) or the sham comparator group (no transfer). The primary outcome measure is the clinically progressive pregnancy rate between groups, and secondary outcome measures include the occurrence of pregnancy, biochemical pregnancy, clinical pregnancy, early miscarriage, live birth, and differential cost-result ratio. The study will run for 3 years and will be conducted at multiple centers in France.

This study aims to construct a database of prognostic risk factors and quality of life of patients with primary solid malignant cancers receiving immunotherapy for the first time through a questionnaire survey. The study will collect baseline information before treatment and follow-up information after treatment to identify factors that may affect the efficacy and prognosis of patients receiving immunotherapy. The primary outcome measures include progression-free survival, total survival period, and scoring results of various questionnaires.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, capturing the key aspects of the trial. It does not explain how the summary was generated.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of acupressure in reducing back pain in late postpartum women who have undergone cesarean section. The study will randomly assign participants to either an acupressure group or a control group. The primary outcome measure will be the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) used to assess back pain, which will be filled in by the participants before and after the application. The study will be conducted at a family health center and will include 70 participants (35 in the acupressure group and 35 in the control group). The study will be conducted over four weeks, with the first application at the end of the first week after birth and the second application at the end of the fourth week after birth. The study will be conducted by a researcher who will apply the acupressure points for 12 minutes, using the LI4, HT2, LI11, ST36, GB21, UB43 points. The study will be analyzed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) 22.0 program, and the data will be evaluated for normality using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. The study will determine the effectiveness of acupressure in reducing back pain in late postpartum women who have undergone cesarean section.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of confidential social network referrals for HIV testing among adults in Moshi, Tanzania. The study will randomly assign participants to either the experimental group (CONSORT referrals + Card referrals) or the active comparator group (Card referrals alone). The primary outcome measure is the uptake of HIV testing, measured by the number of referred clients presenting for HIV testing at participating study sites within 30 days of the testing offer.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled trial to assess the effects of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in septic patients. The study includes 20 patients in each arm, and the primary outcome measure is time to vasopressor discontinuation. Secondary outcome measures include cumulative vasopressor dose, variation in cardiovascular sequential organ failure assessment score, cumulative vasopressor dose for 120 hours, total sequential organ failure assessment score variation, length of stay in the ICU, and mortality during ICU stay. The study is designed to determine whether paroxetine therapy improves cardiovascular function in septic patients.

Note: The output is a summary of the provided clinical trial document, and it does not include any personal information or identifying details of the participants.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a tele-education program in improving medication adherence and reducing barriers to treatment in patients with moderate depression in primary care. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted over a period of 6 months. The intervention group will receive the tele-education program in addition to their usual care, while the control group will receive their usual care from their general practitioner. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of maintenance on continuous antidepressant medication at 6 months after inclusion in the study, and secondary outcome measures will include changes in feelings of self-efficacy and barriers to treatment using self-questionnaires completed via the digital platform at inclusion and 3 months post inclusion.

This is a pilot observational study to assess the ability of continuous 'home' EEG to accurately diagnose narcolepsy and demonstrate response to treatment. The study will enroll participants aged 12 to 25 years who are already under investigation for hypersomnolence at GSTT children and adult sleep service. The primary outcome measures will be the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of the Dreem headband derived EEG in predicting a final diagnosis of narcolepsy derived from gold standard in-patient clinical testing with polysomnography and multiple sleep latency test ICSD-3 protocol.

The study is a Phase 1/Phase 2, open-label, dose-escalation, and dose expansion study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of SAR444836, an adeno-associated viral vector-mediated gene transfer of human phenylalanine hydroxylase, in adult participants with phenylketonuria. The study will enroll approximately 30 participants and will be conducted at multiple sites. The primary outcome measures are the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events and the proportion of participants with sustained plasma levels of phenylalanine below 360 μmol/L for at least 4 weeks without dietary phenylalanine restriction at Week 24 and Week 96 or end of study following SAR444836 administration. Secondary outcome measures include changes from baseline in plasma phenylalanine levels, dietary protein intake, and plasma phenylalanine: tyrosine ratio, as well as the duration of viral vector shedding in urine, saliva, and semen. The study is designed as a single group assignment with no masking and will be conducted over a period of 96 weeks.

The study aims to evaluate the clinical applicability of pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling (pCASL) as a substitute for fluorodeoxyglucose-position emission tomography (FDG-PET) in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and subjective cognitive decline (SCD). The study will assess the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism at baseline, as well as the differences among brain hypoperfusion patterns according to amyloid and tau status. Additionally, the study will investigate the predictive properties of brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism for conversion to dementia, and the correlations between brain hypoperfusion and CSF and blood biomarkers. The study will enroll patients with MCI or SCD, aged 18-80 years, and will use a 3 Tesla MRI with pCASL sequence as the diagnostic test.

This is a prospective, single-arm, multicenter, observational safety surveillance study to assess the safety of VyndaMx® (Tafamidis Capsule 61 mg) in patients with transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM) in India. The study will enroll adult patients (age ≥18 years) with diagnosis of cardiomyopathy of wild type or hereditary transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis (ATTR-CM). The primary outcome measure is the number of adverse events with Tafamidis, which will be assessed based on adverse events that occur within 6 months from first dosing. The study will collect safety-related data until 6 months from first dosing of Tafamidis Capsules and record these data on the Case report Form.

The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial to evaluate the STERN FIX device as a sternal stabilization system in patients after sternotomy. The study will enroll 120 patients and will be conducted at 4 hospitals in France. The primary outcome measure is sternal stability, assessed through clinical assessment using the sternal instability scale (SIS) with grades 0 to 3. Secondary outcome measures include safety SAE/AE prevalence, safety SAE/AE causality, prevalence of device deficiencies, reinterventions - prevalence, reinterventions - causality, prevalence of sternal wound infections, prevalence of dehiscence, sternal closure time, easiness of use of the closure method, surgeon satisfaction of the closure method, chest pain, blood loss, upper limb functional index, quality of life - EQ5D5L, sternal halves union/malunion, sternal halves alignment, sternum integrity, closure system integrity. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months after surgery.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an active break intervention on reducing low back pain and musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting among young people. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with 50 participants divided into two groups: experimental and control. The experimental group will receive recommendations to take an active break with lumbar and hip extension exercises every 30 minutes of sitting, while the control group will receive self-care recommendations. The primary outcome measures will include pain intensity, disability, perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting, and global perceived effect. Secondary outcome measures will include post-intervention questionnaire. The study will be conducted for 12 weeks, and the results will provide evidence-based practice for students, teachers, health professionals, personal trainers, and family doctors.

The study is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of tocopherol acetate vaginal administration in pre-peri and postmenopausal women. The study will assess the pH level of the vaginal secretions, the rate of vaginal mucosa dryness, the rate of vaginal mucosal integrity, the quantity of vaginal discharge, the whiff test, the rate of Lactobacillus grade according to Ison Hay's classification by bacterioscopic smear, microbiological evaluation by culture examination of the vaginal swab, molecular sequencing-based microbiological analysis of vaginal microbiota by next-generation sequencing (NGS) method, and the number of participants with treatment-related adverse events. The study will be conducted over a period of 14 days, and the participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the tocopherol acetate vaginal ovules or a placebo. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France, and the primary outcome measure will be the pH level of the vaginal secretions.

This study aims to investigate the relationship between Hematocrit to Hemoglobin Ratio and Red Blood Cell Distribution Width in patients with Polycythemia Vera and Secondary Erythrocytosis. The study will collect data on clinical manifestations, medical history, and laboratory results, including Hematocrit and hemoglobin levels, serum uric acid, JAK2V617F mutation status by real-time PCR, bone marrow aspiration, and biopsy with reticulin stain. The study will recruit patients from Sohag University Hospital, including those with secondary erythrocytosis as controls.

The study will measure the Hematocrit to Hemoglobin Ratio and Red Blood Cell Distribution Width in both groups and compare the results. The study will be conducted from December 2022 to September 2023, and the primary outcome measures will be collected during this time frame.

The study will help to understand the relationship between Hematocrit to Hemoglobin Ratio and Red Blood Cell Distribution Width in patients with Polycythemia Vera and Secondary Erythrocytosis, which can aid in the diagnosis and treatment of these conditions.

The study aims to determine the effect of PI measurement on the emergency triage classification in patients with dyspnea. The study will enroll adult patients who presented with dyspnea and whose PI values were measured with Masimo Radical-7 device at the time of admission, at the first hour and the second hour of admission. The primary outcome measures will be the use of PI for triage status determination in patients with dyspnea. The study will be designed as a single group assignment with open label and will be conducted in the emergency department of a hospital.

The LSD in Palliative Care study is a randomized, double-blind, active-placebo controlled phase II trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of LSD in palliative care patients with various conditions, including pain, anxiety, depression, demoralization, psychological distress, quality of life, caregiver burden, fear of death, and existential distress. The study will enroll 120 participants and will be conducted at two study sites. The primary outcome measure is the change in state anxiety inventory (STAI-S) scores compared with active placebo, and secondary outcome measures include changes in pain levels, opioid use, spiritual well-being, demoralization, quality of life, and other psychological and physical symptoms. The study will be conducted over a period of 9 weeks, with two intervention sessions, and will include assessments of acute and long-lasting therapeutic effects, as well as qualitative descriptions of subjective changes after intervention. The study will also evaluate the expectancy as a mediator for treatment effects, adverse events, physical and general discomfort during drug sessions, vital signs during drug sessions, and other terms related to the study.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a text messaging intervention, called SmartMom, in promoting health behaviors during pregnancy. The study will measure the change in weight during pregnancy, attendance at prenatal care visits, and secondary outcomes such as changes in health knowledge, health literacy, fear of childbirth, depression, anxiety, and use of tobacco, vaping, alcohol, or cannabis. The study will also assess the rates of planned vaginal birth after cesarean, exclusive breastfeeding at hospital discharge, and adverse pregnancy outcomes. The study will measure the incremental costs per incidence of suboptimal weight gain and inadequate prenatal care avoided. The study will enroll pregnant women at 15 weeks gestation or earlier, and the primary outcome measures will be assessed at enrollment, 38 weeks gestation, and 1 month post birth. The study will use a parallel assignment design, with active comparator and placebo comparator groups. The study will be conducted in Canada, and the primary language of the study will be English.
